webTitle: Call to deduct points from clubs

fields.headline: Call to deduct points from clubs
fields.standfirst:
Gordon Taylor argues that managers must be accountable as well as players in the battle to restore order
Four clubs charged in one day
Referees find no sense and very little reason
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin hears PFA chief executive Gordon Taylor argue that managers must be accountable as well as players in the battle to restore order
fields.body:
There is one surefire way to frighten players into behaving and managers into taking a stand. It is not financial penalties or bans but docking points. Gordon Taylor, the chief executive of the Professional Footballers' Association, raised the idea yesterday as the battle to restore order raged.

"The manager has to be accountable as well as the players," Taylor said. "The players suffer suspensions and fines but we feel clubs with bad records should be warned. If they don't listen to warnings there's a view we could consider the deduction of points."

On current evidence that would make it easier for Manchester United's rivals to win the title in future. The issue will be discussed in coming weeks by representatives from all sections of the game involved in the Football Association's eight-point plan to clean up football's image. But the Premier League spoke out against the idea last night.

It agrees that managers and players must share responsibility but the spokesman Mike Lee said: "It's no good talking about simply penalising clubs, which penalises the fans and all those involved in the club for the actions of certain players. Players have got to accept some direct responsibility.

"We are particularly saddened by the behaviour of certain players who ought to know better. Threatening to deduct points, unless there are specific charges made and proven, is not the answer."

Lee said the PFA had an important part to play and called on managers to clearly spell out what is unacceptable. The PFA agrees, though it feels the weekend's unsavoury events will have had an instant effect.

"I don't think players want to see themselves behaving like that in the cold light of day," said Taylor's deputy Brendan Batson. "Don't forget they've got families and mums and dads. They will think 'Christ, was that me?'

"But what's important is how they control themselves in the heat of competition. Certainly the responsibility is on the players. No one is looking to absolve them of that. But how you get that across to them rests solely with the clubs.

"Players at the top end are very bright in taking on board instructions from their manager. And in the same way that you practise all the time so things become instinctive, the manager has to be saying to all the players from the first team to the academy on a continual basis what their responsibilities are."

Batson believes it would help to apply rugby's 10-yard rule as a penalty for dissent. That will be an idea discussed by the International Board, football's law-making body, at a meeting on Friday and Saturday.

What seems clear is that a recent move advising referees to show more restraint in handing out red and yellow cards has made life more difficult for officials.

Gerald Ashby, the Premier League referees' assessor, says players have exploited the leniency by stepping up the crude challenges and abuse.

"You only have to look at the mass dissent shown by the Manchester United players in recent games towards Andy d'Urso and Steve Lodge," he said. "I am not picking on Manchester United - there have been plenty of other examples of similar things I have seen from other sides - but is that the image of football we want to portray?

"Then, using just one example, some of the challenges I saw on television in the Leeds-Tottenham game at the weekend were appalling. People will get badly injured by some of the tackles I have seen creep back into the game since the refs were told to ease up on the cards."

Incessant references to United's behaviour have angered Sir Alex Ferguson, who believes his players are being victimised "when the whole country is the same".

But he admitted it was time for his squad to learn: "Our players are going to have to be perfect in their behaviour to keep the hounds at bay because one blemish and we are slaughtered."

Many would argue that as role models they have a responsibility in any case. "What is seen on a Saturday and Sunday is certainly reflected during the week in some of our schools football," said Malcolm Berry, the chief executive of the English Schools FA. "It's prevalent in schools football when it didn't used to be and it's definitely proving to be difficult for us."

webTitle: Referees find no sense and very little reason

fields.headline: Referees find no sense and very little reason
fields.standfirst:
Four clubs charged in one day
Call to deduct points from clubs
fields.trailText: Only the dogmatic application of laws and principles can produce the correct outcome in a football match. Sending Dennis Wise down a salt mine for the rest of his life may be the price we may have to pay.
fields.body:
In the late 1980s an unfortunate member of the United States internal revenue service was given the task of knocking on the door of Roberto Duran and telling the volcanic former world welterweight champion that he owed several million dollars in back taxes. As horrible jobs go this is hard to beat but recent evidence suggests that Premiership refereeing may yet overhaul it.

"What is the point of referees?" West Ham's Igor Stimac asked on Saturday. What is the point of being a referee would be an altogether tougher question to answer. Underpaid, harangued by the public and the media, caught between the constantly changing policies of their employers and the increasingly bad behaviour of those in their charge, referees are the teachers of the sporting world. Talk with match officials and the comparison appears even more pertinent.

One told me a tale that would surely produce nods of recognition in staff rooms across the land. A player questioned every decision and answered back whenever asked to be quiet, and in the second half the referee's patience snapped. "Where I grew up," he told the player, "if you carried on like you're doing, you'd likely wind up flat on your back."

There was no further trouble but, when the official left the field, the manager was waiting. "It's been reported to me that you've threatened to assault one of my team and he's very upset," he said. The insolent adolescent who runs crying to his dad the minute he is challenged will surely be familiar to educationalists everywhere. The only difference is that this player was knocking on 30.

That was a few years ago. Things have got worse. The demands placed upon today's match officials are so heavy that it is a wonder none has sunk under the weight and disappeared for ever in the Old Trafford mud.

Not only are they now expected to differentiate between reality and bad acting and be able to run backwards faster than a pursuing pack of players, they are also asked to be more consistent and simultaneously apply greater common sense.

This is surely the refs' toughest assignment of all, since consistency and common sense are about as compatible as Mike Tyson and the Amish lifestyle. What is regarded as gumption varies from generation to generation, from culture to culture and from individual to individual. In the end what most of us regard as the bedrock of human intelligence is actually a pyramid of universal values with our own wisdom waving majestically from the apex.

I suspect those who most vocally champion the use of common sense on the football field (including the FA) are thinking of the good old-fashioned British variety. To these down-to-earth pragmatist Little Englanders the notion of, say, Bolivian nous is as alien a concept as that of an ill-disciplined German or a Brazilian whose movements are not naturally synchronised to the rhythms of the samba.

The game, however, is now a global affair. Consistency must be international. The fact that what appears rock-solid wisdom in England may look like irrational prejudice in La Paz is the reason Fifa has attempted to withdraw common-sense interpretation from refereeing decisions.

The bureaucrats of Zurich have been accused of many things down the years; sound judgment has rarely been among them. In this case, however, they are correct. Oddly enough, the managers of English clubs seem tacitly to recognise this. When it comes to European competition they constantly remind their players of the need to keep their heads, be sensible and maintain their discipline. Presumably such self-restraint is an impediment to progress in the pub-brawl of the Premiership.

That fiery little left-winger Leon Trotsky observed that common sense is not applicable in a revolution. And a football match, like a revolution, is a struggle for control and ascendancy. Only the dogmatic application of laws and principles can produce the correct outcome. If this means sending Dennis Wise down a salt mine for the rest of his life, then that, it saddens me to say, is the price we may have to pay.

fields.headline: Gazza breaks his arm
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 0 - 4 Aston Villa
fields.body:
Another unedifying chapter in the life and times of Paul Gascoigne was chiselled into football's hall of infamy here last night as his self-destructive streak resurfaced to end his season almost before it had begun.

The Middlesbrough midfielder was left with a broken left arm and no one to blame but himself, after announcing his return to first-team duty with a moment of madness that simply defied comprehension on another torrid Teesside night for Bryan Robson. Once again there were tears before bedtime, sympathy was in short supply. Experience has clearly taught Gascoigne precious little, for the challenge on George Boateng that left another substantial question mark hanging over his future was an act of violence.

One win in Boro's previous 10 Premiership games had meant an ignominious tumble into the relegation quicksand, with their manager Bryan Robson admitting in his programme notes that "relegation was a reality" and the chairman Steve Gibson breaking with protocol this week to express his first signs of dissatisfaction about the minimal return on his multimillion-pound investment.

Desperate times call for desperate measures. Hence the return of Paul Gascoigne after the bout of influenza that had rendered him unfit for training but apparently well enough to catch the Mike Tyson circus in Manchester. Once a decorated heavyweight himself, the artist formerly known as England's best footballer was accorded a reception born out of misguided adulation by the home supporters.

Kevin Keegan was there to watch his progress as well, but Gascoigne's night lasted little more than 40 minutes after he flattened Boateng, the visiting midfielder, with a forearm smash that Giant Haystacks would have been chuffed with. It was seemingly missed by the referee Alan Wilkie but, as with Gascoigne's infamous contribution to the 1991 FA Cup final, it backfired spectacularly as it rapidly became apparent he had been a victim of his own recklessness. Yet again English football was treated to the depressing sight of Gascoigne being carried off on a stretcher, attempting with little success to conceal a tear-stained face.

It was widely assumed Keegan was at the Riverside to run the rule over Paul Merson on a caustic night for the Villa forward against his former employers. After his messy departure the atmosphere brimmed with vitriol, but it was not long before the ire of the home supporters was redirected at their own players.

Few were exempt from the criticism that rained down from every corner of the stadium once Gianluca Festa had been caught in possession to present Benito Carbone with the opportunity to fire Villa into an 11th-minute lead. The bitter irony was that the two Italians had been close allies since their days together at Internazionale, but the breakdown in relationships was becoming a theme for the night.

As the news filtered through the ground the mood became one of depression. But when Carbone doubled his tally, quickly followed by two predatory strikes from Julian Joachim as the home defence went awol, the acrimony returned thick and fast. "Robson, what's the score?" inquired the home fans. But this will be remembered as another of those Gazza nights.

fields.headline: Wright to Burnley
fields.trailText: Ian Wright will finish his career in the Nationwide Second Division after leaving Celtic to join Burnley until the end of the season. The former Arsenal and England striker has moved from Parkhead on a free transfer after Kenny Dalglish told him he could not be guaranteed first-team football.
fields.body:
Ian Wright will finish his career in the Nationwide Second Division after leaving Celtic to join Burnley until the end of the season. The former Arsenal and England striker has moved from Parkhead on a free transfer after Kenny Dalglish told him he could not be guaranteed first-team football.

Wright was signed for Celtic by the former head coach John Barnes as a replacement for Henrik Larsson but, after scoring on his debut in a 5-1 win over Kilmarnock, managed only two further goals. The 36-year-old insists he will retire at the end of the season.

Wright is still facing disciplinary action from the Scottish Football Association after he was sent off at Kilmarnock last month following a post-match confrontation with the fourth official. The SFA confirmed last night that any suspension he receives will apply at Burnley.

His push on the official and a subsequent unrepentant attitude in a newspaper column could lead to a heavy fine and a lengthy ban.

"Part of his clearance certificate to join Burnley will be that any outstanding disciplinary action will remain against him," said an SFA spokesman. "He may still be required to attend a hearing and, if he has to serve any suspension, the Scottish FA will notify the English FA accordingly. Normal practice is that any ban will still apply.

"There have been several cases like this before, the most high-profile being Duncan Ferguson. It happens from time to time that players move and, if they do so, they take any suspensions with them."

Wright will almost certainly go straight into the starting line-up for Burnley's match against their fellow promotion hopefuls Wigan at Turf Moor on Saturday as the Clarets' striker Andy Payton begins a three-match suspension.

Jonathan Gould has also decided to leave Parkhead after losing his place as the first-choice goalkeeper to Dmitri Kharine but Celtic have turned down an offer from West Ham to take the Scottish international on loan. Gould was dropped after Celtic's 3-1 Scottish Cup defeat to Inverness Caledonian Thistle, during which he was involved in a dressing-room argument with Eyal Berkovic.

Newcastle's manager Bobby Robson has been angered by Nolberto Solano's appearance for Peru in the Gold Cup nine days after he left Tyneside with medical reports ruling him out of the competition with thigh trouble. Robson, who had ruled out the midfielder for three weeks, said: "Has anybody heard from him? Because I haven't. He'll get a present from me when he gets back."

The Nigerian Football Association has accused the referee of the African Nations Cup final of a pattern of bias throughout the match and protested to the tournament organisers. Mourad Daami did not allow Nigeria's fourth penalty in the shoot-out, which they lost 4-3, despite the ball appearing to cross the line after hitting the underside of the crossbar.

fields.headline: Ferguson defends players
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson yesterday responded to Alan Shearer's claim that "you are not allowed to kick" Manchester United by saying: "I would have thought the FA might look at that sort of comment.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson yesterday responded to Alan Shearer's claim that "you are not allowed to kick" Manchester United by saying: "I would have thought the FA might look at that sort of comment.

"My players never complain about getting kicked," said United's manager. "We have to put up with a lot but we can handle that sort of thing."

Ferguson added: "We're getting criticised for protesting yet you see the situations at Leeds and Chelsea. All players argue every decision that goes against them. It's not just Manchester United."

Shearer said: "Football has gone berserk, totally out of the roof, and you don't know where it's going to end. There is more pressure but it's not going to go away. We shouldn't need telling to behave. If you don't, you get punished and that's the way it should be."

webTitle: Lazio face fresh trouble over fans' racist abuse

fields.headline: Lazio face fresh trouble over fans' racist abuse
fields.trailText: Lazio will today, for the second time in a week, have to answer charges of racism on their terraces after three black Parma players were jeered every time they touched the ball during Sunday's 0-0 home draw.
fields.body:
Lazio will today, for the second time in a week, have to answer charges of racism on their terraces after three black Parma players were jeered every time they touched the ball during Sunday's 0-0 home draw.

Lilian Thuram, Ousmane Dabo and Saliou Lassissi were the targets of Curve Norde, a hard-core element which is understood to have been infiltrated by extremists. Last week the club were fined £1,700 after abuse was hurled at Venezia's black defender Bruno N'Gotty.

Also on Sunday Perugia's Ibrahim Ba, another black Frenchman, was taunted by visiting Roma fans.

Sven Goran Eriksson, Lazio's coach, commented. "If, in the year 2000, there are still people who think like that, this world is all wrong."

Fascist symbols are often on display at the Olympic stadium and two weeks ago, when Bari were Lazio's visitors, a portrait of Benito Mussolini and a banner praising the Serb war criminal Arkan were paraded. Lazio's president Sergio Cragnotti said: "I am ashamed at fans like these; I don't want them at the stadium."

 Uefa has confirmed that Gianluca Vialli is registered to play for Chelsea in the Champions League, though he will miss the Marseille match after being dismissed from the bench at Lazio.

webTitle: England explore the world for crucial cup votes

fields.headline: England explore the world for crucial cup votes
fields.standfirst: Campaigners trek 330,000 miles in quest for finals
fields.trailText: Rumours as to who will win the vote for the 2006 World Cup are reaching fever pitch. Andrew Warshaw identifies some potentially crucial trends that may give an idea as to the likely outcome.
fields.body:
Only five months before 24 high-profile administrators from Norway to New Zealand file into a smoke-free room at Fifa headquarters to cast their votes, the guesswork as to who will be awarded the 2006 World Cup is intensifying by the day - much of it way off beam.

Amid all the misinformation, there are few cast-iron certainties. The most significant is that no one, not even the president of Fifa, Sepp Blatter, knows which one of the five candidates will win in the secret ballot in Zurich on July 6.

Forget any private deals that allegedly have been already struck between the candidates. Forget even more quickly the absurd reports that South Africa's hopes have been wiped out by the chaos that plagued the African Nations Cup, 3,000 miles away in Nigeria. It may have taken place on the same continent but it had as much to do with the South African bid as, say, the unrest in Kosovo has to do with England's.

No amount of rhetoric emanating from England, Germany, South Africa, Morocco and Brazil between now and summer will provide a definitive picture of who will vote for whom until the crunch comes.

But several potentially crucial trends are emerging. None of the five candidates is likely to win with an overall majority in the first round of balloting, making secondary voting - when Fifa officials switch their votes once their preferred candidate is eliminated - vital. But what if Brazil, as could well happen, is asked to withdraw from the bidding because of inadequate facilities? And, should they remain in the campaign, what if they are eliminated in the first ballot?

McGivan said last night he was "very well received" in Paraguay, where most of his rivals were also canvassing.

Fifa's Scottish vice-president David Will was an unyielding supporter from the outset and New Zealand's Charles Dempsey has also opted publicly for England. Uefa's president Lennart Johansson, still the most staunch advocate of the highly contentious "gentleman's agreement" said to have promised full European support for Germany in exchange for giving England Euro 96, will stay loyal to Franz Beckenbauer and his team. Ricardo Teixeira, of Brazil, will back his own country - as long as they are still part of the campaign.

Blatter was initially a supporter of South Africa. But he recently softened that stance, under political pressure not to show bias too early. How he will vote is now less certain.

More certain is that the campaign is shaping up as a three-horse race between England, for whom support is growing, Germany and South Africa. What worries all three most is that they are unable to canvass entire support within their own continents. Half the eight European Fifa members will probably vote for England, the other half for Germany. This split-vote scenario could, as many predict, benefit South Africa, still marginally favourites. Yet they, too, could lose in exactly the same way, having been unable to persuade Morocco to stand down.

English officials believe Morocco's defiance is far more significant than any trouble at the African Nations Cup. "What happened in Nigeria will have little effect on why South Africa don't win," said one source close to the English bid. "The Morocco question is far more important. He does not subscribe to the view of many influential Fifa figures, including Blatter and his predecessor Joao Havelange, that rotation is democratically essential, especially given the many logistical problems facing Japan and South Korea in 2002.

"There is still a strong body of opinion which thinks that Europe should have the World Cup every other time," said Will. "Coming to Europe every 24th year is not correct given where the strength lies in world football. Having said that, South Africa still remains the main challenge to England. Will is particularly surprised that the Brazilian bid has hardly launched, fuelling the idea that they are saving their powder until 2010. He thinks one candidate will get only two votes - he probably means Morocco - and that England will pick up steam as the process unfolds on July 6.

"I feel England may start quite low in the voting but that they will grow in strength and pick everyone's second vote as others drop away. If Brazil withdraws or comes last in the ballot, for instance, we would have a strong chance of getting the three South American votes."

The Argentine FA president Julio Grondona, another Fifa executive committee member, will be heavily courted when England meet Argentina at Wembley next week.

But for England it could all end in tears if the hooligans get their way at Euro 2000. Just as crime in South Africa continues to hinder their crusade, so street riots a couple of weeks before the voting could scupper England's hopes. It is a nightmare scenario, one leaving no time for any damage-limitation schmoozing.

The candidate receiving the least votes in any round of balloting will be eliminated. If two or more candidates are equal in last place in any round, a separate deciding vote will be taken to eliminate one of them.

fields.headline: Tertius Bosch dies
fields.trailText: Tertius Bosch, the South African fast bowler who shared the new ball with Allan Donald in Bridgetown, Barbados in South Africa's first Test on their return to the international circuit has died in a Durban hospital at the age of 33. Bosch, a dentist, died of complications from a viral infection which he contracted about nine months ago.
fields.body:
Tertius Bosch, the South African fast bowler who shared the new ball with Allan Donald in Bridgetown, Barbados in South Africa's first Test on their return to the international circuit has died in a Durban hospital at the age of 33. Bosch, a dentist, died of complications from a viral infection which he contracted about nine months ago.

Meanwhile, Warwickshire may not be able to call on Donald as their overseas player next season following reports that South Africa have made another attempt to persuade him to play in a one-day international series against Australia in April and indoors in Melbourne in August.

Warwickshire's chairman Mike Smith said: "If Allan wasn't available for a full season, then I doubt that we would be in a position to offer him that contract."

webTitle: Freeserve joins BT to offer faster web links

fields.headline: Freeserve joins BT to offer faster web links
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, stole a lead on its competitors yesterday by announcing an alliance with British Telecom to offer its customers high-speed access to the web.
fields.body:
Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, stole a lead on its competitors yesterday by announcing an alliance with British Telecom to offer its customers high-speed access to the web.

It also unveiled a string of new content deals with companies including ITN and Virgin Records.

Freeserve, is testing high-speed access with BT's asymmetric digital subscriber line (ADSL) which will enable customers to send and receive data at speeds 20 times faster than normal.

The company declined to reveal the payment to BT for the use of its line or how many of its existing 1.675m account users were expected to take up the service that will be charged at monthly subscription of £50.

The use of the ADSL platform will also give Freeserve's site better video and audio capabilities allowing it to strike deals to offer ITN news, business and sports reports, video clips from Virgin Records and the downloading of music through Peoplesound.com.

Freeserve's shares fell 4.25p to 765p yesterday. Its issue price was 150p when it was partially floated by Dixons last July.

John Pluthero, Freeserve chief executive, said: "The ADSL trial reinforces our position at the forefront of internet service provision. ADSL will form an essential element of our broadband proposition as we gear up to provide Freeserve customers with high-speed access to rich content from the summer."

Only last month Freeserve reported a pre-tax loss of £3.6m on a turnover of £3.8m.

Its third quarter results are expected on March 16, when it is also likely it will reveal details on customer use of its high speed access service which will be tested in London and Manchester.

The new service claims to offer a permanent connection to the web at a fixed cost with no call charges or dial-up delays, allowing the telephone to be used for fax or voice at the same time.

Danny van Emden, head of Virgin Interactive, said: "The internet is shifting the way people can access music and video. Virgin Records is committed to delivering our artists' content in the most dynamic fashion that the technology currently allows."

ITN's new media managing director Garron Baines said subscribers would see a "much richer range of content on the internet" as a result of ADSL.

In a separate deal, BT announced it would license its photonics technology and transfer its research centre, which employs a staff of 43, to US based Corning, a provider of advanced optical and photonic products for telecommunications.

Fibre networks rely on electronic devices to transmit data and whenever a signal meets an electronic device the network must convert the traffic from photonic form to the electronic form.

The deal is worth £39m to BT. Chris Earnshaw, BT group engineering director, said: "As one of the largest patent holders in the world, BT is keen to maximise the returns from its investments in research and development. Much of our research and development work underpins the modern communications infrastructure, and this agreement unlocks the hidden value of an important part of our rich patent library."

webTitle: Royal Bank staff face fight for their jobs

fields.headline: Royal Bank staff face fight for their jobs
fields.trailText: Royal Bank of Scotland's staff face the prospect of reapplying for their own jobs after its £21bn takeover of NatWest, clinched yesterday.
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland's staff face the prospect of reapplying for their own jobs after its £21bn takeover of NatWest, clinched yesterday.

Royal Bank revealed that 60% of NatWest's shareholders had backed the £21bn bid after a hard-fought contest with its Bank of Scotland rival.

As the marathon battle drew to a close, Royal Bank's top executives yesterday held a "cordial" meeting with their counterparts at NatWest, who had fiercely resisted the bid, to hammer out ways for a smooth handover.

Royal Bank, whose shares fell another 7% to 807p yesterday, has admitted that 18,000 jobs will be cut from the combined workforce. Royal Bank made it clear yesterday it could not make decisions about jobs until it had learnt more about NatWest's operations but reiterated it would not be parachuting in its own managers to restructure NatWest. Royal Bank said this might mean its own employees reapplying for their jobs against NatWest staff.

Senior executives at Royal Bank, which prides itself on its staff relations, will today make a video to their staff after winning the four-month fight.

Fred Goodwin, who yesterday moved from deputy to chief executive, will not take control officially for a fortnight when Royal Bank's shareholders ratify the takeover. In the meantime, Sir David Rowland, NatWest chairman and chief executive, and Ron Sandler, his chief operating officer, will run the business.

fields.headline: Ireland's missing links
fields.standfirst: Thanks to £25,000 from BT's FutureTalk programme, three schools in Northern Ireland hope to nurture communication between Protestant and Catholic youngsters
fields.trailText: Thanks to £25,000 from BT's FutureTalk programme, three schools in Northern Ireland hope to nurture communication between Protestant and Catholic youngsters
fields.body:
There is an uneasy feeling in the stomach when news comes that three Northern Ireland schools have been given £25,000 to run a joint project on video conferencing and web authoring, which will also create trust and understanding.

Laurelhill Community College, a Protestant school in Lisburn, is leading the initiative, which has received the first of a series of awards by British Telecom as part of its FutureTalk millennium programme. The partner schools are Catholic St Malachy's in Castlewellan and integrated Slemish College in Ballymena.

Two other projects, in Birmingham and North Yorkshire, received £5,000 each. Similar amounts will be paid out each half-term in a procedure that is entirely electronic, with schools filling in online application forms and judges assessing them by e-mail. A spokesperson for BT said the judges were unanimous in giving the top award to the Northern Ireland schools. As well as meeting the criteria of having a curriculum focus and promoting communication between schools, the proposal had "a political and social ambition" which other applications lacked. Promoting good community relations was very important in the decision.

That is where the queasy stomach came in. Could it be a case of British-based judges who know little about good practice in cross-community work in Northern Ireland being overawed by the declared intention to promote trust and understanding? Or were ICT fanatics funding electronic technology when a few bus trips might do more for community relations?

Teachers in the schools quickly put these fears to rest. Laurelhill is already closely linked with its local Catholic neighbour, St Patrick's, in curriculum projects, and there are shared activities through Laurelhill Youth Centre. Arnold Carton, head of ICT, who got the project going, is active in cross-community work and devotes a lot of his own time to activities. In July he ran a web summer school for young people from several Catholic and Protestant schools. "This project is an extension of our existing community relations work," he points out. "Visits are a thing you can have once a term, and we are planning for pupils and teachers at the three schools to meet soon, but with video conferencing we can have contact every fortnight."

His colleague at St Malachy's, ICT co-ordinator Paddy McElhinney, agrees that it is important for pupils and teachers to meet up from time to time to supplement electronic links. "I don't want to see pupils on a machine in contact with others without seeing them."

St Malachy's shares activities with a Protestant school, Glastry, in the Ards Peninsula, but it also has electronic links with schools across the world and hopes to build on these with the new facilities.

Cross-community contact will be built into the project in another way. In the first phase, the three schools will create web sites on "A Young Person's Guide to Lisburn" or Ballymena or Castlewellan. Pupils will be encouraged to include information on all schools and youth centres in their town, for which they will have to approach the "other side". This immediately raises issues about different sports, languages and cultural traditions in the different sectors. The organisers know that these differing experiences of Catholics and Protestants must be handled sensitively.

Paul McHugh, senior manager at Slemish College, thinks the task will be easier at his school because pupils have links with all sections of the community. But it will still be a challenge, and even more so in the segregated schools. Paddy McElhinney says a team of pupils at St Malachy's has been discussing the issue: "We want to involve different ages and religions and I want the pupils to come up with the ideas."

As the web site develops, pupils in the three schools will use video conferencing to share ideas and offer constructive criticism and support. At the end they will give their impressions of each other's sites.

In the second phase, the pupils will link up by video conferencing to agree a joint area of research, and will draw up a questionnaire to find out the views of young people. The findings will be analysed and the results displayed on their web sites.

Phase three is expected around November/December of this year, when the schools had hoped to mark the first anniversary of the setting up of the Northern Ireland Executive. The idea can go ahead even if the executive has not been resurrected. Each school will arrange for a local politician to come to the school and be interviewed on what the new political arrangements offer young people.

This offers the opportunity for real dialogue among the schools on delicate political issues. The host school will make their politician available to the other schools by video conference, and the interview will be reported on their web site.

The project has a strong community relations theme, but its main focus is English. "This project will encourage communication, both written and verbal," says Arnold Carton. "It will encourage data-handling and develop interpersonal skills. Pupils will gain communications skills not available in English lessons: e-mail, video conferencing and web site production.

"Video conferencing will be important in business in years to come," says Pat McHugh. "We are skilling them up."

The host school will make their politician available to the other schools by video conference, and the interview will be reported on their web site. The project has a strong community relations theme, but its main focus is English. "This project will encourage communication, both written and verbal," says Arnold Carton. "It will encourage data-handling and develop interpersonal skills. Pupils will gain communications skills not available in English lessons: e-mail, video conferencing and web site production. "Video conferencing will be important in business in years to come," says Pat McHugh. "We are skilling them up."

webTitle: UK e-uni to be global giant

fields.headline: UK e-uni to be global giant
fields.standfirst: Education secretary announces top-up fees and a new breed of 'e-universities'
fields.trailText: Britain's "e-university" announced by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, could become the biggest in the world teaching millions of students, according to Tim O'Shea, Master of Birkbeck College, London.
fields.body:
Britain's "e-university" announced by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, could become the biggest in the world teaching millions of students, according to Tim O'Shea, Master of Birkbeck College, London.

The project - the most ambitious since the foundation of the Open University in the 1960s - is intended to draw together the cream of expertise in British universities to mount web-based courses around the globe. It is an attempt to compete with the major corporate and virtual universities emerging in the United States. As Mr Blunkett said, no one institution has the range of expertise or the financial clout to undertake the job.

Universities and private companies throughout the UK are being invited by the Higher Education Funding Council for England to bid to become part of the consortium to run the e-university. The funding council which will put up the pump-priming money decided against asking existing regional consortia in an effort to secure the 'best of British' in higher education. They may well use existing links with overseas universities especially in countries such as Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and China.

Professor O'Shea predicted start-up costs could be as high as £120m over two years but if funded properly the British e-university could become the biggest in the world. For academics there would be a huge change - designing an hour-long learning experience on the web would take 200 hours so the concept depended on attracting large numbers. Tutors would also need to learn how to support students online through email and computer conferencing.

"It is exciting and innovative but also credible," he said. "No other country has said it will try and take the best of its higher education and make it available for electronic delivery over the world wide." Alice Frost, who is heading the project, gives full details on the council's website.

There will be no physical campus and there will be no new incorporation as in the case of the Open University. Much of the funding will come from student fees, including professional reskilling by people in work.

There was no shortage of universities with high quality teaching and learning materials and expertise in their delivery via the internet or other new technologies, she said. "Many are seeking to develop web-based applications on their own or in groups. But no single institution has the resources to exploit existing materials and expertise with the necessary scale and profile. Such investment can only be justified if one can be confident of reaching a large market at home and overseas. Hence the need for a pump-priming initiative to bring together existing resources and talents in a way that achieves the necessary critical mass."

webTitle: IRA pulls out of disarmament talks

fields.headline: IRA pulls out of disarmament talks
fields.standfirst: The IRA statement
fields.trailText: The Irish Republican Army, stung by Britain's decision  to suspend Northern Ireland's power-sharing government, broke off negotiations  today with the province's disarmament commission.
fields.body:
The Irish Republican Army, stung by Britain's decision to suspend Northern Ireland's power-sharing government, broke off negotiations today with the province's disarmament commission.

In a statement, the IRA accused the British government and the Ulster Unionists of seeking "a military victory" over the outlawed group.

The IRA said it also was withdrawing its recent proposals to the disarmament commission, which had suggested the group would be prepared to put its weapons stockpiles "beyond use" in certain political circumstances.

These proposals were made public on Friday, hours after Britain revoked powers from the province's 10-week-old Cabinet, which included Sinn Fein.

"Both the British government and the leadership of the Ulster Unionist Party have rejected the propositions put to the (disarmament commission) by our representative. They obviously have no desire to deal with the issue of arms except on their own terms," the IRA said.

"Those who seek a military victory in this way need to understand that this cannot and will not happen," it continued.

Earlier, Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams insisted Mr Mandelson failed to offer hope of a breakthrough.

After discussions with the Ulster Secretary at Stormont, he claimed republicans had no more room to move on the decommissioning issue. He said: "It was a very bad meeting."

In his bleakest assessment yet of the crisis which threatens to leave the peace process in ruins, Mr Adams said there was no sign the Government was prepared to lift the suspension.

On a day of frenetic attempts involving the British and Irish governments and the pro-Good Friday Agreement parties to try to get the process back on track, a sombre-looking Mr Adams added: "We had no evidence whatsoever from this meeting that the British Government, or certainly this Secretary of State, is contemplating that."

Mr Adams, who also had talks with Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble, claimed Mr Mandelson was not prepared to take a decision that did not have the approval of Unionist Unionists, who are demanding a start to disarmament.

He said his party had stretched its constituency to the limit in trying to achieve decommissioning.

"As far as we are concerned, we have moved beyond our obligations. We have been morally and politically bound to do all of that and this Sinn Fein leadership has now no further room to move.

"We have seen the failure of politics and if I can say so, we have seen for Irish republicans and nationalists the British Government once again bringing back the veto which unionists used to enjoy and which was effectively removed as a result of the Good Friday Agreement.

"So we will continue to focus to try and make progress but it was always a collective responsibility. The unilateralism and the illegality of the move to suspend the institutions will ripple for a very long time indeed."

Mr Mandelson had a series of meetings with smaller pro-agreement parties at Castle Buildings who demanded a greater role in attempts to break the political impasse. Irish Foreign Minister Brian Cowen, who also met the smaller parties, insisted all sides wanted to see a quick return to the institutions and he continued to stress the importance of last week's report by the international disarmament commission. "The message which is coming across so clearly is people want to see a return to the institutions quickly, urgently and the need to focus on the re-establishment of the institutions is a priority."

"All the parties have to acknowledge the independence of the international commission and the significance of that development in the words of General de Chastelain himself.

"Applying a subjective, partisan political opinion to superimpose on that does not help to allow people to recognise the progress that is being made."

Mr Cowen was speaking before leaving for Dublin for a meeting involving the Irish Prime Minister Bertie Ahern and the nationalist SDLP.

Mr Ahern and Mr Blair, who are due to hold talks in London tomorrow, will also meet separately with representatives of the Ulster Unionist Party, Sinn Fein and the SDLP. Women's Coalition assembly member Monica McWilliams called for a working party of pro-Agreement parties to establish a way out of the deadlock and seek further clarification from Gen de Chastelain on his contacts with the IRA. Progressive Unionist Party assembly man David Ervine warned that the peace process had become fixated on the "prize fight between Trimble and Adams".

"We cannot have a Mr Magoo-type process. We cannot stumble all over the place into crisis after crisis," the East Belfast MLA argued.

The leader of the cross-community Alliance Party, Sean Neeson, also called for Gen de Chastelain to provide more detail on the offer the IRA had made to him last week about resolving the disarmament issue.

fields.trailText:
"On November 17 the leadership of the IRA agreed to appoint a representative to
enter into discussions with the IICD (Independent International Commission on
Decommissioning).
fields.body:
"On November 17 the leadership of the IRA agreed to appoint a representative to enter into discussions with the IICD (Independent International Commission on Decommissioning).

"This was on the basis that it would be part of a series of events including, and in particular, the establishment of the political institutions set out in the Good Friday Agreement. This was designed to move the situation out of an 18-month impasse. This impasse was created and maintained by unionist intransigence and a failure by the British Government to advance the implementation of the Good Friday Agreement.

"The British Secretary of State has reintroduced the unionist veto by suspending the political institutions. This has changed the context in which we appointed a representative to meet with the IICD and has created a deeper crisis.

"Both the British Government and the leadership of the Ulster Unionist Party have rejected the propositions put to the IICD by our representative. They obviously have no desire to deal with the issue of arms except on their own terms.

"Those who seek a military victory in this way need to understand that this cannot and will not happen.

"Those who have made the political process conditional on the decommissioning or silenced IRA guns are responsible for the current crisis in the peace process.

"In the light of these changed circumstances the leadership of the IRA have decided to end our engagement with the IICD. We are also withdrawing all propositions put to the IICD by our representative since November."

webTitle: Mugabe heads for defeat in poll

fields.headline: Mugabe heads for defeat in poll
fields.trailText: In what appeared to be a decisive rejection of President Robert Mugabe's proposals to reform Zimbabwe's constitution, early results yesterday indicated overwhelming "No" votes in Harare and Bulawayo, the country's two largest cities.
fields.body:
In what appeared to be a decisive rejection of President Robert Mugabe's proposals to reform Zimbabwe's constitution, early results yesterday indicated overwhelming "No" votes in Harare and Bulawayo, the country's two largest cities.

Other cities were also reporting rejection of the changes, which include prolonging Mr Mugabe's term and giving the government authority to seize mostly white-owned farms without compensation to resettle blacks.

A low turnout in rural areas, which hold 70% of Zimbabwe's 12m people, means that the urban vote could decide the results of the referendum. Heavy rain has delayed the transport of ballot boxes from rural areas and final results are expected today.

The state-controlled media have already begun reporting partial results that indicate a negative vote, after weeks of campaigning for a "Yes" vote.

Lovemore Madhuku, the spokesman for the National Constitutional Assembly (NCA), which opposes the constitutional changes, said: "People are showing they are opposed to this undemocratic constitution."

He added that the Mugabe government "did not anticipate the magnitude of the No votes in the urban areas. Now that they have been taken by surprise, they will find it hard to cheat enough to win this referendum. They cannot announce Yes votes from the cities, and not enough people voted in the rural areas to outweigh the urban votes."

The government has begun blaming the white minority for the No vote. The state Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation and the Herald newspaper yesterday reported that large numbers of whites had encouraged their employees to vote against the constitution.

"They are trying to promote racial tensions where there are none," Mr Madhuku said. "The government thinks the Zimbabwean people are so foolish they will think that the whites are demons. But the government misjudged the situation. Whites are no longer seen as responsible for the people's suffering."

Others were more cautious about the results. "We have not won yet, and we know the government does not want to lose this,"' said Isaac Maphosa, NCA chairman.

"We had monitors in most urban centres, but many rural voting areas did not have monitors. There are reports of irregularities in many rural areas. The government could still try to pull off a victory."

Human rights lawyer Tendai Biti, women's activist Priscilla Misihairabwi and seven other opposition supporters remained in jail for a second night. They were arrested on Sunday while campaigning in Harare's Highfields township.

The opposition ran a lively campaign on a shoestring budget, tying posters on to trees and handing out leaflets in workplaces. Thousands of monitors were mobilised to watch polling stations.

As counting continued last night, arguments broke out between monitors and government officials over the appearance of ballot boxes which had not been monitored.

Government officials seemed shocked that the referendum would be defeated.

"This is a decisive day for Mugabe, it appears to be a decisive defeat," said Iden Wetherell, deputy editor of the Zimbabwe Independent. "The early results indicate a massive rejection not only of the draft constitution, but of Mugabe's rule and mismanagement. Things will never be the same."

webTitle: Report lifts lid on years of abuse

fields.headline: Report lifts lid on years of abuse
fields.standfirst:
Calls for massive overhaul of care after damning inquiry into children's homes

More about the Welsh child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: A massive shake-up of the care system was called for today after the publication of a damning report into two decades of sexual and physical abuse of youngsters in north Wales children's homes.
fields.body:
A massive shake-up of the care system was called for today after the publication of a damning report into two decades of sexual and physical abuse of youngsters in north Wales children's homes.

Social workers, care home staff, local authorities, police and the Welsh office were severely criticised by the report into the UK's worst welfare scandal.

Speaking in the Commons today, Welsh secretary Paul Murphy said the victims were subject to "appalling suffering".

Mr Murphy told MPs: "In its report the tribunal has named many people: alleged abusers, convicted abusers, local government officers and elected members and Welsh office officials."

The report concluded that there was widespread sexual abuse of boys, and to a lesser extent of girls, in local authority and privately-run children's residential establishments and schools and in a NHS psychiatric unit in Clwyd between 1974 and 1990.

Children at the homes were also subjected to a "climate of violence" by staff who used "impermissable force" and condoned and even encouraged bullying, the report said.

Mr Murphy said there was no evidence of persistent sexual abuse in children's residential establishments in Gwynedd, but that sexual and physical abuse did occur in a small number of children's homes in the county.

But there was a paedophile ring in the Wrexham and Chester areas that preyed on teenage boys, he said. These children were especially vulnerable because they were in care.

In total, the long-awaited report of the tribunal of inquiry into abuse at the children's homes runs to 500,000 words and makes 72 recommendations about how some of the country's most vulnerable youngsters should be protected.

The inquiry also found that children were also being abused by the people appointed to deal with their complaints. The report recommends that every child in care should also be appointed a social worker who should see them at least every eight weeks. Police, teachers, nurses and doctors should be trained to spot and deal with suspected abuse.

The report was published following a £13 million, three-year tribunal of inquiry into the abuse of up to 650 children at 40 homes in North Wales over two decades. The three-strong inquiry panel, headed by former High Court judge Sir Ronald Waterhouse, strongly criticised the "cult of silence" which allowed the abuse to continue for years, despite repeated allegations and half-hearted investigations by police and social services.

Children had complained as early as 1978 about abuse, but four damning reports in the early eighties about the state of homes in Clwyd were suppressed by the council.

It was only in 1996, after a string of high-profile prosecutions of former staff at the children's homes, that the then Welsh secretary, William Hague, ordered the public inquiry.

One of the victims told today how he was abused both physically and sexually within a week of arriving at Bersham Hall.

Steven Messham, now chair of Norwas (North Wales Abuse of Survivors), said the abuse lasted for three-and-a-half months. He wrote letters to the press begging for help but later found out they had not been posted. The police too ignored his complaints. He was later transferred to Bryn Estyn, also in Wrexham, which he has since described as the "Colditz of care".

"I was physically and sexually abused every other day. It wasn't just by staff in the home but by others who were brought in," he said. Mr Messham named 89 abusers in his evidence to the inquiry panel at Ewloe. "Everything that I ever said was corroborated during the inquiry. I started making police statements and complaining to the police in 1978. Yet still nothing was done."

Earlier, Plaid Cymru said the abuse was a "collective national failure which is unforgivable".

The chair of the Welsh nationalists at the Welsh Assembly, Helen Mary Jones, said: "It is very important that we learn the lessons from what has gone on and are absolutely assured that nothing on this scale can ever happen again.

"There is no room for complacency. We expect the Government to say a great deal has changed in the last 15 years and the situation is not now comparable. But there are still many, many things that are wrong. We must not assume this is just ancient history and can never happen again."

The Conservatives' health spokesman at the Welsh Assembly, David Melding, said: "We need to strengthen regulations at care homes. There must be more rigorous inspections."

fields.headline: Breezy, Squeezy and Queasy
fields.trailText: VAN - THE INCREDIBLE MIND-CHANGING MAN
fields.body:
VAN - THE INCREDIBLE MIND-CHANGING MAN

Two weeks ago, Ruud van Nistelrooy was off to Serie A. Last week he wasn't going anywhere. This week, he's definitely coming to England. "I will definitely be going to England, and not to Italy and Spain," were his exact words. What, the nation asks itself while incredulously brushing its hair in the morning, will the record-breaking striker be doing next week? Joining a footballing circus and travelling around the world on a unicorn?

Apparently, Van feels that the speedy nature of the Premiership (and not the poor quality of the defending) will suit his predatory skills. He would also like to live in London. This may well encourage the 350-man Chelsea transfer team, who recently appear to have been spending every waking hour in Eindhoven watching Van score past Willem IX, or whatever. Suggestions are that the Blues could even be prepared to exchange Tore Andre Flo (currently valued at £15m) to get him.

However, the same disreputable sources insist that Chelsea are not alone in chasing the white Van man. fields.headline: Trust me, I'm a doctor
fields.standfirst: You call the surgery and a locum answers. But can you be sure that such stand-ins are qualified?  Timothy Johnson was horrified that local practices failed to make any checks on his medical credentials when he covered for full-time staff
fields.trailText: You call the surgery and a locum answers. But can you be sure that such stand-ins are qualified? Timothy Johnson was horrified that local practices failed to make any checks on his medical credentials when he covered for full-time staff
fields.body:
After working as a GP in south London for a few years, with the constant stresses and strains that come with life in a big city, I decided to move to the provinces. I chose the west country, where I'd long dreamed of living.

Finding the right practice to join is always difficult, so since I had no knowledge of GPs in the area, I decided to work as a locum at first. I thought I'd get to know the different partnerships before applying for a permanent position.

Locuming is the equivalent of working freelance. You fill in for other doctors who are away, say, or off sick or on study leave. It is usually on a very short-term basis, commonly just a morning or afternoon, and you can be booked in at the last minute.

I began by sending out my curriculum vitae with the names of two referees to all the practices in the district. Five came back with offers of work. Before taking up any of them, I asked my referees how many had been in contact. To my surprise, they reported that nobody had asked for a reference.

On the day of my first locum job - by chance, the day that Harold Shipman was found guilty - I was due to be the only working doctor in a nearby practice. I loaded my bag with medical items, but also copies of my certificates from the General Medical Council, the joint committee on postgraduate training for general practice, and for medical indemnity.

Never having worked as a locum before, I imagined that I would have to produce them before seeing patients. I also thought that the practices would contact the relevant bodies to confirm the certificates were genuine. As an extra precaution, I took along my passport, expecting to show it as positive proof of identity.

But when I got there, no checks were made. It's fair to say I was extremely concerned. I wasn't asked to show any documentation at all, even when I informed them that I had brought it all with me. In that practice I did meet the partners, who asked a little about me - who I was, where I was living and why I had left London - but then, with no further formalities, I was given a room, shown how to use the computer and presented with my first patient.

Within 10 minutes of starting my surgery, an urgent house call was requested. As with all calls for home visits, I prioritised it - was it urgent, or could it wait a little while? As the request was to visit a woman with diarrhoea and vomiting, I decided to delay the visit until after my surgery was finished. The woman's husband agreed, but few minutes later was back on the phone saying his wife was getting worse. I had no choice but to leave the patients in the waiting room and visit the woman immediately.

By the time I got there, however, the woman had died. I tried to resuscitate her, but it was too late.

The day had hardly begun, and of the two patients I'd seen, one was already dead. As the dead woman had not been seen by a doctor from the surgery for three months, her death was referred to the coroner and a post-mortem was arranged.

To my relief this meant I was not asked to issue the death certificate for a patient I had never previously met. (I assume the post-mortem has shown a natural cause of death.) I spent the rest of the day concerned that the practice would wonder whether I had done something I should not have done, and was relieved when the day ended with everything else running smoothly.

In the last two weeks, I've gone on to work in a further five practices, and only two have asked to see my certificates.

Another cause for concern is that each of the practices has given me a prescription pad in case I cannot use the computer to print one out. Last year the government introduced new prescriptions to try and counter fraudulent use. These pads are supposed to be signed out for use by the relevant doctor, to ensure each one is accounted for. But not once have I been asked to sign for the pack and only in one practice have I had to make a record of what I have used.

It would be extremely easy to pocket a few empty scripts for use at a later date, which would mean I could easily obtain controlled drugs such as diamorphine - the drug Shipman used to kill his patients.

In one of the practices I have covered, the only member of staff I met was a receptionist. I found it very worrying that the partners were willing to entrust the care of their patients to a complete stranger, without even saying hello. It seems to show a lack of respect to their patients, and to me, as well as a disregard for their livelihood. If I'd made a bad mistake, they'd be dealing with the consequences of it for years to come.

Interested in finding out how common my experience was, I spoke to doctors locuming in other parts of the country. They all reported similar circumstances. Some practices do ask for copies of all certificates before offering work, but a substantial number ignore such precautions.

There appears to be no legal duty on general practices to check certificates, although some health authorities are beginning to tighten up. Oxfordshire for example, has recently written to all GPs strongly advising them to obtain certificates from locums, and ring the General Medical Council for verification.

In the wake of the Shipman case, and numerous cases of impersonation of medical professionals, surely there is a need for a firm set of rules on how to hire a locum? I would suggest a minimum of GMC, JCPTGP, indemnity certificates and passport or birth certificate to be supplied by the locum before they turn up, so that they can be checked with the relevant authorities. The practice should also have copies of suitable references on file.

This may not prevent another Shipman, but would present better cover for the practice and its patients, and a feeling of working in an organised and safe atmosphere for the locum. I have been shocked by the lack of effort made by practices to ensure they are employing a fully qualified GP. I hope this article will stimulate some debate to help bring about change.

fields.headline: Bad habits die hard
fields.standfirst: We suffer more heart disease than almost every country in Europe - but we still like to think we're healthier than our continental cousins. Emma Brockes reports on Britain's curiously ambivalent approach to healthy living.
fields.trailText: We suffer more heart disease than almost every country in Europe - but we still like to think we're healthier than our continental cousins. Emma Brockes reports on Britain's curiously ambivalent approach to healthy living.
fields.body:
The gap between Britain's self-image and its actual shape in the mirror widened this week, with a report by the British Heart Foundation which put the country third from bottom in the European league of deaths by heart disease.

We are not the sveltest nation, we know, but in those rare moments of nutritional doubt, one glance through the lens of national stereotype - at Germans scoffing fatty sausage and Italians bolting pasta - reassures us enough to retire to the sofa and order a takeaway. But one day, the statistics imply, this moment of self-satisfaction will be spoiled by some shooting pains in the chest and fish-out-of-water breathing.

Look in the mirror again, says Neil Poulter, professor of preventive cardiovascular medicine at Imperial College, London, and this is what you should see: "We've got high levels of smoking; we've got a high fat intake, cholesterol levels are up and we're overweight. We've got high blood pressure, and we have too much salt in our diet. And we don't exercise. More than 30% of the population do nothing whatsoever, apart from breathing. And it's getting worse."

Yet when he appeared on a radio show to discuss the report yesterday morning, the first thing the presenter said was: "Come on, it's the Italians who eat all these creamy and fatty foods, not us." "I said absolutely not," says Poulter. "It is extraordinary that this notion persists. The British breakfast has killed more people than the British army."

Figures released by the British Heart Foundation put the death rate by coronary heart disease in this country at more than double that of France. In the UK, an average of 188 out of 100,000 people between the ages of 35-74 die each year from heart disease. In France, that figure is 57 (which puts it at the head of the league), in Italy, 96, making it joint fourth with Luxembourg.

The reasons are a combination of economic factors and national truculence. Last April, a report entitled Looking to the Future was published, identifying the discrepancy in the amount of heart disease suffered by low and high-income brackets. In the 70s, those on low incomes were 25% more likely to die from heart disease than those on high. In 1999, that figure was more than 30%.

"I'm worried about people thinking we are a healthy-eating nation," says Professor Klim McPherson, who contributed to the study. "It has been apparent for quite a long time that we're high up in the coronary heart disease stakes - even in comparison with America and Australia." The study highlighted not only the relationship between diet and health, but between health and habit.

"The problem is that in some European countries you just eat a more healthy diet because it's how you are brought up: to eat more fruit and vegetables and to drink wine, which is of course very good for your coronary arteries. Your attitude is dominated by where you're born and brought up and what is made available to you."

This question of attitude might be linked to the vague British resentment of interference from the busy-body state and a suspicion of scientists who appear to change their minds every other week. "In the past, we've had some adverse influences from people saying cholesterol didn't matter," says Poulter, "and there have been arguments about the harmfulness of salt in this country, when everyone else in the world acknowledges that there's too much salt and it's not necessary. We've always been very conservative about accepting research."

"There is such a plethora of contradictory medical warnings, that people don't know what is worthwhile and what is cranky," says Dr Peter Marsh, social psychologist and director of the science and research unit in Oxford. But Dr Elizabeth Dowler, of Warwick University's department of social policy and social work, is doubtful that unhealthy eating has much to do with the public's distrust of nutritionists: "There is a strong view that the trouble with nutritionists is they are always changing their minds, and I don't think it is particularly true. There are a lot of popular myths around, but experts have always advocated a balanced diet, and recommended eating fruit and vegetables."

If there is stubbornness over the dinner table, she says, it is more likely to be a generational thing. "Everyone has an Uncle Arthur who smoked like a chimney and lived to be 86," says Dowler. "There's no doubt that this is quite a dominant idea. The kinds of messages that were inculcated in people before the second world war are things that have governed food choice among older people. This always plays an important point in the story."

"My father used to say, I've eaten butter all my life and I'm not going to stop now," says Poulter. "It was all rather Thatcherite." Even accounting for the rash of detoxification diets that were used to advertise a certain lifestyle in the 90s, the consensus still tends to be that watching what you eat is fussy and boring. "It is part peer pressure, part tradition and part habit."

In these circumstances, it is easy to fall back on the familiar cycle of bad eating followed by a prim week off chocolate and a binge at the weekend. "We have an ambivalent relationship to what we eat," says Marsh. "On the one hand, we're rather neurotic, and, on the other, we have some bad consumption habits. The Italians have a much healthier attitude towards eating: they enjoy it and have less of a sense of guilt."

Guilt doesn't cause heart disease, but Marsh strongly believes that the attitude one has towards eating creates a climate in which the likelihood of falling ill can be tipped either way. That attitude is not always determined by choice. "For a lot of people, the health of their children and to a lesser extent themselves, is a source of constant anxiety," says Dowler. "But it is a question of what they can afford to put on the table."

In the 70s, those on low incomes were 25% more likely to die from heart disease than those on high. In 1999, that figure was more than 30%. "I'm worried about people thinking we are a healthy-eating nation," says Professor Klim McPherson, who contributed to the study. "It has been apparent for quite a long time that we're high up in the coronary heart disease stakes - even in comparison with America and Australia." The study highlighted not only the relationship between diet and health, but between health and habit. "The problem is that in some European countries you just eat a more healthy diet because it's how you are brought up: to eat more fruit and vegetables and to drink wine, which is of course very good for your coronary arteries. Your attitude is dominated by where you're born and brought up and what is made available to you." This question of attitude might be linked to the vague British resentment of interference from the busy-body state and a suspicion of scientists who appear to change their minds every other week. "In the past, we've had some adverse influences from people saying cholesterol didn't matter," says Poulter, "and there have been arguments about the harmfulness of salt in this country, when everyone else in the world acknowledges that there's too much salt and it's not necessary. We've always been very conservative about accepting research." "There is such a plethora of contradictory medical warnings, that people don't know what is worthwhile and what is cranky," says Dr Peter Marsh, social psychologist and director of the science and research unit in Oxford. But Dr Elizabeth Dowler, of Warwick University's department of social policy and social work, is doubtful that unhealthy eating has much to do with the public's distrust of nutritionists: "There is a strong view that the trouble with nutritionists is they are always changing their minds, and I don't think it is particularly true. There are a lot of popular myths around, but experts have always advocated a balanced diet, and recommended eating fruit and vegetables." If there is stubbornness over the dinner table, she says, it is more likely to be a generational thing. "Everyone has an Uncle Arthur who smoked like a chimney and lived to be 86," says Dowler. "There's no doubt that this is quite a dominant idea. The kinds of messages that were inculcated in people before the second world war are things that have governed food choice among older people. This always plays an important point in the story." "My father used to say, I've eaten butter all my life and I'm not going to stop now," says Poulter. "It was all rather Thatcherite." Even accounting for the rash of detoxification diets that were used to advertise a certain lifestyle in the 90s, the consensus still tends to be that watching what you eat is fussy and boring. "It is part peer pressure, part tradition and part habit." In these circumstances, it is easy to fall back on the familiar cycle of bad eating followed by a prim week off chocolate and a binge at the weekend. "We have an ambivalent relationship to what we eat," says Marsh. "On the one hand, we're rather neurotic, and, on the other, we have some bad consumption habits. The Italians have a much healthier attitude towards eating: they enjoy it and have less of a sense of guilt." Guilt doesn't cause heart disease, but Marsh strongly believes that the attitude one has towards eating creates a climate in which the likelihood of falling ill can be tipped either way. That attitude is not always determined by choice. "For a lot of people, the health of their children and to a lesser extent themselves, is a source of constant anxiety," says Dowler. "But it is a question of what they can afford to put on the table."

fields.headline: The Bowen technique
fields.trailText: I am lying face down on a fold-out couch in my front room under a towel, wearing only knickers and bra, wishing I'd turned the heating up. Guy Mitchell, Bowen technique practitioner, is crouched outside the door. After getting me to strip off and lie down, he has prodded my lower leg then left the room. He is, he says, putting himself outside my "energy field". We wait like this for a minute while my body allegedly "resets and heals itself".
fields.body:
I am lying face down on a fold-out couch in my front room under a towel, wearing only knickers and bra, wishing I'd turned the heating up. Guy Mitchell, Bowen technique practitioner, is crouched outside the door. After getting me to strip off and lie down, he has prodded my lower leg then left the room. He is, he says, putting himself outside my "energy field". We wait like this for a minute while my body allegedly "resets and heals itself".

The Bowen technique was developed in Australia in the 1950s by Tom Bowen, who modestly said his healing power was "simply a gift from God". Word spread and soon people were struggling across Australia to him with their untreatable ailments. Most of those who turn to the technique suffer from persistent complaints such as backache that conventional medicine hasn't healed. Bowen practitioners say, though, that it will cure anything from asthma to PMT, from bunions to anxiety.

Bowen is a less worrying therapy than bone-crunching osteopathy. There are no sudden moves or uncomfortable noises. Instead, the practitioner performs a series of light prods on various muscles which are, apparently, fine-tuned to channel "natural energy" into problem areas. They will, says Mitchell, "empower the body's own resources to heal itself". How, exactly, this takes place is a divine mystery. But with a claimed 9,000 practitioners world wide it must work for someone.

Mitchell himself discovered Bowen after a car crash left both his shoulders locked. He was told by doctors that he'd always be in pain, but after a course of Bowen, he was a new man.

I am hoping the treatment will heal my niggling lower back pain and pep me up generally. Mitchell claims it will, and suggests a "body balance". This takes about 30 minutes and is what most people having Bowen for the first time can expect: a series of gentle pokes to the back, knees, shoulders and neck. These pokes are called "cross-fibre muscle manipulations", and feel like a thumb pressed down deep into the muscle, twiddled slightly, then released.

Once I've got used to Mitchell slinking in and out of the room, and have stopped worrying about whether it's going to hurt, the treatment turns out to be quite relaxing. The whole 30 minutes is carried out in companionable silence, and I assume my body must be doing something, as I feel less cold and my muscles even buzz a little.

When it's finished, I'm relaxed, but then so I should be: I've been lying down quietly for half an hour with nothing to do but look at a white ceiling. I can't identify any special release or uplift, but I'm not, thank God, weeping. Mitchell says some people break down afterwards, the release is so profound. But he assures me that the results can also be gradual.

While getting dressed, I wobble my head around a bit in the hope of detecting some difference in my stiff neck. Mitchell whizzes over, gives three prods, and immediately the stiff left side is liberated. This instant, tangible difference suggests that Bowen is best for a specific ache. Mitchell agrees. If you come to him with, say, tennis elbow, you'll get an initial "Body Balance" and then more specific, extra moves on the problem area. The results, he adds, should be permanent.

Like most complementary therapies, there's much talk of energy flows and not much hard fact. Bowen literature talks about "penetrating to a deep cellular level" and "the release of toxins", and claims to "embrace the physical, chemical, emotional and mental aspects of each person receiving treatment". These are weighty claims. But since practitioners say it works on animals (one woman treats horses, apparently with amazing results), the benefits can't just be psychosomatic.

It didn't sort my lower back out, but it was only an initial treatment, so it's probably unfair to judge on this alone. Given the effects on my stiff neck, though, I'd say Bowen would be worth a try if conventional medicine has failed you.

 Guy Mitchell runs the Bowen Association UK. Tel: 01455 841800. Email: info@bowen-technique.co.uk. Sessions cost between £15 and £45.
