fields.headline: My trainer's top 10 fitness tips
fields.standfirst: In the second part of his quest for the body beautiful,  Stephen Moss enlists the aid of Schubert and a few sneaky lattes
fields.trailText: In the second part of his quest for the body beautiful, Stephen Moss enlists the aid of Schubert and a few sneaky lattes
fields.body:
It's an attitude. I had to fly to the US the other day. This is going to sound so preachy and smug, but normally I would have drunk a couple of those small bottles of Chardonnay, eaten all the nuts on offer, snaffled bars of Toblerone, got bored, eaten some more nuts, scoffed an entire trayful of inedible sludge ("Chicken or steak, sir" - who can tell them apart?) and fallen asleep. Well, I didn't: I ate a salad, drank water, watched a movie, read the New Yorker from cover to cover, and was moved by Horowitz playing Schubert's Serenade in a recording made in his New York flat when he was over 80. It's an attitude.

Ten days into life with a personal trainer I feel transformed. I haven't lost any weight and I'm still struggling with tempting foods (PLEASE take that chocolate cake away), but people tell me I look better, I certainly feel better, and I've convinced myself that my stomach is marginally less shapeless than previously.

What I am undoubtedly feeling is mentally more organised: I have more energy - except immediately after each of my thrice-weekly workouts - and more mental focus. I am in control, empowered, ready to take on the world.

I've found that reducing alcohol and cutting out the snacks (eaten out of boredom rather than hunger) is easy; I'm still addicted to sweet tea and occasional biscuits, and I'm not really counting the calories. If the weight doesn't start to reduce, I will have to be stricter with myself.

The exercise has been great. I spend 10 minutes on a walking machine that simulates cross- country skiing (no problem); 10 minutes running on a treadmill (enjoyable - my heart rate shoots up worryingly before it stabilises) and six minutes on a bike (very dull). We'll also be moving on to the rowing machine. All these are designed to get the heart working and improve stamina levels, but I will also need to do some running outside the gym.

The other half of each one-hour session is spent on weights. Each time, we use four sets of equipment designed to build up different muscles: biceps, triceps, pecs, quads, abs, delts, traps, rhomboids and lots of other muscles I didn't know I had.

By far the toughest is the machine where I have to lift myself up using two bars: this cruel contraption is clearly designed to show how ridiculously heavy the user is. If you can simultaneously increase your muscle tissue and reduce your body weight, this becomes a cinch. At the moment it is purgatory.

The only mistake I've made so far was seeing the movie American Beauty, in which Kevin Spacey plays a dysfunctional 42-year-old (the age is cruel!) whose mid-life crisis takes the form of lusting after his daughter's best friend and working out like a maniac to impress her. It all ends in blood, sweat and tears (not necessarily in that order). Why are you doing it, someone asks the Spacey character - to increase strength or stamina? To look good naked, he replies with admirable candour. My motives are of course far less crudely physical: I want to be a productive worker, a good citizen, a well-rounded (metaphorically speaking) human being; I'm not doing this for me, but for mankind.

My first report produced a lot of reasonably good-natured abuse from friends and colleagues, and two letters. The first, from the head of leisure services at Fenland District Council, told me that if an investment of £600-plus a month on a personal trainer became too much, I could join a Fenland leisure centre for £28. Well worth considering, although I have become rather hooked on my trainer Sam's psychological support. (He says some of his clients pour out their emotional problems to him - so far, thankfully, I have resisted that. One hour just wouldn't be long enough.)

The other letter took me to task for referring vaguely to five pieces of fruit. "Does one plum count as a piece? And how many grapes?" demanded my correspondent. Just for the record: one piece of fruit includes a whole apple, banana or pear, or a cupful of grapes or something similar. The same correspondent thought two litres of water a day impossible and said I must have to get up throughout the night. Well, I haven't been measuring the quantity precisely, but I have been drinking a great deal more water, without so far having my sleep disturbed. I am drinking a lot during the intensive one-hour exercise session, and making sure I drink cups of water throughout the day in our hot, unhealthily dehydrated office. It's really a question of substituting water for tea, coffee, cola and booze, so the overall quantity of liquid is not much changed.

I am keen to be a bit of a force for collective change, so I asked Sam for some healthy tips that everyone can follow. You see, he's your personal trainer, too. Here goes:

1 Reduce fat intake to 20% of your total calories. Cut down the fatty foods - fried foods, chips and cakes.

2 Eat more fruit and veg.

3 Eat natural foods rather than processed foods, which are filled with sugar, salt and chemicals.

4 Drink lots of water and cut down on tea and, especially, coffee. Drink two cups of coffee a day, max. (My gym is right next to a Starbucks with a comfy armchair and this is proving a bit of a problem; my motto at the moment appears to be better latte than never. Sorry, Sam.)

5 Do a minimum of 20 minutes of cardio-vascular exercise three times a week - running, biking, rowing, walking at a pace fast enough to get your heart rate up (don't overdo it though, especially at first).

6 Exercise will also reduce stress: a brisk 30-minute walk will do you a lot of good mentally and physically. (Apparently, it produces endorphins in the brain, and that is good for you.)

7 Try weight training at home: cans of beans can make perfect dumb-bells (but don't drop one of the family-sized cans on your foot).

8 Try some push-ups (extremely hard work) and squats.

9 Do regular stretching exercises - hamstrings, calves, chest, shoulder blades.

10 Swim regularly - good cardio-vascular exercise and, since it isn't weight-bearing or impactive, excellent for people with sore joints.

I'd like to add one more tip. Make some time for yourself, turn off the lights, sit alone in a darkened room and put on a CD of Horowitz playing Schubert or Chopin. There, you feel better already.

 Stephen Moss is working out at Matt Roberts at One, a health club at 1 Aldwych, London WC2 (tel: 0171 300 0600).

fields.headline: Dear doctor: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.trailText: How to keep kids asleep | Irregular heartbeat
fields.body:
How to keep kids asleep

Q: I've got three kids and none of them have managed to sleep through the night until they reach the age of five. Cumulatively, I've been sleep-deprived for nearly a decade now. I have to admit that I resort to dosing my two-year-old with a couple of liberal teaspoons of Piriton syrup, since my GP told me that's what she did with her kids. Is that OK and is there anything better?

A: When my first child finally slept through the whole night (aged about six), my mother-in-law warned me: "You'll never sleep properly again, you know!" And she was right. One in five under-threes and one in 10 four to five-year-olds sleep badly enough for their parents to seek help, often from a health visitor or GP. It makes mums feel ill, and relationships suffer. Sedation with antihistamines or more powerful prescription drugs is a common response, but it doesn't work in the long term: it can buy you one night's sleep, but won't have any impact after four weeks.

Giving drugs to children is not ideal - they might become drowsy during the day or you might be one of the unlucky minority whose child becomes more active when given antihistamines. A recent report in the British Medical Journal confirms the benefits of a 20-minute wind-down routine which is begun five to 10 minutes earlier each week until you arrive at the desired bedtime. This needs to be coupled with ignoring bedtime tantrums for preset time intervals.

For kids who wake several times a night, waking the child 15 to 60 minutes before they usually wake, then resettling them, can help. No one behavioural strategy works better than any other, but all are better than drugs in the long term.

Q: About a year ago, after prolonged breathlessness, I was diagosed as having an irregular heartbeat. My GP referred me to a specialist and I was prescribed amiodarone and warfarin for six weeks. When this had no effect I had cardioversion. This resulted in a regular pulse but when the amiodarone was stopped I reverted to the irregular heartbeat. The specialist said that nothing else could be done and that I should come back when I get worse. My GP is "not worried". I continue to take warfarin plus beta blockers and train regularly at a fitness centre. I do not push myself, but my pulse varies wildly: up or down 10-15 bpm is not unusual. Should I be worried?

A: It sounds as though you had an irregular heartbeat known as atrial fibrillation (AF). The upper chambers of the heart (atria) fire off ineffective, chaotic, irregular and rapid bursts of electrical activity. It can cause palpitations, breathlessness or merely an irregular pulse, often picked up by chance. AF can be a sign of underlying heart disease, high blood pressure or an overactive thyroid.

If there's no underlying cause, as in your case, it's known as "lone AF". Cardiologists usually suggest one go at giving the heart a big electric shock to try to tip it into normal electrical activity (cardioversion). Your blood is thinned with an anticoagulant, warfarin, before and after cardioversion because there's a small risk that when the heart changes from AF to normal rhythm or vice versa, small clots can be thrown out of the heart, which may cause a stroke. A lot of people slip back into AF after cardioversion.

Drugs such as amiodarone, digoxin or beta blockers (eg sotalol) may not return the heart to normal rhythm but they make it beat more slowly so you get fewer symptoms, and there is less strain on the heart.

Foreskin trouble

Q: My foreskin keeps adhering to the lower part of the glans of my penis. It becomes itchy and feels painful during sexual intercourse. To counteract the effects, I pull it away, which hurts and causes bleeding, but gradually it sticks again. Circumcision has been recommended, but at the age of 54 I do not wish to have surgery if a less radical solution can be found. Is there one?

A: Your unfortunate condition is called a paraphimosis and tends to happen if the foreskin is a bit tight. As you say, the retracted foreskin gets trapped behind the glans, especially when the penis is erect. The glans gets engorged and swollen so it becomes even harder to slide the foreskin forward again. You can squeeze the glans for half an hour to reduce the swelling (ouch!) or soak a piece of gauze in a sugar solution and hold over the glans for an hour. But if it happens time and again, circumcision may be the best option.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o the Health Editor, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

Foreskin trouble Q: My foreskin keeps adhering to the lower part of the glans of my penis. It becomes itchy and feels painful during sexual intercourse. To counteract the effects, I pull it away, which hurts and causes bleeding, but gradually it sticks again. Circumcision has been recommended, but at the age of 54 I do not wish to have surgery if a less radical solution can be found. Is there one? As you say, the retracted foreskin gets trapped behind the glans, especially when the penis is erect. The glans gets engorged and swollen so it becomes even harder to slide the foreskin forward again. You can squeeze the glans for half an hour to reduce the swelling (ouch!) or soak a piece of gauze in a sugar solution and hold over the glans for an hour. But if it happens time and again, circumcision may be the best option.  These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. fields.headline: Higher student fees for Oxbridge
fields.standfirst: Education secretary announces top-up fees and a new breed of 'e-universities'
fields.trailText: Higher student fees for Oxford, Cambridge and other elite universities could become a reality after the next election, David Blunkett, the education secretary, admitted today when he made a landmark speech on higher education.
fields.body:
Higher student fees for Oxford, Cambridge and other elite universities could become a reality after the next election, David Blunkett, the education secretary, admitted today when he made a landmark speech on higher education.

Speaking at the university of Greenwich, he said he was personally opposed to the idea but he would not be in his present job forever. His announcement of a 'second Dearing' inquiry into university funding marked a major potential shift in government policy and a recognition that leading institutions need additional income to compete with global competitors.

Mr Blunkett announced two major initiatives - an 'e-university' to draw on the best available in British higher education and teach students around the world, and a new two-year foundation degree to draw more people in the UK into high level vocational qualifications.

"The arrival of the knowledge economy has intensified the competitive pressures on higher education institutions. Learning has become a big business," said Mr Blunkett.

Bids to become Britain's e-university will be invited from consortia of universities and private companies. "We want to create a new partnership between universities and the private sector which will develop a novel means of distance learning and exploit the new information and communication technologies. It will concentrate resources from a number of partners on a scale which can compete with leading US providers."

Britain's historic skills deficit lay in people with intermediate skills - including highly-qualified technicians, added Mr Blunkett. Courses would run in IT, finance and the creative industries. "We have to develop new higher education opportunities at this level, orientated strongly to the employability skills, specialist knowledge and broad understanding needed in the new economy.

"We therefore intend to create new two-year Foundation Degrees to help meet our objective that half of all young people benefit from higher education by the age of 30. Last year some 80,000 students with two or more A levels, or the vocational equivalent, did not enter higher education directly. That's more than one in three of those who gained qualifications at this standard. "

Mr Blunkett said that there was a special responsibility on higher education institutions to forge links with businesses. Liaison with small and medium-sized enterprises was particularly critical, since these companies are drivers of innovation and employment growth.

"Universities are autonomous institutions, and rightly so. But as the prime minister put it in his Romanes lecture last year, in the knowledge economy, entrepreneurial universities will be as important as entrepreneurial businesses, the one fostering the other. The 'do nothing' universities will not survive - and it will not be the job of government to bail them out. Universities need to adapt rapidly to the top-down influences of globalisation and the new technologies, as well as the bottom-up imperatives of serving the local labour market, innovating with local companies, and providing professional development courses that stimulate economic and intellectual growth."

fields.headline: A window on wages
fields.trailText:
A newsagent's window may not be a scientific instrument of inquiry, but it is 
an invaluable aid to gauging the economic health of a small community.
fields.body:
A newsagent's window may not be a scientific instrument of inquiry, but it is an invaluable aid to gauging the economic health of a small community.

A couple of years ago, the window of our local newsagent-cum-post office in Chipping Norton was liberally plastered with for-sale postcards. There was not a job in sight. Now, the same window is spattered with offers of work, and fly-posters have appeared on lamp-posts and noticeboards around the town, brightly promising extra cash for home workers.

It's a seller's market for job-seekers. In the whole of West Oxfordshire district (pop. 97,434), there are fewer than 350 registered unemployed. That is just 0.7% of the workforce. Clearly, compared with employment blackspots in the post-industrial north or in Wales and the West country, ours is a privileged area. But appearances can be deceptive.

Virtually all those jobs on offer in the newsagent's window are part-time and unskilled. Cleaners are in particularly high demand and though most prospective employers are coy about wages, the highest on offer is £5 an hour. A local shop is looking for a Saturday assistant at £4 an hour; a hotel wants a cook for £4.50.

One of the fly-poster merchants is dangling the prospect of up to £7 an hour, for delivering catalogues of household goods and collecting orders. He himself is doing nicely from what is clearly a variant of pyramid selling, by recruiting the door-to-door sales force and taking a cut of their earnings.

One of the local papers, the Cotswold Standard, is plump with job advertising. Some are upmarket career positions; most are at best semi-skilled and offering less than £10,000 a year. A high proportion are part-time; a device much favoured by employers who want to avoid national insurance payments, holiday entitlements, and other so-called perks. Just one job, as a skilled home carer, is advertised at the national minimum wage of £3.60 an hour.

"I'd tell them to stuff it," said an acquaintance; a home carer herself on a less than princely hourly rate of £4.40. "You just can't expect people to work for that kind of money. It's not as if this is a cheap area to live."

The same point was made by virtually everybody who was prepared to take part in a brief straw poll in the market place. "I suppose tenpence extra an hour means something in a place where there is no work to begin with," was one thought-provoking comment.

Another much repeated theme is the lack of any relationship between wage rates and house prices. This is Range Rover country, where retired folk, weekenders and other incomers have driven up property prices relentlessly. Social housing is in desperately short supply, and there is little by way of family accommodation on sale for under £100,000, in a local economy dominated by low-paid sectors like agriculture, retail, and tourism.

Not surprisingly, the minimum wage is an uncomfortable subject on the street. "Nothing to do with me, mate," barked one man, clearly offended by the (unspoken) implication that he was earning peanuts. If anyone in the impromptu discussion did earn £3.60 an hour, neither he nor she was prepared to admit it. Local employers were similarly reluctant to talk about what they were prepared to pay - though one bemoaned the projected rise of 20p an hour for young workers. "It's all very well to talk about minimum rates for adults with responsibilities, but youngsters have to learn to hold down a job before they can rely on a decent wage," he said.

fields.headline: Other news
fields.trailText: • Christina Ricci is to make her behind-the-scenes debut when she takes a co-producing credit on the upcoming adaptation of Elizabeth Wurtzel's Prozac Nation. The star of Sleepy Hollow and The Opposite of Sex will also take the lead role as a precocious, Harvard-educated New Yorker whose suicidal depression parallels her career as a top-flight journalist (not a million miles away from Jennifer Jason Leigh's Selena St George character in Dolores Claiborne then). Based on Wurtzel's own experiences, the film treatment of Prozac Nation had stalled at the development stage until Ricci's hands-on commitment to the project gave it a new lease of life. The independently financed picture will be helmed by Norwegian director Erik Skjoldbjaerg, who won critical plaudits for his dour 1998 murder mystery Insomnia. Shooting begins in New York on May 15.
fields.body:
 Christina Ricci is to make her behind-the-scenes debut when she takes a co-producing credit on the upcoming adaptation of Elizabeth Wurtzel's Prozac Nation. The star of Sleepy Hollow and The Opposite of Sex will also take the lead role as a precocious, Harvard-educated New Yorker whose suicidal depression parallels her career as a top-flight journalist (not a million miles away from Jennifer Jason Leigh's Selena St George character in Dolores Claiborne then). Based on Wurtzel's own experiences, the film treatment of Prozac Nation had stalled at the development stage until Ricci's hands-on commitment to the project gave it a new lease of life. The independently financed picture will be helmed by Norwegian director Erik Skjoldbjaerg, who won critical plaudits for his dour 1998 murder mystery Insomnia. Shooting begins in New York on May 15.

 Fox's much hyped backpacker saga The Beach limped in a disappointing second as weekend takings were confirmed at the US box office. The Thailand-set pic pulled in $15m from its opening three days to finish behind the fast-fading Scream 3, down to $16.4m from an opening weekend gross of $34.7m. But The Beach's poor fortunes could well dent main star Leo DiCaprio's reputation. "Leonardo is in for a salary reduction after this," entertainment analyst Art Rockwell told Bloomberg News. The 25-year-old actor is believed to have pocketed around $20m for his role as an American tourist in search of an idyllic island paradise. "A lot of teenage girls want to see him, but their male counterparts are bored silly by a movie like this. It is a significant disappointment for Fox," Rockwell added.

 The original man in black is to receive the full silver-screen treatment as country-and-western legend Johnny Cash becomes the subject of a movie biopic. Simply entitled Cash, the picture will be directed by James Mangold - the creator of Cop Land and the current Girl, Interrupted starring Winona Ryder and Angelina Jolie - and produced by long-time Cash buddy James Keach. The movie, Keach told Variety, will be the story "of every man who has descended into hell and found redemption in the love of a woman, in his music, in the love of his fans." The casting of Johnny Cash has yet to be announced.

 Eddie Murphy is poised to revisit his role as an animal-chatting vet in Fox's follow-up to Doctor Doolittle, according to a Variety report yesterday. The 1998 original was credited with providing the ailing Murphy with his biggest hit in a decade, and Lord knows the comedian has never been averse to revisiting the scenes of former glories: witness Beverly Hills Cop 2 (and 3) and Another 48 Hours. Doolittle 2 could begin production this autumn for a summer release in 2001.

 Christian Slater married former TV producer Ryan Haddon in a ceremony in Los Angeles at the weekend. The couple already have a son, Jaden Christopher, who was born in April last year. Slater, 30, and Haddon, 28, are honeymooning in Hawaii.

 Francis Coppola is to present Steven Spielberg with his Directors Guild Lifetime Achievement award at a ceremony on March 11. Coppola won the award himself when it was named the DW Griffith Award, after the controversial maker of the influential, but racially dubious 1915 picture, Birth of a Nation.

 The producers of Nicole Kidman's new film, The Others, are having problems finding a suitable little girl to play the star's daughter. Casting directors have spent four months visiting British stage schools and drama clubs looking for a 7-9 year-old girl with flame coloured hair to star in the "Gothic thriller" set in 1940s Nazi-occupied Jersey, but have had no luck. They are now faxing schools asking to interview girls who would like to become actresses. According to a spokesman for Sogetel, the Madrid production company making the film, the lucky girl and her screen brother would spend about two months in northern Spain, working in countryside similar to that of Jersey. "It could be a very exciting experience for them. They could travel to another country, meet exciting people and perhaps begin a very promising acting career. It certainly could enrich their lives."

fields.headline: Oscar nominations 2000
fields.trailText: The principal nominations for the 72nd Academy Awards were announced at 1.38pm GMT in a brief ceremony co-hosted by two-time Oscar winner Dustin Hoffman. The nominations are as follows:
fields.body:
The principal nominations for the 72nd Academy Awards were announced at 1.38pm GMT in a brief ceremony co-hosted by two-time Oscar winner Dustin Hoffman. The nominations are as follows:

Best film

American Beauty, The Cider House Rules, The Green Mile, The Insider, The Sixth Sense

Best director

Sam Mendes (American Beauty), Spike Jonze (Being John Malkovich), Lasse Hallstrom (The Cider House Rules), Michael Mann (The Insider), M. Night Shyamalan (The Sixth Sense)

Best actor

Russell Crowe (The Insider), Richard Farnsworth (The Straight Story), Sean Penn (Sweet and Lowdown), Kevin Spacey (American Beauty), Denzel Washington (The Hurricane)

Best actress

Annette Bening (American Beauty), Janet Mcteer (Tumbleweeds), Julianne Moore (The End of the Affair), Meryl Streep (Music of the Heart), Hilary Swank (Boys don't Cry)

Best supporting actor

Michael Caine (Cider House Rules), Tom Cruise (Magnolia), Jude Law (Talented Mr. Ripley), Michael Clarke Duncan (The Green Mile), Haley Joel Osment (The Sixth Sense)

Best supporting actress

Toni Collette (The Sixth Sense), Catherine Keener (Being John Malkovich), Chloe Sevigny (Boys don't Cry), Angelina Jolie (Girl, Interrupted), Samantha Morton (Sweet and Lowdown)

Best original screenplay

American Beauty, Being John Malkovich, The Sixth Sense, Topsy-Turvy, Magnolia

Best adapted screenplay

Cider House Rules, Election, The Green Mile, The Insider, The Talented Mr. Ripley,

Best foreign language film

All About My Mother, East West, Caravan, Solomon and Gaenor, Under the Sun

Art direction

Anna and the King, The Cider House Rules, Sleepy Hollow, The Talented Mr Ripley, Topsy-Turvy

Cinematography

American Beauty, The End of the Affair, The Insider, Sleepy Hollow, Snow Falling on Cedars

Costume

Anna and the King, Sleepy Hollow, The Talented Mr Ripley, Titus, Topsy-Turvy

Visual effects

The Matrix, The Phantom Menace, Stuart Little

Editing

American beauty, The Cider House Rules, The Insider, The Matrix, The Sixth Sense

Make-up

Austin Powers: the spy who shagged me, Bicentennial Man, Life, Topsy-Turvy

Sound

The Green Mile, The Insider, The Matrix, The Mummy, The Phantom Menace

Original score

American Beauty, Angela's Ashes, The Cider House Rules, The Red Violin, The Talented Mr Ripley

Original song

Blame Canada (South Park: Bigger, Longer, Uncut), Music of my Heart (Music of the Heart), Save Me (Magnolia), When She Loved Me (Toy Story 2), You'll be in My Heart (Tarzan)

Best documentary

Buena Vista Social Club, Genghis Blues, On the Ropes, One Day in September, Speaking in Strings

The most notable surprise is the poor showing of The Talented Mr. Ripley, with Minghella's film missing out in the nominations for Best film and Best director. Matt Damon was also tipped to be nominated for Best actor. In the event, Ripley has only a cursory nod in the category of Best adapted screenplay, and Best supporting actor for Jude Law.

Other big losers include Star Wars Episode 1: the Phantom Menace (with two minor nominations), Angela's Ashes (one nomination), Man on the Moon, and Stanley Kubrick's posthumous Eyes Wide Shut.

As predicted, American Beauty leads the field with eight nominations in all, closely followed by Michael Mann's The Insider and the unheralded The Cider House Rules, both with seven nominations apiece.

For trivia buffs, Meryl Streep enters the record books with her twelth nomination for acting - an achievement that ties her with Katherine Hepburn. Meantime, 79-year-old Richard Farnsworth becomes the oldest man ever to be nominated for the Best actor oscar for his turn as a lawnmower-driving traveller in David Lynch's The Straight Story.

fields.headline: Oscar hints: The leaked nominations
fields.trailText: The nominations for the 72nd Academy Awards are officially announced later today. But if you can't wait that long, a top-secret leaked list has served up a sneak preview of this year's prime contenders.
fields.body:
The nominations for the 72nd Academy Awards are officially announced later today. But if you can't wait that long, a top-secret leaked list has served up a sneak preview of this year's prime contenders.

The nominations leaked to Ain't It Cool News purport to show the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences's "longlist" for this year's Oscars. The eight names in each category will today be whittled down to the crucial five who will each vie for their respective statuettes on Sunday March 26.

If reliable, the list already throws up some surprises: namely the non-showings of Fight Club, Being John Malkovich or Boys Don't Cry in the nominations for Best Picture. Widely judged to be one of the most inventive and entertaining pictures of the year, Being John Malkovich appears to have been cruelly snubbed by the Academy.

It also misses out on a nomination for Best Original Screenplay and for Best Director (for Spike Jonze). On the plus side, the determinedly small-scale, decidedly un-Hollywood Mike Leigh has apparently been graced with a brace of nominations for his Gilbert and Sullivan drama Topsy-Turvy.

The leaked longlist in the key Oscar categories is as follows:

Best picture
American Beauty, The End of the Affair, The Green Mile, The Hurricane, The Insider, The Sixth Sense, Topsy-Turvy, The Talented Mr Ripley.

Best director
Paul Thomas Anderson (Magnolia), Norman Jewison (The Hurricane), Mike Leigh (Topsy-Turvy), Michael Mann (The Insider), Sam Mendes (American Beauty), Anthony Minghella (The Talented Mr Ripley), David O Russell (Three Kings), M Night Shyamalan (The Sixth Sense).

Best actor

fields.bodyText: The nominations for the 72nd Academy Awards are officially announced later today. But if you can't wait that long, a top-secret leaked list has served up a sneak preview of this year's prime contenders. The nominations leaked to Ain't It Cool News purport to show the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences's "longlist" for this year's Oscars. The eight names in each category will today be whittled down to the crucial five who will each vie for their respective statuettes on Sunday March 26. If reliable, the list already throws up some surprises: namely the non-showings of Fight Club, Being John Malkovich or Boys Don't Cry in the nominations for Best Picture. Widely judged to be one of the most inventive and entertaining pictures of the year, Being John Malkovich appears to have been cruelly snubbed by the Academy. It also misses out on a nomination for Best Original Screenplay and for Best Director (for Spike Jonze). On the plus side, the determinedly small-scale, decidedly un-Hollywood Mike Leigh has apparently been graced with a brace of nominations for his Gilbert and Sullivan drama Topsy-Turvy. fields.headline: TheStreet joins crowded market
fields.trailText: TheStreet.co.uk today became the latest financial website to launch in Britain, hoping to capitalise on the growing enthusiasm for investing through the internet.
fields.body:
TheStreet.co.uk today became the latest financial website to launch in Britain, hoping to capitalise on the growing enthusiasm for investing through the internet.

TheStreet.co.uk joins an increasingly crowded field of financial sites such as the brash Motley Fool site and more established players like ft.com, the web operation of the Financial Times, which relaunched this week.

With 20 financial journalists, TheStreet.co.uk claims to have one of the largest dedicated online editorial teams in Britain. The team includes four former city editors of UK papers. The site will provide investors with up to the minute comment and analysis of breaking financial news. It has gained the backing of major portals such as AOL UK, Compuserve and Lycos, which have signed content syndication deals with the new venture.

The prototype for TheStreet.co.uk is the TheStreet.com in the US. TheStreet.com has established itself as a popular destination for small American investors thanks partly to the frequent appearances on TV of James Cramer, its opinionated commentator. The UK arm is backed by Chase capital partners, Barclays private equity, 3i, ETF group and Intel, the chip maker.

webTitle: Court rules medical report must be revealed

fields.headline: Court rules medical report must be revealed
fields.trailText: Jack Straw must give a key medical report on former Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet to those countries seeking his extradition, the high court ruled this afternoon.
fields.body:
Jack Straw must give a key medical report on former Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet to those countries seeking his extradition, the high court ruled this afternoon.

Lord Justice Simon Brown, sitting with two other judges, said: "For the reasons given in our judgments we allow this application to the extent we hold the medical report should be disclosed to the four requesting states under conditions of strict confidentiality."

The home secretary's refusal to reveal the medical reasons behind his provisional decision that he was "minded" to allow Gen Pinochet to go home led to today's successful application for judicial review by Belgium and six human rights organisations.

Belgium, France, Spain and Switzerland - which have outstanding extradition requests - will now be allowed to see the medical report.

The decision is a significant victory for countries and human rights groups who want Pinochet to face torture charges stemming from his 1973-1990 rule.

Today's decision is likely to further delay Mr Straw's final decision on whether the 84-year-old former dictator escape extradition and return home to Chile after some 16 months under house arrest in Surrey.

fields.headline: The trouble with the countryside
fields.standfirst:
The most pressing problem facing the countryside is not the hunting issue, but the increasing lack of resources - something the Countryside Alliance needs to address if it is to have an impact on country life, says David McKie
Plus: I Kilfoyle, you Kilfoyle, they Kilfoyle
fields.trailText: The most pressing problem facing the countryside is not the hunting issue, but the increasing lack of resources - something the Countryside Alliance needs to address if it is to have an impact on country life, says David McKie
fields.body:
Although Tony Blair believes that the traumas of rural life are sometimes exaggerated, his government does not dispute that country-dwellers, and especially farmers, have problems, and it hopes to do something about them. To this end it is busy consulting some of the relevant organisations. Some, but not others - the most striking exclusion being one of the best supported: the Countryside Alliance.

It was the Countryside Alliance which mustered thousands of people of every county and every class to demonstrate in London, so being shunned in this way is making it very cross. But its protests will go unheeded. Ministers think the alliance is simply a clever front for defenders of hunting. Aware that large majorities, even in country areas, support the banning of hunting, its inventors constructed the alliance to make hunting appear to be part of a wider countryside cause, taking in poverty, unemployment, the decline of the rural school, the death of the rural shop, and so on.

The alliance likes to pretend that all these issues are seamlessly interwoven. That is the case its officials make, and it is also made in various newspapers by various notable country-dwellers sympathetic to hunting. John Mortimer, for instance - playwright, novelist, creator of Rumpole and general good egg. He wrote a sizeable piece in the Observer about the village in the Chilterns where he has lived for 70 years. He did not name this village, but it sounds to me suspiciously like Turville, Bucks, whose inhabitants also include such gnarled straw-chewing rustics as Jeremy Paxman.

When he was a child, he wrote, the village had three pubs, three shops, a post office, two schools, two churches, a chapel and a bus into town. Now it has no shops, no post office and no bus, and - most fatal of all - no school. One of the pubs has gone and a second is soon to become a commuter residence. People who grew up in the village cannot afford homes of their own when they marry because the commuters have driven up prices beyond their means. One local farmer, hit as so many have been by the crisis in the industry, is making a profit of £9 a week to keep himself and his family.

The philosopher Roger Scruton marshalled a similar case for his village in Wiltshire. But each of these pieces slipped in a significant thought at the end. John Mortimer did it almost in passing: the fox-hunting issue, he said, simply confirmed rural suspicions that urban MPs do not understand the countryside. Roger Scruton pitched his defence on a higher plane. Yes, schools and churches and pubs bound rural communities together; but what united them most of all, he maintained, was the hunt.

When philosophers speak, we tend to listen in awe. They are not mere polemicists, but seekers after the truth. And yet this conclusion is tosh. There are many harmonious country communities scattered across the land where the hunt is never seen. If you made a map of Britain and coloured in the areas where hunts operate, howling great gaps would be left. And while it's true that the threat to hunting leaves even some non-hunters in villages baffled, its disappearance would hardly make the dent in their lives which the loss of church and chapel, pub, post office and school inflicts on their communities.

The moral for the Countryside Alliance is obvious. If it really wants to halt and then reverse the steady decay of traditional rural life, let it campaign on the issues that really matter. If it dropped its commitment to what it calls field sports and others call blood sports, it would find official doors opening, right up to Number 10's. But it won't, of course, since trying to save hunting is its very essence, its raison d'être, and the rest is merely convenient cover.

Useful links
Countryside in crisis: special report
The hunting debate: special report
Countryside Alliance

I Kilfoyle, you Kilfoyle, they Kilfoyle

Peter Kilfoyle, the Merseyside MP who left the government in protest against its neglect of Labour heartlands, may be feeling pleased with himself this morning.

It wasn't Kilfoyle who organised the Labour backbench protest over the government's refusal to step up the minimum wage which threatened big trouble at this week's meeting of the parliamentary Labour party. Yet his principled resignation may have been just the shock which was needed to get Tony Blair and Gordon Brown to look with rather more sympathy on this Labour party/trade union revolt than on most which have preceded it.

With the Tories still in a state of pitiful disarray, there is little real threat of middle-ground voters swinging back to the right. But there are plenty of protests suggesting that unless this government does something to placate its own party faithful, membership will erode and its core vote will fail to turn out, initially for the local elections in May and even perhaps in national contests beyond. Perhaps we ought to invent a verb to Kilfoyle: meaning, to issue a forcible reminder of the roots from which you come.

Related documentary
New Labour in power: special report

fields.headline: Neither laddish nor sappish
fields.trailText: Last week Catherine Zeta Jones revealed that, not content with being swept off her feet by Michael Douglas, she had also fallen for the dubious charms of golf. This provoked a tirade in the Evening Standard from columnist Zoe Williams, who wrote:
fields.body:
Last week Catherine Zeta Jones revealed that, not content with being swept off her feet by Michael Douglas, she had also fallen for the dubious charms of golf. This provoked a tirade in the Evening Standard from columnist Zoe Williams, who wrote:

"No sport is a woman's sport, and women who pretend otherwise think they're being modishly post-feminist and laddish, when actually they're being pre-feminist and sappish.

"Some women think that, just because they play good sport, or shout very well, this means they're not being culturally tyrannised, they're winning in a man's world. This is bogus: just by trying they've already lost.

"Next time you agree to play squash with your squeeze, think about it - what would you do if he suddenly professed an interest in the different opening mechanisms of Mac eyeshadow and, worse, could tell Bobbi Brown from Trish McEvoy?"

Thanks Zoe. There's always some cachet in taking the alternative viewpoint, but to pour scorn on women's involvement in sport at a time when even most men are coming round to the idea, seems rather desperate.

Men don't own sport. They acquired ownership of it over the years, but only in the same way that they grew accustomed to the director's comfy chair and arriving home to find tea on the table at six o' clock. We've got beyond separating life into masculine and feminine spheres - now women can join the army, lose cricket matches for England as ignominiously as the men, and sing Don McLean's American Pie.

The whole point of feminism is equality. Yet Williams accuses women of selling out if they try to get involved in something traditionally dominated by men. Talk about cutting off your nose to spite your (in this case, perfectly made-up) face. Would she really tell Billie Jean King, Steffi Graf and Fanny Blankers-Koen that just by trying to compete in a man's worldthey lost?

The bicycle played an important part in the emancipation of women in the early part of this century. It gave women the scope for unchaperoned adventure as well as an excuse to wear trousers. Was it wrong, post-feminist and sappish for flappers and others to take advantage of the freedom the bicycle offered? And if not, then what is so different in a woman showing an interest in the Tour de France today?

Women in some countries risk the wrath of fundamentalists when they play sport. But they play on, because they love it. If a woman risks her life each time she goes onto the football field, she might feel it was a bit much to be accused of pandering to men.

A survey of football fans published last week showed that 14% of all fans attending games in the Premiership were women, as are 33% of all new fans (who have started watching football in the past five years). This is something we should be celebrating, not denigrating. The more women are involved with sport, the less violent and hostile the environment. And not many women are likely to pay thousands of pounds for a season ticket and sit freezing to death of a Saturday afternoon, just for some post-feminist satisfaction.

So what if some women first show an interest in sport because their boyfriend does? This isn't the worst crime in the world. One of the best things about meeting someone new is that he or she will broaden your horizons. It is far worse to pigeonhole women with make-up and men with sport. This is the sort of stereotyping you would expect from a monosyllabic neanderthal, not from an intelligent women who writes for a leading newspaper.

Sport brings pleasure to millions - men and women. The crowd that watched the American women's football team win the World Cup was ten thousand stronger than the one that watched last year's FA Cup final. Sport can bring you untold pleasure and riches. And it releases the same endorphins and gives you the same euphoria as those produced by chocolate or sex. Surely Williams would not claim that they were the sole preserve of the man?

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. And she's not short of support. Read Ian Healy on the blossoming love affair between women and cricket

webTitle: PIA lift Quaid-e-Azam Trophy in Pakistan

fields.headline: PIA lift Quaid-e-Azam Trophy in Pakistan
fields.trailText: Pakistan
fields.body:
Pakistan

Pakistan International Airlines lifted the Quaid-e-Azam Trophy after a low-scoring victory over Habib Bank Limited in the final. It was scheduled to last five days, but needed just two as a serious of brilliant bowling displays undermined the batting. For PIA, both Nadeem Afzal and Ali Gohar finished with match figures of 8-102 as HBL, who led by 59 on first innings, were bowled out for 106 in their second, Salim Malik top-scoring with 26. PIA required 165 to win and cruised to victory with 73* from Ghulam Ali and captain Asif Mujtaba's 54*.

Habib Bank Ltd 171 and 106
Pakistan International Airlines 112 (Sajid Shah 5-42) and 166 for 2
PIA won by 8 wickets

Australia

Western Australia cruised to victory in their Pura Milk Cup match against Tasmania thanks to centuries from three of their batsmen. Damien Martyn scored 169 in the first innings, enabling WA to declare on 457 for 9, before Justin Langer hit 129 and Ryan Campbell 111 second time round to set Tasmania 387 to win. In between, Tassie opener Dene Hills made 139. His side then put up a brave batting display in their second innings with Jamie Cox scoring 101. But Bradley Hogg took 4-56 as Tasmania were dismissed for 261.

Western Australia 457 for 9 decl (Colin Miller 4-109) and 280 for 4 decl
Tasmania 351 for 4 decl and 261
Western Australia won by 125 runs

Captain Dene Hills hit 64 and Daniel Marsh 67 to lead Tasmania to a 46-run victory in the corresponding Mercantile Mutual Cup game. Set 234 to win, Western Australia lost early wickets and, with the score on 88 for 5, Tasmania looked like they were heading for a crushing victory. But Michael Hussey delayed things with 53 off 65 balls. Shaun Young took 3-24 however, to leave WA well short.

Tasmania 233 in 50 overs
Western Australia 182 in 42.4 overs
Tasmania won by 46 runs

In the other game, Matthew Hayden thrashed an unbeaten 120 from 100 balls to send Queensland to a nine-wicket victory over South Australia. For SA, only Greg Blewett, who made over half his side's runs with 101*, had put up much of a fight. Queensland sailed to victory with more than 14 overs remaining, losing only James Naher for 49.

South Australia 193 in 46.4 overs (Scott Prestwidge 3-25)
Queensland 197 for 1 in 35.5 overs
Queensland won by 9 wickets

India

Rain ruined the Ranji Trophy Super League game between Delhi and Rajasthan, after 102* from Delhi's Mithun Minhas had helped set up a first-innings declaration. Rajasthan started their massive climb well with Anshu Jain and captain Gagan Khoda sharing an opening partnership of 131. But Delhi seamer Amit Bhandari took 4-87 as they were dismissed for 311. No further play was possible.

Delhi 453 for 9 decl (Ashu Dani 82, Virender Shewag 64, Ajay Sharma 52)
Rajasthan 311
Drawn

Punjab's Gagandeep Singh ripped out the heart of the Hyderabad batting with 5-49 to skittle them for 117 in their first innings. Punjab opener Ravneet Ricky then made a fluent 134, allowing Punjab to declare 246 runs ahead. Hyberabad recharged their batteries and three of the top four batsmen registered half-centuries, captain Mohammad Azharuddin chipping in with an unbeaten 63. But rain meant that Hyderabad's fightback was all to no avail.

Hyberabad 117 & 244 for 3 (Devisetty Vinay Kumar 67)
Punjab 363 for 8 decl
Drawn

Shalabh Sriwastava of Uttar Pradesh took 6-82 to send Haryana tumbling to 198. Only Jasvir Singh, with 94, made any headway. But play began only after lunch on the third day, and when fog also held up proceedings on the fourth, a draw was inevitable. Uttar Pradesh had time to crawl to 93 for 5.

Haryana 198
Uttar Pradesh 93 for 5
Drawn

South Africa

Two weeks after steering his side to victory in the final of the first-class Super Sport Series, Gauteng bowler Andrew Hall was at it again in the one-day Standard Bank Cup. Promoted to open the innings, Hall smashed an unbeaten 129 runs from 136 balls, before taking 3-52, as Gauteng squeezed out Border by three runs. Set 254 to win, Border's opening pair put on 103 for the first wicket before captain Peterus Botha was clean bowled for 51. But wickets fell regularly after that, with three batsmen falling to run outs.

Gauteng 253 for 5 in 45 overs
Border 250 for 9 in 44 overs
Gauteng won by 3 runs

West Indies

The Leeward Islands won the first semi-final of the Busta Cup, against Barbados at Bridgetown, by virtue of their first-innings lead in a drawn game. Curtly Ambrose took 5-39, his second five-wicket haul of the tournament, to send Barbados crashing to a first-innings total of 148. fields.headline: Rechts-belehrung für Österreich
fields.standfirst: Nicole Prestle asks young Austrians what their government's move to the far right means for the country
fields.trailText: Secondary German
fields.body:
Der israelische Botschafter hat Österreich verlassen, noch bevor die neue Regierung vereidigt war. Ausländische Firmen haben Investitionen in Österreich storniert. Ihr Gesamtwert: rund 430 Millionen Mark. Die Europäische Union (EU) hat der Alpenrepublik mit der diplomatischen Isolierung gedroht. Innerhalb weniger Tage ist das kleine Land in den Mittelpunkt der politischen Diskussion geraten.

Der Mann, der all die Aufregung auslöst, kann sie selbst gar nicht so recht verstehen: Jörg Haider, Chef der Freiheitlichen Partei (FPÖ), bezeichnet sich als einen "begeisterten Österreicher", der sein Land eingebettet sehen will in ein "Europa der Vaterländer". Obwohl er in Interviews immer wieder betont, daß er sich auch zutraut, Österreich als Kanzler zu führen, wirder vorerst Landeshauptmann in Kärnten bleiben. Kanzler wird sein Koalitionspartner Wolfgang Schüssel von der konservativen Volkspartei (ÖVP).

Viele Österreicher befürchten, ihr Land könnte - geleitet durch die neue Regierung - nach rechts abdriften. Vorsichtig wird das Programm der Koalition nach ausländerfeindlichen Spitzen durchforstet. In Wien und anderen Städten demonstrierten Bürger gegen Haider und Schüssel. Doch eine andere Regierung war wochenlang vergeblich gesucht worden, der Zusammenschluss von ÖVP und FPÖ blieb als einzige Möglichkeit einer stabilen Koalition. Was halten junge Österreicher vom Wechsel an der politischen Spitze?

Wir haben uns bei Jugendlichen erkundigt.

Was ist Deine Meinung zur Regierungskoalition aus FPÖ und ÖVP?

Florian (18): Diese Koalition ist so ziemlich das Rechteste, was es geben kann. Und da ich eher weniger konservativ bin, hätte mir eine andere Regierung besser gefallen. Irgendwie ist für mich auch jetzt schon klar, daß Haider nach Schüssel Kanzler werden wird.

Christian (16): Mein Fall ist diese Regierung nicht. Schüssel ist mir absolut unsympathisch und Haider mag ich auch nicht. Seine Anhänger hat er doch nur, weil er jetzt international im Kreuzfeuer steht und einige es toll finden, wie er sich behauptet.

Clemens (21): Ich war nie ein Haider-Fan, und ich werde es auch nie werden. Ich bin auch gegen die FPÖ, zumindest so, wie sie jetzt geführt wird. Es trifft zwar nicht auf alle zu, aber einige Parteimitglieder sind eben rechtspopulistisch. Das Traurige ist nur, daß es ohne die FPÖ keine stabile Regierung geben kann. Somit wären auch Neuwahlen keine Lösung, denn dann würde Haider vielleicht noch mehr Stimmen bekommen und am Ende sogar Kanzler werden.

Glaubst Du, diese Koalition kann Österreich weiterbringen?

Stefan (18): Die Regierung wird sich wohl in erster Linie dem Ausländerproblem widmen. Aber ich finde, es gibt wichtigere Dinge. Ich lebe in einem kleinen Dorf, da fällt es gar nicht auf, ob es Ausländer gibt oder nicht.

Florian: Es wird sicherlich Veränderungen geben, das hat das Volk ja auch gewollt. Die FPÖ ist derzeit auch etwas gemäßigter in ihren äußerungen. Sie will der breiten Masse gefallen. Ich kann allerdings noch nicht einschätzen, wie die Arbeit sich auswirken wird.

Christian: Wenn Haider alle Ausländer vertreibt, wirft er das Land eher zurück. Man muß aber erstmal abwarten, ob er sein Programm überhaupt durchsetzen kann. Wenn er wirklich darauf drängt, werden sich über kurz oder lang wohl auch einige ausländische Firmen aus Österreich zurückziehen.

Clemens: Ich lebe in einem Skigebiet und befürchte, daß Parolen gegen Ausländer auch Gäste vergraulen werden. Es könnte auch passieren, daß ausländische Unternehmen nicht mehr in Österreich, sondern an anderen Standorten investieren. Ich glaube aber auch, daß FPÖ und ÖVP einige gute Ziele verfolgen.

Die EU droht Österreich mit Sanktionen, der israelische Botschafter ist aus Wien abgereist. Hältst Du solche Reaktionen für übertrieben oder sind sie gerechtfertigt?

Clemens: Die Bevölkerung kann, glaube ich, ganz froh sein, daß es von außen Einmischungen gibt. Somit wird verhindert, daß wie in den 30er Jahren die Falschen an die Macht kommen. Wenn die EU Österreich ins Abseits stellt, fördert das allerdings auch die Popularität Haiders.

Florian: Das Volk hat diese Regierung gewählt. Jetzt setzt die Europäische Union uns unter Druck, obwohl die Entscheidung demokratisch gefallen ist. Klar, Haiders äußerungen in Richtung Frankreich waren für einen Staatsmann nicht angemessen. Trotzdem sollte die EU die Entscheidung der Österreicher akzeptieren.

Stefan: Haider hat zwar eine große Klappe, aber ob was dahinter steckt, ist doch fraglich. Österreich nimmt viel mehr Ausländer auf als andere EU-Länder. Aber jetzt hacken alle gleich auf unserem Land herum. Die rot-schwarze Regierung hat auch nicht alles richtig gemacht. Ich denke, man muß jetzt erstmal abwarten.

abdriften to drift off
durchforsten to search for
einbetten to imbed
sich einrenken to be sorted out
gemäßigt moderate
herumhacken to criticise
eine große Klappe haben (coll) to show off
das Kreuzfeuer crossfire
stornieren to cancel
vereidigen to swear in
jmd etwas zutrauen to trust someone to do something

fields.headline: Österreich hat gewählt
fields.trailText: Beginners' German
fields.body:
Österreich hat gewählt. Die Wahlen liegen Monate zurück. Doch erst jetzt gibt es eine neue Regierung. Es war nicht einfach, sie zu finden. Und schon gibt es Probleme mit der neuen Regierung.

Nun demonstrieren die Bürger gegen "ihre" Koalition. Der Grund: Viele fürchten sich vor der Macht der Freiheitlichen Partei Österreichs (FPÖ). Ihr Chef, Jörg Haider, fäll zu oft auf. Seine rechtspopulistischen Äußerungen rufen Argwohn hervor. Nicht nur in Österreich, sondern auch im Ausland.

Die Europäische Union will die diplomatischen Beziehungen zu Österreich abbrechen. Israels Botschafter ist aus dem Land abgereist. Die Österreicher gehen gegen die Koalition auf die Straße. Doch Haider und sein Partner Wolfgang Schüssel (ÖVP) arbeiten an ihrem Programm. Unbeirrt versuchen sie, ihr Land voranzubringen. Viele Leute sind skeptisch, ob dies gelingen wird. Sie befürchten, daß Haider die ausländischen Investoren vertreiben wird. Andere geben der neuen Regierung eine Chance. Ihre Devise ist: abwarten.

Österreich hat gewählt. Wie die neue Regierung arbeitet, wird sich zeigen, wenn sich die ersten Wogen glätten.

der Botschafter ambassador

er fällt auf, auffallen to attract attention

etwas fürchten to fear sth.

rechtspopulistisch rightwing

unbeirrt unfazed

webTitle: Chinese struggle to contain migrant stampede

fields.headline: Chinese struggle to contain migrant stampede
fields.trailText: Desperate job-seeking peasants have overwhelmed the Chinese railway system after the new year holiday, with up to 4m on the move in a single day. Many migrants have been hurrying back to work out of fear that they will lose their jobs if they stay away too long, and thousands of others have set out looking for work.
fields.body:
Desperate job-seeking peasants have overwhelmed the Chinese railway system after the new year holiday, with up to 4m on the move in a single day. Many migrants have been hurrying back to work out of fear that they will lose their jobs if they stay away too long, and thousands of others have set out looking for work.

Soldiers are being posted in railway waiting-rooms and booking halls at junctions in central China to keep order among those heading south.

"We expected 10,000 daily," explains Ms Cao, a spokesperson at Hengyang station in Hunan province, "Instead we have an average of 50-60,000. Many of them can't get tickets and clog up the station."

The migrant return to work is usually spaced out over two weeks following the "Spring Festival", which this year fell on February 5. But this year an economic downturn has made many fearful for their jobs.

In the week after the new year, more than 100,000 migrant workers arrived daily in the southern city of Guangzhou. The numbers peaked on Saturday, when 260,000 returned within 24 hours. Across China, an estimated 4m were travelling back to work on Saturday - higher than the peak daily figure of 3.4m going home before the holiday.

Authorities in Guangdong province have asked employers not to hire new workers this month to try to stem the flood. But its reputation as China's richest region means that millions of peasants will head there anyhow.

Train tickets are sold a day or two in advance to minimise congestion. But many migrants camp out in the station as soon as they have a ticket, fearing that they will be unable to board the train.

A train to Guangzhou from the central province of Anhui was held to ransom last week, when hoodlums forcibly collected "boarding fees" from migrants trying to board it.

fields.headline: The best poetry scene
fields.standfirst: A Room for Romeo Brass
fields.trailText: Nottingham. Having taken the object of his affections, Ladene (Vicky McClure), out for the evening, Morell (Paddy Considine) brings her back to her house.
fields.body:
Nottingham. Having taken the object of his affections, Ladene (Vicky McClure), out for the evening, Morell (Paddy Considine) brings her back to her house.

"Been a nice night, hasn't it?"

"Mmm, I've enjoyed it."

"Been lovely really, hasn't it?"

Ladene moves towards her front door.

"Look, I'd better get in 'cause of work and that_"

"Will you kiss me, please?"

"It's a first date and you're asking me to kiss you?"

"I know it's a bit forward and that, but I'd just like to kiss you. If you say no, just let me say this to you."

His face grows serious as he starts to recite.

"One beat, two beat, three beat, sugar beat. Four beat, five beat, six beat, weet-a-beet. Seven beat, eight beat, nine beat, heart beat. My heart beat . My heart is beating... for you."

He smiles triumphantly.

"Nice, isn't it?"

Ladene's jaw hangs open.

"Will you kiss me now, please?"

"I've really got to get in."

"I'm not going to bite you, am I?"

"I know you're not."

Gingerly, she leans forward and kisses him. From the window above, Romeo (Andrew Shim) and Knocks (Ben Marshall) let out a chorus of jeers.

"Go on Morrell!"

"He can't even stand up straight!"

Ladene runs back inside the house; Morell flicks two fingers up at the kids and retreats to his Mini.

See also: Dead Poets Society, Peggy Sue Got Married

Don't see also: Total Eclipse

fields.headline: Edgar Bowers
fields.standfirst: American poet exploring the mysteries of life with an aesthetic and sensitive intellect
fields.trailText: The distinguished American poet, Edgar Bowers, has died in San Francisco at the age of 75. The title poem of his 1990 collection, For Louis Pasteur, announces his key loyalties. He confessed to celebrating every year the birthdays of three heroes: Pasteur, Mozart and Paul Valéry, all of whom suggest admiration for the life of the mind lived at its highest pitch - a concern for science and its social uses, and a love of art that is elegant, cerebral and orderly.
fields.body:
The distinguished American poet, Edgar Bowers, has died in San Francisco at the age of 75. The title poem of his 1990 collection, For Louis Pasteur, announces his key loyalties. He confessed to celebrating every year the birthdays of three heroes: Pasteur, Mozart and Paul Valéry, all of whom suggest admiration for the life of the mind lived at its highest pitch - a concern for science and its social uses, and a love of art that is elegant, cerebral and orderly.

Though he was essentially a rationalist, Bowers's poems are marked by extreme aesthetic refinement and an intense feeling for the mystery of things. His teacher and friend Yvor Winters described him as having "the temperament of a mystical Calvinist" though with "too good a mind to accept the Calvinist faith or any other". He was, indeed, brought up as a Presbyterian.

Bowers experienced a brief period of prominence in the early 1960s. In Britain, for instance, he was anthologised both by Donald Hall and by Thom Gunn and Ted Hughes, but today, even among committed readers of poetry, his name is little known.

Yet the list of his admirers is impressive, including Robert Lowell, Richard Wilbur, Geoffrey Hill, Tony Tanner and Harold Bloom, who placed him in his tally of modern immortals in the western canon. Winters thought the poems in his early books "among the best American poems" of the 20th century. He was the recipient of several important prizes and fellowships, including the prestigious Bollingen prize.

Born in Rome, Georgia, Bowers matriculated at the University of North Carolina in 1942, but was called up for military service the following year. In 1945, at 21, he travelled across the ruins of Europe to be stationed for a year in Hitler's retreat at Berchtesgaden, where he was active in the de-Nazification campaign. The impact of these sights and experiences on a sensitive and ethical consciousness can be felt throughout his Collected Poems (1997).

At the end of the war, Bowers returned to his studies, then in 1947, drawn by the reputation of Yvor Winters, departed for California. He studied under Winters at Stanford University, attended its celebrated writing programme and completed his doctorate on the poems of Yeats's friend and contemporary, T Sturge Moore. A conventional academic career followed: jobs at Duke University, Harpur College and the University of California at Santa Barbara, from 1958 to 1991.

Bowers was an effective and sometimes charismatic teacher, but he was never wholly at home in an English faculty. He fought against political compromises (over Vietnam, for instance) and the exploitation of young, untenured teachers. He sometimes suffered from sneering suggestions about his homosexuality, and, despite being the most radical and egalitarian of men, stood accused of elitism.

His poetry falls into roughly two periods. The Form Of Loss (1956) and The Astronomers (1965) consist mainly of poems in immaculately constructed, rhymed stanzas, in which the influence of Valéry, and perhaps of Wallace Stevens, is noticeable. The mood is tragic. Among his masterpieces is The Astronomers Of Mont Blanc, in which his protagonists gaze from their "icy tower" into "the colder distances":

It is your hope that you will

know the end

And compass of our

ignorant restraint

There in lost time, where

what was done is done

Forever as a havoc

overhead.

Aging, you search to master

in the faint

Persistent fortune that you

gaze upon

The perfect order trusted to

the dead.

The sombre dignity of this - with its language slightly removed from everyday usage - has been characterised by the critic Gordon Harvey as "newness of sense, antiquity of voice".

In his second phase, Bowers's manner is less antique. From 1965 to the mid-1980s he wrote little, perhaps inhibited by bouts of depression and alcoholism. When the clouds lifted, however, he entered his most sustained creative phase.

For Louis Pasteur, and most of the new pieces in his Collected Poems, are more relaxed in manner. Almost all are in a supple and subtly musical blank verse. This is a medium mostly associated with longer works of narrative or description, but these are short meditations, hospitable to casual observation, bits of quirky humour and conversational phrases. They are sometimes allusive and appear discontinuous. But closer reading reveals the same Jamesian feeling for elaborations of syntax, and an underlying thread of rational argument. The emphasis is more social than personal, in particular a concern for the fragmentation and casual nihilism of post-modern society.

But Bowers was not a pessimist by nature. To British friends, he exemplified a pattern of American openness and practicality. He retained a hint of his old accent, and a certain southern courtliness of manner. But time had made him a Californian too, and this showed in his casual friendliness and a willingness to experiment.

When he moved to Santa Barbara, Bowers had the good fortune to buy a small, traditional wood-frame house in the wealthy suburb of Montecito. Its raised verandah reached out over the beach and provided a magnificent view of the ocean, with a glimpse of dolphins or surfers to inspire him. In his last two decades, he travelled a good deal, often with his much-loved nonagenarian mother. When she died in the early 1990s, he moved north to San Fransisco, where he benefited from the love and support of an openly gay community.

webTitle: Opposition maintains lead in Zimbabwe referendum

fields.headline: Opposition maintains lead in Zimbabwe referendum
fields.standfirst: Fears of vote tampering cloud poll
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe appeared to be heading for defeat in Zimbabwe's constitutional referendum, in what would be the biggest electoral rebuff for the country's president after two decades of virtually unchallenged rule.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe appeared to be heading for defeat in Zimbabwe's constitutional referendum, in what would be the biggest electoral rebuff for the country's president after two decades of virtually unchallenged rule.

With three-quarters of the votes counted, the state's Elections Directorate said 56.5% were opposed to the constitutional changes, which would allow Mr Mugabe to stay in power for another 12 years and permit his government to seize land owned by white settlers without paying compensation.

Opposition leaders claimed victory: "We are heading for a win unless they manipulated the vote from the rural areas in a big way," said Lovemeore Madhuku, deputy chairman of the National Constitutional Assembly, a coalition of civic and opposition groups that campaigned against the new constitution.

Independent monitors provided by civic groups and churches have said they could reach only about two-thirds of voting stations because the Elections Directorate only announced each voting location on Friday, raising fears of electoral irregularities.

Over the weekend, police arrested a top opposition leader and eight supporters in the western Harare township of Highfields for alleged illegal campaigning and incitement to violence. The group are still being held in police cells and are expected to appear in court today.

The vote is an indication of Mr Mugabe's waning popularity as Zimbabwe faces its worst economic crisis since independence from British colonial rule in 1980.

The Zimbabwe leader's party could now face another defeat in parliamentary elections to be held in early April. It has won landslide victories in every poll since independence and currently holds all but three seats in the 150-member parliament.

"No" votes dominated 49 districts, many of them in towns, in results declared after overnight counting, chief elections officer Tobaiwa Mudede reported.

In 89 of the nation's 120 voting districts, opponents of the new constitution posted 532,800 ballots. Supporters of Mr Mugabe polled 409,380 votes and took the majority in 40 mostly rural areas.

Mr Mugabe's largest defeat came in central Harare, where 16,882 voters rejected adoption of the new constitution and 4,821 favoured it.

Analysts expect the "yes" campaign to claw back some ground in rural areas where the ruling ZANU-PF party commands a large following.

During polling on Saturday, lines for scarce kerosene, used by the poor for cooking, lighting and heating, were longer than those at polling booths. Shortages of gasoline and power blamed on economic mismanagement by the government have crippled transport, agriculture and industry in recent months. Inflation and unemployment have soared to record levels.

webTitle: How a BT FutureTalk award could change your school

fields.headline: How a BT FutureTalk award could change your school
fields.trailText: The BT Schools Awards Programme - supported by the Guardian - was launched online in January 2000 and will run for two years.
fields.body:
The BT Schools Awards Programme - supported by the Guardian - was launched online in January 2000 and will run for two years.

The BT Education website contains everything schools will need to know if they want to be considered for the scheme. It provides details of how to apply, a database of schools keen to work with other schools, examples of projects and opportunities to discuss ideas with other teachers and experts.

Schools are encouraged to form a consortium with a number of other schools across the UK. Together they need to submit a working project idea that uses ICT to support curriculum projects.

If a project is successfully chosen by the BT Schools Awards Programme, the schools are granted awards of £5,000 or £25,000 with which to run the project.

A total of £300,000 in prizes will be distributed across the nation each academic year, for two years. Each term up to two £25,000 and five £5,000 awards are available.

The awards are open to pupils up to the age of 16.

In order to apply, schools need to go to the website and read about the awards programme and the rules governing the programme and any entries.

They are then encouraged to register their interest in the programme through an online form. School details are then input into the database and other schools from around the country can contact them with project ideas.

By going to the 'how to apply' section, schools can find out who is eligible and read examples of projects that fit the criteria of the BT Schools Awards. These past winners are intended as stimuli for ideas and to encourage the creation of new ideas.

Once schools have decided on a project to submit, they can go to the application section and complete the online application form.

The awards programme comes at a time when schools are increasingly attempting to provide children with sophisticated computer skills that will carry them into the future. Comments Estelle Morris, education minister: "ICT is playing an increasingly important role in education and the world of work. BT has to be congratulated on the enterprise it has shown in sponsoring the Schools Awards initiative and in making such an imaginative contribution to helping prepare children for the challenges of tomorrow."

Richard Hamer, BT programme manager, says: "Through the BT Schools Awards programme, we aim to assist schools in improving students' communication skills through greater working knowledge of ICT. The online awards programme opens up opportunities for UK schools to share their teaching skills across counties, and broaden the scope of current school projects.

"We are delighted to be able to assist a number of schools every term throughout 2000 and 2001 and look forward to seeing the successful outcomes of each project."

fields.headline: 'End bunker mentality', Hague warned
fields.trailText: Tory leader William Hague is today warned that his party faces certain electoral defeat unless it reverses a shift to the right and promotes mainstream one-nation policies.
fields.body:
Tory leader William Hague is today warned that his party faces certain electoral defeat unless it reverses a shift to the right and promotes mainstream one-nation policies.

In a damaging intervention which will overshadow Mr Hague's launch today of his Save the Pound tour of Britain, former frontbencher John Maples paints a picture of the Conservative leader holed up in his "bunker" at central office, surrounded by inexperienced junior officials but "almost completely cut off" from his own shadow cabinet.

Mr Maples, sacked by Mr Hague as shadow foreign secretary in a reshuffle two weeks ago, warns of the "danger" that rightwingers are now shadowing most government departments, while moderates are in lower profile backroom jobs.

And he reveals that, despite "several attempts", he never managed to have a serious discussion of foreign policy with his party leader, nor to convince him that Jeffrey Archer would "get us into trouble" as mayoral candidate.

The critique, though presented as comradely advice from a colleague now "outside the bunker", amounts to one of the most outspoken assaults on Mr Hague's political judgment and leadership ability during his career as leader.

Though the party leadership is certain to play down the remarks, contained in an open letter to Mr Hague in the Times, as the revenge of an embittered former front bencher, the criticism will be seen as reflecting unease among other moderates in the Conservative party.

Some may feel the intervention - including a warning not to be seen as too anti-European - is particularly timely as Mr Hague today appears to pull his party towards a still tougher line on Europe, publishing five reasons to oppose the euro which indicate that the party will never join the single currency under his leadership.

While Mr Maples did not shine in his foreign affairs brief, he is regarded as a grounded "voice of reason" in his party. His warning that Mr Hague has dragged his party too far to the right echoes similar claims made over Christmas by former prime minister John Major and Kenneth Clarke, and privately dismissed by senior party figures as the grumblings of yesterday's men.

Mr Maples urges his party leader to "use" his shadow cainbet more. He writes: "You have got some very 0bright people with real experience of government and policy both inside it and outside. Kids do not know everything and grey hairs have their part to play."

Highlighting what he calls "significant weaknesses" in the Conservative central office "war room" operation, he warns: "You have surrounded yourself with a private office which is almost completely cut off from the shadow cabinet and the parliamentary party. You have got the loyalty and commitment of your staff, but none of them has ac tually been a minister or responsible for policy."

While the shadow cabinet has been "extraordinarily well behaved", some central office staff have "constantly" briefed the press against frontbenchers, he adds.

On policy, Mr Maples endorses the party's Save the Pound message, but warns against any further talk of renegotiation of the European Union treaty rather than simply flexibility.

"Our policies and our tone must be mainstream and speak to the whole nation," he writes, stressing: "We cannot win the election through private health insurance and being tough on asylum seekers".

Mr Hague, meanwhile, is still pinning his hopes on public opposition to the euro as a key plank of his election strategy. Launching the Tories' Save the Pound campaign at St Albans in Hertfordshire on his much-hyped customised truck, Mr Hague will issue reasons for keeping sterling in cluding higher taxes; a European superstate and a single European interest rate "which will nearly always be wrong for us".

The pro-European pressure group Britain in Europe, which will hand out its own leaflets at today's rally, described the Tory leader's tour as a "secondhand idea which fell of the back of a lorry".

Simon Buckby, the group's director, said: "The van will embarrass the anti-Europeans and amuse the public wher ever it goes."

The Conservatives' failure to be seen as a credible alternative to Labour is all the greater when the results of the Guardian ICM monthly "euro" referendum question are studied. It shows the gap between those who would vote against joining the euro and those prepared to vote for entry has grown to a record 39 points. Sixty-three per cent now oppose entry compared with 24% in favour and 12% don't knows.
