webTitle: Hague close to rejecting any euro deal

fields.headline: Hague close to rejecting any euro deal
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague will today toughen up the Tories' opposition to the single currency when he outlines five reasons to oppose the euro which make clear that the party will never join the currency under his leadership.
fields.body:
William Hague will today toughen up the Tories' opposition to the single currency when he outlines five reasons to oppose the euro which make clear that the party will never join the currency under his leadership.

Mr Hague will be joined at the launch of the Tories' Keep the Pound campaign at St Albans in Hertfordshire on his long-awaited truck by Michael Portillo, the newly appointed shadow chancellor.

His presence will fuel speculation that Mr Hague has been forced to toughen up his opposition to the euro by Mr Portillo, who has already ditched two key Tory economic policies since his appointment.

Leaflets which will be distributed at the rally make clear that Mr Hague is coming close to abandoning his official European policy which is to rule out membership of the euro for the lifetime of this parliament and the next.

Mr Hague's five reasons to preserve the pound - echoing the government's five economic tests before Britain joins the euro - are so hardline that they virtually rule out membership of the euro whatever the economic conditions.

The Tory reasons for keeping the pound warn of:

 One interest rate across Europe which "will nearly always be wrong for us";

 A European superstate which is opposed by the British people;

 Higher taxes - rising by a sixth - as Brussels sets tax rates;

 A threat to the success of the British economy which, as the fifth largest in the world, has no reason to scrap its currency;

 A multi-billion bill for businesses to prepare for the euro.

Mr Hague will reinforce his message in a 20-minute speech at today's rally in the centre of St Albans. Standing on a stage on the side of his "Keep the Pound" Leyland Daf truck, the Tory leader will declare that his campaign is a "battle for the soul of Britain".

Mr Hague's new message is likely to alarm pro-European Tories at Westminster who reluctantly accepted his decision to rule out membership of the euro for the next parliament on the understanding that he would change the policy.

The pro-European pressure group Britain in Europe, which will hand out its own leaflets at today's rally, last night described the Tory leader's tour as a "secondhand idea which fell of the back of a lorry". Simon Buckby, Britain in Europe's director, said: "The van will embarrass the anti-Europeans and amuse the public wherever it goes."

webTitle: Universities forge alliance for global teaching on net

fields.headline: Universities forge alliance for global teaching on net
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Four leading universities will today announce plans to form a global alliance with four American counterparts as the first step towards the creation of "e-universities".
fields.body:
Four leading universities will today announce plans to form a global alliance with four American counterparts as the first step towards the creation of "e-universities".

The multi-million pound deal comes on the day that the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, sets out his vision for higher education in a speech emphasising the need for such alliances if Britain's universities and colleges are to thrive in the competitive global economy.

The four universities - Leeds, Sheffield, Southampton and York - are linking up with four research-led American institutions - the university of California at San Diego, Pennsylvania state university, the university of Washington and the university of Wisconsin-Madison.

They will share research and teaching facilities, and use new technology to allow students to take part in long-distance learning and teaching across the Atlantic.

Students are likely to be able to tap into the sister universities' research bases and libraries, and will be able to communicate regularly with their academic staff.

The partners have agreed to collaborate initially on research and postgraduate degree programmes, so students can benefit from a wider choice of subjects by tapping into the the expertise of the partner universities.

The group, with a working title of Worldwide Universities Network, will invite other universities from around the world to help to establish an even larger network. The deal follows an £85m link-up between Cambridge university and the Massachusetts institute of technology in Boston.

In a speech at the university of Greenwich in south-east London this morning, Mr Blunkett will spell out the importance of globalisation. Writing in today's Guardian Education, Mr Blunkett says: "Higher education can use global alliances to secure new forms of diversity with excellence for an expanded student population. No institution can offer real excellence in teaching or research across the full range of disciplines - the resources on the required scale are not there."

In his speech this morning, he will invite bids for the world's first e-university, which could award online degrees from prestigious universities through the internet, attracting students from overseas. The higher education funding council will co-ordinate bids from consortiums of universities and companies.

Sir Gareth Roberts, vice-chancellor of the university of Sheffield, said of the link-up: "This alliance has potentially far-reaching consequences for the delivery of higher education in the emerging global market."

A spokesman for Cambridge university said: "There will be far more global partnerships between universities in the future. Cambridge is seriously looking at ways of extending the potential of teaching and learning using the internet, and its new initiative with MIT will be pioneering ways of electronic teaching and research collaborations as one of its priorities. It will be particularly useful for mature students who are not able to come to Cambridge for professional or family reasons."

The participating universities do not imagine that life as an e-student will be a solitary, screen-based experience without any classroom teaching. A spokeswoman for the Association of University Teachers said: "The communal experience open to the full-time student is itself a way of learning about the world and life."

Andrew Pakes, president of the National Union of Students, said: "My worry about it is whether the government wants to use it to bump up numbers in colleges, while cutting costs. On the other hand a 9.15am virtual lecture might be a good thing for students who have difficulty getting out of bed."

webTitle: Public backing for schools sex education compromise

fields.headline: Public backing for schools sex education compromise
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: There is overwhelming public backing for the idea that teachers should promote marriage as part of sex education classes in schools, according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.
fields.body:
There is overwhelming public backing for the idea that teachers should promote marriage as part of sex education classes in schools, according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.

But there is also strong public support that schools should at the same time teach children that it is wrong to be abusive towards gay and lesbian people.

The response indicates that there is heavy public backing for the two elements in the compromise on the section 28 gay rights row which the cabinet is close to agreeing to avert a showdown with the House of Lords.

More than two-thirds of voters support the compromise, which has been put forward by the Bishop of Blackburn, and is being canvassed within the cabinet as a way of overcoming the opposition of the Lords to the repeal of section 28 which bans the promotion of homosexuality in schools. The poll shows that 74% of voters agree that sex education in schools should ensure that children are not verbally or physically abusive to gay and lesbian people. Only 18% disagree. Some 70% agree that sex education in schools should promote marriage as a concept. Only 23% disagree. The poll results for both questions show little difference across age groups or social class although Labour voters (66%) are less enthusiastic than Conservative voters (76%) that schools should promote the concept of marriage.

But if the public believe peers are wrong to mount a last ditch defence of section 28 the House of Lords does have strong public backing for its fight with the government over Jack Straw's plans to abolish the right of defendants to choose jury trial.

Fifty-seven per cent say that defendants charged with crimes such as theft and bur glary should keep the right to elect to jury trial and only 35% back the home secretary's plan. The strength of public opposition to the plan will surprise ministers who are trying to decide when the best time would be to force the plan through the House of Commons. There is an equal amount of hostility to the measure among Labour voters as in the general public.

February's Guardian/ICM opinion poll shows that Labour's lead dropped last month to 15%. Political turbulence over the section 28 gay controversy, the Welsh devolution debacle and the Afghan hijack asylum row have contributed to a further three point fall in Labour's poll position. Labour is at 44% (-3). The Conservatives, despite the return of Michael Portillo to the shadow cabinet, have failed to benefit from Labour woes and are at 29% (-1) still below their general election performance in May 1997. The Liberal Democrats are on 18% (up 1) and other parties are on 9% (up 3).

The failure of the Conservatives to be seen as a credible alternative to Labour is all the greater when the results of the ICM monthly "euro" referendum question are studied. It shows that the gap between those who would vote against joining the euro and those prepared to vote for entry has grown to a record 39 points. Sixty-three per cent now oppose entry compared with 24% in favour and 12% don't knows. With the balance of public opinion so strongly backing any campaign to "save the pound" the only wonder about William Hague's planned tour of Britain starting this week is that he didn't hit the road sooner.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,205 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between February 11-13 2000. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Morning Ma'am, I have a  problem

fields.headline: Morning Ma'am, I have a  problem
fields.standfirst: If students or staff at an 'old' university find  their complaints are not dealt with  satisfactorily, they can always resort to the  Visitor - an often archaic, ponderous and  under-funded institution in need of reform
fields.trailText: If students or staff at an 'old' university find their complaints are not dealt with satisfactorily, they can always resort to the Visitor - an often archaic, ponderous and under-funded institution in need of reform
fields.body:
You are a student or staff member at an "old" university whose complaint has been allowed to drag on unresolved and you want to appeal to the Visitor. You may regard this with some awe, since the Visitor is likely to be the Queen. What will actually happen?

It is a bit of a lottery. In some of the chartered universities a petition to the Visitor is dealt with by the Clerk to the Privy Council in consultation with a politician, at present Margaret Beckett. No legally qualified person is involved and there is no provision for legal costs to be covered to enable the Privy Council to take advice.

In others the petition goes to the Lord Chancellor's Department, which is not short of real lawyers but has other problems. The head of its civil law development division admits that "for almost all of the 1997 calendar year" no single officer was responsible for dealing with Visitorial petitions.

No formal framework for handling petitions exists, so petitioners get no advice on how to set out their cases and no information about the grounds they can cite. Neil McDougall, a former postgraduate at Bath University, was sent an apologetic admission of "the department's failure" to provide guidance on procedures and time-tables. It also acknowledged that "those presenting Visitorial petitions should be given a clear indication of procedures to be followed".

The Queen, in her two contrasting guises, is not the only Visitor in the system. A Visitor may be a bishop, an archbishop, or anyone at all by election, such as Mary Warnock, Visitor to Royal Holloway College. Someone may even be "called" a Visitor but is not really a Visitor in law, like Mary Archer at Hertfordshire University. It's hopelessly confusing for the student or staff member with a problem, for whom a clear sense of who to go to, about what, is essential.

The amateurs cannot guarantee expertise. Viscount de l'Isle, Visitor of Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, was required by the courts to deal with an issue for which he realised he lacked the legal knowledge. The bishops of Winchester and Durham report some difficulty in knowing how to proceed in Visitorial appeals at universities or colleges.

Harris Manchester College, Oxford, newly incorporated as a college of the university, appointed Sir Tony Wrigley as its Visitor. After a first foray into visiting, he is now being replaced.

The expense of using real lawyers can be prohibitive unless they are prepared to give their time for the public good. Sheila Cameron, QC, the Chancellor of the Province of Canterbury, acts for the Archbishop of Canterbury as Visitor. But there is no provision for the Archbishop or the Church of England to pay for her services on behalf of the Visitor, or those of the solicitor who is registrar of the Province.

At a recent seminar attended by Visitors and their representatives there was an air of surprise as the delegates compared notes for the first time in history. Visitors who were not aware of one another's procedure or practice have been making it up as they go along.

It emerged that there is a lack of consistency in the practice of different Visitors. If even the Lord Chancellor's Department has no system it is perhaps not remarkable that other Visitors are still more at sea. For example, the Lord Chancellor's Office rarely holds hearings. Sheila Cameron QC, acting for the Archbishop of Canterbury, usually does hold a hearing. The Privy Council Office does not. There is no requirement to give reasons but they are routinely given by Sheila Cameron and, for a year now, also by the Lord Chancellor's office on behalf of the Queen, to avoid the risk of an application for judicial review.

There is a clear need for procedural guidelines, avoiding rigidity but embodying good practice in conformity with the new human rights legislation.

It can be unclear who the Visitor is working for. The Bishop of Winchester said he thought the rights of the individual ought to be uppermost. Some Visitors believe they have a duty to act in the interests of the institution. That leads awkwardly to the question of independence.

The system is not only discredited but increasingly overloaded. The proposal to set up an independent panel of senior, experienced individuals was made by the Council for Academic Freedom and Academic Standards to the Nolan Committee, and found its way into its Second Report. The Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals has toyed with the notion for several years. It is time to come back to it. It would be in the spirit of the moves by the Lord Chancellor's Department to encourage Alternative Dispute Resolution.

A fresh, independent, senior eye to look at the problem is what is needed. It should be someone who can apply common sense and a knowledge of the core principles of fairness to what has happened, someone invested with powers to call for papers, evidence and a written or oral response from those involved in the dispute. They could achieve a great deal.

There should be an expectation that the university will accept the recommendations of the resulting report unless it can show good reason why it should not. It is worth a try.

 Gillian Evans is public policy secretary at the Council for Academic Freedom and Academic Standards.

fields.headline: The new citizens
fields.standfirst: Your children will soon be studying citizenship at school because David Blunkett is passionate about the idea. But what exactly will they be taught, and how?
fields.trailText: Your children will soon be studying citizenship at school because David Blunkett is passionate about the idea. But what exactly will they be taught, and how?
fields.body:
Hands stop rattling pencil cases and the back chat dies to a murmur as flickering images of a Holocaust survivor, telling how nearly one million people were killed at Treblinka, illuminates a slightly worse-for-wear classroom TV. But when the off button is flicked, some of the gobbiness returns.

"That Hitler sounds dead dodgy," says Mark, 13, with a smirk. Marie and Amy affect overt lack of interest, while Becky remarks that "It all sounds a bit like a history lesson." Which is a fair enough observation when you're in a year 9 personal and social education lesson and you've just spent half an hour talking about the second world war.

If education, education, education was the mantra of the late 90s, then citizenship, citizenship, citizenship looks set to be the soundbite for the new millennium. Citizenship is Blunkett's baby. After the rosy glow of Labour's 1997 landslide turned a little pallid when a MORI poll revealed the lowest postwar electoral turnout, with a 43% abstention rate in the 18-24 age group, the Secretary of State turned to his old tutor, Bernard Crick, to dream up ways of reversing the tide of political indifference, illiteracy and cynicism. Crick hooked up with the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority and a few other interested schools and organisations to devise a gameplan, and late last year the National Curriculum for Citizenship was published.

When the orders to make citizenship a statutory subject in 2002 were passed by parliament last Wednesday, Blunkett was in effusive, optimistic spirits. "It is one of the most important steps in developing and understanding our democracy and encouraging active citizenship that has been introduced for a very long time," he said. "I hope this will engage young people in their community and in their understanding of the subject."

He went on to suggest that in those schools where citizenship was already being taught as part of personal and social education, attainment levels in other subjects had increased. One of the schools that Blunkett may have had in mind is Mill Chase Community School in Bordon, Hampshire, which he singled out as a shining example of best citizenship practice in a speech at the Institute of Education Citizenship Conference in July last year.

Mill Chase Community School is a strange hybrid - a rural school with urban problems. The area is top-heavy with single-parent families, travellers and the military, there's no railway station, bus links are poor, there's no pub or cinema and there's a tangible sense of frustration and neglect. The school has a higher than average number of free school dinners and an A-C GCSE pass rate of 40%.

Understandably the headteacher, Tony Philpott, isn't one for grandiose attainment statements; but he is more than happy to let me sit in on some citizenship lessons that he and PSE teacher Chris Waller were instrumental in introducing into the school in the early 1990s.

"Years 7, 8 and 9 get one hour of citizenship per week," says Waller, himself an adviser to the Crick report, "and years 10 and 11 get two. We felt it was a really important way of getting the children to understand that they do have a voice and that their opinions can make a difference." So Waller has incorporated issues such as democracy, bullying, community action, xenophobia, racism, refugees and human rights into the personal and social education syllabus.

Which is why year 9 are talking about the Holocaust. For some, the lesson is just an opportunity to switch off and chill out. Others struggle and fail to see the point. Ben sees it perfectly. "It's a bit like Kosovo, isn't it?" Leanne reckons it would be easier to get away with the Holocaust now because of nuclear weapons; Tanya reckons it would be harder because everyone could see what was going on. There's a similar range of ignorance and insight when the debate moves on to voting. John doesn't have a clue what you do, Nick reckons his mum and dad take a card to the newsagent, while Rebecca knows all about booths and ballot boxes.

"I'm introducing the children to some of the big questions," continues Waller, " and getting them to see there may not be any obvious answers." Questions without answers is a mind-blowing concept for most children; it is also a mind-blowing concept for most educationalists, who like to measure everything in marks out of 100. And predictably, citizenship has drawn fire from many traditionalists who see citizenship as a return to the woolly liberalism of much of the teaching in the 1970s.

Bizarrely, one of citizenship's fiercest critics turns out to be none other than that renowned 1970s reactionary, Ken Livingstone, who said on Radio 4's Question Time that "it would be the most bunked-off subject on the school timetable".

Even though its advocates swear blind that citizenship is about the practicalities of life, the only practicalities that many schools are interested in are GCSE results. And although Blunkett has said that citizenship teaching will be assessed - though there are no details at present - unless a last-minute rabbit is produced out of the hat, there are going to be no league table ranking points at stake. So some schools, struggling to cram the latest literacy and numeracy initiatives into an already overcrowded timetable, may well see citizenship as an edict too far.

Cynics suspect that some schools will subvert citizenship into extra history and politics lessons, and that for others it will be the graveyard shift for which teachers will need a machine gun to ensure attendance. It has even been suggested that some schools will fulfil their statutory hours by declaring one day a "citizenship day" in which everyone can run around like mad doing fantastically good works in the community for eight hours before reverting to their preferred, introverted, GCSE-obsessed state.

Chris Waller is perfectly well aware of the potential for disaster, not least over the question of assessment. "You can't have people failing citizenship," he says. "So the only way you can measure what someone knows is by talking to them. And that is extremely time-consuming".

Waller is clearly prepared to invest the effort; his inference is that others will not be so willing. Indeed, one can't help feeling that citizenship teaching as a whole will stand or fall on the amount of enthusiasm and effort that schools are prepared to make. Mill Chase School has worked hard to ensure that citizenship is not a bolted-on adjunct to other curricular activities.

"I want the staff and students to realise there is a structure and to see where they are all heading," says Waller. "So when they learn about the same issue in different classes, they don't just think this is daft and that the teachers don't talk to one another. The idea is to create a spiral of connected learning that feeds off itself. For instance, with human rights, the art and design teacher this year decided to do a project on freedom and captivity."

Mill Chase School is not alone in good practice. The Institute for Citizenship has been working with 13 schools from Derby, Halton, Leicester and London to develop ways of delivering citizenship and some London schools are actively engaged on a Mayor for London project. The Citizenship Foundation has been working on a Primary Citizenship Project, developing stories for key stages 1 and 2 that explore themes of friendship, laws and rules, respecting differences, property and power and community and environment. Save the Children has given Roundhay School in Leeds an award for its work in the area.

One doesn't want to knock this work, but there is a residual feeling of atavism. Of schools scrabbling around to find ways to incorporate citizenship into their curriculum, rather than a collective response to a central initiative. The finger inevitably points back to the Department for Education and Employment. The published national curriculum for citizenship looks very plush, but is actually rather vague. It is long on worthy statements about understanding rights and responsibilities and developing skills, but desperately short on how to implement them.

Nor can we expect much more practical information. The QCA has just published schemes of work for history, geography, design and technology, ICT and science, which include areas that may be linked to citizenship, but there are no schemes of work for citizenship per se. Nor, we are told, are there plans for any. In other words, everyone will continue to make it up as they go along.

As far as Mill Chase School is concerned, that means more of the same, with greater emphasis on advance planning so that every teacher knows what is going on elsewhere to deliver a holistic curriculum. It also means teaching by stealth; keeping the dreaded citizenship word, with its pious overtones, off the agenda. Part of Blunkett's vision is of a syllabus that includes voluntary work in the community, a concept that goes down like wet sick with many teenagers. The only trouble is that if you make voluntary work compulsory, then it's obviously not voluntary. I grab a group of year 11 pupils away from their PSE lesson on pressure groups and ask them about community work. "It's boring and babyish," they chorus in unison. "We did it at primary school but we wouldn't do it now."

"That's interesting," says Waller, a little later over a sandwich lunch, "because in the last few years they were all involved in work outside the school. Some went to talk to other schools, they have written letters to the high commissioner to Malawi about conditions in a prison, others have written to Tony Blair about world debt, and some conducted an all-night vigil for Human Rights Day. It's how you sell the projects that counts. If they feel it is a continuation of what they are doing in school, it makes sense to them and they are happy to go along with it. If you just say, 'do some voluntary service,' they won't bother."

Back in the year 11 PSE class, the work on pressure groups is scaled down from a general look at who holds what power to local interests. The skate park. Or the lack of it, to be precise. Waller suggests ways they could make a difference by getting involved with the local authority. He is met by faces of defeat. "It's just not worth it," says Dazza. "No one listens to us."

Teaching citizenship is an uphill struggle. It's not like other subjects, which rely on the imparting of knowledge. To be effective, citizenship has to change attitudes, which is a much tougher call. Waller reckons it could take over 10 years to generate a feeling of empowerment amongst a generation of children who have grown up feeling life has little to offer them. I ask year 11 if they feel that anything they have learnt has changed a strongly held attitude. They think before replying. "No, not really". Eventually Scott chirps up, helpfully. "I dunno," he says, "I reckon I've become more tolerant of queers and lesbians."

So what do they all think of citizenship? A few will admit to enjoying it and to it having made a difference. The reaction of most is that it's a bit of a doss, a second-class citizen, in effect, that is nowhere near as important as subjects such as maths, English and science. "It's not going to help us get a job, is it?" says Andrea, speaking for them all.

"Ah," says Waller, "if it's such an unimportant subject, how come they all turn up? Their lessons are either just before lunch or just after - the ideal time to cut class. But they don't. My classes are better attended than many core subjects."

Waller believes that if he can shift the attitudes of just two students he has been successful. If so, he may be able to find some victories in unlikely places. As I leave, Ashley, year 11's professional bad boy, chips in. "You know, the teachers here are sexist," he says. "If the girls get caught smoking or swearing they're always given a warning. I get into trouble just for saying shite".

fields.headline: Time is short
fields.standfirst: The advent of electronic time pieces thirty years ago means the world now faces a shortage of traditional watch repairers
fields.trailText: The advent of electronic time pieces thirty years ago means the world now faces a shortage of traditional watch repairers
fields.body:
A strange thing happened at the beginning of the 1990s. Whether it was Hugh Scully's influence on Antiques Road Show or whether there was just a spontaneous synergy of good taste, the effect was the same; people stopped buying only the cheapo quartz watches that had dominated the market since the mid-70s and started to show an interest in the old-fashioned pieces with springs, levers and wheels.

By 1993 demand was so great that Swiss watch manufacturers became a little panicky, as there were too few horologists to service and repair all the pieces they were selling.They sent out an SOS to horology training institutions around the world asking for 25,000 new watch repair men and women by 2000.

Britain's response has been muted, to put it mildly. The horology course at Hackney College closed down three years ago due to lack of demand for places, and the only remaining institutions offering this training are Manchester City College and the University of Central England. Together, they send out between 30 to 40 graduates each year.

Our lack of enthusiasm is matched abroad, with America, mainland Europe and Australia showing an equal reluctance to make things tick. So at a rough estimate, the Swiss watch manufacturers are almost certainly 20,000 watchmakers short of the full cog.

Tomorrow, manufacturers, such as Omega, Seiko, Rolex and Rotary, along with training providers and careers services, will link up at a conference hosted by the British Horological Institute (BHI) at its Nottinghamshire headquarters to find ways of halting what they fear is a terminal decline in the industry. "No one even thinks of watchmaking as a possible profession these days," says Tony Lewis, vice-president of the BHI. "The average age of those working as horologists is going up and up and we aren't attracting young people in. What's more we now have a situation where most of the main Swiss retail outlets are in the capital and we don't have a single training establishment in the south-east."

Horology has never been exactly sexy, and one could argue that watchmaking has always lived in the shadows. John Harrison never received the recognition he deserved for his series of marine chronometers that effectively enabled sailors to determine longitude at sea, and by the 1920s all four of them were gathering dust, forgotten in some corner of a cellar in the Maritime Museum. They would be languishing there still, had it not been for the unpaid restoration work of Rupert Gould, a clock obsessive. But, at least, in those days you could always find at least one person in any town who understood the insides of a watch. Now you may not be so lucky.

If the art of watchmaking does die out, it won't be for want of effort from John Murphy, course lecturer at Manchester City College. He is aware he has an uphill struggle. "A newly-qualified graduate can expect to earn £16K as a starting salary," he says, "and getting by on that in London can be difficult." However, he is adamant that though the rewards aren't financial, they are there. "The work is fascinating, and a job is virtually guaranteed."

Manchester offers two different courses - the basic 3 year BHI technical course which takes up 16 hours per week, 36 weeks per year and offers a basic grounding in all areas of horology from the maths to the mechanics of watches and clocks and the two-year Watches of Switzerland Training and Education Programme (WOSTEP) which takes up 35 hours per week, 38 weeks a year and also includes work experience.

As its name suggests WOSTEP is sponsored by Swiss watch manufacturers, and their £35K per annum is designed to produce and train the staff for their workshop. As such, the course is narrowly focused on wrist watches.

For those looking for a slightly bigger canvas, the best - and only - option is the two-year course in Conservation and Restoration of Antique Clocks at West Dean College.

Those seeking to work on a grand scale, up clock towers, need two main qualifications, according to John Murphy - a head for heights and no claustrophobic tendencies.

Small, medium or large. The choice is yours. But make your mind up fast because the clock is ticking and time is running out.

 For details of the BHI conference on February 16, telephone 01636 813795.

fields.headline: No flies on us
fields.standfirst: Agricultural colleges need no advice from Tony Blair. They are already diversifying
fields.trailText: Agricultural colleges need no advice from Tony Blair. They are already diversifying
fields.body:
Farmers are undoubtedly glum about Tony Blair's blunt declaration that there is no more public money to ease their problems.

But his airy talk about diversification must surely have prompted yawns all round - at least in agricultural training circles.

For the last seven years at least, every agricultural college has been coming to terms with radical upheaval. Diversification has been the order of the day.

Long gone is the era when college was the preserve of the male farm student. Today you are as likely to see young women exercising horses, or mature students practising the art of garden design, as you are to come across a tractor-driving course. This expansion of their role is reflected by the fact that only two colleges in Great Britain still have "agriculture" in their title.

Change, which a decade ago was progressing slowly, was accelerated by the need for survival. In the 60s every county had its local education authority-funded farm institute. Some, such as Lincolnshire and Suffolk, had two.

County councils were proud of their agricultural heritage and keen to support their agricultural colleges. By the end of the 80s, though, some local authorities started to cut back, changing from block to per capita funding. At incorporation in 1993, when institutions were cut loose from local authority control, there was an immediate move towards parity with other further education colleges. Agricultural colleges had enjoyed vastly different levels of funding, most well above the average further education level. Drastic changes were needed just to survive.

For some which had already started changing, this sped things up. To others, survival dictated loss of independence and identity. For them, merger with other education establishments was the only answer. Their high overheads and low student numbers were unattractive to potential partners, but most had one highly-sought commodity, the space to expand.

Some have lost their identity, becoming just an outlying campus of their larger partner, but most mergers have benefited agricultural colleges. One such happy marriage of convenience happened in 1996 between Warwickshire College of Agriculture and Mid-Warwickshire FE College.

Four years on, the agricultural campus of the new Warwickshire College is thriving. It boasts new engineering, construction, residential and teaching blocks. The old polo school has been converted into a state of the art library and IT centre, and the farm has acquired an advanced modern milking parlour.

Most colleges have seized the chance to expand their higher education provision, some by merging with a university to become its land-based campus, others by forming unions in which they retain their identity. One such is Hartpury College in Gloucestershire which is linked to the University of the West of England.

As Gloucestershire College of Agriculture, Hartpury had survived with 100 agricultural students until the local authority changed to funding by student numbers. In 1990, it was hardly viable as a further education college, but with the introduction of equestrian and animal care courses there was an explosion in numbers. There are now some 1,300 students, split equally between further and higher education, and studying the full range of land-based courses, from countryside conservation to sports science and from equine to golf studies.

Despite diversifying to survive, agricultural colleges have not lost sight of their original objective - to produce tomorrow's farmers. Courses, such as animal welfare, marketing and business studies are standard, while organic agriculture courses, for years run only by Broomfield College in Derbyshire, are becoming more widespread.

The wide variety of subjects now available at the colleges means that agricultural students have never had such a good opportunity to diversify.

Who knows? One of them might make prime minister.

Case studies

Hartpury College is in a far healthier position than it's ever been, says Eirwyn Jenkinson, an agricultural lecturer there for the last quarter of a century.

"Twenty-five years ago we had all our eggs in one basket," he says.

"By spreading our brief the college is a lot stronger, and we are still able to offer agricultural courses."

But he adds a note of caution. "There is a danger in going entirely over to the provision of leisure, because I cannot see the nation depending entirely on imported food.

"It would not be politically sound."

Tom Cox has been the farm manager at Warwickshire College for 30 years.

"When I started there were just 38 students, all male and all studying agriculture full-time, with seven teaching staff. On the same site now there are about 4,000 students, full and part-time - 90 of them studying agriculture, and 250 staff. I believe there'll always be a place for good people willing to put their back into agriculture."

Rachel Dawson, aged 19, is in the first year of a Higher National Certificate in Agriculture at Warwickshire College.

"The course is brilliant because it is flexible. I want to be an agricultural adviser and I had a place a Reading University, but that would have meant being away from home and having to give up my herd of pedigree Charollais cows.

"Attending college one day a week, the Higher National Certificate in Agriculture will take two years. I can then do an HND in 18 months, convert that into a degree in a year and develop my herd at the same time."

webTitle: You find the evidence, we'll pick the policy

fields.headline: You find the evidence, we'll pick the policy
fields.standfirst: Social research is back with a bang at Whitehall, but  David Walker  asks if there is a hidden cost
fields.trailText: Social research is back with a bang at Whitehall, but David Walker asks if there is a hidden cost
fields.body:
After long years of rejection and straitened budgets, happy days are here again for researchers in the social sciences. In Whitehall corridors the buzz is "evidence". In the Cabinet Office the Social Exclusion Unit and the Performance and Innovation Unit have proved to be avid consumers of academic work. Social scientists are regular visitors to Gordon Brown's policy seminars at Number 11.

The government seems determined to ensure that social research fits with its policy priorities, especially in education. There, ministers and their special advisers seem to have been convinced by criticism levelled by Professors David Hargreaves of Cambridge and James Tooley of Newcastle University at academic colleagues for failing to address such practical questions as how children might perform better in the classrooms.

To secure more knowledge, money is flowing out to economists, sociologists and those in related disciplines working in the universities and research units. The Department for Education and Employment is doubling its research budget; the Home Office's crime reduction programme includes £25m for research and evaluation; health is spending £30m on policy research while the annual budget of the arm's length Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC) will increase from £70m to £73m by 2001-2002.

But government largesse does not come cost-free. And the nature of the bargain Whitehall is offering was spelled out recently by education secretary David Blunkett. He said policy is better if informed by empirical evidence. "Too often in the past, policy has not been informed by good research," said Blunkett. "A former permanent secretary once ruefully described the old department of education and science as a "knowledge free-zone".

"Too many academics want to address issues other than those that are central and directly relevant to the political and policy debate."

They focus on questions that fail to take reality into account. Sometimes, he said, research is "setting out with the sole aim of collecting evidence that will prove a policy wrong rather than genuinely seeking to evaluate or interpret impact".

Blunkett is not alone. Lord (David) Lipsey was speaking for the New Labour establishment when he told a recent meeting of the Association of Research Centres in the Social Sciences that academics had to try harder to communicate their work to the wider public, who paid for it.

Lord Sainsbury, the science minister, is conducting a review of how well public money spent on science gets translated into commercial opportunity as part of the treasury's year 2000 comprehensive spending review. There will be renewed determination to make sure the research council consults "users" in business and government before it allocates research contracts.

But academic social scientists don't accept their primary purpose is to service Whitehall. Gordon Marshall, the Oxford sociologist and new head of the research council, has said only work of the highest intellectual quality will get funded.

Janet Lewis, research director at the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, which commissions a large-scale programme of work from universi ties, worries that "evidence led" may mean "what we want for our own political purposes".

With the Higher Education Funding Councils and the ESRC, Blunkett's department is putting £12.5m into a five-year teaching and learning initiative. Sir Michael Peckham from the school of public policy at University College, London, is chairing a new national educational research forum "to achieve greater coherence and agreement between funders, researchers and users of research".

The idea is that academics and policy-makers share knowledge faster - and improve consensus on what is important. Malcolm Wicks, minister for continuing education is chairing a series of seminars where researchers can put their ideas directly to David Blunkett, Sir Michael Bichard, the permanent secretary and their colleagues.

The research preferred by government involves longitudinal studies - moving pictures of how people's lives and livelihoods change, eg how children with special educational needs fare through their final years of schooling into the world of work, training and further study.

To ensure it gets what it wants Whitehall is setting up six dedicated centres within the universities, including the London School of Economics and Birkbeck College and a new Centre for Evidence Informed Policy and Practice at the Institute of Education. This is meant to collect together examples of "what works" among policy recommendations and ensure the message is conveyed to ministers. The research council is also putting £3m into a new initiative "to improve the knowledge base for policy and practice".

What was that old adage about pipers and tunes?

fields.headline: Into the hotseat
fields.standfirst: He has just stepped into one of the most crucial jobs in education today - to attract more people to teaching. Ralph Tabberer, new head of the Teacher Training Agency, talks to  Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: He has just stepped into one of the most crucial jobs in education today - to attract more people to teaching. Ralph Tabberer, new head of the Teacher Training Agency, talks to Rebecca Smithers
fields.body:
Ralph Tabberer is just three days into his new job as chief executive of the Teacher Training Agency, and he has already made his mark. While his predecessor, Anthea Millett, was no great fan of grey boxes, his personal computer and laptop - which he considers essential tools of the trade - are up and running in his 13th-floor office in Victoria, London. Within the agency itself, his colleagues welcome the prospect of a wind of change.

The fortysomething former humanities teacher, local education authority adviser and "classroom researcher" (his own rather modest description) has moved just down the road from the Department for Education and Employment, where he worked as a civil servant from 1997, initially as a senior adviser in Michael Barber's Standards and Effectiveness Unit and most recently heading the National Grid for Learning division.

Tabberer has landed arguably one of the most important jobs in education, leading a high-profile drive to recruit teachers as the profession faces the biggest modernisation programme in its history. But he is under no illusion that ministers, teaching unions and providers - ie the teacher training colleges - expect the agency to become one of the most successful graduate recruitment bodies, in competition with industry. And he is also well aware of the strong personal interest of the prime minister, who even appeared in the first phase of the £1.5m national recruitment campaign alongside one of his former teachers.

"The most important thing is that we get involved in promoting the profession, while making sure that we are one of the most effective graduate recruiters, on a par with the banks and big businesses," Tabberer says. "We have got to be that good".

Strong partnership with teacher training colleges is also key to the drive to raise standards, by offering top quality courses. Interestingly, he sees the slimming down of the role of the agency - the result of a government review into the agency's first five years - as a positive development rather than a setback.

Last spring, education secretary David Blunkett rejected calls for the agency to be scrapped at the end of the review, despite strong criticism over its failure to meet government recruitment targets. But he decreed that if the agency was to remain, it would have a reduced remit allowing it to concentrate only on key areas. Now, as Tabberer explains, the agency's responsibility is to oversee the recruitment and training of teachers, up to the point when they arrive in the classroom. Thereafter, the fledgling General Teaching Council will take over as the voice for the profession, once teachers have registered with it. "The whole organisation is now much more focused," he explains.

Inevitably, his first week was packed with meetings with ministers and other senior education figures. But while Tabberer expects to spend the first weeks of his new job simply listening, a priority is to listen to new entrants to the profession - young entrants as well as older "returners" - in order to find out about their expectations. As he puts it himself: "If I can get a sense of the voice of teachers, and find out if we are delivering what they want, that will be a good starting point." He has also promised a root-and-branch review of the organisation itself, examining every process it carries out, although top quality research will be key to its work.

Despite the continued public perception of a so-called recruitment crisis, Tabberer believes the corner has been turned, and points out that inquiries from potential trainees have leaped by 30% as a result of the advertising campaign. Recent research shows - surprisingly - that teaching is the fourth most popular option for graduates after broadcast and media, marketing and public relations, and communications. The profession also continues to attract around 30,000 new trainees every year.

Nevertheless, the national vacancy rate continues to hover at around 0.7%, with proportionately even more jobs unfilled in London. And there remain serious shortages in some subjects, despite the introduction of the "golden hello" incentive scheme for graduates in maths, science and languages. Another depressing trend is the huge number of trainees who never set foot in the classroom, or who quit soon after qualifying.

All these conflicting signals suggest the need for a definitive picture of recruitment and supply. School standards minister Estelle Morris has asked Tabberer for a detailed report by Easter, which will be critical to the next phase of implementing the reforms in the Green Paper.

Inevitably, pay has dominated much of the recent debate, and the government has tried to counter concerns about poor remuneration with the introduction of performance-related pay, which will provide significant rewards for talented teachers who qualify to pass through the "threshold". But Tabberer believes pay must be considered within the broader context of professional development. "Research shows that what graduates want are 'prospects', which includes the chance to progress within a clearly defined framework," he says. He is also keen to allay the National Union of Teachers' worries about forthcoming numeracy, literacy and ICT (information and communications technology) tests, which he believe will help teachers to do their jobs better.

Aware of the need to meet tough targets to attract more male, ethnic minority and disabled teachers, Tabberer would like to see more classroom-based initiatives to emphasise the attractiveness of teaching early on. "We need to make more of the fact that we have a captive audience, with every youngster spending around 15,000 hours in the classroom between the age of five and 16," he says.

One possibility, he explains, might be getting older children to try their hand at the front of the class. He described how as a sixth-former he stepped in to teach a class American politics, and experienced the buzz and thrill of being at the front of the class. Keen to stamp out the myth that teaching is unexciting or "cissy", he says: "There is absolutely nothing cissy about teaching. All those of us who have taught know it is challenging and exciting and an incredibly responsible job. For me it is also a great passion."

That first taste of teaching as a Plymouth schoolboy led him, after Cambridge, to a postgraduate certificate in education at Brunel University, and thence to the classroom as a humanities teacher. He then moved into research with the National Foundation for Educational Research. He believe his own career shows how teaching can lead to other interesting education jobs that may not necessarily be classroom-based.

Barriers need to be broken down, he says, and older entrants need to be encouraged. Similarly, there is no reason why younger teachers should not move on after, say, 10 years. "We have to recognise that the whole nature of work and careers is changing beyond recognition," he stresses. He quotes, for example, the influx into the jobs market of around 3,000 BT workers, whose skills would be invaluable for teaching design and technology and ICT. The next phase of the advertising campaign, which will be rolled out over the coming weeks, will emphasise the many skills involved in teaching.

Education department colleagues who have worked with Tabberer describe him as thoughtful and hard-working, passionate about ICT and "a bit off the wall, not your typical civil servant," according to one. Whether he brings about a wind of change or a hurricane now remains to be seen.

webTitle: Making a pact with the devil

fields.headline: Making a pact with the devil
fields.standfirst: When inspectors visited his college,  Donald Hiscock had to resort to desperate measures
fields.trailText: When inspectors visited his college, Donald Hiscock had to resort to desperate measures
fields.body:
I have a confession to make. I hope that those nice people at the Further Education Funding Council are not reading this, because, if they are, my cover as a lecturer whose strengths far outweigh his weaknesses will be blown.

Like the fallen hero of those noir movies I have watched with my Film Studies class, I have a confession to make. Most of what I am about to describe takes place in a dimly lit room and, yes, there is a femme fatale involved.

It all began on a wet Tuesday morning a week before inspection. Arriving late, I found only half the group in the room. Those present were either lost inside their Walkmans or slumped with their heads on their arms. Nothing unusual about that, but I imagined how it might look to an inspector.

"Where is everyone?" I said.

"Dead," replied Roxanne, the only student who seemed to be vaguely conscious of my presence. "Party last night," she offered. "New club... cheap booze... great."

But that was only the beginning. I listened, with a feeling of panic, to the news that this scene would be repeated next week. Monday night is student night at the Auteur Club.

Something had to be done. Aside from the curling posters on the classroom wall there was the creeping growth of Blu-Tack stalactites that hung down from the ceiling. Every day there were more, in ever more anatomically surprising shapes. I had a clean-up job to do, and I had to act fast. I had to start with the students.

"This is not good enough," I announced at the end of the lesson. No one stirred. "Things have got to be a lot better by this time next week," I puffed. No one stirred. "Is anybody listening to me?" I demanded.

"Yes we are," said Roxanne, the flickering fluorescent light glinting off her facial piercings.

So I told them straight. I asked them for their co-operation during inspection week. I asked them to get to class on time, be alert, bring their folders and remember something about what they had been taught over the past term. It was a tall order.

"What's in it for us?" asked Roxanne defiantly.

Quite a lot, as it turned out. The next day they were all wide awake as we thrashed out the terms of the deal. Roxanne revealed her skills at bargaining. She knew that she was dealing with a desperate weakling. She went for the jugular.

For one week only they were the college's star attraction. They performed brilliantly. It could have been real. They professed ownership of a scheme of work that I had almost forgotten. They worked in groups, made enthusiastic contributions to discussions and gave me rave notices when left alone with the inspector. Even the principal half-smiled at me in the staff room.

And so it is Tuesday morning again. I am in my empty classroom, the lights are off, the video is on. I am pretending I have a class. I won't see any students until this afternoon. And it will be the same until the end of the year. Roxanne, bless her, has seen to that.

Every day there were more, in ever more anatomically surprising shapes. I had a clean-up job to do, and I had to act fast. I had to start with the students. "This is not good enough," I announced at the end of the lesson. No one stirred. "Things have got to be a lot better by this time next week," I puffed. No one stirred. "Is anybody listening to me?" I demanded. "Yes we are," said Roxanne, the flickering fluorescent light glinting off her facial piercings. So I told them straight. I asked them for their co-operation during inspection week. I asked them to get to class on time, be alert, bring their folders and remember something about what they had been taught over the past term. It was a tall order. "What's in it for us?" asked Roxanne defiantly. Quite a lot, as it turned out. The next day they were all wide awake as we thrashed out the terms of the deal. Roxanne revealed her skills at bargaining. She knew that she was dealing with a desperate weakling. She went for the jugular. For one week only they were the college's star attraction. They performed brilliantly. It could have been real. They professed ownership of a scheme of work that I had almost forgotten. They worked in groups, made enthusiastic contributions to discussions and gave me rave notices when left alone with the inspector. Even the principal half-smiled at me in the staff room. And so it is Tuesday morning again. I am in my empty classroom, the lights are off, the video is on. I am pretending I have a class. I won't see any students until this afternoon. And it will be the same until the end of the year. Roxanne, bless her, has seen to that.

fields.headline: Let them keep their shirts!
fields.standfirst: There will be no special cover for college governors, says  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: There will be no special cover for college governors, says Peter Kingston
fields.body:
The government is refusing to boost college governors' legal protection from being sued for all they possess if their institutions hit the skids and they are held to blame.

Baroness Blackstone, the further education minister, has rejected a call from colleges for a clause in the Learning and Skills Bill guaranteeing their governors safety from being held personally liable, provided they acted in good faith.

She says governors are "protected by existing law against any risk to their own assets" so long as they are honest and show common sense.

But existing law is inadequate and the lack of proper safeguards can only exacerbate a current serious shortage of volunteers to become governors, according to the Association of Colleges. The association is calling for college governors to get the same statutory protection as is enjoyed by school governors, company directors and charitable trustees.

In January it wrote to the minister reminding her that a study commissioned two years ago by the Committee on Standards in Public Life established that there was a need for legislation to ensure equal legal protection for all appointees to responsible bodies of "public service organisations" (PSOs).

The study concluded that this safeguard should be equivalent to that bestowed by the 1925 Trustee Act and the 1985 Companies Act on charitable trustees and on company directors. This gives courts discretion to grant relief on those individuals who have acted honestly and reasonably but nonetheless find themselves facing potential liability.

The 1998 study - Personal Liability in Public Service Organisations -looked at the position of college governors among other people serving PSOs. It concluded that while the risk of unwarranted personal liability was low it could not be ruled out.

John Brennan, the association's director of further education development, said: "Nobody's saying that if governors act recklessly, or negligently, or for ulterior motives there should be protection.

"But if they act in good faith and reasonably, they shouldn't end up in court."

Governors have been criticised in several high-profile cases of college financial mismanagement and this may be deterring the government from taking any measure to improve governors' protection against individual liability.

fields.headline: Digital dimensions
fields.standfirst: David Blunkett announces a new initiative in virtual higher education as part of a global vision of learning
fields.trailText: David Blunkett announces a new initiative in virtual higher education as part of a global vision of learning
fields.body:
Thirty-five years ago, Tony Crosland made his landmark speech on the future of the polytechnics at the then Woolwich Polytechnic - now part of the University of Greenwich. I shall return there today to make a major speech on the key challenges and new directions for higher education in the 21st century.

Globalisation has restructured production and trade, transformed financial markets and accelerated technological development. Since the key to success and prosperity in the new global economy are skills, knowledge and innovation, higher education has become central to our competitiveness and social cohesion.

Globalisation is also reshaping higher education itself. Learning has become a big global business. Enrolments in higher education are set to rise to 159 million by 2025, 87 million of them in Asia. And as reports in this supplement have shown, powerful competitive forces are emerging in the learning market - new private sector providers - media and IT corporations, as well as established universities, which are expanding aggressively across the world.

I believe we can harness globalisation as a force for progressive change in higher education. New international alliances are already springing up between universities - Universitas 21, for example, or the link we have sponsored between MIT and Cambridge University and the Institutes of Enterprise. These alliances share resources, facilitate staff and student mobility, and use new technology to spread excellence. Just as other industries and services have restructured, so higher education can use global alliances to secure new forms of diversity with excellence for an expanded student population. We have a huge advantage in the English language and the world-class reputation of our universities, and we must use it.

The alternative is simply to go it alone. I do not believe that is the answer. No institution can offer real excellence in teaching or research across the full range of disciplines - the resources on the required scale are not there, despite the huge boost we have given to higher education funding through the creation of the new student support system and the income stream of £710 million that it will generate in 2001/2 alone.

As importantly, a unitary sector should not be a uniform one. We have to secure genuine diversity, in which institutions identify their strengths and play to them, and student choice and demand drives flexibility and quality. That is why I am also announcing today a new national initiative for the UK in virtual higher education.

In order to concentrate our effort and resources, so that we can compete successfully with the big US players, the Higher Education Funding Council for England will call for bids from consortia of universities and private companies - perhaps in publishing or information technology - to create an "e-universities" venture. The chosen consortium will be clearly positioned overseas as a flag carrier for the best of UK higher education in web-based delivery. Alongside learndirect, the University for Industry, the e-universities will ensure that the UK is at the cutting edge of global developments in virtual learning.

Diversity with excellence will also require the creation of new routes into higher education. So I am opening consultation today on new, two-year foundation degrees. These degrees will be available in diverse subject areas, but always designed with strong links to the world of work. They will be taken part-time, for those staying in employment, or full-time, providing a building block for future learning and career success, and enabling us to meet the prime minister's target that half of all young people can participate in higher education by the age of 30.

In a knowledge economy, expansion in high-quality higher education is critical to social justice. So as higher education drives forward economic competitiveness, it must also act as a force for social inclusion. A modern, open higher education system will reflect the wider society of which it is a part, both in its student population and in the equal opportunities for its staff. Better managed, inclusive and globalised, UK higher education will play a critical role in building prosperity and social cohesion.

 David Blunkett is secretary of state for education and employment.

fields.headline: Hurdles for screen stars
fields.standfirst: However many bright new computers you provide for the kids, without enlightened teachers and a wise strategy your school will make little or no headway in ICT
fields.trailText: However many bright new computers you provide for the kids, without enlightened teachers and a wise strategy your school will make little or no headway in ICT
fields.body:
Could do better. Despite considerable government investment and commitment to information and communications technology over the past few years, Ofsted's conclusion is that ICT teaching across the country is still patchy and uneven.

It's a verdict confirmed by Becta, the government's ICT and education agency. According to its schools director, Niel McLean, there are two populations - those schools that know what to do with ICT and those that don't: "It's not so much that they do it badly as they don't do it at all. It's as stark as that."

While at one time many schools could plead lack of funding as the reason for their prevarication, that excuse is nearing the end of its shelf life. The government has now stumped up a total of £1.7bn in funding for equipment and teacher training. "We wouldn't be spending money like that if everything was hunky dory," admits McLean.

Certainly Willow Tree Primary in Ealing has benefited from the extra cash. Getting ICT right comes down to money, believes headteacher Deryn Harvey. "Three years ago we were faced with real budgetary constraints. I had a lot of vision for ICT but my hands were tied because I had no spare money for hardware."

Since then she has tapped into NGfL and industry support and leapt ahead - her teachers have their own training suite, pupils have two machines in every classroom and there's an interactive whiteboard for every lesson. "To do well you do need to keep your eyes open for funding, keeping in contact with the right organisations, and the local authority," she concludes.

But how much is enough? Geoff Brookes, deputy headteacher with responsibility for the curriculum at Easingwold School, a comprehensive with 1,200 pupils in North Yorkshire, is trapped with outmoded hardware. "One problem is that we've been locked into the BBC and Archimedes computers. Like many schools, we were geared up to using these machines and their software; they were very good, but PCs became the common currency and it costs an awful lot to change over."

His school is in the second phase of NGfL funding and has not yet received cabling. "Although we're very grateful for what we're getting, funding is still a key issue because the technology is still so expensive. For £500, for instance, you can buy 50 textbooks, but only one PC. There's never enough to do everything you want to do - if there were, we could all provide excellent resources for both pupils and staff."

Money is not the only issue. Even those schools that have won Ofsted's praise for their ICT teaching acknowledge the difficulty facing others. Three years ago Ofsted criticised Ifield Special School in Kent for not making enough use of its technology - more recently Ofsted described it as outstanding.

"No matter how much money you throw at it, it takes a long time to get the structure in place, and then you need time to consolidate it," says headteacher Simon Harrison. And getting it right means getting everyone on board, he believes. "Ultimately it depends on the commitment of the head and the entrepreneurial enthusiasm of the staff. If they are computer literate and committed then the school can develop things and move forward very quickly, looking for cost-effective and creative solutions for developing ICT further."

Keith Parry, director of ICT at Hyde Technology School in Tameside, also believes the solution is to win over hearts and minds. "ICT here is not just a separate subject but something used by all our departments. Each has its own computer suites and facilities to manage and control," he explains.

"It's important that ICT is seen as a strategic issue for the whole school, as something underpinning the whole curriculum to improve teaching across the board. Only then will it be seen as an area for strong investment and commitment, and a lot of the perceived problems will simply melt away."

But therein lies the rub, according to Tony Poulter, ICT co-ordinator at Hugo Meynell CofE Primary in Shropshire, which has had ICT highlighted as an area of strength by Ofsted. "Some teachers are resistant to ICT even now. It probably comes down to unwillingness to change, fear of technology, or being threatened by the fact that the children are so red hot on it. Older teachers winding down a career may think they don't have to get to grips with it.

"While the extra training is a step forward, it's not compulsory and there's no accreditation at the end of it. It's a question of how you make some people actually switch on the computer in the first place, let alone use it effectively in the classroom."

But many teachers may simply need time to catch their breath, argues Geoff Turrell, headteacher at St Peter's CofE Junior School in Birmingham, also rated by Ofsted as exemplary. "For some schools the introduction of the numeracy and literacy strategies has put ICT on a backburner, and there has been no clear support for using ICT in these contexts. The government is now sending out the right signals that ICT has to be a priority."

His advice to struggling schools is to carry out an audit of teacher confidence in ICT. "You can then link that with training opportunities and ensure a good match between the two." And as schools feel more confident, they need to set themselves a challenge. "Pick an area like video-conferencing where you can become really leading edge, and that confidence will trickle down into all sorts of areas."

One area that needs attention is content, says Kevin Satchwell, headteacher at Thomas Telford School in Shropshire, a technology college which has developed its own online curriculum: "If you haven't got exciting, stimulating material you're stuck, because if it doesn't impact upon the quality and standard of teaching and learning, what's the point?"

While there are lots of good CD-roms and websites, these need to be gathered and cross-referenced to the curriculum for easy access and use, and teachers haven't got time to develop their own software or surf the web, he argues. "Getting the content right is a bigger challenge than putting cabling in. What we need is a whole series of exemplary curriculum for ICT that teachers can pick and mix from."

McLean agrees: "The trouble is we've turned it into too big a challenge for many teachers. Telling them they need to rethink their approach is not that good a message."

But at least most now recognise ICT as an issue that has to be addressed. "There's been a number of passing fads over the past 20 years and it can be tricky working out which are here to stay," he says. "But this one is not going away."

fields.headline: How do you bounce back?
fields.standfirst: Norman Gentry describes how the profession of bouncers, glimpsed in the television series Muscle, has toiled hard to win respectability
fields.trailText: Norman Gentry describes how the profession of bouncers, glimpsed in the television series Muscle, has toiled hard to win respectability
fields.body:
For years we have been trying to improve the image of our occupation, which is currently featuring on a late night BBC series. If telly cameras in the kitchen put people off the catering profession, the vignettes shown of bouncers' work could well deter most people.

For the last few years, councils up and down the country have been setting up registration schemes for door staff, to weed out the problem thug. This has, in many areas, been supplemented with compulsory training covering the law, licensing, basic first aid, drugs awareness and people control.

The work has led to a newly announced British Standard for door staff and two awarding bodies offering national certificates and even the possibility of an NVQ (National Vocational Qualification).

Here in Carlisle the local bouncers were extremely sceptical of people being able to teach them anything, but, slowly, a rapport has been built between the doorman, the council and the local police. To such a point that they now find that there are certain local characters they would rather not work with.

The New Year's Eve after our first course, the Carlisle Police reported there wasn't any trouble in any club in Carlisle - what an achievement!

The local doormen, and let's not forget the increasing number of women, are well aware that they have a dangerous and unenviable job - acting as support for the police, making sure that the general public have a good and safe time, but, at the same time, having only a split second to make the right decision.

We are living in an increasingly violent world, the old style fisticuffs will no longer do. The public is often going out on drink and drugs. Full of aggression. Sometimes armed.

To cope with this, not only doormen, but all people dealing with the public - witness recent events at a hospital where a nurse was attacked - are having to learn a whole range of complex aggression control and people management skills and how to put them into effect very rapidly.

Look at the work of the Suzy Lamplugh trust in raising the profile of this problem. This is not a job for the stereotype bouncer, but for someone who is skilled.

Let's hope that television and the critics have done nothing to spoil this perception. There are another five weeks of the series to go.

Spare a thought for the poor person working on the door tonight.

 Norman Gentry is the course organiser for the door supervisor programme at Carlisle College and a freelance consultant.

fields.headline: A small degree of danger
fields.standfirst: Australia is tempting our students one way, America the other, as overseas universities line up for our best young minds. We're fighting back with two-year degrees, but will they work?
fields.trailText: Australia is tempting our students one way, America the other, as overseas universities line up for our best young minds. We're fighting back with two-year degrees, but will they work?
fields.body:
The two-year foundation degree planned by the government could damage the international reputation of Britain's universities, warn academic leaders aware that competition in the global higher education market is hotting up.

The scramble for students was highlighted just days before today's announcement by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, of his "e-universities" initiative to sell internet learning worldwide. The University of Technology Sydney revealed it was to "undertake a vigorous promotion campaign in the UK".

In an audacious move, it has set up offices in London "with the aim of attracting several hundred young Britons to its campuses each year". The university believes that, despite fees of £3,000 per term for postgraduates, it can lure UK students to the other side of the world to enrol for degrees that are respected worldwide. The carrot is what it calls Sydney's "beach culture".

Later this month the Financial Times launches FT Knowledge in collaboration with the prestigious University of Michigan business school and Regents College, a New York State-based distance learning institution with 17,000 students. The Pearson group, which owns the Financial Times, already cooperates with Heriot Watt University in Edinburgh, delivering its MBA to 5,000 students worldwide.

And the Massachussetts Institute of Technology is busily establishing a global presence through links with Cambridge, and outposts in Dublin and Singapore, besides distance courses. It is poised to scoop up scarce research funding as well as students.

Now, in an effort to fight back against US and Australian competition, the British Council has launched Education UK as a brand to promote universities, colleges and private schools overseas. Blunkett and his advisers are convinced the two-year foundation degree will appeal abroad as well as drawing more people in the UK into technical and vocational qualifications.

The pilot scheme for the foundation degree, unveiled this week, confirms that the new qualification will be focused mainly on those in jobs. It will be taken part-time in local further education colleges, validated by universities, with both academic and vocational strands.

It is a dramatic turnaround for the two-year degree, which was dismissed in one line by the Dearing review of universities three years ago. It will underpin the government's drive to attract half of school leavers into higher education by 2010.

Many academics in universities are sceptical. A major concern is the so-called double demand problem: only when companies are convinced of the value of the new degree, will students be attracted to it.

Demand will also depend critically on whether students will have to pay tuition fees, and whether it offers automatic entry into the final year of honours degrees after completion. If successful though, the degree will almost certainly sound the death knell for existing vocational qualifications such as higher national diplomas and certificates.

However, alarm bells are sounding in the academic sector, which fears the foundation degree will devalue the jealously guarded reputation of the British degree overseas. The standing of UK universities abroad has suffered a series of blows recently, with questions raised about the standards of some UK franchised degree courses overseas.

The British Council recently launched a new global brand for British education to help safeguard the country's share of the multi-billion dollar market for international students. David Triesman, general secretary of the lecturers' union, the Association of University Teachers, said he "could see the value of a higher education foundation course" but was "concerned at possible confusion for students and organisations, particularly for those outside the UK".

Geoffrey Copland, vice-chancellor of Westminster University and convenor of the coalition of modern universities, said the use of the word degree could rebound badly on the sector. "The Quality Assurance Agency has gone through all sorts of contortions to define what a degree is, and we have been struggling very hard to describe that framework in words which will not be misconstrued in the international markets.
