These concerns are summarily dismissed by David Robertson, one of the main architects of the new degree and professor of public policy at Liverpool John Moores University. "It's absolute rubbish. Far from eroding quality of the degrees in US universities, associate degrees have enhanced quality. There is no evidence that they have led to a deterioration." He argued that the two year-degree will in fact be far better suited to many international students.

For the leading research universities the key issue was plugging a funding shortfall of at least £1.8bn - New Labour had halted but not reversed the decline of the Tory years, said David Triesman. The number of Fellows of the Royal Society - the most distinguished scientists - living abroad had doubled in recent years and 78 clinical academic professorships had been vacant for six months.

"These things take time to turn around. Unless the money for leading edge research universities comes through in the Comprehensive Spending Review they will be forced to take a decision essentially to go private on the north American model or they are out of the international game. I don't think the universities can go to 2003 in their present state and survive as public institutions."

Without more government funding, elite universities would start charging top-up fees - probably in collaboration with a US partner, he predicted. A degree from MIT/ Cambridge could be highly attractive to British and European students, for instance, and as a private venture would be outside government restrictions however much David Blunkett remains opposed to differential fees.

Scotland's universities banded together two years ago to sell themselves abroad. The venture is proving so profitable that it has attracted the interest of Rupert Murdoch who is next week due to clinch a £3.5m deal with their company Scottish Knowledge.

His News International will take a 25% stake, swinging their global marketing and distribution muscle behind the distance learning courses devised by the Scots. Steve Beere, the company's Australia-born chief executive, predicts that in three to five years' time the universities' income from distance courses will be £40m a year.

The main targets are the emerging markets of south-east Asia and the Middle East, where countries want quick results and cannot afford to send more of their students overseas.

Edinburgh neighbours Napier University and Heriot Watt are providing business and ICT training, while Heriot Watt, Aberdeen, Robert Gordon and Strathclyde are working with the United Arab Emirates on oil and gas training. A £50m institute is proposed there.

fields.headline: The key grip
fields.trailText: The key grip
fields.body:
The what? The key grip.

Yes. I heard you. But what is it? Not what. Who.

Oh shoot, you're not one of those people who gives names to all your household appliances? Look, it's not a household appliance.

Well, who is this key grip, then? Somebody who holds tight to keys? Oh, come now, you've surely read the credits that come on screen at the end of a film.

Certainly not. Once Arnie's shot his load I've no interest in knowing who buttered the extras' buns. Well, if you had, you would know that a key grip is a member of a film production unit.

So, what's he do then? He or she leads a team of grips and riggers on the film set and works closely with the camera crew.

Grips and riggers, eh. Isn't that a song: Grips and riggers, come away, come away... Stop that awful howl or I'm leaving. I'm missing a Bergman retrospective to talk to you.

Sorry. But what do grips and riggers do? Once the camera angles and lighting effects have been decided between the director, production designer and director of photography, the grips and riggers will prepare the tracks, cranes and dollies as required for the shots.

Dollies, eh? And teddies, too, no doubt. Dollies are the wheeled platforms on which the camera is pushed by the grips and riggers.

So it's basically a posh name for dogsbody? Not at all. Grips usually have an interest in lighting and how it affects the shot as they move the camera. Being a grip is actually a highly sought-after post. It's seen as an entrée to camera work.

Well, it's nicer to be the guy pushed than the poor sap pushing. Have you no soul? Don't you realise that there are thousands prepared to cut off a limb to get into film-making?

Really? Amputation is an entry requirement to the business? No, no. But anyone in the industry will tell you that perseverance, determination and adaptability are essential. Few positions are advertised. It's a friends and word-of-mouth business. But do scour the ads in Broadcast, Screen International, Time Out, the union BECTU's job listings and, of course, The Guardian.

No entry exams, then? There is no recommended qualification or advisable route into the film industry. Even with no formal qualifications, you can still come through. Traditionally there's little formalised training. Most is picked up on the job. As a result progress can be slow.

What about film schools? Some studios can be a bit snooty about them, and there are no job guarantees, no matter how extensive your education. But the more knowledge you get, the better, and a film course may give you some useful contacts. Some courses can act as a substitute for apprenticeships as messengers or runners. But, beware! Not all courses are practical.

How do you get on a course? Applicants usually need to show some previous work and have a sound educational background. Creativity is essential.

 British Film Institute (BFI), 21 Stephen Street, London, W1P 1PL Telephone 0171 255 1444
 British Kinematograph, Sound and Television Society (BKSTS) , 547-549 Vernon Place, Victoria House, London, WC1B 4DJ, Telephone 0171 242 8400
 Broadcasting Entertainment Cinematograph Technicians Union , 111 Wardour Street, London, W1V 4AY, Telephone 0171 437 8506
For courses in other English-speaking countries: the American Film Institute Guide to College Courses in Film and Television is available from Simon and Schuster Inc, 15 Columbus Circle, New York, NY 10023, USA (this covers Canada as well).
 learndirect 0800 100 900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Freed hostages tell of 'infidel' Britain
fields.standfirst:
Stansted hijack: special report

Hijack hearing Thirteen accused as 73 passengers return to Afghanistan
fields.trailText: Thirteen men appeared in court yesterday accused of seizing the Boeing 727 at the centre of the Stansted airport hijack drama, while 73 of the freed passengers voluntarily returned to Aghanistan, apparently calling Britain a damp and "infidel" nation.
fields.byline: Owen Bennett Jones in Kandahar, Will Woodward  and  Paul Baldwin
fields.body:
Thirteen men appeared in court yesterday accused of seizing the Boeing 727 at the centre of the Stansted airport hijack drama, while 73 of the freed passengers voluntarily returned to Aghanistan, apparently calling Britain a damp and "infidel" nation.

The accused men, all Afghan nationals aged between 18 and 36, appeared at Southend magistrates court and were charged under section one of the Aviation Security Act 1982. The charge said that "within the jurisdiction of the central criminal court they unlawfully and by use of force or threat seized aircraft Boeing 727 YA-FAY and its passengers".

In an hour-long hearing they appeared in three separate groups, all bearded and wearing 1970s-style prison-issue track suits in navy, marine blue or green, and slippers. At least one man was said to have a wife and child on board the plane, and all are believed to be seeking political asylum.

The men, including two sets of brothers, heard the proceedings through Farsi and Pashtoo interpreters, although some of the accused answered "yes" in English to the magistrate. None applied for bail.

The stipendiary magistrate Kevin Gray remanded the 13 in custody and adjourned the committal proceedings until March 13 at 9.45am.

Earlier yesterday, half of the freed Afghan hostages, trapped in the aircraft from February 6-10, landed at Afghanistan's spiritual capital Kandahar, and spoke of their ordeal and of "infidel" Britain.

Despite stopping at the Stansted Hilton, one said: "It is not a Muslim country, how could we stay? The weather was depressing and the food was awful."

Mohammed Latif Nasri, a ground engineer who was on board the plane, added: "They requested that they stay in the United Kingdom. That was their only demand."

Another said: "They have nothing to do with politics."

The Taliban foreign minister, Wakil Ahmad Mutawakil, looked embarrassed as he met the freed hostages at Kandahar airport. He has sought to play down the idea that those on the plane were trying to escape the Taliban's strict Islamic government.

The defendants appearing at Southend were named as Muhammad Sediqui, 36; Abdul Showaib, 20; Mohammad Safi, 32; Ali Safi, 34; Mohammad Sediqui, 30; Khalil Ullah, 30; Muhammad Kazem, 27; Waheed Lufti, 22; Reshad Ahmodi, 18; Nazamuddin Mohammidy, 26; Mohammed Showaib, 25; Taimur Shah, 28; and Ghayur Abdul, 24.

The charged men were represented in court by three barristers and six solicitors. Kenneth Carr, acting for two of the defendants but supported by all counsel, made an application in camera for the men's names to be withheld from publication under section 11 of the Contempt of Court Act.

After hearing arguments for about two hours, the magistrate rejected the request. The men are understood to fear that their families in Afghanistan will be persecuted by the Taliban once their names are made public. One legal source said: "These aren't militants, they are just ordinary guys."

Police yesterday also released without charge a further six men after questioning, and they were to join other passengers waiting for asylum applications to be processed in Moreton in the Marsh, Gloucestershire.

But another man was arrested at the temporary immigration centre in the same town and returned to Essex for questioning on suspicion of being involved in the hijack.

fields.headline: Words of a weasel
fields.standfirst: Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: A standard Whitehall technique when confronted by embarrassing allegations is to dismiss them by caricature or resorting to a kind of reductio ad absurdum. Seize the least plausible claim to rubbish them all.
fields.body:
A standard Whitehall technique when confronted by embarrassing allegations is to dismiss them by caricature or resorting to a kind of reductio ad absurdum. Seize the least plausible claim to rubbish them all.

Thus foreign secretary Robin Cook in 1998 described claims by MI5 fugitive David Shayler that British intelligence plotted to assassinate Libyan leader Colonel Gadafy as "pure fantasy".

Yesterday, he told the BBC Today programme: "What I said two years ago is that I am absolutely satisfied that the previous foreign secretary [Sir Malcolm Rifkind] did not authorise an assassination attempt." And, he added, "that SIS [the secret intelligence service] has never put forward such a proposal for an assassination attempt and in my time in office I have never seen any evidence that SIS is interested in such an escapade".

There are separate issues here. Shayler's apparent exaggeration gave Cook an easy way out. For the claim that SIS (MI6) actually plotted to kill Gadafy, implying the plan was initiated by British agents, is not borne out by the top secret document placed on the internet last week. The MI6 file, dated December 1995, describes in detail a report by a Libyan "walk in" - called a "delicate source" - about an existing plot to oust Gadafy, by having him arrested or killed.

The plotters, said the source, had already distributed 250 British-made pistols and had many more guns at their disposal. MI6 said the source was revealing the information in the hope that if the coup was successful, the new Libyan regime could enlist "HMG [her majesty's government] support".

The plot failed, though according to Arab press reports, an attempt to kill the Libyan leader did take place in February 1996, killing innocent bystanders. The MI6 report says other plotters were aware of the source's contact with HMG but did not entirely approve of it. Cook could not resist seizing on that yesterday. "This intelligence document", he said, "actually ends with the contact saying to SIS that the other plotters were unhappy about him even telling SIS, which does rather prove that SIS were not manipulating this coup attempt."

Point taken. But to return to Cook's words back in 1998, more or less repeated yesterday: he said he had never seen any evidence that MI6 was interested in such "escapades".

Sure, this all happened under the previous Conservative administration but it can hardly be said that MI6 was not interested in the plot. Indeed, its three-page report was distributed throughout Whitehall, to the foreign office, the joint intelligence committee, the ministry of defence, GCHQ, and MI5. It was also sent to the British embassies in Tunis, Cairo, and Washington.

Cook's remarks in 1998 show that having produced the "pure fantasy" sound bite he chose his words carefully. "I'm fairly clear," he said, "there has never been any SIS involvement." Well, it depends on what Whitehall sophists mean by "involvement". The detail in the MI6 report, and its distribution list, reflects the importance the agency attached to the plot. It seems to have been widely discussed by enthusiastic MI6 officers. According to Shayler, MI6 paid its source - code-named Tunworth - £30,000. He told the BBC last year Tunworth's MI6 handler referred to the plot "in a note of triumph".

Rifkind was foreign secretary at the time. Like Cook, he had regular meetings with the head of MI6. Was Rifkind told? He almost certainly was not. For a well-placed source said yesterday that it was up to MI6 to judge what to tell ministers about their activities.

You do not need to take all of Shayler's claims at face value to suggest that the episode raises serious questions about MI6's lack of accountability.

Shayler, exiled in Paris, will be delighted to know that the cross-party parliamentary intelligence committee - which in the past has dismissed his allegations as nothing more than disaffected rantings, will raise the matter at a meeting today.

And Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, is asking Cook to set up an inquiry, asking when the agency first knew of the plot, and when the foreign secretary was informed. The questions deserve more than the dismissive mantra that governments never comment on the activities of the intelligence agencies; or claims that Maude is merely trying to embarrass his political opponent.

Maybe MI6 tipped Gadafy off. That might explain the Libyan leader's decision to provide valuable information to the government about what weapons he supplied to the IRA in the 1980s and to hand over the two men indicted for the Lockerbie bombing. Fantasy ? Who knows?

The questions deserve more than the dismissive mantra that governments never comment on the activities of the intelligence agencies; or claims that Maude is merely trying to embarrass his political opponent. Maybe MI6 tipped Gadafy off. That might explain the Libyan leader's decision to provide valuable information to the government about what weapons he supplied to the IRA in the 1980s and to hand over the two men indicted for the Lockerbie bombing. Fantasy ? Who knows?

webTitle: Austria demands end to sanctions over Haider affair

fields.headline: Austria demands end to sanctions over Haider affair
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austria's controversial new government mounted a brisk counter-offensive in the heart of Europe yesterday, insisting it was not represented by the far-right leader, Jörg Haider.
fields.body:
Austria's controversial new government mounted a brisk counter-offensive in the heart of Europe yesterday, insisting it was not represented by the far-right leader, Jörg Haider.

Benita Ferrero-Waldner, the foreign minister under the new chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, demanded that the 14 other European Union member states drop bilateral sanctions and resume "business as usual" with Austria.

Mrs Ferrero-Waldner - a member of Mr Schüssel's conservative People's party - told a packed press conference in Brussels that Mr Haider was not in power and should not be demonised.

"I trust the people of Europe will listen to those who are entitled to speak for Austria and not to the word of a Carinthian governor," she said, urging partner countries to "leave Haider where he is".

At the same time Mr Haider announced he had abandoned plans to attend a meeting of the EU's committee of the regions in Brussels which is scheduled for tomorrow.

Mrs Ferrero-Waldner admitted that Austria had failed to isolate the Freedom party and therefore had to "convince them to share responsibility and bring them back on a pro-European path".

However, she added: "The Austrians are European patriots who need the European Union. And the union needs Austria."

There were signs that her robust approach had paid off when none of her fellow ministers walked out of the lunch at which she gave her address - unlike last Friday's EU social affairs ministerial meeting in Lisbon, when the Belgian and French delegates walked out during a speech by a minister who is a member of Mr Haider's party.

 EU foreign ministers have agreed to a temporary lifting of a ban on flights to Serbia, but will tighten financial sanctions designed to prevent the Yugoslav government from moving large amounts of cash through banks abroad.

The list of people close to the regime who are banned from obtaining visas to the west will also be increased from its current 600 names to some 800. Britain and the Netherlands, with US support, had resisted pressure for lifting of the flight ban unless other sanctions were tightened.

webTitle: Haider's success should not infect our political system

fields.headline: Haider's success should not infect our political system
fields.standfirst:
Our dealings with asylum seekers must avoid tabloid hysteria

The Austrian far right in power: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The demonising of Jörg Haider is something the British find hard to understand. He leads, after all, a democratic party. It got enough votes in a fair election to become a player in a coalition government. Why not wait until the Freedom party does something intolerable, before making its mere presence in the government of Austria a cause for ostracism? When the Austrian foreign minister met her peer-group in Brussels yesterday she was, at least, listened to. Having made their point, perhaps European leaders are prepared to put her on parole.
fields.body:
The demonising of Jörg Haider is something the British find hard to understand. He leads, after all, a democratic party. It got enough votes in a fair election to become a player in a coalition government. Why not wait until the Freedom party does something intolerable, before making its mere presence in the government of Austria a cause for ostracism? When the Austrian foreign minister met her peer-group in Brussels yesterday she was, at least, listened to. Having made their point, perhaps European leaders are prepared to put her on parole.

But the British were slow off the mark. For two days, they appeared more fastidious towards Austrian voters than European values. Though Robin Cook gets irritable with anyone who asks him questions about this, and has now placed himself in the European mainstream, the early hesitation was noted. It was specifically British - and in the wrong sense. Here is a case where, if one looks at the Haider problem in the round, this country has the opportunity, indeed duty, not to be a reluctant follower but a certain kind of leader.

This is not the obvious place from which to take Jörg Haider seriously, or understand why others do so. For Britain is not threatened by a party like Haider's. To many Brits, the reaction against him looks like another example of the EU over-reaching in pursuit of dubious uniformity. Who will be next, even respectable BBC voices inquire, in the Euro-purge of political incorrectness? Might Portillo follow, where Haider fell?

But to Belgium, Haider is a real and immediate threat. The Flemish separatist party, Vlaams Blok, pursues the same racist, anti-immigrant agenda as the Austrian Freedom party, but has so far been studiously excluded from power both in the nation and the cities. The VB is homing in on Antwerp in October's municipal elections, having been kept out for six years by a coalition of the orthodox left and right. In other words, neo-fascism - and there's no doubt that the Haider programme, however smarmily dressed up, deserves the epithet - is seen in Belgium for what it is, and the other parties have treated it as the prime enemy against which they must organise their country's politics.

Another place where Haiderism is more than academic is France. In the 1998 elections, the National Front made gains which put it in line for a role in coalitions. In three of the 22 regions, it is part of government, thanks to breakaway centre-rightists. But the official parties of the right have denounced the NF unequivocally. President Chirac's RPR forbade any coalitions, and the UDF did the same. Like Vlaams Blok, the Front attacks immigrants and favours blood-purity tests for family allowances, along with a host of other extreme racist positions. Both parties take jubilant comfort in the legitimation Jörg Haider has received from the Austrian political establishment. So it is as much to defend their own political stability as to advance pan-Europeanism that France and Belgium are trying to fix a cordon sanitaire around him. For them this is no small or theoretical question.

Having a different history and different politics, Britain has different preoccupations. Yet we face similar social issues, in particular migration in all its forms. The seeds of Haider's appeal lie in the stoked-up fears he excites about Austria's identity and Austrians' jobs being destroyed by foreigners. It's a potent line, difficult to contest at the same demagogic level. But the same line is now being pumped out in Britain. The country happens to have the opportunity to test its vaunted political system against the weakness that allowed the Blok, the Front and Herr Haider to advance.

We can see Haideresque language in the reaction of many British newspapers to the Afghan asylum hijacking. There are the same metaphors of swamping, the same recklessness with facts, the same populist terror, the same impression of a country that's a soft touch for invaders of every bloodsucking kind: Austria from its exposed borders, Britain from its allegedly lenient immigration laws. The world, we've been told for a week, is full of hijackers with immigrant cargo and a global intelligence service homing in on Stansted. Where will it all end, unless Jack Straw makes good his promise to send every manjack of them home to Afghanistan?

These are not easy decisions for the British government. Hijacking cannot be allowed to become the new weapon of asylum-busting. On the other hand, we have international obligations, and a plain moral duty not simply to return, unverified, every unwilling Afghan citizen to the brutal mercies of the Taliban. If asylum has serious origins, Afghanistan is prominent among them, as is shown by its position at the top of the global list of regimes people are trying to get away from, and the fact that of 805 applications from Afghanis in Britain adjudicated in the first half of 1999, 800 were accepted.

As Straw addresses the choices, however, it's becoming more common to hear Haiderism brought into play. On this view, Haider is a caution to us all, and the best way to avoid the contagion is for Britain to toughen is own immigration and asylum regime. Such is the high moral ground on which our domestic xenophobia can be heard coming to rest. To draw a line in the channel, beyond which neo-fascism shall not pass, it's the solemn task of government to harden its line against refugees and send them back the other way.

If this turns out to be the lesson Britain takes from Haider, it will be a shameful one. It's not only inhumane, it would repudiate the kind of lead that Britain is uniquely placed to give. For Britain, unlike Denmark and Italy, as well as France and Belgium, faces no political turmoil from fragments of the alienated masses. It has no party of the extreme right, nor an electoral system capable of producing one. This luxury, blinding them to the broader perspective, may have induced some politicians to underestimate what Haider means for Europe. But it should also be a liberation. The government is reluctant to unleash a referendum that might bring electoral reform. If so, at least let's get the benefits from the rotten old existing system, one of which is not having to watch the fascist threat coming up behind.

Britain is under less asylum pressure than most other European countries. Its immigration laws, contrary to almost everything you read in most newspapers or hear implied on television, make it an unattractive place for migrants to try their chances. Its political structures are strong. Bent on dividing the EU, Haider has already claimed an affinity with Tony Blair. This falsehood can be flicked aside. But it will be more easily done if we are as clear as every country facing greater threats than we do: that there is no place for Haiderism in the undivided European house.

webTitle: Commons committee to question MI6 about Gadafy assassination plot

fields.headline: Commons committee to question MI6 about Gadafy assassination plot
fields.standfirst: Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: Parliament's intelligence and security committee is to question MI6 on what it knew about a plot to assassinate Colonel Muammar Gadafy, the Libyan leader, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Parliament's intelligence and security committee is to question MI6 on what it knew about a plot to assassinate Colonel Muammar Gadafy, the Libyan leader, the Guardian has learned.

The cross-party committee, chaired by Tom King, the former Conservative cabinet minister, is expected at a private meeting today to agree to ask MI6 whether ministers were told about the plot, details of which are contained in a secret British intelligence report placed on the internet.

In a separate development Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, yesterday tabled a series of questions to Robin Cook about the affair. He asked the foreign secretary to set up an inquiry into allegations that MI6 knew of the assassination plot.

The parliamentary committee - which hitherto has accepted MI6 and MI5 assurances that claims about British involvement in the plot were baseless - is concerned about the implications of the intelligence report. Headed "UK eyes alpha" and distributed widely in Whitehall, it says MI6 was told by "a delicate source" about the plot two months before it took place in February 1996.

Allegations about MI6 involvement in the plot were first made by David Shayler, the former MI5 agent, two years ago. He will not be able to give evidence, at least not in person, since he is likely to be arrested under the official secrets act if he returns to Britain from Paris.

Mr Cook told the BBC yesterday that he was "absolutely satisfied that the previous foreign secretary [Sir Malcolm Rifkind] did not authorise an assassination attempt, that [MI6] has never put forward such a proposal for an assassination attempt and in my time in office I have never seen any evidence that [MI6] is interested in such an escapade".

webTitle: Prospectors hunt human gene clues in New World

fields.headline: Prospectors hunt human gene clues in New World
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Centuries after waves of emigrants sailed from the British Isles in search of the riches of the New World, a British biotechnology firm is crossing the Atlantic to prospect for treasure too small to be seen with the naked eye: human genes.
fields.body:
Centuries after waves of emigrants sailed from the British Isles in search of the riches of the New World, a British biotechnology firm is crossing the Atlantic to prospect for treasure too small to be seen with the naked eye: human genes.

The Cambridge-based biotech company Gemini Holdings announced yesterday that it was forming a multi-million-pound joint venture with a group of doctors in Newfoundland to hunt in the province's unique gene pool for the elusive mutant genes which cause illnesses.

Because the bulk of the Newfoundland's 550,000 citizens are descended from just 25,000 English, Scottish and Irish settlers who colonised the province between the 17th and 19th centuries, they are genetically much more similar than the inhabitants of big communities with diverse origins, such as 21st century Britain.

The more similar a group of people's genes are, the more the differences stick out, making it easier for researchers to spot the subtle mutations which could be the cause of diseases such as cancer or Alzheimer's.

It remains to be seen how news of the project will play in greater Canada, where Newfies are already popularly regarded as having lived too long together in remote isolation.

"I think 'inbred population' is a recognised genetic term," said Howard Christley, Gemini's clinical director. "I'm not sure whether it's politically correct."

So far the best known case of large scale gene prospecting is in Iceland, where a local firm, deCode Genetics has - with parliamentary consent, and majority public support - won the exclusive right to put the medical records and scrupulously maintained family trees of the entire population of 250,000 into a giant genetic database.

Even more than the Newfies, the Icelanders are genetically similar, mostly tracing their ancestry back to the small groups of Norse settlers who colonised the island at the turn of the last millennium.

That project has raised questions both about patient confidentiality and potential "ownership" of naturally occurring human genes.

If commercial gene prospectors isolate genes responsible for illnesses, their first step, even as they publish their findings in scientific journals, is to patent the gene in order to make commercial use of it. Non-profit researchers now do the same thing, ostensibly to keep the gene in the public domain.

The Newfoundland project is on a smaller scale than the Icelandic effort. To be known as Newfound Genomics, it brings Gemini together with a consortium called Lineage Biomedical, set up by Newfoundland doctors.

The doctors will recruit families with a high proportion of sufferers from diseases common in the province such as psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis and diabetes. Gemini will use its genetic data-processing expertise, gained working on thousands of sets of non-identical twins, to identify genes in the patients which differ from those in healthy Newfies.

As in Iceland, family trees will help show how genetic diseases are transmitted from generation to generation. But unlike in Iceland, Newfound Genomics will not have access to the medical records of everyone in the province.

The researchers aim to develop drug or gene therapies to counter the effect of the isolated genes - a boon for mankind and a rich prize for the firms which find the genes.

Dr Christley said his company was focusing on gene discovery and would leave it up to the big drug companies to create treatments.

Newfoundland, old stereotypes

Population 560,000

Size 156,185 sq miles

Capital St John's

Economy Canada's poorest province, with lowest per capita income and highest unemployment

Culture Resentment at perception of Newfies as congenital idiots, and hence the butt of national humour, fuels self-expression through songs, plays and film. The Rock, as it is known, was the setting for E Annie Proulx's novel The Shipping News

Moose 7,700 live in the Gros Morne national park, a world heritage site, a land of fjords, glacial lakes, marshes, bogs, and alpine plateaux

Sex Bad weather, isolation, a close-knit community, and a lack of multi-screen cinemas conspire to make Newfies Canada's most enthusiastic copulators. Surveys show that 69% are sexually active, 10 points ahead of the national average

fields.headline: Russia's third man
fields.standfirst:
Vladimir Putin comes in from the cold

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Who is Vladimir Putin? If you have any information, the CIA among others would like to know. As the March 26 elections approach, western governments and their intelligence agencies are scrambling to define the new Russia's third man. Mikhail Gorbachev: bold reformer. Boris Yeltsin: ally of the west. But Mr Putin, who stands poised to win a four-year presidential term? Hawk or dove? Friend or foe? The files at Langley and Vauxhall Cross are worryingly thin.
fields.body:
Who is Vladimir Putin? If you have any information, the CIA among others would like to know. As the March 26 elections approach, western governments and their intelligence agencies are scrambling to define the new Russia's third man. Mikhail Gorbachev: bold reformer. Boris Yeltsin: ally of the west. But Mr Putin, who stands poised to win a four-year presidential term? Hawk or dove? Friend or foe? The files at Langley and Vauxhall Cross are worryingly thin.

Secretary of state Madeleine Albright went to Moscow for a look-see earlier this month and declared Mr Putin a man the US could do business with - probably. But she may have been out-foxed by Beria's lineal successor. Robin Cook will make his own case study when he pays a personal call next week. But Mr Putin has many faces, not all of them smiling. A clear profile of the Kremlin's new Harry Lime is unlikely to emerge until well after he takes power. Which worries the manhole-watchers no end.

A few facts are known. V. Putin, born 1952, studies law in Leningrad, joins the KGB in the early '70s. He spends several years in Erich Honecker's East Germany where his job, reportedly, is to recruit and run agents against the west. Later he becomes an "aide" to Anatoly Sobchak, pro-Yeltsin mayor of St Petersburg. In foreign intelligence for 17 years, he rises to the modest rank of lieutenant-colonel. Even during the 1991 coup attempt and the turbulent early post-Soviet years, he makes no unambiguous political commitments. He remains a backroom boy, an undercover man. In the mid-'90s, he disappears altogether. And then something surprising happens. Emerging on the Kremlin's security staff, he suddenly pops up - those manhole covers again - as boss of the FSB (the reorganised KGB) in 1998. In August, 1999, he is Mr Yeltsin's dark-horse choice as prime minister. Then comes the biggest shock of all. Less than six months later, Mr Yeltsin quits early and mysteriously, and he is named acting president and heir apparent. Russians and Russia-watchers unite in asking: how could this happen? Surely, it is argued, his ruthless prosecution of the Chechnya war cannot alone explain this extraordinary rise. The key question, covertly asked, is no longer "who is Vladimir Putin?" but rather "what does Vladimir Putin know?"

From his earliest KGB days, Mr Putin's job seems to have involved spying on his own side as much as on the west. In Dresden, according to published accounts, he worked with Honecker's Stasi in keeping tabs on reformers. In 1987 the East German security apparatus awarded him a medal of thanks. After the wall fell, Mr Putin followed the tide but appears to have maintained close ties to the security services (which he had ostensibly left around 1991). As in the past, his strengths seem to be toughness, discretion and, like Yuri Andropov before him, his sources of information. As the March 26 elections approach, western governments and their intelligence agencies are scrambling to define the new Russia's third man. Mikhail Gorbachev: bold reformer. Boris Yeltsin: ally of the west. But Mr Putin, who stands poised to win a four-year presidential term? Hawk or dove? Friend or foe? The files at Langley and Vauxhall Cross are worryingly thin. Secretary of state Madeleine Albright went to Moscow for a look-see earlier this month and declared Mr Putin a man the US could do business with - probably. But she may have been out-foxed by Beria's lineal successor. Robin Cook will make his own case study when he pays a personal call next week. But Mr Putin has many faces, not all of them smiling. A clear profile of the Kremlin's new Harry Lime is unlikely to emerge until well after he takes power. Which worries the manhole-watchers no end. A few facts are known. V. Putin, born 1952, studies law in Leningrad, joins the KGB in the early '70s. He spends several years in Erich Honecker's East Germany where his job, reportedly, is to recruit and run agents against the west. fields.headline: Freeing the internet
fields.standfirst:
Unmetered calls would promote use

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The main reason the US is so far ahead of the rest of the world in internet usage is that they have flat-rate telephone calls. Users pay a monthly rental then surf as long as they like. Because they don't feel they are "on the clock" with charges mounting up all the time they spend much more time learning, chatting and visiting e-commerce sites. A report by Durlacher this week claims that the UK internet economy is being "dramatically held back" by the absence of unmetered calls. The research shows that average residential users could triple their use from 130 to 386 hours per year if unmetered access were introduced.
fields.body:
The main reason the US is so far ahead of the rest of the world in internet usage is that they have flat-rate telephone calls. Users pay a monthly rental then surf as long as they like. Because they don't feel they are "on the clock" with charges mounting up all the time they spend much more time learning, chatting and visiting e-commerce sites. A report by Durlacher this week claims that the UK internet economy is being "dramatically held back" by the absence of unmetered calls. The research shows that average residential users could triple their use from 130 to 386 hours per year if unmetered access were introduced.

In the US the driving force for cheap access was fierce competition whereas in the UK (and, to be fair, most other countries) domestic telephone monopolies were left largely unaffected by privatisation. It was never in their interest to risk something that might dent their revenues. But now the market is changing fast as BT faces new competition from cable companies. In the domestic market Telewest, the UK's largest cable company, is to introduce unlimited web access for a flat monthly fee of £10 (as long as subscribers make £10 worth of ordinary calls a month). This makes BT's plans (from £6.99p a month for free weekend access to 34.99p for unlimited access all the time) look expensive.

In the business market, the American company Metromedia Fibre Network is laying high capacity fibre-optic cables (each hair thread of which can carry 4m phone calls at once) in central London. These will, for the first time, be tariff-free after rental payments. BT argues that, until recently, there wasn't the demand for unlimited access to the web. But in the internet world supply generates its own demand. And in the internet world delays of even a few months can be fatal. In the national and corporate interest BT should introduce affordable unmetered access now. Then it can sit back and watch demand booming.

webTitle: Prescott report challenges Blair on north-south divide

fields.headline: Prescott report challenges Blair on north-south divide
fields.trailText: A housing survey undertaken for John Prescott's department of the environment is set to strongly challenge the prime minister's claim that the north-south divide is a myth.
fields.body:
A housing survey undertaken for John Prescott's department of the environment is set to strongly challenge the prime minister's claim that the north-south divide is a myth.

The findings of the largest survey of housing demand undertaken in England will confirm the existence of a poor north and an increasingly wealthy south.

A week ago Tony Blair angered councillors at Labour's local government conference by attacking leftwingers peddling the "myth" of a prosperous south and a poor north. "It's not true, and it is a false illusion that the answer to the problems of the north is somehow to punish the south," he said.

But the report, produced by housing and planning specialists from Edinburgh's Heriot-Watt university, finds inescapable evidence of a widening gulf.

After examining the housing market throughout the coun try for over a year, it says: "Low demand (for houses) is concentrated in northern England and the contrast between north and south has increased over the recent period."

It says two thirds of an estimated 380,000 council homes blighted by low demand are in the north, while there is little evidence of a similar problem in the south.

The report draws a distinction between low demand for housing and unpopular neighbourhoods, which can occur in London where demand for low cost housing outstrips supply.

Claims of a widening north-south divide, which Downing Street sought to rubbish in a recent report produced for Mr Blair by the cabinet office, will clearly embarrass the prime minister.

With northern backbenchers increasingly uneasy over falling support in the party's core areas, the prime minister last week accused his critics of promoting division and setting north against south.

One official close to the report challenged a central assertion of the prime minister that divisions within regions themselves were wider than any north-south split.

"While that might be true on one level, there are hardly any areas in the south where there is a significant level of low demand for public housing - or abandoned private houses on the scale of the north," he said. "Inescapably, there is a big problem in the north, fuelled by unemployment and people moving away."

Labour backbenchers close to Downing Street appear increasingly concerned that the prime minister's rhetoric is not matched by the reality on the ground.

In a new study flagging up Labour's achievements in the north-east, the Blairite MP for Houghton and Washington, Fraser Kemp, underlines the north-south divide.

He points to lower levels of wealth - and says northern household income is the lowest in the UK and unemployment the highest.

webTitle: Toshiba makes late entry into e-market with £1.4bn investment

fields.headline: Toshiba makes late entry into e-market with £1.4bn investment
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Toshiba, a laggard among Japan's big electronics firms in internet-related services, announced yesterday that it is to invest 250bn yen (£1.44bn) in e-commerce and internet content businesses during the next three years.
fields.body:
Toshiba, a laggard among Japan's big electronics firms in internet-related services, announced yesterday that it is to invest 250bn yen (£1.44bn) in e-commerce and internet content businesses during the next three years.

Toshiba's president, Taizo Nishimuro, said the company would be launching a new business unit, i-Value Creation, on April 1 to develop a range of internet-related services. These are to include leisure, finance, travel, music, video distribution and auctions, to be made available through cellphones and other mobile terminals.

"We see the planned launch of next generation mobile phone service as a great opportunity. We will focus our resources to take full advantage of its potential," Mr Nishimuro told a press conference.

With next generation mobile phone service to be offered in Japan in the spring of 2001, users will be able to surf the internet, check and respond to email, conduct video conferences and make various e-commerce transactions.

Toshiba, one of the world's biggest manufacturers of notebook computers, has lagged behind rivals such as Fujitsu and NEC in developing a strategy for internet business.

Fujitsu and NEC, both of which own large internet service providers, are considered two of Japan's leading internet-related shares.

A HREF="[http://www.sony.com/]" TARGET="_new">Sony, meanwhile, with its large stock of films, games and other content and a clear network strategy, has become one of the stock market's most popular issues.

But Toshiba, while strong in the manufacture of advanced electronics parts, has no such internet-related assets.

News of Toshiba's internet-based assault helped lift its shares 5.6% to ¥924 yesterday, despite a decline in the Tokyo stock market overall.

Mr Nishimuro said Toshiba as a first step will cooperate with Matsui Securities - a pioneer in online share trading in Japan - to provide stock information services to Matsui's customers via cellular phones, portable computers and other mobile devices.

It also aims, he said, to reinforce alliances with existing partners such as AOL-Time Warner and Warner-EMI, which recently announced merger deals.

Toshiba will also strengthen its systems integration and outsourcing services to tap into the fast-growing market in internet-based business to business transactions, Mr Nishimuro said.

Toshiba aims to boost annual revenues from such internet-related services to ¥500bn by 2003 from the current ¥100bn.

Toshiba also plans to put all of its procurement systems online by 2001, hoping to cut annual costs by ¥200bn in 2003 compared with 1999 levels.

Toshiba

Year-end March 1999

Sales: $44.5bn

Year's sales growth : 8.5%

Workforce: 200,000

Toshiba is the world's biggest PC company with about 60% of sales from computers and electronic devices such as semiconductors.

Nearly 75% of its total sales - including industrial components and consumer appliances - are made in Asia. But it has been sluggish to embrace the internet and needs catch up.

webTitle: Mr Murdoch finally takes the leap

fields.headline: Mr Murdoch finally takes the leap
fields.standfirst:
News Corp answers critics

E-finance: special report
News Corporation)
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch yesterday moved to counter critics who have complained that News Corp has been too slow in embracing new media.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch yesterday moved to counter critics who have complained that News Corp has been too slow in embracing new media. Like Bill Gates at Microsoft, Mr Murdoch has found himself outpaced by younger, more nimble rivals who have been quicker to capitalise on the potentially vast opportunity of the internet. Like Mr Gates, News Corp has taken on the appearance of a company desperately hedging its bets by making investments and striking deals wherever it can because the two moguls who were once regarded as visionaries appear to have no real idea of what happens next.

The decision to pool News Corp's satellite television businesses into a single company certainly gives the appearance that Mr Murdoch is thinking bigger and has started by leveraging some of the group's assets.

The argument is that with a single business News Corp would be better placed to build on its international network by doing deals with internet service and content providers that were born thinking global.

Ploughing cash into websites which use existing media brands is the accepted way of old media firms to adopt the new - often without any sense of when they will make any money. This latest move from News Corp gives it control of a potentially lucrative infrastructure for other internet providers to exploit - or thinking bigger without much risk.

Interestingly, Mr Murdoch's big idea draws on the ideas of two inspirational and far-sighted individuals.

The first is science fiction writer Arthur C Clarke, who has long figured in the thinking of the media mogul. It was Mr Clarke who popularised the notion of a global information network created by a world encircled by satellites. The other is Netscape's Jim Clark, who talked of interactive TV as being the way to get into everybody's living room. Time Warner, one of Mr Murdoch's rivals, spent a fortune trying to make the system work. It failed. Mr Murdoch has been warned.

Wake-up.call

Everything about Finelist says heartlands. The midlands-based company is involved in parts distribution for the auto industry, about as traditional as you can get. It is involved in a real business involving real products and employs real people. By any yardstick a firm that employs 7,000 and has a turnover of £400m is an outfit to be reckoned with, and in normal circumstances you would expect that a publicly quoted company like Finelist would attract plenty of interest among investors in the City when it expressed a desire to expand into Europe.

But these are not normal circumstances. Companies which sell motor exhausts and clutches are of little interest to investors obsessed only with the latest internet flotation. As such, Finelist is to be swallowed up by French rival Autodistribution in a private venture capital deal.

Like many other better known companies, from British Airways to Marks & Spencer, Finelist found that its paper simply was not in demand. It was trading at five times earnings at a time when most of the internet start-ups would be on a price to earnings ratio of around 1000:1 - assuming that they actually had any earnings in the first place.

What is happening, both in the City and on Wall Street, is the development of a two tier market, with a handful of internet stocks doing amazingly well and the rest languishing in the doldrums. For much of the stock market, this is already a bear market and has been for some time. The FTSE 100 was off another 2% yesterday.

E-commerce is undoubtedly an important business development, but some of the stock market valuations placed on the dot.com tigers only appear to be sustainable if all 58m of us are to spend 24 hours a day for the rest of our lives surfing the internet and buying books, insurance, air fares and last minute Valentine's day bouquets.

Looking at the stock market it is hard to avoid arriving at the conclusion that investors are gripped by a collective speculative madness which will end in tears when the high-flyers crash into a reality checkpoint.

One look at the balance sheet of Amazon.com - where cash and securities were more than four times current liabilities in June last year but less than current liabilities by December - is an indication of how hard it is going to be for many of the darlings of the stock market to turn good ideas into profits.

It may be tempting for the cheerleaders of the new economy to assume that we will spend all our money with lastminute.com. But in the real world, we spend a lot of money on having the tyres changed on the car, eating out and buying clothes for the kids. Companies involved in selling these products will continue to make decent profits - and sooner or later, the stock market will wake up to that fact.

webTitle: Nokia chooses London for start-up fund

fields.headline: Nokia chooses London for start-up fund
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Nokia, the world's largest supplier of mobile telephones, yesterday chose London as the European headquarters for its venture capital fund, with at least £30m to invest in wireless internet technology.
fields.body:
Nokia, the world's largest supplier of mobile telephones, yesterday chose London as the European headquarters for its venture capital fund, with at least £30m to invest in wireless internet technology.

Martti Malka, a partner of Nokia Ventures, said the company considered itself the first corporate venture capitalist committed to wireless internet investment in Europe.

Nokia Ventures has offices in Helsinki, California and Washington, and has already in vested $50m in 15 start-ups. "We believe Europe is very much up and coming in the wireless internet marketplace," Mr Malka said.

"In the next 12 to 18 months you will see a lot of activity in wireless internet and a lot of venture capitalists coming into this space."

Mr Malka said London was chosen as the European headquarters because of its business networks supporting the venture capital industry and the proliferation of entrepreneurial internet companies seeking finance from the City.

Nokia Ventures also invests in early stage internet ventures, e-commerce and new media sectors and has existing stakes in eVoice, Pogo.com, Confinity and FusionOne.

Its typical investments range up to $5m, depending on the stage of a start-ups development, business model and industry category.

"Nokia Ventures has a hands-on approach to its investments via board membership in the portfolio companies," Mr Malka said. "Our first and foremost objective is to partner with and support en trepreneurs in building successful companies."

 The government said yesterday it had cleared all 13 applicants for third generation mobile telephone licences to bid at an auction in March. British applicants for licences for UMTS, or universal mobile telecoms system, include Orange, Vodafone, BT Cellnet and One2One.

The government has set a total reserve price of £500m for five licences, but the auction is expected to raise £2bn. Telecoms groups have had to put up £50m to join the auction.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: • Enhancement PC maker Dell has offered its first desktop system using a combination of long-awaited memory chips from Intel-based on Rambus technology.
fields.body:
 Enhancement PC maker Dell has offered its first desktop system using a combination of long-awaited memory chips from Intel-based on Rambus technology.

The new OptiPlexGX300 desktop PC features the Intel 820 chipset, which uses Rambus's memory enhancing technology, known as RDRAM, which had been delayed in the autumn after Intel discovered several bugs. The delays caused a headache for Dell, which already had customer demand for personal computers with the powerful Intel 820 chipset.

Club Internet is likely to cost the German telecoms group several million euros and forms part of the company's plan to build up its internet business abroad, according reports in Germany last night.

fields.headline: Focus:  Greenchip
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Greenchip
fields.trailText: Another day, and another technology investment firm signals its intention to come to market. The torrent of money pouring into the net sector shows little sign of abating.
fields.body:
Another day, and another technology investment firm signals its intention to come to market. The torrent of money pouring into the net sector shows little sign of abating.

It seems everyone is involved in the new gold rush. Entrepreneurs, bankers, management consultants, teenagers, celebrities - they are all having a go. Trying to sort the wheat from the chaff is a thankless task.

Yesterday's new arrival was Greenchip, an Ofex-quoted vehicle which said it is looking for an Aim listing. It claims its "mission" is to secure marketing , manufacturing and other licence rights in technologies owned and developed outside Europe and introduce them to the continent. The focus is on the internet and life sciences.

Deal flow is maintained through a strategic alliance with Oceanic Management, a north American technology ventures company.

The Greenchip model is a slightly different one from the traditional investment and incubator offerings and, after taking a glance at the shareholder list, appears a little more fruity than many others.

Almost inevitably Luke Johnson, surely one of the most prolific investors in small internet investment companies, features prominently. Mr Johnson, on behalf of his Intrinsic Value listed investment trust and on his own account, owns around 10%.

John Gunn, former director of British & Commonwealth, holds a further 9%. Arlington Group, another Ofex-listed investment group which counts Kerry Packer's family business, JellyWorks' David Rowland and Mr Johnson among its investors, holds a further 14%.

Gavin Simonds, a former director of UBS and Kleinwort Benson, is to be chairman. Having floated British Steel and Abbey National his role will be to add investment banking expertise.

Shareholders are bullish, management confident and the move away from the lightly regulated Ofex market likely to improve Greenchip's profile. But whether they can deliver value investments in such a volatile area is still unclear.

fields.headline: Sounding out the band
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Site intends to profit by selling preview data to the recording industry
fields.trailText: Oasis, Blur, Pearl Jam and Sheryl Crow will all vouch for the ability of Borderline, a small basement club in London's Soho, to give the careers of aspiring rock bands a kick-start.
fields.body:
Oasis, Blur, Pearl Jam and Sheryl Crow will all vouch for the ability of Borderline, a small basement club in London's Soho, to give the careers of aspiring rock bands a kick-start.

Tonight four teenagers from Derby who make up the punk band Stumble hope to emulate them by taking to the stage in front of an audience heavily populated with record industry executives to perform their catchily named single "How many times do I have to kill you before I die?"

The budding guitar-wreckers' chance has come not because they have been grinding their way around the regional circuit of pubs and clubs but because of their popularity on the internet. Over the past six months Stumble has consistently been one of the most listened to bands on Peoplesound.com, a website that allows users to listen to and download music for free.

Peoplesound.com showcases 3,500 unsigned artists on its site, attracting 60,000 regis tered users and 750,000 visits a month. Surfers use MP3 technology to download the music, a phenomenon which many in the record industry believe will soon make compact discs obsolete.

Ernesto Schmitt, Peoplesound's president and founder, claims that sites such as his could revolutionise the way new bands are signed and listened to. The music industry writes off $5bn (£3.1bn) in unrecoverable investment each year mainly because 95% of debut albums fail, according Boston Consulting Group research.

Mr Schmitt believes that the user data Peoplesound generate could significantly reduce that wastage. "A&R men have an unenviable job trying to choose which bands are going to be a commercial success," he said. "Traditionally they have relied on gut feeling but through Peoplesound an artist's popularity relative to their peer group, the demographics and geographic location of the listeners can all be measured at the click of a button. We hope to become the AC Nielsen [television ratings organisation] of the record industry."

Mr Schmitt hopes that major labels will soon use Peoplesound to test market bands for which they have high hopes. "After a month or so on the site the label will have a fairly clear idea what sort and how many people the artist will appeal to. Then they can decide whether to invest in them. It will be like a nursery school for artists."

Peoplesound is not alone in offering new artists exposure to a global audience on the internet. MP3.com in the United States is the world's largest site with 50,000 artists. Web music, MP3, is so popular that it has overtaken sex as the most commonly entered internet search term.

Peoplesound is Europe's largest site showcasing unsigned talent and is three times bigger than its nearest rival Vitaminic, Mr Schmitt claims. Musicunsigned.com and Popwire.com are smaller rivals.

Mr Schmitt says Peoplesound differentiates itself by filtering out poor quality artist submissions before they are posted on-line. "We get rid of the crap early on. Some sites will post recordings of kids singing in the bath but we have a dedicated team of ex-A&R men deciding which artists will make it onto Peoplesound.

"Songs are categorised by genre but we also have a facility whereby the user can enter the names of the bands he or she likes and we will point them in the direction of acts with similar style and sounds."

Peoplesound has a number of different revenue streams. Providing consumer research data to major labels is potentially one of the most lucrative. The same demographic-rich research can be offered to advertisers. Sales of compilation albums which users put together themselves also account for a significant proportion of revenues.

LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault's internet investment group Europe@web has backed Peoplesound to succeed and Mr Schmitt is looking for strategic investment from some of the Europe's leading internet service providers.

Though revenues are small at the moment and Mr Schmitt is working to make downloading music less confusing and time consuming for new internet users, it would be no surprise if Peoplesound floated in the summer.

By then Stumble could be thrashing its way to the top of the charts.

webTitle: Vodafone gets sporty as it forges net link with BSkyB

fields.headline: Vodafone gets sporty as it forges net link with BSkyB
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Mobile telephone users will be able to download live sports news later this year under a new internet deal between BSkyB and Vodafone that was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Mobile telephone users will be able to download live sports news later this year under a new internet deal between BSkyB and Vodafone that was announced yesterday.

BSkyB, the satellite television broadcaster, said Vodafone customers would be able to gain access to sports results, team news, audio commentaries and statistics.

"Breaking news headlines and audio news summaries could also become available alongside showbiz news, television listings, movie reviews and instant games," officials from the groups said.

The deal is the latest venture outside its core satellite operations by BSkyB, which plans to spend £250m on internet activities and has teamed up with Kingston Communications to deliver pay-TV and multimedia services down telephone lines.

The group is in talks with BT Cellnet, Vodafone's chief British rival, about offering internet services as mobile telephony gears up for a technological step change.

Yesterday Patricia Hewitt, e-commerce minister, said that the two rivals and 11 other applicants had been cleared to bid for third generation mobile telephone licences to provide high-speed internet access at an auction in March.

Ms Hewitt gave the go-ahead for Orange, bought for £20bn last autumn by Mannesmann, to take part, even though it now belongs to Vodafone after the British group's £100bn-plus takeover of the German group. Vodafone plans to demerge or float off Orange - which is now thought to be worth up to £30bn - later this year, probably in June or July.

One2One, which is owned by Deutsche Telekom, will compete in the auction which has attracted many of the world's biggest telecoms groups, such as MCI WorldCom, and is expected to net the treasury up to £2bn.

The five licences on offer have a minimum reserve price of £100m each.

Vodafone, meanwhile, said it planned to float up to a quarter of its Australasian business in June or July, in an effort to reduce its debt after the Mannesmann takeover.

The float, which is one of the biggest in Australia this year, could raise up to A$4.1bn (£1.6bn) if Vodafone opts to sell 25% rather than the 20% it had been expected to offer to the public. Shares in the group fell 16p to close at 329p.

webTitle: Murdoch's satellite plan to join internet goldrush

fields.headline: Murdoch's satellite plan to join internet goldrush
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corporation, is poised to make an aggressive move for a share in the internet goldrush with a plan to offer web services from his network of satellite operations based around the globe.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corporation, is poised to make an aggressive move for a share in the internet goldrush with a plan to offer web services from his network of satellite operations based around the globe.

Mr Murdoch, whose media empire includes the Times and the Hollywood studio that made the film Titanic, is planning to bundle his disparate satellite television assets into a single company with its own listing on the stock market.

City analysts see the restructuring of Mr Murdoch's business as a means of attracting internet partners, such as Yahoo, which could use the network as a way into hundreds of millions of homes. Most analysts expect the chief route for internet access to migrate from the personal computer to the more ubiquitous TVs and mobile phones in the not too distant future.

The assets which will be injected into the new business are made up of 40% of BSkyB in Britain, the whole ownership of pan-Asian network Star TV, and minority stakes in Japan Sky Broadcasting, Italy's Stream, Sky Latin America, Germany's Premiere and Foxtel in Australia. It could be worth more than £20bn.

News Corp has come under criticism for being too slow in moving into the internet market and appeared to have been caught out by the merger in January of its old media rival, Time Warner, with the internet upstart America Online.

Mr Murdoch seems to be betting on satellite as a way of connecting to the internet which can rival "broadband" cable - a system that can handle large amounts of traffic - despite concerns over its ability to cope with two-way traffic such as e-commerce.

A statement from News Corp said the plan, which could see the parent company hanging on to 60% of the satellite business, was "under serious consideration".

A company spokesman added: "This float would create a worldwide digital platform. It would mean the distribution of TV, audio, video and data on a global basis."

He admitted that the announcement of the America Online and Time Warner merger had "given renewed vigour" to the plans but said the group had been working on the project before the deal was disclosed.

In the past 12 months, Mr Murdoch has found himself increasingly taken up with possibilities with the internet. News Corp has set up e-partners and a venture capital fund to invest in web start-ups.

Recently he also met executives of Nokia to discuss means of adapting News Corp content for internet-enabled mobile phones. And he has taken a stake in an Australian mobile phone network which is among the bidders for a licence in the generation of phones in Britain which will receive high-speed internet access and video clips.

The Murdoch media empire, which also includes 20th Century Fox, the film business behind Titanic, the television production house which makes the X-Files, and Harper Collins books, last week poured cold water on suggestions that it may seek a merger partner among the new breed of internet companies.

Media analysts said the latest Murdoch move had merit. One commented: "A lot of internet companies are truly global businesses and to have a more integrated strategy for News Corp's pay-TV assets has a pretty compelling commercial logic.

"This is evidence of Mr Murdoch trying to regroup and get the best out of his resources. News Corp are trying to get back on the front foot and whenever Mr Murdoch puts his mind to something he tends to be fairly committed."

BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball was said to have been astonished by the lack of any clear internet strategy when he arrived last year. He has since announced plans to plough £250m into the development of online businesses using Sky brands.

Although satellite systems can be used to send high "bandwidth" applications, including internet access, the reply from the consumer needs to be sent through fixed telephone wires or cable.

BSkyB last week announced a venture with Hull-based telecoms company Kingston Communications to deploy a technology which upgrades existing copper wires for high bandwidth use without digging up roads.

webTitle: Police in second drug deaths case check records

fields.headline: Police in second drug deaths case check records
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating a second GP over claims of deliberate injections of lethal doses of diamorphine, the drug used by Harold Shipman to kill at least 15 women, began examining medical records yesterday.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating a second GP over claims of deliberate injections of lethal doses of diamorphine, the drug used by Harold Shipman to kill at least 15 women, began examining medical records yesterday.

Officers are checking files on two women who died 10 years ago in Doncaster, South York shire, where a 74-year-old doctor had some 2,500 patients on his list until he retired six years ago. A spokesman for Doncaster health authority said: "We are cooperating with South Yorkshire police."

The checks involve Julia Price and Alice Bell, who died after receiving 15 and 20mg doses of diamorphine, compared with the usual dose of between five and 10mg.

Detective Chief Superintendent Mick Burdis, head of the inquiry, said: "Officers are examining medical and other records to try to establish whether there is any truth in information passed to us by a third party."

The force was alerted by Granada TV two weeks ago, when a caller rang a phone-in discusion on the Good Morning programme about the Shipman affair. The material was not broadcast but staff contacted police after deciding that the caller - who is understood to have been the doctor's wife - was genuine.

Concern about the doctor's actions was raised at the time by relatives of one of the women, prompting an inquiry by the General Medical Council. The GMC imposed conditions on the doctor's use of the drugs but agreed that he could continue practising.

The GP was supported by a petition from 350 patients at the Hollybush medical centre in Edenthorpe, Doncaster. But relatives were upset that no local witnesses were called by the hearing in London and some have remained unhappy with the GMC decision.

South Yorkshire police have already interviewed GMC staff.

fields.headline: Woman in smear errors row
fields.standfirst:
The future of the NHS: special report

Compensation fight for victim failed by three health bodies
fields.trailText: A young woman whose cervical cancer was not spotted in spite of regular smear tests is facing a prolonged and expensive legal battle for compensation because of a dispute as to which of three NHS trusts and health authorities should pay up.
fields.body:
A young woman whose cervical cancer was not spotted in spite of regular smear tests is facing a prolonged and expensive legal battle for compensation because of a dispute as to which of three NHS trusts and health authorities should pay up.

Experts agree that Ruth Tudor was let down by the NHS cervical smear programme. Screeners failed to spot her cancer in 1989, 1991 and 1995. By the time her cancer was finally diagnosed, in 1998, when she was 35 and about to try for a baby, it was very serious. She had to undergo a radical hysterectomy which removed not only her womb but her ovaries.

Forest Healthcare NHS trust has admitted liability for the third smear which was misreported by the cytology lab at Whipps Cross hospital in east London. But instead of agreeing to pay Ms Tudor's compensation, Forest is arguing that the lawyers must decide which of the three bodies responsible for the screening of Ms Tudor's smears - Forest, Redbridge and Waltham Forest health authority or St George's NHS Trust - should foot the bill.

Ms Tudor says that whoever pays, the money will ultimately come from NHS funds, and legal wranglings over responsibilities between the separate firms of solicitors representing the different authorities will increase the bill to the taxpayer.

Forest's case is that the damage had been done by the time its screeners wrongly reported the smear test in 1995 as clear, and that Ms Tudor would have had to have had a hysterectomy even if they had got it right. Its lawyers have told her solicitors that they should pursue Redbridge and Waltham Forest health authority, which was responsible for the lab that misreported the 1991 smear.

Ms Tudor, a tax consultant, said: "They are saying because I can't prove that the cancer wasn't invasive in 1991, it probably was invasive, so although they were negligent in 1995 I'd already suffered the damage so it isn't their problem."

"I decline their invitation to sue another health authority. If I was to do that, it not only leads to my costs increasing but to the legal costs the NHS will have to pay increasing."

The expert employed by Forest to report on Ms Tudor's cancer, John Monaghan, a consultant gynaecological oncologist, says in his report that all three smears showed cancerous changes to the cervix.

Ms Tudor said: "I feel comprehensively let down. I feel cheated because what's hap pening now is that we are being told cervical cancer screening is not 100% reliable. They are saying that we always knew that. But they are re-writing the past."

She says that suing the NHS as a taxpayer feels like "robbing Peter to pay Paul", but she is doing it because "money talks". The NHS needs to see there is a cost attached to negligence, she says.

A spokesman for Forest Healthcare trust said they admitted negligence on the 1995 smear but confirmed they were looking at the role of the other authorities. "The trust has made an admission of a breach of duty regarding the smear in 1995 but as there could be other defendants, we have to await the advice of the NHS litigation authority."

The worst of several scandals over the misreporting of cervical smears by cytology labs was at Kent and Canterbury hospital in the early 1990s. At least eight women died and 30 underwent major surgery because cell changes were not spotted.

Sarah Harman, the solicitor for the Kent and Canterbury victims who is representing Ms Tudor, says it took Forest at least 16 months to admit liability and is impatient at the further delay.
fields.bodyText: A young woman whose cervical cancer was not spotted in spite of regular smear tests is facing a prolonged and expensive legal battle for compensation because of a dispute as to which of three NHS trusts and health authorities should pay up. Experts agree that Ruth Tudor was let down by the NHS cervical smear programme. Screeners failed to spot her cancer in 1989, 1991 and 1995. By the time her cancer was finally diagnosed, in 1998, when she was 35 and about to try for a baby, it was very serious. She had to undergo a radical hysterectomy which removed not only her womb but her ovaries. Forest Healthcare NHS trust has admitted liability for the third smear which was misreported by the cytology lab at Whipps Cross hospital in east London. But instead of agreeing to pay Ms Tudor's compensation, Forest is arguing that the lawyers must decide which of the three bodies responsible for the screening of Ms Tudor's smears - Forest, Redbridge and Waltham Forest health authority or St George's NHS Trust - should foot the bill. Ms Tudor says that whoever pays, the money will ultimately come from NHS funds, and legal wranglings over responsibilities between the separate firms of solicitors representing the different authorities will increase the bill to the taxpayer. Forest's case is that the damage had been done by the time its screeners wrongly reported the smear test in 1995 as clear, and that Ms Tudor would have had to have had a hysterectomy even if they had got it right. Its lawyers have told her solicitors that they should pursue Redbridge and Waltham Forest health authority, which was responsible for the lab that misreported the 1991 smear. Ms Tudor, a tax consultant, said: "They are saying because I can't prove that the cancer wasn't invasive in 1991, it probably was invasive, so although they were negligent in 1995 I'd already suffered the damage so it isn't their problem." "I decline their invitation to sue another health authority. If I was to do that, it not only leads to my costs increasing but to the legal costs the NHS will have to pay increasing." The expert employed by Forest to report on Ms Tudor's cancer, John Monaghan, a consultant gynaecological oncologist, says in his report that all three smears showed cancerous changes to the cervix. Ms Tudor said: "I feel comprehensively let down. I feel cheated because what's hap pening now is that we are being told cervical cancer screening is not 100% reliable. They are saying that we always knew that. But they are re-writing the past." She says that suing the NHS as a taxpayer feels like "robbing Peter to pay Paul", but she is doing it because "money talks". The NHS needs to see there is a cost attached to negligence, she says. A spokesman for Forest Healthcare trust said they admitted negligence on the 1995 smear but confirmed they were looking at the role of the other authorities. "The trust has made an admission of a breach of duty regarding the smear in 1995 but as there could be other defendants, we have to await the advice of the NHS litigation authority." At least eight women died and 30 underwent major surgery because cell changes were not spotted. Sarah Harman, the solicitor for the Kent and Canterbury victims who is representing Ms Tudor, says it took Forest at least 16 months to admit liability and is impatient at the further delay.

webTitle: Court shows mercy to man who faked death in Paddington crash

fields.headline: Court shows mercy to man who faked death in Paddington crash
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: A man walked free from court yesterday after having faked his death in the Paddington rail crash in an attempt to escape his record as a sex offender and begin a new life.
fields.body:
A man walked free from court yesterday after having faked his death in the Paddington rail crash in an attempt to escape his record as a sex offender and begin a new life.

Karl Hackett, 38, a computer graphics worker of Barking in Essex, used a name assumed 10 years ago on leaving prison to phone the Scotland Yard casualty bureau, reporting himself as missing and believed to have been on the train in which 31 people died last October.

At Horseferry Road court in central London he yesterday pleaded guilty to wasting 31 hours of police time, and was given a five-month sentence suspended for two years.

Hackett has two convictions for indecent assault, the second of which, in 1987, resulted in a 12-month jail sentence, following which he assumed a new identity as Lee Simm.

Hackett's lawyer, Michael Ivers, told the court the deception had been "a very desperate and spur of the moment offence" and, pointing to press coverage of the case, said: "By his own very actions, the past has come back to haunt him."

The court heard that the man police knew as Simm maintained his story for a month before they realised he and Hackett were the same. His father and sister had joined families of genuine victims at the memorial service.

Magistrate Geoffrey Breen urged Hackett to seek help for his psychological problems. He had led a hard-working life since prison, said Mr Breen.

"I don't think there is any suggestion he was waiting for a disaster to dispose of his alter ego."
