fields.headline: Of ethics and fertility
fields.trailText: In your interview with Ruth Deech of the human fertilisation and embryology authority (Cracking fertility's ethics code, February 14), there were inaccuracies regarding both myself and my late husband, some of which I found offensive and upsetting.
fields.body:
In your interview with Ruth Deech of the human fertilisation and embryology authority (Cracking fertility's ethics code, February 14), there were inaccuracies regarding both myself and my late husband, some of which I found offensive and upsetting.

Firstly, I've never even spoken to Max Clifford, let alone employed his services to publicise my case. I actually went to great lengths and cost to try to limit publicity with an anonymity order. The details of the case first became public because the HFEA issued a press statement to the BBC several days before the court hearing. I replied in order to balance the authority's view with my side of the argument - as I am forced to do now.

Mrs Deech is correct in that my husband did not know we had been successful in finding a medical expert who was able to try to obtain some of his semen. However he had indicated his wishes in a prior conversation, so I know he would have been pleased.

My husband's sperm was not illegally taken. British law does not cover this point and it was never ruled in my court case. The HFEA stated that they disagreed with it being taken but were not interested in pursuing the fact. Their argument hinged on the fact that it had been illegally stored. There is no law which states that "you don't carry out medical procedures on the dead or unconscious". It is the doctor's duty to act in the best interests of the patient. In previous court cases this has been shown in some instances to cover wider social interests and is not necessarily limited to life-saving measures. If Mrs Deech's statement were correct then what exactly are organ donations or post-mortem operations? I would never have subjected my husband or his body to a procedure I did not know he would agree with.

As for Mrs Deech's fears that the human rights bill could help future Diane Bloods, I can only think that she worries that it may displace some of her own and the authority's power. Why disagree with people seeking rulings and justice based on rights which they already have, if they only had the time and financial resources to take their case to Strasbourg? Often this is impossible after already pursuing an alternative course in domestic courts. Human rights cases are usually individuals versus the state. The current procedure means that some individuals lose their rights by default. The state runs them out of time and money. I would have welcomed the human rights bill being enshrined in UK legislation when my case went to court although, for the record, it had nothing to do with my ultimate victory. We won on my right to seek treatment in another European Union member state. If we had lost in domestic courts we sought reference first to the European court of justice, not the European court of human rights.
Diane Blood
Worksop, Notts

 This is the first time that the UK's new bill of rights has made the headlines, and the whole point of it seems to have been missed. It is highly unlikely that the human rights act will prove to be the "real can of worms" predicted by Lady Warnock. But for the first time we will be able to legally challenge, in our own courts, decisions by public bodies that affect our intimate or private lives on human rights grounds.

It is surely incumbent on newspapers like the Guardian, which have crusaded for individual rights for so long and criticised the "control-freaks" in the government, to explain what the act will do for democracy. While still leaving MPs with the final say on what is in acts of parliament, it will give us all the chance to question authority where now we are powerless to do so. It will make public (and some private) bodies accountable where now they are immune from challenge. And it will introduce a common set of values into our national life, the interpretation of which it will be open to all of us to debate and influence. Introducing a bill of rights is one of the most exciting and significant things this government has done.
Francesca Klug
King's College Law School, London

fields.headline: Yesterday in Parliament
fields.standfirst: Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Robson Green. The TV actor raised his political stock among leftwingers when he attacked Tony Blair's government for being middle of the road and lacking "passion". He said he stayed true to his socialist principles by giving away some of his money. Asked about his new-found millionaire status, Green said: "I distribute a lot of wealth. People call it philanthropy, I call it redistribution."

Bad day

David Logan. He may have been celebrating his selection as Tory parliamentary candidate for Conwy but there was concerned muttering back in the largely Welsh-speaking constituency. Mr Logan may be a farmer - that's good - but he farms in east Sussex and is deputy leader of Wealden district council. Former Tory constituency secretary Elwyn Jones said: "This is a Welsh-speaking constituency, but I am afraid that selection committees have a way of acting that is quite a mystery to me."

Today

Commons: Foreign Office questions. Postal services bill, second reading.Lords: Learning and skills bill, committee.

fields.headline: Love in a cold climate
fields.trailText: Is anyone prepared to defend monogamy? AC Grayling (Love's story, February 12) thinks "family values" are best left for bishops and old maids to advocate (the implication being that no one will take any notice) and scorns the idea of teaching lifelong monogamy in school.
fields.body:
Is anyone prepared to defend monogamy? AC Grayling (Love's story, February 12) thinks "family values" are best left for bishops and old maids to advocate (the implication being that no one will take any notice) and scorns the idea of teaching lifelong monogamy in school.

On the contrary, I think this would would be an excellent school policy in our "walk away from relationships" society which leaves so much distress in its wake. I'm beginning to think those of us who enjoy a monogamous relationship are becoming increasingly rare, or are we just boring and unnewsworthy?
Linda Thorburn
Seahouses, Northumberland
john@jthorburn.freeserve.co.uk

 Where does AC Grayling get the idea that "Christian monogamy" has no place for companionship? Long before Thomas Hardy wrote about companionate marriages, every Church of England wedding has declared that marriage is ordained "for the mutual society, help and comfort that one ought to have of the other, both in prosperity and adversity" (Book of Common Prayer, 1662). That sounds to me like an endorsement of marriage as companionship.
David Leaver
Manchester
liz.leaver@mcmail.com

 AC Grayling departs from his habit of quoting from the Greek dramatist, Euripides, perhaps because some of the plays would not quite fit his thesis. A running theme in Euripides is that ignoring or opposing the instincts of desire and passion can lead to psychological destruction. In the imagery of the plays, the prudishly prurient Pentheus is dismembered by orgiastic revellers and the priggishly chaste Hippolytus is mangled to death under his chariot.
Michael Bulley
Ashford, Kent
michael@ashford.hi-net.co.uk

webTitle: Mickey Fab and the scandal of free shower caps

fields.headline: Mickey Fab and the scandal of free shower caps
fields.standfirst: Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The date: 14 February 1850, and MPs are outraged by the numbers of French Jews who are arriving in Britain, living in our workhouses, and stealing our jobs as chimney sweeps, boot blacks and rat eviscerators.
fields.body:
The date: 14 February 1850, and MPs are outraged by the numbers of French Jews who are arriving in Britain, living in our workhouses, and stealing our jobs as chimney sweeps, boot blacks and rat eviscerators.

One family, the Fabricants, has aroused especial anger, with their peculiar foreign appearance, incomprehensible speech and mysterious hair. "These people have nothing in common with our British way of life!" thundered the MP for Lichfield, Sir Tadcaster Barmcake. "The thought that these - let us not mince words - these Semites could ever rub shoulders with the stout British yeomen of Lichfield is enough to make any decent Englishman's hair fall out!"

Flash forward with me. The Fabricants have stayed and prospered, mainly as disc jockeys and rabbis. One even rose to become MP for the city of Lichfield. Yesterday he joined in home office questions to rail against the treatment being given to the Afghan asylum seekers.

There would be "anger and incredulity" in Lichfield, Mickey said, and that while hospitals and police were being "slashed", the asylum seekers were being "put up in luxury accommodation" - at the Hilton hotel.

"This gives the wrong sort of message: that Britain is a soft touch!"

(Mr Fabricant never met a cliché he didn't love.)

A curious exchange then followed:

Mr Straw: "The electors of Lichfield understand that it is you who is soft."

Mr Fabricant: "Thank you."

No doubt in another century, the new MP for Lichfield, Mr Wakil Ahmed, will be moaning about Inuits who arrive here in their birch bark canoes, scrounging off the welfare system, at a time when many Lichfield folk cannot even afford to buy private jets for their children.

But the Tories are all over the place on asylum seekers. Having failed to do anything useful about the situation, they are now blaming the government for not solving it at a stroke. They can't even decide how the new arrivals should be treated.

While Mickey Fab was furious about their luxury hotel, no doubt featuring complimentary shower caps, shampoo, and minibars stocked with rancid goats' milk, Geoffrey Clifton-Brown was furious about the hostel where they are now staying in his constituency. "The accommodation is pretty spartan, and not suitable for long-term use," he raged.

Guys, guys, please make up your minds! How about something inbetween, such as a Forte Travelodge or Portcullis House, the luxurious yet hideous new office block for MPs? I can think of no better setting for a horde of Afghan warriors. They could trash the place in a day.

Meanwhile, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, was strangely quiet. Usually, against Jack Straw, her body resembles a sack full of furious ferrets. Yesterday, faced once more with a home secretary more hardline than herself, she was overcome by an unaccustomed repose, save for one moment when she suddenly rolled her eyes back in contempt, causing her head to crash back against the bench.

She tried her best to sound angry, but she wasn't really, so it didn't work. As so often, the real opposition came from behind Mr Straw.

Mike Gapes of Ilford South rose to ask a creepy question about the new greater London authority. Apparently this organisation will be so wise, so far-seeing and able to evoke such confidence among the voters and police that crime in the capital will melt away like snow in a wok.

"Ken'll make sure of that!" shouted the Labour rebel Paul Flynn, to the delight of the Tories, who have little to delight them these days.

"I agree with my hon friend," said Mr Straw, causing even more delight. So he added hurriedly, "for Ilford".

Too late. It's been a good month for Mr Flynn, scourge of the Blairite poodles.

fields.headline: Bermondsey's choice
fields.trailText: The suggestion by Chris Jones (Letters, February 14) that Peter Tatchell, in effect, rigged his own selection as candidate at the Bermondsey byelection, is outrageous. I was assistant secretary of the local party at the time and the moment it became clear that Peter intended to put himself forward as a candidate he resigned and I took over as acting secretary. I remember well the dreary paperwork involved!
fields.body:
The suggestion by Chris Jones (Letters, February 14) that Peter Tatchell, in effect, rigged his own selection as candidate at the Bermondsey byelection, is outrageous. I was assistant secretary of the local party at the time and the moment it became clear that Peter intended to put himself forward as a candidate he resigned and I took over as acting secretary. I remember well the dreary paperwork involved!

This was closely followed by an intense scrutiny of the process by regional and national officials of the Labour party. At no time did anyone, even Peter's most outspoken critics, or the two current government ministers who lost out to him at the selection meeting, suggest that there was anything dubious about the selection. At the second selection conference the scrutiny was, as one might imagine, even more obsessive, yet Peter was selected with a much bigger majority.

Of course an internal candidate will enjoy certain advantages in knowing the people, the issues, the patch and every inch of those much-mentioned Bermondsey doorsteps, but I can vouch that the selection process was scrupulously fair in a contest where fairness was in markedly short supply.
Nicholas Murray
London
nicholas.murray@britishlibrary.net

webTitle: Learning to live with a peace of sorts in Ulster

fields.headline: Learning to live with a peace of sorts in Ulster
fields.trailText: Both Peter Preston's article decrying the lack of public outcry over the suspension of Stormont and your leader (February 14) are to be applauded. Tony Blair must shoulder the responsibility for the consequent loss of life if our cities are again blown to smithereens. Why he replaced Mo Mowlem, who did all the spade work for the historic Good Friday agreement, with Peter Mandelson - who cynically conferred the George Cross on a body as thoroughly discredited as the RUC - must be a question which will forever hover over the prime minister.
fields.body:
Both Peter Preston's article decrying the lack of public outcry over the suspension of Stormont and your leader (February 14) are to be applauded. Tony Blair must shoulder the responsibility for the consequent loss of life if our cities are again blown to smithereens. Why he replaced Mo Mowlem, who did all the spade work for the historic Good Friday agreement, with Peter Mandelson - who cynically conferred the George Cross on a body as thoroughly discredited as the RUC - must be a question which will forever hover over the prime minister.

But where are the street demonstrations - like the million Spaniards against ETA - that one would expect from one's English Catholic co-religionists? If we had a cardinal with the leadership qualities of Cardinal Winning we might get them.
Marcus Bessner
Sunbury on Thames, Middx
marcus.bessner@virgin.net

 I find it very difficult to share the guarded optimism conveyed by your leader about Northern Ireland (February 12). Decommissioning has been presented by unionists and the UK government as simply a "technical" problem. However, it is obvious that republicans see it as forcing them to into a position where they would lose the only leverage they have for trying to ensure that the democratic process is centrally concerned with a meaningful search for justice for all the people of Northern Ireland.

Lack of decommissioning thus makes it possible for republicans to enter into the political process as the equals of unionists. To insist on it is to close down the political option and encourage a return to violence. It is not the guns or the bombs per se that matter: it is whether they are seen as the only option.
Alan Waters
Lancaster

 Why can't we accept what we have, a peace of sorts, and live with that for the next 10 or 20 years? Things will look different after several years. I believe the reason we do not is because the unionists do not want it.
M Cox
Oxford
mike@cox-oxford.freeserve.co.uk

 Why don't the IRA follow the example of the British government and sell their arms to some deserving third world country?
John Campbell
Penruddock, Cumbria
john@stoddahfarm.screaming.net

Tony Blair must shoulder the responsibility for the consequent loss of life if our cities are again blown to smithereens. Why he replaced Mo Mowlem, who did all the spade work for the historic Good Friday agreement, with Peter Mandelson - who cynically conferred the George Cross on a body as thoroughly discredited as the RUC - must be a question which will forever hover over the prime minister. But where are the street demonstrations - like the million Spaniards against ETA - that one would expect from one's English Catholic co-religionists? If we had a cardinal with the leadership qualities of Cardinal Winning we might get them. Marcus Bessner Sunbury on Thames, Middx marcus.bessner@virgin.net  I find it very difficult to share the guarded optimism conveyed by your leader about Northern Ireland (February 12). Decommissioning has been presented by unionists and the UK government as simply a "technical" problem. However, it is obvious that republicans see it as forcing them to into a position where they would lose the only leverage they have for trying to ensure that the democratic process is centrally concerned with a meaningful search for justice for all the people of Northern Ireland. Lack of decommissioning thus makes it possible for republicans to enter into the political process as the equals of unionists. To insist on it is to close down the political option and encourage a return to violence. It is not the guns or the bombs per se that matter: it is whether they are seen as the only option. Alan Waters Lancaster  Why can't we accept what we have, a peace of sorts, and live with that for the next 10 or 20 years? Things will look different after several years. I believe the reason we do not is because the unionists do not want it. M Cox Oxford mike@cox-oxford.freeserve.co.uk  Why don't the IRA follow the example of the British government and sell their arms to some deserving third world country? fields.headline: Cook report
fields.trailText: Your headline reports that MPs "hit at weapons exports policy and at secrecy" (February 12). What the select committee said was "the annual reports are a significant breakthrough in open government, and we join in the general welcome afforded them".
fields.body:
Your headline reports that MPs "hit at weapons exports policy and at secrecy" (February 12). What the select committee said was "the annual reports are a significant breakthrough in open government, and we join in the general welcome afforded them".

I am familiar with the modern principle that truth must never stand in the way of the headline. Nonetheless, the Guardian played a creditable part in campaigning for more transparency in arms exports and I don't see that it serves your purpose to deny that transparency has increased rather than, rightly, take some of the credit for its happening.
Robin Cook MP
Foreign secretary

fields.headline: A painful reminder
fields.standfirst: South Africa's press is threatened - again
fields.trailText: As a rule, journalists prefer reporting the news to making it. Yet the press itself is making the headlines in South Africa just now. The editors of the Johannesburg Sunday Times, the Mail and Guardian and two other Cape Town papers have been threatened with jail if they refuse a summons to appear before the country's human rights commission, to face accusations of racism. This is an alarming development. With its ugly echoes of the past, it sends a worrying signal for the future.
fields.body:
As a rule, journalists prefer reporting the news to making it. Yet the press itself is making the headlines in South Africa just now. The editors of the Johannesburg Sunday Times, the Mail and Guardian and two other Cape Town papers have been threatened with jail if they refuse a summons to appear before the country's human rights commission, to face accusations of racism. This is an alarming development. With its ugly echoes of the past, it sends a worrying signal for the future.

First, some full disclosure. The Guardian Media Group, which includes this newspaper, owns a majority share in the Mail and Guardian. But this goes beyond looking after our own. For all journalists, indeed all those who believe that a free press is a prerequisite of a democracy, have cause for concern here. There is something totalitarian about demanding the minutes of editorial meetings, threatening searches of offices, seizures of documents and jail for editors - all because of what they choose to print in their newspapers. And there is something McCarthyite in hauling journalists before a panel asking them, in effect, "Are you now or have you ever been a racist?" This is not the conduct of a new democracy, but a reminder of the worst days of apartheid dictatorship. That fact is underlined by the grim presence on the interrogators' panel of one Leon Wessels, who served as apartheid's deputy minister for law and order. Once he was the cat's paw for racism; now he is the tool of the "anti-racists" - but the methods remain thuggishly similar.

The post-apartheid constitution enshrines freedom of the press as a basic right. But that does not mean our South African colleagues can rest easy. At the last election, the African National Congress fell just one MP short of the two-thirds majority it needs to rewrite the constitution. There are enough persuadable MPs around to close that gap - leaving open the possibility that Nelson Mandela's successor as president, Thabo Mbeki, could tinker with that irritating document any time he chooses. Perhaps he will hold back, not least for fear of the international backlash such a violation of democracy would trigger. But the current vendetta against the South African press, including a paper which fought so hard against apartheid, is a bad omen. It suggests a new regime which is taking a few too many lessons from the old.

fields.headline: My brilliant idea
fields.standfirst: From ladder-free legs to toilet seats that know their place:  Anita Chaudhuri  meets the women inventors flushed with success
fields.trailText: From ladder-free legs to toilet seats that know their place:  Anita Chaudhuri  meets the women inventors flushed with success
fields.body:
What might the world be like if it had been invented entirely by women? Surely it would be an enchanted domain where tights never run, teapots never drip and loo seats bark at men to put them back down where they belong. Actually, this isn't just wishful thinking - these ideas are all winning innovations from the Female Inventor of the Year Award, sponsored by the Patent Office.

The scheme was established two years ago to encourage women to put up their ideas for development. This year there were a record number of entries and a shortlist of 14 life-enhancing inventions, including a "squeeze box" for ensuring popcorn doesn't escape out of its carton when you're snogging in the back row of the stalls; Snappy Sox that stick together so you don't lose them in the wash; and, best of all, a hands-free hairdryer that allows the user to dry her hair upside down without having to hold the wretched thing at the correct angle.

Despite these positive advances, the overall number of female inventors is still minute. For example, there are only 40 female members of the thousand-strong Society of Patentees and Inventors. This is hardly surprising, given that becoming an inventor is not an obvious career choice for women. It sounds way too like being a polar explorer or a team captain on Never Mind The Buzzcocks to deserve serious consideration.

"There's a tendency to think that being an inventor, you have to come up with something earth-shattering," explains Liz Chantree, the 27-year-old inventor of Runaway, a fixative to stop tights from laddering. Eight years and £27,000 after coming up with her idea - "Which is a very simple one" - it looks set to have sales of £6m in its first year.

Laura Grant, who invented the miracle hairdryer, has been less fortunate. "I came up with the idea one morning when I had a bad hangover and was feeling dizzy drying my hair upside down. I'm a singer in a band and that night at a gig, I got the inspiration to design a hairdryer based on a microphone stand. All the major companies have been interested but no one wants to pay to manufacture the idea. One well-known firm showed the design round the factory, then the guy smiled sweetly and told me they had just put the same idea into production. There's no way I can prove whether they've stolen it."

Damini Kumar, 23-year-old inventor of the drip-free teapot, believes that being an inventor is as much about having a sound business plan as coming up with amazing ideas. "When I was five years old, I kept telling everyone I wanted to be an inventor when I grew up. People just laughed but I persisted. After I'd finished a degree in mechanical engineering, I set up my own company so I could negotiate effectively." She believes women make good inventors because it requires both practical and artistic skills. "Take the dripping teapot. That's something that has baffled scientists for years. I invented a small groove in the spout which stops the problem and looks pretty."

But when it comes to services to womenkind, the most inspired idea is surely the talking loo seat. Iris White, 63, won an award two years ago for her "talking potty", a device that trains children in the gentle art of lavatorial etiquette. "It was a great success and I soon realised grown-ups could do with a bit of toilet training, too." The result is a device that clips on to the back of a loo seat and allows its owner to record a brief message. "The seat can detect when someone is approaching and it makes helpful suggestions such as 'Put the seat back down when you've finished, boys' and 'John, if you went to the curry house last night, can you leave the window open as well?' " White has had a lot of support from other female inventors, but has so far failed to find anyone to buy her invention. "No one really wants my idea but maybe people just aren't ready for it yet," she laughs.

She may be right. If she could invent a sensor that identifies whether a man or woman is entering the room, there might be more commercial interest. And if she could see her way to invent a device that compels men to don the rubber gloves a little more often, that would surely be a global business success.

webTitle: Why abortion could swing the US election

fields.headline: Why abortion could swing the US election
fields.standfirst: Ever since it became legal back in 1973, it has been a burning issue in American politics. But never more so than now.  Sharon Krum reports
fields.trailText: Ever since it became legal back in 1973, it has been a burning issue in American politics. But never more so than now.  Sharon Krum reports
fields.body:
Any woman turning on the radio in South Carolina this morning will not be hearing those ubiquitous ads for washing powder, toothpaste or nappies that normally clamour for her vote at the supermarket. Instead, with the next Republican presidential primary on Saturday, local radio has been taken hostage by candidates anxious to redirect her from the aisles of Safeway to the ballot box.

But curiously, what they are selling over the airwaves in their bid to become president isn't the usual troika of tax cuts, education and jobs, but abortion. While Democrats, whose next round of primaries is on March 7, swear black and blue they will protect abortion rights, Republicans promise that if they take the White House, abortion will be abolished.

"If you want a strongly pro-life president, then on February 19, don't support John McCain," exhorts one radio advertisement paid for by the National Right to Life Committee. It ran in both New Hampshire and South Carolina, and will continue to air wherever underdog Senator John McCain campaigns against Texas Governor George W Bush for the Republican nomination.

"I'm going to set a goal that says the unborn ought to be protected in law and welcomed to life. That ought to be a national goal. And the first step is to have a president who values life," Bush states continually.

Ever since primary season began in January, both Democrats Al Gore and Bill Bradley, and Republicans McCain and Bush, have been talking nonstop about their stands on reproductive rights. The question is why. Abortion has never decided the outcome of a primary vote or a federal election. A recent poll found only 14% of Americans want abortion banned. So why the great debate?

"Abortion has become the new litmus test for presidential candidates," explains New York political columnist Danielle Crittenden. "If you declare yourself pro-life, what it means is you are solid on social conservative issues, you respect the family - all these issues the pro-life movement has tied to the abortion issue. And if you declare yourself pro-choice, you are saying you are sound on women's issues. Abortion has become symbolic beyond the actual procedure. It is a way to tell voters what side of the political spectrum you are on."

In an election year in which there are few major issues defining the campaign - the American economy is booming, unemployment and crime are down, dot.com millionaires sprout like poppies - coupled with a ferocious two-man race for each party's nomination (in 1996 Clinton and Dole ran uncontested), abortion is a useful way to divide and conquer the competition.

"The candidates are so indistinguishable on tax cuts and healthcare that they are using abortion as a wedge issue," explains Dr Leslie Wolfe, director of the Center for Women's Policy Studies, a feminist think-tank in Washington DC. "But the real issue is the gender gap. It was the women's vote that put Bill Clinton into office - twice - and all the candidates need women at the polls. So the conservatives are appealing to pro-life women and the democrats are appealing to pro-choice women, hoping the single issue will draw them out on primary day."

Wolfe says it certainly will draw pro-choice women to the ballot box because the next president will in all likelihood appoint up to five new judges to the Supreme Court (a number are due to retire). "Pro-choice women are taking this primary season very seriously because there is a real danger that Roe vs Wade [the 1973 decision legalising abortion] could be reversed if pro-life judges are appointed."

The fact that abortion has come to dominate this primary campaign might have caught some off-guard, but seasoned campaign watchers say they saw it coming. In 1992, after the Supreme court reaffirmed Roe vs Wade, pro-life Republicans, the majority of whom live in the Bible Belt, demanded that their party beef up its commitment to overturning abortion rights.

By 1996, the pro-life wing had organised in an attempt to influence the election agenda. Though small in number, they proved militant and media savvy, and unlike many election voters, they turned out for primaries. This year they continue to agitate and with the campaign now heading South, there are more crucial pro-life votes for the picking. The real problem for Republican candidates in South Carolina on Saturday will be pulling off the trick of appealing to hardcore right-to-lifers who swing primary votes, without alienating voters, the majority of whom are pro-choice, come November.

For John McCain, who in 86 votes in Congress voted 82 times against any abortion funding, this dilemma is acute. Despite his voting record, he now declares himself a pro-lifer who would not, however, overturn Roe vs Wade, because "outlawing abortion would drive women to illegal and dangerous operations".

While dismissed as a sellout by the extreme rightwing, McCain's blatant attempt to appeal to pro-choice conservative and independent women worked. They turned out in their droves to vote for him in New Hampshire and some political observers suggest another upset win in South Carolina on Saturday.

In response to McCain's having a bet each way, Governor Bush has hardened his stance considerably, hoping to secure the pro-life votes McCain has surrendered. While Bush once said he supported abortion in cases of rape, incest and the life of the mother, he now insists he would overturn Roe and pass a human-life amendment to the Constitution without the three exceptions.

"Bush is appealing to the extreme right wing of the party right now," Crittenden says. "But he could never be that extreme during a general election without alienating voters."

Curiously, the in-fighting is just as aggressive among Democratic candidates, despite both Gore and Bradley promising to protect reproductive rights and veto any legislation that bans late-term abortions. Bradley, who has so far suffered defeats in Iowa, New Hampshire and Delaware, is trailing with female voters and the pressure to lure them and keep his candidacy alive is intense. As he and Gore differ on so little else, Bradley has settled on abortion to sabotage Gore's nomination chances. Seizing on Gore's voting record during 1977-1984, when he opposed federal funding for abortions, and an old letter in which Gore said: "Abortion is arguably the taking of a human life," Bradley has hammered the vice president in South Carolina, damaging his credibility with pro-choice women.

Gore, who says he would "no longer use that phrasing today", is furious that Bradley is insinuating that he is simply trawling for votes. "For far too long, some politicians have been willing to play with the issue of choice for their own personal political ambition," Gore said last week at a fund-raiser organised by women activists. "So I say to Senator Bradley, stop trying to divide us on the issue of choice. It's time to join hands and fight the real enemy in the Republican party." But Bradley, having found Gore's weak spot, just keeps pressing it.

"The struggle between Bradley and Gore is ridiculous because they are both as pro-choice as politicians get," Wolfe says. "The good thing is that, come November, this issue will not loom so large because we will have one clear pro-choice and one pro-life candidate, and they can move on to other issues."

On Saturday, South Carolinians will decide whether they want Bush or McCain to be their next president. While McCain is being touted to women as the lesser of two evils in the abortion debate, Wolfe is not so sure. "What would be worse for women, McCain or Bush? The answer is both of them. McCain's voting record is very anti-women, he is not a supporter of reproductive rights, and Bush will roll back Roe vs Wade. If we are going to protect a woman's right to choose, the only answer is a Democratic candidate."

As he and Gore differ on so little else, Bradley has settled on abortion to sabotage Gore's nomination chances. Seizing on Gore's voting record during 1977-1984, when he opposed federal funding for abortions, and an old letter in which Gore said: "Abortion is arguably the taking of a human life," Bradley has hammered the vice president in South Carolina, damaging his credibility with pro-choice women. Gore, who says he would "no longer use that phrasing today", is furious that Bradley is insinuating that he is simply trawling for votes. "For far too long, some politicians have been willing to play with the issue of choice for their own personal political ambition," Gore said last week at a fund-raiser organised by women activists. "So I say to Senator Bradley, stop trying to divide us on the issue of choice. It's time to join hands and fight the real enemy in the Republican party." But Bradley, having found Gore's weak spot, just keeps pressing it. "The struggle between Bradley and Gore is ridiculous because they are both as pro-choice as politicians get," Wolfe says. "The good thing is that, come November, this issue will not loom so large because we will have one clear pro-choice and one pro-life candidate, and they can move on to other issues." On Saturday, South Carolinians will decide whether they want Bush or McCain to be their next president. While McCain is being touted to women as the lesser of two evils in the abortion debate, Wolfe is not so sure. "What would be worse for women, McCain or Bush? The answer is both of them. McCain's voting record is very anti-women, he is not a supporter of reproductive rights, and Bush will roll back Roe vs Wade. If we are going to protect a woman's right to choose, the only answer is a Democratic candidate."

webTitle: Bush stakes all on South Carolina

fields.headline: Bush stakes all on South Carolina
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: With just four campaign days remaining in which to recapture pole position in the race for the Republican presidential nomination, George W Bush yesterday launched a saturation onslaught against his rival John McCain in South Carolina, which votes in a crucial party primary contest on Saturday.
fields.body:
With just four campaign days remaining in which to recapture pole position in the race for the Republican presidential nomination, George W Bush yesterday launched a saturation onslaught against his rival John McCain in South Carolina, which votes in a crucial party primary contest on Saturday.

Mr Bush has scrapped planned trips this week to campaign for impending primaries in California and Arizona in order to concentrate all his resources on the South Carolina contest, which is now the pivotal event in the battle between the two men. Mr Bush and Mr McCain hold a final televised campaign debate in the state tonight.

As the two candidates traded accusations on the campaign trail again yesterday, new opinion polls showed Mr Bush remains narrowly ahead in the South Carolina race. A Los Angeles Times poll yesterday had Mr Bush leading Mr McCain by 42% to 40%, while a Newsweek survey published on Sunday showed Mr Bush with a 43-40% advantage. But a poll conducted in Michigan, which is holding a primary on February 22, showed voters in the state giving Mr McCain a nine-point lead.

Both sides are battling for support not just among registered South Carolina Republicans but among independents and even Democrats, who are also entitled to register to take part in the Republican contest. Depending on their numbers, these voters could decisively shift the outcome in Mr McCain's favour.

Mr Bush tried yesterday to paint Mr McCain's candidacy as part of an effort by Democrats to shape the Republican race, despite the fact that most of the signs are that the Democratic hierarchy would far rather face Mr Bush in the November election than Mr McCain. For his part, Mr McCain said his appeal among independents and Democrats was proof that he was the more formidable contender.

"I'm very proud that libertarians or vegetarians or anybody would consider supporting me because I have a vision of reform for America that I think is taking hold, not only in South Carolina but all over the country," Mr McCain said.

In the latest spat of an increasingly bitter contest, Mr Bush and Mr McCain clashed yesterday over the issue of public funding of US election campaigns. Mr McCain said that his record of sometimes supporting the issue and sometimes opposing it showed that compromise was "the essence of legislating". But Mr Bush's spokesman said the inconsistency meant that "the Straight Talk Express [Mr McCain's campaign bus] has come to a screeching halt."

Neither camp makes any bones about the fact that the South Carolina primary has become an all-or-nothing political struggle. Both men need to win on Saturday in order to dominate a string of primary contests culminating in the March 7 "Super Tuesday" primaries and caucuses in 16 states. With the stakes so high, both Mr Bush and Mr McCain are pouring every dollar and every ounce of effort into South Carolina this week.

Mr Bush, the governor for Texas, has snapped up all the South Carolina television advertising time previously booked by the conservative publisher Steve Forbes, who withdrew from the Republican race last week.

The Bush campaign is now spending $3m (£1.9m) on television and radio advertising in South Carolina in a period of under three weeks, the same sum that it spent in New Hampshire over several months before Mr Bush's disastrous defeat in the state's primary on February 1.

Voters in South Carolina are being besieged by telephone calls from Bush campaigners. More than 200,000 calls have been made already from a company based in Arizona, Mr McCain's home state.

Another company, based in Houston, is bombarding floating voters in South Carolina with controversial "push polling" questions on Mr Bush's behalf. These calls begin with innocuous questions about whether the voter is intending to participate in the primary, before moving on to more loaded questions critical of Mr McCain.

 The billionaire property tycoon Donald Trump yesterday officially abandoned his possible presidential election run, but did not rule out a future bid for the White House.

His move followed last week's decision by Governor Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, a Trump backer, to leave the Reform party. Mr Trump said he was quitting because the party was "self-destructing".

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: Cucu to Commodore
fields.body:
So it's all over for another year. Not until next Valentine's Day will we be exposed to public declarations of emotion from Blairy to Lambchops, Cucu to Commodore (Times), or enduring exposure to such intimate details as "Jumbo Prawn loves lobster eating petite pomfret always" (Daily Telegraph). Enough already of fluffy teddies, handcuffs and roses slowly suffocating in plastic. What, Sidelines wonders, do Lambchops and co do when they really have something to celebrate? Valentine's Day takes third place in a Mori poll of the 10 sexiest nights of the year. Half of those surveyed said they are more likely to get passionate on their wedding anniversary or the anniversary of their first encounter. So, come on, if you haven't sussed that the cure for VD is in your hands this year, take direct action and shun it next.

 Oh puleez, will Gwyneth Paltrow just get a grip? The actress who blubbed her way through her Oscar acceptance speech tells the Times: "I had this intensely personal moment in front of a billion people... I'd had a very difficult year and I associate the Oscar with a difficult time. And I moved into a new house... and I haven't taken it out of storage. I just don't want to right now." Poor Paltrow, having to bear the strain of a new house, an Oscar and stacks of dosh. Perhaps she should consider early retirement as stress release and give us cinema-goers a break.

 Feeling a bit old, saggy, wrinkly? The face begins ageing at 17 and it's all downhill from there. Or so says the bumph for "facial training", a regime that exercises those parts the gym doesn't reach. Apparently the tongue, jaw, cheeks and lips can all be tightened with a workout. And, er, the "inner and outer nose". Wouldn't a cold have the same effect? And isn't chewing a toffee a lot more fun?

 Mush and slush aside, there is just one good thing about Valentine's Day... the chocolates. Thanks to the "sweeties" who sent the women's page all those soft centres. No nicknames necessary. You know who you are.

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText: 87% back clamp on arms sales
fields.body:
87% back clamp on arms sales

A poll commissioned by Amnesty International, Oxfam and other campaigners has found 87% support among the public for stronger controls by the government on arms sales abroad.

Timed to coincide with the fourth anniversary of the Scott report on the arms to Iraq affair, Gallup interviewed by phone a representative sample of 1,005 adults.

Some 77% agreed that Labour "has not done enough to stop the sale of arms to governments which abuse human rights since coming to power". Kate Allen, director of Amnesty International, said yesterday that the poll showed the public was not going to "let the government get away with continuing to ignore the human consequences of Britain's slack control of its arms traders".

David Bryer, director of Oxfam, said that despite promises made in the wake of the Scott report, British traded arms continued to fall into the wrong hands.

The government was willing to send arms to Indonesia and Pakistan with little or no guarantee that they would not be used to worsen violence, he said. Richard Norton-Taylor

Art criticism 'led to jail rampage'

A prisoner took hostage a teacher who criticised his drawing and threatened to kill him, Luton crown court heard yesterday.

Charles Bronson, 47, barricaded himself in the A wing of Hull prison and towed Phil Danielson around with a skipping rope around his neck while he carried a makeshift spear, it was alleged. He denies false imprisonment, making threats to kill, assault and damaging property between January 31 and February 4 last year.

David McGonigal, prosecuting, said Bronson had cut his head with a broken glass and suffered an electric shock when he pulled a washing machine out of a wall.

At one point Bronson was asked by another prisoner whether he was calm and he replied: "Yes I'm all right, but I'm going to kill him." Later he danced around the A wing, singing songs while tugging his hostage along with a skipping rope.

Mr McGonigal said the episode began after Mr Danielson attended A wing to teach another inmate

He said: "What happened thereafter may have been triggered by a criticism Mr Danielson made about a poster Mr Bronson had drawn. Mr Bronson had in the past drawn cartoons or pictures and he had won prizes.

"He had been asked to draw a poster relating to health and safety issues and in particular the dangers of Aids. When he got wind that Phil Danielson had criticised the poster it was clear Mr Bronson was not very happy."

The case continues today.

Death fall student 'was drunk'

An Oxford university student who fell to his death from a 200ft crane was the promising son of a district councillor, it emerged yesterday.

Kai Dawson, 21, a metallurgy and material science student at St Edmund Hall college, died after what was believed to be a drunken prank went wrong.

Mr Dawson's mother Gitte is a Liberal Democrat councillor for Bathavon South, on Bath and North East Somerset council.

John Hunt, a professor in materials at St Edmund Hall, said: "Kai was a very promising student who coped with his studies with ease while enjoying the other aspects of his life to the full."

Mr Dawson was preparing for his final exams this summer. An Oxford university spokeswoman said he had received an exhibition from his college in recognition of good exam results in his first year.

An Oxford resident called police at midnight on Friday saying he could hear someone on a crane who "sounded drunk". Mr Dawson's body was discovered 15 hours later, in a neighbouring garden.

Thames Valley police said they were investigating the death but it is not being treated as suspicious.

An autopsy was due to be carried out yesterday.

Guardian Unlimited wins award

Guardian Unlimited, the Guardian's network of websites, has won a design award for online news.

The "Eppy", from the American Editor's and Publishers Association, is one of the most prestigious awards in the online world.

News Unlimited was also shortlisted in the best news category, an award won by WashingtonPost.com.

David Rowan, editor of Guardian Unlimited, said: "This is a hugely prestigious award - and one which our design team clearly deserved."

Since the site's inception a year ago, Guardian Unlimited has collected the Pre-press and Publishing award for creative achievement and NetMedia awards for best news design and best entertainment site.

Mail stance kills deal for gay festival

The main gay pride festival has pulled out of a publishing deal with the Daily Mail's parent company, in view of the paper's campaign against proposed abolition of section 28 of the local government act, which bans promotion of homosexuality in schools.

The organisers of the annual Mardi Gras in London had been in talks with Associated Newspapers to produce the festival's magazine.

As the Mail's campaign intensified, Mardi Gras officials became uncomfortable with the proposed deal. An article attacking the moderate gay rights campaigner Angela Mason is thought to have been the deciding factor, and last week the contract was awarded to the publishers of Gay Times.

At the weekend the weekly gay Pink Paper attacked Associated for "hypocrisy" in discussing the deal while its flagship paper was taking such an anti-gay line.

Associated said yesterday its contract publishing division, which would have produced the magazine and two "gay pride" editions of the London Evening Standard's Hot Tickets listings, was separate from its newspapers.

It pointed out that the Mail and the Standard had taken different editorial stances on section 28.

The Mail denies that its campaign is homophobic. Matt Wells

Pub design panel finds little cheer

For the 14th time in the past 15 years, the judges in the Camra real ale pub design awards have failed to find any new pub to which they could bear to award a prize.

The prize had never been presented until the Wharf, the ultra modern pub beside Walsall's new art gallery, took the honour last year.

The judges say the upheaval in recent years, with thousands of pubs changing hands as small traditional pub groups were snapped up by the brewery giants, has led to the construction of fewer new pubs of real design quality.

The judges were equally depressed by the upkeep of venerable pubs: the English Heritage conservation award will not be presented either. "Many of the 1999 entries seemed to equate the concept of conservation with wholesale gutting and the reinvention of history," said Steve Parissien, chairman of the judging panel.

The JD Wetherspoon chain will score a first by having two of its pubs jointly win the pub conversion prize: the Half Moon, a former fringe theatre at Mile End in east London, which was itself originally converted from a derelict chapel, and the Billiard Hall, in West Bromwich, which was originally an exuberant art nouveau billiard and snooker hall.

"We're delighted with ourselves," spokesman Eddie Gershon said. "We've got a bit of a love-hate relationship with Camra."

The judges praised the Half Moon as "a most encouraging and impressive renewal of a building which three years ago seemed to have little future", and admired the striking contrast in the Billiard Hall between the conservation of the exterior and the "strikingly modern language" of the interior.

Cains brewery will take the best pub refurbishment award for the Dispensary in Liverpool which the judges said had "an appalling local reputation" before the Victorian restoration.

Rally victim wanted to be a driver

The young spectator killed in a rallying tragedy at the weekend was described yesterday as a "most lovely boy", who had cheered and waved as his father sped past only moments before another driver went out of control and somersaulted his car into a knot of onlookers.

Marc Taylor, 11, was itching to be a "real rally driver like his dad", according to his primary school headteacher.

An off-duty policeman was credited with saving the life of Marc's eight-year-old cousin Christopher Hymers. He gave first aid to Christopher, who had stopped breathing, until paramedics arrived.

Christopher, from Winlaton, Gateshead, remained on the critical list yesterday with severe head and internal injuries, along with his father Ian, 39, who has broken ribs, and his grandfather, also Ian, 60, who suffered head injuries. Two other spectators were recovering from less serious injuries.

Police are studying amateur video of the tragedy at the annual Apex Cheviot rally on Otterburn army ranges in Northumbria. The driver of the car, Alyn Stockton of Oulston, near Chester-le-Street, county Durham, is to be interviewed by police.

Colin Wilson, of rallying's governing body, the Motor Sports Association, said Mr Stockton had held a competitor's licence for five years. Martin Wainwright

Sale halted by bar on export of old master

The arts minister Alan Howarth yesterday stepped in to stop an erotically charged old master painting from leaving the country, writes Fiachra Gibbons.

François Lemoyne's Diana and Callisto, a work that hits three perennial raw nerves at once - sex, hypocrisy and the plight of single mothers - has been sold to an unnamed foreign buyer for £1.6m. But Mr Howarth said it was of such aesthetic value that time should be allowed for the painting to be saved for the nation.

The small-scale canvas shows shows the goddess Diana stripping and denouncing her handmaiden Callisto, a luckless wench made pregnant by Jupiter, who came to her in the guise of Diana herself.

Lemoyne, a favourite of Louis XV, was a key figure in the decoration of the palace at Versailles and taught Boucher. The only two other Lemoynes in the country are housed in the Wallace Collection, London: Perseus and Andromeda (1723), and Time Saving Truth from Falsehood and Envy (1737). The bar on export holds until August.

webTitle: Crime targets cannot be met, say police

fields.headline: Crime targets cannot be met, say police
fields.standfirst: Straw's scaled-down figures still seen as being too demanding
fields.trailText: Chief police officers last night bridled at the decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to set new targets for the reduction of burglary and car crime over the next five years. "These targets are already in some difficulties," said Sir John Evans, president of the Association of Chief Police Officers.
fields.body:
Chief police officers last night bridled at the decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to set new targets for the reduction of burglary and car crime over the next five years. "These targets are already in some difficulties," said Sir John Evans, president of the Association of Chief Police Officers.

Police fear that inadequate resources will make it difficult to meet the targets in each of the 43 forces in England and Wales even though they have been scaled down since the national figures were first announced by Tony Blair at the Labour conference in 1998.

Sir John said the ability of each force to deliver the targets depended on resources. "There will be one or two chief constables looking at what else they need to do. These targets are demanding and they will not all be met," he said.

Ministers still hope that the original national target to reduce car crime by 30% by 2003 will be met but the new figures now only ask forces to achieve a minimum 10% cut in the rate of car crime or domestic burglary in their area by 2005. Last year there were 1,072,241 reported thefts of cars and from cars, and 464,400 domestic burglaries.

Forces which fail to reach this minimum will not face any direct sanction but ministers hope that a system of inspection of police forces backed by public scrutiny will be an effective pressure.

The inspector of constabulary is to be given power to investigate the 375 police divisions - known as basic command units - over the next three years.

This more rigorous regime is modelled on that used by Ofsted to inspect schools. It will produce benchmark figures for "families of forces" so that effective comparisons can be made. The focus on the mixed performance of police divisions in cutting crime comes as ministers have been warned to expect a continuing upward pressure on the national crime rate in the run-up to the general election and beyond.

The reduction targets published yesterday are an estimate by each force of what they believe they can achieve. They vary from the Nottinghamshire police's ambitious 64% reduction in domestic burglary to the 0% proposed by Suffolk, which says it has more pressing priorities.

The national targets call for a 30% reduction in vehicle crime over the next five years and 26% reduction in domestic burglary. Ministers regard the 10% as a "floor" and 40% as the realistic ceiling. Plans to develop a national indicator for violent crime have run into problems as officials try to devise a measure that does not undermine the campaigns to improve the under-reporting of rape, sex crimes and domestic violence.

Home office ministers instead yesterday published a limited indicator covering the robbery rate in the five areas where the problem is concentrated. The robbery reduction targets range from a 34% fall promised in the West Midlands, to 22% in West Yorkshire, 15% in the Metropolitan area, and a 10% reduction in Merseyside and Greater Manchester. They hope to produce a national target for violent crime next year.

Mr Straw said the criminal justice system was still full of arcane ritual and bogged down in bureaucracy and delay. The public had no means of knowing how their crime rates compared with similar towns and where there seemed to be little link between how much was spent and success at cutting crime.

"If forces deliver on their commitments the result in five years' time will be over 120,000 fewer burglaries a year, over 300,000 fewer vehicle thefts and over 8,000 fewer robberies," he said, launching the scheme with Mr Blair in Newham, east London.

webTitle: Car clock fixer jailed for nine months

fields.headline: Car clock fixer jailed for nine months
fields.trailText: A computer expert who appeared on BBC2's Top Gear to promote a car-clocking device has been jailed for nine months for inciting members of the public to commit offences.
fields.body:
A computer expert who appeared on BBC2's Top Gear to promote a car-clocking device has been jailed for nine months for inciting members of the public to commit offences.

Colin Whittall, 35, from Oxford, was featured on the motoring show in August 1996 with his Dash Master device - a hand-held computer which enabled car mileage to be clocked by changing the odometer reading.

He claimed it could alter readings on expensive cars including BMWs, Jaguars and Mercedes.

The programme was seen by trading standards officials in Shrewsbury who decided to prosecute Whittall.

They raided his company in Telford, Shropshire, but could only find leaflets advertising the Dash Master, which costs between £450 and £750.

Whittall pleaded guilty at Shrewsbury crown court to inciting the public to commit offences under the trade descriptions act and an offence of evading a liability by deception.

Sentencing him, Judge Michael Mander described the Dash Master as a diabolical device which was plainly intended to incite customers to behave illegally.

"Clocking cars is an enormous evil," he said. "One of its consequences is to deprive decent, honest, hardworking people from money they can ill afford.

"If you or anyone else thinks that this court will deal with this offence with anything other than a custodial sentence, you are not living in the real world." He ordered Whittall to pay £6,000 costs.

Peter Moss, prosecuting, told the court: "It is clear he understood that his device could have criminal use." He said Whittall initially developed a system which used a laptop computer to tap into the digital dashboard of a car and alter the odometer reading.

Leaflets at his company's premises claimed: "It is not illegal for us to advertise and sell you this at the moment, but there is a very real possibility this will change due to the media interest. If you don't purchase it soon, the price may go up through the roof."

Whittall's barrister, Mohammed Latif, said in mitigation that the device had a legitimate use. He said it had been developed in conjunction with BMW.

A BBC spokesman said last night: "Far from promoting Mr Whittall's business. Top Gear carried a critical report which made it clear that he was only able to operate as a result of a legal loophole. Presenter Quentin Willson said at the time: 'It is only illegal to sell a clocked car not to physically do the clocking."

fields.headline: Officer fired 'in fear for life'
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A police officer who shot dead an unarmed IRA terrorist suspect during a bungled raid told an inquest yesterday that he believed he was about to be killed when he fired the shots.
fields.body:
A police officer who shot dead an unarmed IRA terrorist suspect during a bungled raid told an inquest yesterday that he believed he was about to be killed when he fired the shots.

Diarmuid O'Neill, 27, was killed during a raid on a hostel in Hammersmith, west London, in September 1996 by the officer identified yesterday by the codename Kilo.

Giving evidence from behind a screen at the inquest at Kingston crown court, Kilo admitted that the raid had gone "badly wrong" but insisted that he was justified in opening fire on Mr O'Neill, who was dressed only in his underpants.

During questioning by Michael Mansfield QC, acting for Mr O'Neill's family, Kilo described what he saw when Mr O'Neill pulled open the door to his room: "His whole body language suggested he was holding a weapon. He was bristling; this was the man who was going to kill me. He was standing in a classic boxer's stance, his hands were down."

Officers had planned to enter the room, where Mr O'Neill and two associates were believed to be staying, with a duplicate key, but when that did not work and a ram failed to break the lock 10 rounds of CS gas were fired into the room.

Kilo, who had left his respirator in a police van because he did not think CS gas would be used, admitted that he could barely see when he fired.

Mr Mansfield said: "Eyes streaming, choking, unable to breathe and with the lobby full of smoke, you see a figure and that's all you see. I suggest you were not in a position to make a decision."

Kilo replied: "No sir, the figure I saw was presenting a serious threat to me. He wasn't reacting to anything I said."

The raid was the culmination of an operation by Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch and the security service against an IRA active service unit.

fields.headline: Valentine divorce for happy couple
fields.trailText: On the day when piglet declares her love for baby bear - and other bizarre terms of endearment - one Manchester couple was last night celebrating a win in an anti-Valentine competition.
fields.body:
On the day when piglet declares her love for baby bear - and other bizarre terms of endearment - one Manchester couple was last night celebrating a win in an anti-Valentine competition.

Ex-childhood sweethearts Kath Rose, 28, and Darren Wilson, 31, won an all-expenses-paid divorce after topping a listeners' poll by a particularly unromantic local radio station. He had explained he could not stand the way she breathed; she had said he hogged the TV zapper and left the lavatory seat up. They agreed love had irreversibly faded and they deserved the divorce and free holidays ("divorce-moons") that came with it.

The pair, who have no children, separated four years ago but could not afford a divorce. Independent radio station K103 will also pay for the couple to jet off to Mexico - with new partners, and to opposite ends of the country.

Ms Rose, an accounts clerk, met Mr Wilson in their home town of Sale, Greater Manchester, when she was 15 and he was 17. Three years later he gave her a ring, and in 1994 they had a large white wedding. Conubial bliss began to fade as soon as the confetti had been thrown.

"I suppose things were okay for six months," said Mr Wilson, "but we just got married too young. It's quite sad really, but I feel ecstatic today."

Ms Rose believed that they should have lived together longer to learn about each other. "I decided to enter the competition but never thought we'd get anywhere," she said. "I thought it would be a giggle."

The pair beat off strong competition by a couple from Gorton in Manchester: the wife complained her husband had a habit of putting on his underpants inside-out so that he could get a second day's wear.

A station spokesman denied any bad taste. "Divorce is a reality," he said. "We are just trying to help one couple get on with the rest of their lives."

fields.headline: Protesters challenge legality of Trident
fields.trailText: More than 180 protesters, including a Euro MP and a member of the Scottish parliament, were arrested yesterday after blockading a naval base which houses Britain's Trident nuclear submarines.
fields.body:
More than 180 protesters, including a Euro MP and a member of the Scottish parliament, were arrested yesterday after blockading a naval base which houses Britain's Trident nuclear submarines.

The activists were among 400 who descended on the Faslane base near Garelochhead in Argyll in an attempt to force fresh legal challenges to the Trident system, including a hearing in the European parliament.

In a court case last year a Scottish sheriff ruled that Trident was illegal under international law and that attempts to disarm it were justified. Three women who had broken into Faslane and smashed equipment were found not guilty of criminal damage.

One of the three, Angela Zelter, 48, was among the first to be arrested in the protest yesterday. The lord advocate, Scotland's senior law officer, has asked the high court to rule on whether the sheriff who acquitted Ms Zelter last year was correct in law.

Others arrested yesterday included the Scottish Socialist MSP Tommy Sheridan and the Green MEP Caroline Lucas, who plans to claim parliamentary immunity, forcing a debate on Trident in the European parliament.

"These weapons are illegal under international law," said Dr Lucas after her arrest for breach of the peace. "I agreed to risk arrest because it is time the government owned up to the fact that its possession of nuclear weapons is illegal."

Dr Lucas said her immunity could be lifted by the European parliament only after a formal debate, at which she would claim she was legally allowed to "disarm" Trident. A spokesman for Mr Sheridan said he would use his arrest to push the Scottish parliament to obstruct the Trident project.

Trident Ploughshares, the group organising the demonstration, the biggest at the base for 15 years, said the two main entrances to the facility had been blocked. A spokeswoman for Strathclyde police said 179 people - 87 women and 92 men - were arrested during the blockade and charged with a variety of minor offences. Three more were arrested by MoD police.

There are four Trident submarines based at Faslane, three of them armed, each with 48 nuclear warheads.

fields.headline: Hitman 'hired to kill rich stepson'
fields.trailText: A woman who bitterly resented the wealth of her stepson and his wife hired a hitman to murder them, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman who bitterly resented the wealth of her stepson and his wife hired a hitman to murder them, a court heard yesterday.

Sylvia Paterson, 54, complained that her husband, Kenneth, handed over a controlling interest in his metal business to his son Paul without informing her. She also blamed her stepson and his wife, Sarah, for a deterioration in her own marriage, Anthony Gee QC, prosecuting, told Manchester crown court.

Paterson, of Wilmslow, Cheshire, is accused of conspiring with John Holmes, 43, a businessman friend, to murder Paul and Sarah Paterson last April.

The prosecution claims that they hired Paul Thurslog, a criminal who also worked as a clown called Banjo, as a hitman. The price agreed was £20,000 for Paul and £20,000 for Sarah.

Paterson and Holmes deny conspiracy to murder and Holmes denies a further charge of attempting to pervert the course of justice.

Mr Gee said Paterson wanted her stepson and his wife, who have two young children, killed when they were celebrating their wedding anniversary.

Paterson allegedly told Thurslog that her stepson had caused a lot of problems and that she wanted him and his wife to go missing. "Their bodies would never be found and after seven years they would be declared dead and the business would go back to Kenneth," Mr Gee said.

"The motive lying behind the conspiracy appears to have been spite or a desire for revenge with the hope of possible financial benefit on the part of Sylvia Paterson. So far as John Holmes was concerned, his motive appears to have been money and greed."

Thurslog, however, had no intention of carrying out the killings, and Holmes and Paterson were arrested after he contacted police.When Paterson and Holmes were arrested, Holmes claimed he had tried to help Thurslog by giving him odd jobs and denied any involvement in a conspiracy. She declined to answer any questions during police interviews, but in a statement prepared through her solicitor said she hired Thurslog to spy on her husband as she suspected he was having an affair.

The court heard that Paterson married her husband, who is in his 70s, in October 1994.

His son had been very close to his father, who had been married for 30 years until his first wife died in 1991. After Kenneth Paterson married Sylvia, the relationship between her and Paul and Sarah Paterson became increasingly acrimonious. In a series of letters and faxes, Sylvia Paterson accused her stepson of trying to break up her marriage. "Your actions have only resulted in bringing us closer together," she wrote. "Your father needs the love I can offer him. You offered him no love at all."

In a reply to his stepmother, Paul Paterson said her behaviour was futile. He wrote: "You seem to forget he has a son and daughter-in-law and grandchildren who love him very much."

Kenneth Paterson transferred half the family business, Park and Paterson, in Marple, Stockport, to his son in 1989.

When his mother died, Paul inherited half his parent's house, valued at more than £250,000. He later moved in to the house with his family when his father moved to a smaller house. He gained control of the business in 1997 in a buy-out, with the other shares being held by his wife and children in trust.

The trial continues today.

webTitle: Rift with Dublin as IRA wins Ahern praise

fields.headline: Rift with Dublin as IRA wins Ahern praise
fields.standfirst: Timing flaw forced direct rule, says Mandelson
fields.trailText: A damaging rift appears to have opened between the British and Irish governments over the IRA's latest initiative on arms decommissioning, with Dublin yesterday insisting in vain that devolution should be reintroduced immediately.
fields.body:
A damaging rift appears to have opened between the British and Irish governments over the IRA's latest initiative on arms decommissioning, with Dublin yesterday insisting in vain that devolution should be reintroduced immediately.

Brian Cowen, Irish foreign affairs minister, made it clear he wanted to avoid a second review of the Good Friday agreement. He wants the focus to be solely on the latest IRA initiative, and the Irish government is keen for David Trimble, Ulster Unionist leader, to have a speedy meeting with John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday sounded a more positive approach to the IRA's move on decommissioning than on Friday night. He then suspended the institutions of self-government after 72 days to avert Mr Trimble's resignation as first minister.

Mr Mandelson accepted the IRA's offer could represent a commitment to decommission. But he told British and Irish MPs in London there was no indication of when it would begin to do so.

He said: "I do not for a moment underestimate the significance of this. If it means what it appears to mean, it may be the first sign that the IRA are, after all, prepared to give up their arms. But in the situation we faced on Friday, it was too unspecific and it came too late.

"Had it come earlier, we could have sought, and possibly received, greater clarity. But, as it was, with the institutions on the point of collapse, I had no choice but to act as I did - as I said I would - under the review provisions of the Good Friday agreement."

General de Chastelain believes he has an IRA commitment to decommission, but no start date.

Mr Trimble conceded that there had been progress. But he said clarity was now essential. "We can see some language in the de Chastelain second report, and we can scratch our heads about what it means. Rather than do that, we would simply say to Gerry Adams it's time for you to say what it is."

Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, dashed Mr Mandelson's hope of quickly restoring relations with Dublin with a ringing endorsement - in an article in the Irish Times - of the IRA's move. He spoke at length to Tony Blair yesterday, during a flurry of telephone calls and meetings.

Mr Ahern wrote: "In effect, what the commission is saying is that it now believes that, for the first time, it has a commitment from the IRA itself that decommissioning will happen. Given where we have been coming from, that is a huge advance and one we must now build on quickly."

Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, said his party had still to decide if it would participate in a second review of the agreement. He doubted whether it could succeed, and accused the government of usurping General de Chastelain's role.

Sinn Fein denies Mr Mandelson's assertion that the IRA move came too late. It said the government knew of the move 12 hours before Mr Mandelson restored direct rule.

"We can see some language in the de Chastelain second report, and we can scratch our heads about what it means. Rather than do that, we would simply say to Gerry Adams it's time for you to say what it is." Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, dashed Mr Mandelson's hope of quickly restoring relations with Dublin with a ringing endorsement - in an article in the Irish Times - of the IRA's move. He spoke at length to Tony Blair yesterday, during a flurry of telephone calls and meetings. Mr Ahern wrote: "In effect, what the commission is saying is that it now believes that, for the first time, it has a commitment from the IRA itself that decommissioning will happen. Given where we have been coming from, that is a huge advance and one we must now build on quickly." Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, said his party had still to decide if it would participate in a second review of the agreement. He doubted whether it could succeed, and accused the government of usurping General de Chastelain's role. Sinn Fein denies Mr Mandelson's assertion that the IRA move came too late. It said the government knew of the move 12 hours before Mr Mandelson restored direct rule.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: July trial set for Woodwards
fields.body:
July trial set for Woodwards

Susan and Gary Woodward go forward to trial in July after yesterday pleaded not guilty at Chester crown court to defrauding their daughter's appeal fund.

The separated couple are jointly charged with furnishing a false invoice for £9,600 for accommodation while Mrs Woodward stayed with the lawyer for Louise Woodward while on trial in Boston in 1997 for killing a baby. Helen Carter

Spacecraft keeps Eros date

A tiny spacecraft kept its St Valentine's date with the asteroid Eros - and at 4pm began waltzing round it, 160m miles from earth.

The craft found a valley on the asteroid that, due to the play of light and shade, seemed to be a heart three miles long. Tim Radford

What's German for Red Bull?

Red Bull, the energy drink, costs a fifth more in the UK because a diabetic warning has to be in English.

Tesco said it could not import cheap cans from Germany or Austria because the warning was in German; it wanted compulsory multi-lingual labels.

Waiter jailed for torching bistro

A French waiter torched the Bistro St Pierre in Haywards Heath, West Sussex, when he was suspended for throwing a slice of garlic bread across the kitchen.

Claude Raude, 28, was yesterday jailed for two and a half years at Lewes crown court after admitting arson.

Spice Girls ruling reserved

Judgment was reserved yesterday in the high court action against the Spice Girls. Geri Halliwell had appeared for the group to contest a claim by Aprilia that its sponsorship contract was broken when she left.

Lancaster's log sold for £500

An internet auction raised £500 for a flight engineer's logbook from the Lancaster thought responsible for the death of Glenn Miller in 1944. Last year, the navigator's log fetched £28,850.

fields.headline: Marchioness survivors hail 'healing' inquiry
fields.standfirst: More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: Survivors and relatives of victims of the Marchioness riverboat disaster last night welcomed the Government's decision to launch a full public inquiry into the incident, saying it would "heal a lot of pain".
fields.body:
Survivors and relatives of victims of the Marchioness riverboat disaster last night welcomed the Government's decision to launch a full public inquiry into the incident, saying it would "heal a lot of pain".

The inquiry, announced yesterday by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, comes more than 10 years after the disaster on the Thames near Southwark, despite an inquest verdict that the 51 victims had been unlawfully killed.

In a Commons statement, Mr Prescott said the inquiry, to be chaired by Lord Justice Clarke, would centre on the collision between the Marchioness and the dredger Bowbelle on August 20 1989 and the search and rescue operation.

A separate non-statutory public inquiry will examine why the hands of 27 victims were cut off to allow fingerprint identification, without the knowledge or consent of relatives.

Mr Prescott told MPs he hoped the investigations would "at last draw a line under an incident which shook the nation and left a legacy of misery and grief" for the families. "A public inquiry cannot bring their loved ones back. But it can, I hope, bring some peace of mind to know that their case can be told and lessons learned."

Shirley Bennett, a campaigner for an inquiry, said she was thrilled by the decision, "although it is not before time. This inquiry will allow us to know what happened on that night."

Malcolm Williams, a survivor, said it "will heal a lot of pain, a lot of hurt and anger. I have waited 10 years to find out why I was left struggling for my life in the water."

Last summer Mr Prescott called in Lord Justice Clarke to conduct a public inquiry into safety on the Thames and to examine whether a further investigation of the circumstances of the Marchioness sinking was required. His interim report was published late last year.

The government has accepted all 44 recommendations in that report. Ten, including the provision of experimental life saving equipment along the Thames and a formal safety assessment on search and rescue facilities, have been implemented and work is under way on the rest.

The inquiry into the removal of victims' hands goes further than the recommendations. Mr Prescott said he was acting in recognition of "the anguish this incident caused".

The judicial inquiry will stop short of an examination of the police investigation, the two inquests and the failure to secure criminal convictions. The final report of the initial Clarke inquiry, published yesterday, argues that the public interest does not require those matters to be covered.

A report by the marine accident investigation branch in the early 1990s said the failure of lookouts on both boats was the immediate cause of the tragedy.

The Bowbelle's skipper, Captain Douglas Henderson, was acquitted of failing to keep a proper lookout after juries twice failed to reach verdicts.
