webTitle: Trainee clergy may have to seek corporate sponsors

fields.headline: Trainee clergy may have to seek corporate sponsors
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Church of England is being warned that it may have to seek corporate sponsorship for students training to become clergy, according to a report prepared for this month's general synod.
fields.body:
The Church of England is being warned that it may have to seek corporate sponsorship for students training to become clergy, according to a report prepared for this month's general synod.

The proposal is one of several suggestions to relieve a cash-flow crisis, including attracting wealthy candidates - probably from abroad - who are able to pay their way through training or co-ordinating funding and amalgamating some courses with the Methodists.

Parishes will have to consider sponsoring individual candidates for ordination, according to the proposals. Although the report does not suggest which corporations might be prepared to pay for vicars in training, the church's working party review group is planning to discuss the option.

Since the church's funding crisis eight years ago when commissioners lost more than £500m through ill-judged property speculation in an attempt to fund clergy wages and pensions, shortfalls in funding for ordinands have been met from central reserves.

The report warns that reserves are now down to £1m - the equivalent of six weeks' expenditure - and that other means must be found to pay for fluctuations in student numbers.

There are currently about 1,450 ordinands in training at 11 colleges, producing 320 stipendiary and 200 non-stipendiary candidates for ordination each year. About three-quarters of the church's £8.5m annual training budget goes in course fees with most of the remainder allocated in allowances. It costs about £10,000 a year to train each student.

The report warns that the church will have to plan for the number of vicars it estimates it will need. Until now the house of bishops has funded all those recommended for training. In future any college exceeding its quota of students is likely to have to find its own funding for them.

Church officials yesterday were anxious to play down the implications of the report, insisting that the problem was caused by an increase in the number of candidates over the past few years.

Philip Mawer, secretary general of the archbishops' council, said: "There is a very strong wish to stick with the notion that when the church calls somebody to ordination, the means will be found to enable them to do so."

webTitle: Synod rails at BBC's religious output

fields.headline: Synod rails at BBC's religious output
fields.standfirst:
The future of the BBC: special report
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC faces criticism from the Church of England for its religious broadcasting, which the church describes as "trite drivel".
fields.body:
The BBC faces criticism from the Church of England for its religious broadcasting, which the church describes as "trite drivel".

A debate critical of the BBC's output, to be held by the church's synod this month, has received so much backing that it will be called instead of a motion about the appointment of women as bishops. More than half the synod has supported the complaints - the greatest number for any motion put forward for more than 10 years.

The complainants claim that the number of hours devoted to religious broadcasting is falling, programmes are getting worse and going out later.

Nigel Holmes, a former radio producer and the synod member who is leading the charge, claimed that one series called the Big End, broadcast last year, was nothing more than trite drivel and accused it and the more recent Heaven and Earth show of displaying "unacceptably low production values and minimal serious religious content".

He claims success already in persuading programme schedulers to move the venerable Songs of Praise programme back to peak viewing hours on Sunday evenings and bringing forward its Everyman documentary series to an hour when most of the audience is still awake. Songs of Praise, on during Sunday teatimes, attracts 5m viewers a week - more than five times the number attending Church of England services the same day.

"There's a Sunday morning programme called Heaven and Earth which is a sort of Richard and Judy show, which in the edition I saw had nothing that could remotely be described as spiritual, even in discussions which would have lent themselves to it," Mr Holmes said.

A briefing document drawn up by Mr Holmes claims that religious output on BBC network radio has fallen by 15% in the past decade and that the average of 156 hours of television a year in the 1980s has now declined to 124 hours, though some of that may be accounted for by the dropping of a repeat of Songs of Praise shown on Monday mornings.

His report said: "The hours of BBC1 and 2 have increased by half within 10 years, so the percentage of output defined by the BBC as religious has fallen from 1.6% to 0.7%. The 6m active and 30m nominal Christians deserve better."

The BBC hit back with Richard Staples, its regional religious affairs correspondent, claiming: "The church would be successful in getting more coverage if they got out and did things in the community. If they are an exclusive club, we will give them as much coverage as we would the local cricket club."

A BBC spokeswoman said: "They wish to have programmes of a Christian nature and are not keen on other programmes which we broadcast for other faith groups or those not turning to established religions. We are trying to accommodate these people too."

Mr Holmes said: "This debate is very well timed with the BBC desperate to increase the amount of money it receives. They cannot afford to alienate millions of viewers. A survey in 1996 showed 80% wanting more religious programmes."

webTitle: Chancellor conjures up a surprise pay rise

fields.headline: Chancellor conjures up a surprise pay rise
fields.standfirst:
Brown's shrewd move on minimum wage shows sensitivity to Labour's core values

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Brown's shrewd move on minimum wage shows sensitivity to Labour's core values
fields.body:
Tomorrow's meeting of the parliamentary Labour party could have been a big problem for Gordon Brown. The normally-docile gathering looked set to urge the government to increase the national minimum wage and to brand the chancellor a hard-hearted skinflint for insisting on economic and financial prudence.

That will no longer be the case. In fact, the audience - give or take a few die-hards - is now likely to be eating out of Mr Brown's hand, after the decision taken by the prime minister, the chancellor, and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, to increase the minimum wage by 10p an hour for adults and 20p an hour for young people.

The decision was classic Brown in three respects. First, it was only taken after weeks of deliberation, during which it was assumed that the chancellor was digging in his heels against an increase. In fact, he wanted reassurance that there would be no adverse effects on employment or inflation from a small rise; something that has now been provided by a treasury study.

Black arts

Second, the timing reflected the chancellor's understanding of the black arts of politics. Announcing a higher minimum wage two days after MPs have demanded it smacks of weakness, of being prodded into doing something against your will. It is not good politics.

Announcing the same decision 24 hours before the meeting sends out a different message altogether.

But there is more to Mr Brown than merely a cautious Whitehall operator. He enjoys a freedom of operation denied to other members - even senior members - of the cabinet, and he has been able to carve out a public image for himself as the minister who delivers on Labour's core values.

The evidence that the chancellor operates by different rules was there even from Labour's first weekend in office, when Mr Brown and his aides arrived at Tony Blair's Islington home to tell the prime minister that they planned to give operational independence to the Bank of England.

Reaction

For all the talk of mutual mistrust and warring camps, Mr Blair's immediate reaction was that if his chancellor thought establishing a monetary policy committee was a good idea, that was fine by him. Similarly, when Mr Brown used a speech to Oxfam earlier this year to announce that Britain would stop arms sales to around 50 countries, he came up with the policy first and consulted with the other ministers involved later.

Somewhat bruised though some of them have been by the chancellor's willingness to treat the whole of domestic policy as his own fiefdom, few would deny that Mr Brown has been the ballast for the Blair government.

The willingness of the chancellor and the international development secretary, Clare Short, to press hard for the write-off of unpayable debts in the world's poorest countries has put some flesh on the bones of the government's ethical foreign policy. And, for all the recent brouhaha about Labour turning its back on its core constituency in favour of the leafy shires of southern England, the three years since the election have seen a hefty slug of redistribution.

Child benefit has been increased, poor pensioners have seen their weekly incomes rise by around £20 a week, money has been pumped into some of Britain's most deprived estates to fund a comprehensive multi-agency approach to regeneration, and the newly-introduced working families tax credit (WFTC) provides a generous top-up to the earnings of the working poor. Mr Brown is fond of quoting the precise increases in weekly incomes for those benefiting from the minimum wage, the WFTC and the new 10p starting rate of income tax.

Critics

Critics of the chancellor argue that it was a betrayal of Labour principles to rule out an increase in both the basic and top rates of tax during this parliament. Mr Brown and his advisers say that even without putting up income tax, they still have another 200 or so revenue raising options at their disposal.

The rich may still be paying marginal tax at 40%, but they have been hit in other ways. After 20 years in which the tax system became more regressive, the main beneficiaries of Labour's tax changes have been those at the bottom.

It is Mr Brown's record of delivering with his nitty-gritty policies that has left his stock high, both inside and outside the party.

When William Hague appointed Michael Portillo to be the opposition treasury spokesman, the spin from central office was that the Conservatives needed their top gun to match the government's heaviest hitter.

Yet Mr Portillo arrives at an awkward time for his party. There will be more money for the poor in the budget, more money for schools and hospitals in the summer.

Economy

The economy has performed well since the election; whatever other problems the prime minister has, they do not include rising unemployment, soaring inflation, a collapsing pound or the arrival in Britain of planeloads of hard men from the International Monetary Fund.

webTitle: Cook to trade veto in fight for EU reform

fields.headline: Cook to trade veto in fight for EU reform
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Britain faces months of potentially bruising battles with its European Union partners in talks launched yesterday aimed at streamlining the EU to avoid paralysis when new members join.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Britain faces months of potentially bruising battles with its European Union partners in talks launched yesterday aimed at streamlining the EU to avoid paralysis when new members join.

Under fire from the Tories for allegedly planning to agree to a "single European superstate", Tony Blair will today pledge an "unwaveringly pro-European" policy as negotiations begin on the nitty-gritty of institutional reform.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, who will formally present the government's position to MPs, said in Brussels last night that Britain's priority was to secure a change in voting weights in the council of ministers when the EU expands to take in up to 13 extra members.

"Without these treaty changes it will be very difficult to proceed with enlargement," Mr Cook warned.

He will set out Britain's negotiating stance in a white paper to be published this afternoon. Britain will seek the reweighting of ministerial council votes to reflect its population: at present a country such as Luxembourg with only 400,000 people has two votes, compared with Britain's 10 for a population of 59m.

The white paper will also confirm that Britain is ready to surrender its veto in several key areas: transport policy, the European court and EU appointments. But Mr Cook will seek to retain the veto for tax matters, defence, social security, border controls, treaties and own resources.

Using the white paper to make a positive case for the EU, the foreign secretary will claim that surrendering the veto in a few instances will benefit Britain by speeding up decision making.

As part of an overall package of reforms, he will also agree to give up one of Britain's two commissioners - currently Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten.

Britain enters these talks - formally an intergovernmental conference (IGC) - more in tune with its EU partners than ever before, though with the crucial exception of its lukewarm attitude towards the single currency.

But it can still expect some hard bargaining from those who seek to remove the national veto over some tax issues. There is also pressure from the European commission president, Romano Prodi, to erode the number of issues on which a unanimous vote is required.

Whitehall is also worried about calls for flexibility, which would allow more integrationist countries to forge ahead with policies of their choice, leaving others behind.

Britain's increasingly lonely position on the euro has boosted concerns about formally permitting a so-called two-speed Europe, even though opt-outs already exist on the single currency, border controls and other issues.

All the proposed changes are highly technical but of huge political sensitivity, and will be codified in a treaty of Nice under the French EU presidency in December.

The three main issues on the table - voting weights, the number of commissioners for each country, and the possible extension of qualified majority voting - were outstanding from the 1997 Amsterdam treaty precisely because they were so difficult to settle.

Reform is urgent if the EU is to function when new members join. The 15 have already launched talks with Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic, Cyprus, Estonia and Slovenia.

Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, Bulgaria and Malta are in a second wave due to join within a few years. Negotiations with them are to be ceremonially launched in Brussels today. Turkey's turn will take longer.

Mr Cook said: "Germany, France and Britain contain the majority of the population of the EU, but they do not have a majority of votes in the council of ministers. After the next enlargement, those three countries will not even have sufficient votes for a blocking minority."

In London the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, launched a pre-emptive strike, claiming: "The IGC is designed to set the stage for a single European superstate. Between now and December ... Labour will try to maintain it is a non-event.

"Labour's cover-up must be blown apart. We have already exposed Labour's plans to scrap the pound as soon as they think they can get away with it. We must now expose how they plan to let Britain slide into a single European superstate by stealth."

Today's commons statement from Mr Cook will coincide with the Tory leader William Hague's launch of his "keep the pound" anti-euro campaign. He plans to talk directly to voters to attack the government's wait and see policy on the single currency.

fields.bodyText: Britain faces months of potentially bruising battles with its European Union partners in talks launched yesterday aimed at streamlining the EU to avoid paralysis when new members join. Under fire from the Tories for allegedly planning to agree to a "single European superstate", Tony Blair will today pledge an "unwaveringly pro-European" policy as negotiations begin on the nitty-gritty of institutional reform. Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, who will formally present the government's position to MPs, said in Brussels last night that Britain's priority was to secure a change in voting weights in the council of ministers when the EU expands to take in up to 13 extra members. "Without these treaty changes it will be very difficult to proceed with enlargement," Mr Cook warned. He will set out Britain's negotiating stance in a white paper to be published this afternoon. Britain will seek the reweighting of ministerial council votes to reflect its population: at present a country such as Luxembourg with only 400,000 people has two votes, compared with Britain's 10 for a population of 59m. The white paper will also confirm that Britain is ready to surrender its veto in several key areas: transport policy, the European court and EU appointments. But Mr Cook will seek to retain the veto for tax matters, defence, social security, border controls, treaties and own resources. Using the white paper to make a positive case for the EU, the foreign secretary will claim that surrendering the veto in a few instances will benefit Britain by speeding up decision making. As part of an overall package of reforms, he will also agree to give up one of Britain's two commissioners - currently Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten. Britain enters these talks - formally an intergovernmental conference (IGC) - more in tune with its EU partners than ever before, though with the crucial exception of its lukewarm attitude towards the single currency. But it can still expect some hard bargaining from those who seek to remove the national veto over some tax issues. There is also pressure from the European commission president, Romano Prodi, to erode the number of issues on which a unanimous vote is required. Whitehall is also worried about calls for flexibility, which would allow more integrationist countries to forge ahead with policies of their choice, leaving others behind. Britain's increasingly lonely position on the euro has boosted concerns about formally permitting a so-called two-speed Europe, even though opt-outs already exist on the single currency, border controls and other issues. All the proposed changes are highly technical but of huge political sensitivity, and will be codified in a treaty of Nice under the French EU presidency in December. The three main issues on the table - voting weights, the number of commissioners for each country, and the possible extension of qualified majority voting - were outstanding from the 1997 Amsterdam treaty precisely because they were so difficult to settle. Reform is urgent if the EU is to function when new members join. The 15 have already launched talks with Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic, Cyprus, Estonia and Slovenia. Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, Bulgaria and Malta are in a second wave due to join within a few years. Negotiations with them are to be ceremonially launched in Brussels today. Turkey's turn will take longer. Mr Cook said: "Germany, France and Britain contain the majority of the population of the EU, but they do not have a majority of votes in the council of ministers. After the next enlargement, those three countries will not even have sufficient votes for a blocking minority." In London the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, launched a pre-emptive strike, claiming: "The IGC is designed to set the stage for a single European superstate. Between now and December ... fields.headline: Strange days
fields.standfirst: It's a big night for Sky One. The Strangerers, its first ever home-grown comedy, hits the nation's screens. How will it fare in television's cut-throat battleground?  Lucy Barrick  talks to its creators
fields.trailText: It's a big night for Sky One. The Strangerers, its first ever home-grown comedy, hits the nation's screens. How will it fare in television's cut-throat battleground? Lucy Barrick talks to its creators
fields.body:
Let's play a little game of word association. We'll start with something easy: Sky One. Got that? Sky One. So what's coming to mind? Bulk-buy American imports(your Friends, Simpsons and X-Files)? The tawdry delights of the various Uncovereds? Surely not Dream Team (you sick puppy)?

OK, let's try it another way: there's a new comedy starting tonight, it's called The Strangerers, it's written by Rob Grant (co-creator of Red Dwarf), it stars Jack Docherty and The Fast Show's Mark Williams, and i's about a pair of vegetable-based lifeforms who make a (very poor) attempt to take over the earth. What channel do you think it's on? BBC 2, bastion of new British comedy for as long as anyone can remember? Or Channel 4, home of everything from Drop The Dead Donkey to Father Ted?

Well, unlikely as it may seem, it's Sky One: that's right, the channel hitherto best known for its commitment to spending wads of cash on the best - and worst - US TV has to offer, has decided to put some serious weight into its own original comedy . Big money deals with the likes of David Baddiel, Harry Enfield and Perrier Award-winner Al Murray suggest Sky is increasingly fond of homegrown comedy - but why? And, perhaps even more importantly, what can they offer in return?

The Strangerers is, as the press release boasts, "Sky One's first original comedy series": as good a place as any to start. Rob Grant, who admits he came up with the initial concept for The Strangerers while "having a pee", claims he "used to be an alien atheist, until I read Arthur C Clarke saying 'either there is life out there or we are the only living things in the universe, and either alternative is equally astonishing'. That changed my mind and set the ball rolling."

That was back in 1995; logically, once the script - complete with new alien language - was written, Grant's first port of call was the BBC (his previous home with the hugely successful Red Dwarf). Except, as Miles Bullough - MD of Absolutely Productions, co-producers of The Strangerers with Grant's own Taken For Granted - explains, the Beeb had "just bought Third Rock From The Sun, which queered that pitch."

Hence the move to Sky - but why not simply take the idea to another, more established, channel? Bullough admits he was "very suspicious" when he heard Sky were looking to do home-grown comedy; at least ntil being won over by what Grant calls their "sheer unremitting enthusiasm". And, yes, James Baker, Head Of Network Programming at Sky, is certainly enthusiastic.

"I think it's absolutely a flagship show", he gushes. "If we're going to be serious about creating original programming, we've got to set down a marker to our intentions. And The Strangerers is a perfect marker."

So far so good. Except it's still not clear what (other than vast sums of money) is in it for the talent? According to Grant, Sky's aforementioned eagerness is in stark contrast with other channels where, he claims "you can often feel invisible". For Docherty, meanwhile - coming off the disappointment of his short-lived Channel 5 chat show - "I'm always interested in doing stuff that hasn't been done before. That said, money is a consideration as well - let's say they've got a decent enough budget!"

Indeed, aside from star salaries, a £300,000 per episode budget, also means The Strangerers could be shot on film, with quality special effects."I'm not trying to be arty about it," remarks Baker, "but if you spend the time and money you build something better." Sky's hands-off approach is, he believes, appealing to the talent largely because "second-guessing the creators is a disease across a lot of television."

Yet something jars about Sky's new identity as a benevolent patron of the arts. Which is probably why the question marks still hover over its investment in original comedy. If we're being cynical about it, it could have more than a little to do with the fact that Friends, one of Sky One's biggest shows, has been pinched by Channel 4 (at the bargain price of $140 million).

Only The Strangerers, and the other British deals, had been in place long before Sky got gazumped. For John Thoday, MD of Avalon (which represents Baddiel and Murray), it's got more to do with the channel simply having "gone as far as it can with football and acquired product".

The effusive Baker freely admits that "if you want people to become emotionally involved with a channel, you've got to provide programming that's relevant to them. We're making Sky more British, more relevant and more recognisable. And The Strangerers is a good way to start doing that." Or, as the slightly more sceptical Docherty laughs, "17

It's true that giving the shows the potential to "travel" is one of the keys to Sky's new comedies: The Strangerers has ten parts, while forthcoming shows will have an internationally standard 13 or 22 episodes, instead of the usual six typical of British sitcoms. This six-part format, Thoday argues, not only prevents shows from being sold abroad, but means they can't even compete on home turf with imports: "The viewer likes to see Friends every week, but then again I'm sure they would have liked to have seen Absolutely Fabulous every week."

"Making six episodes", he continues, "is like making a film so it won't fit in the projector - it's just not going to get shown."

Apart from making their own comedy product more marketable abroad, the general hope seems to be that other broadcasters will follow Sky's lead. For his part, Bullough sees Sky becoming "just another player", on equal footing with terrestrial channels, while Grant describes them as the "new kid on the block coming to put a boot up the backsides of the rest". Thoday, meanwhile, simply knows good business

"A 22-episode sitcom costs about £5 million", he points out. "With the £100 million-odd that Channel 4 spent on Friends you could make 20 original shows, and of those 20, however bad you were at choosing them, you'd probably have a few hits."

Whether or not The Strangerers will be a hit for Sky remains to be seen. But the channel's longterm plan must include luring new customers with its original shows, and a series of 10 gives the show enough time to pull in fresh viewers. Baker envisages the show stirring interest - the masterplan is for people to notice Sky's output "and then go and get it". Yet, as Thoday says, "You can't hide with a long-running sitcom - by the end of the run its either successful or its not. And its the people who watch who decide."

At which point, it's over to you.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Kids Alone 9pm, C4
Rikki, Roxanne, Curtis and Leanda are all in care because their mothers couldn't cope. They are now reaching the age when long-term adoption is a remote chance, but even getting them mentally prepared for fostering is a long and painful process. Rikki, 12, has finally come round to the idea, but sister Roxanne, 11, still pitifully pines for her mother. Ten-year-old Curtis also wouldn't mind being fostered, but his sister Leanda is having problems with their mother's fortnightly visits. This is the grim reality behind the oft-used words "in care", and it makes for uncomfortable yet thought-provoking viewing.

Queer As Folk 2 10pm, C4
The lively and engaging drama returns, but, unfortunately, only for a two-part finale. Vince, at 30, feels he's ready to grow up and act responsibly, but Stuart is still up for partying hard in Manchester's gay area. Yet even he can't fail to notice that the competition is getting younger. The developing "will they, won't they" element between the two best friends certainly steps up a gear, with everyone, bar Stuart, wishing they would just get on with it and settle down together. But Stuart has another problem to deal with, notably a nasty little blackmailer. It might be time to tell his parents about his sexuality.

Black, Bent And Beautiful 11.20pm, C5
While the Queer As Folk boys large it in Canal Street, Trevor Nelson narrates more sobering experiences from a group of gay Londoners who, because they are also black, find life doubly difficult. All four participants readily admit that they get the most grief from their own community. Tariano left his native Jamaica because he feared for his life; his neighbours had a habit of lynching gay men. Rap artist Adeshola Idowu felt she had to leave Nigeria, as homosexuality is illegal there. And Femi desperately wants to be more involved in his church but his sexuality, according to a local pastor, is against the Christian religion.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
Even without Dr Harold Shipman and bungled kidney operations, National Health Service complaints are rising steeply. One of the government's early promises was to improve the cumbersome system of dealing with grievances, making it both independent and effective. But, as Liz Carney reports in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4), there is still a long way to go.

Two outfits woke up to the global power of radio in 1933 - Joseph Goebbels's Deutschlandsender, which pumped out Nazi propaganda, and Radio Luxembourg, which beamed light music, quizzes and jingles to Germany, France and England. Naturally, the BBC hated Luxembourg's English language broadcasts, but not as much as the press lords. They thought it would steal all their advertising. However, as Noel Edmonds (pictured) recalls in The Great 208 - The Story Of Radio Luxembourg (9.0pm, Radio 2), the audience and sponsors absolutely loved it.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Hollywood Conversations 10pm, FilmFour
Lots of interviews promise to bring you The Hidden Side Of, but few are as revealing as this Mike Figgis chat with Sylvester Stallone. It's a bizarre experience to listen to the star of Demolition Man describe a version of Herman Hesse's Siddartha that he wrote at college, wonder how much fun it would be to hang out with Kafka, and mourn for the grittiness of 70s cinema, but slowly you start to believe that this is a side of Sly you really have never seen. Figgis, by pitching up rather than down, has hit upon a great formula.

Northwest Passage (King Vidor, 1940) 9pm, TCM
Riproaring adventure in Last Of The Mohicans style. Spencer Tracy stars as Major Rogers, in the 1760s leading colonial rangers into Canada to fight the savages (not very PC). The battle scenes still rank with the best, as does the Technicolor camerawork of Wagner and Skall; and Vidor maintains a powerful sense of history in the making.

Dr Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (Stanley Kubrick, 1963) 10pm, 3.45am, Sky Cinema
Satirical cold war comedy at its blackest with barking mad General Jack D Ripper (Sterling Hayden) ordering a nuclear strike on the Soviet Union. Peter Sellers plays US President Merlin Muffley, desperately trying to preserve the peace; he also plays loony adviser Strangelove and RAF pilot Lionel Mandrake. George C Scott's manic chief of staff doesn't see what all the fuss is about.

The X Files (Rob Bowman, 1998) 10.10pm, Sky Premier
Bowman, a veteran director of the TV series, dumps agents Mulder (David Duchovny) and Scully (Gillian Anderson), pictured, into a dense but pleasantly familiar plot involving alien bodysnatchers and dodgy characters in smoke-filled rooms. There are impressive special effects and Martin Landau's manic conspiracy theorist stokes up the spooky atmosphere.

fields.headline: It's a crazy idea, but...
fields.trailText: Bill had been in Colditz for three years before he thought of an escape plan. "Throw yourself out of the window. All other methods of escape had been attempted. This seemed much simpler to me. Just stand on the roof and jump off."
fields.body:
Bill had been in Colditz for three years before he thought of an escape plan. "Throw yourself out of the window. All other methods of escape had been attempted. This seemed much simpler to me. Just stand on the roof and jump off."

Escape From Colditz (C4) was full of stir-crazy lunacy. Forced to live in nine square feet with a smell of wet socks, most of them enjoyed it, having served time at public school. Some built cardboard telescopes to look down at the town and spy the German lovelies in their pantyhose. "This was an enormously popular pastime, as the only females we had were the male ones dressed-up."

You don't get resourcefulness like that anymore. David, the Nature Boy (BBC2) could catch a trout with his bare hands, leaving them on the doorstep of the mother who'd abandoned him for smack.

In Colditz, a man who could catch fish would have been put with the man who thought you should jump off the roof, so they could build a gIider together. Unlike today's welfare system, the escape officers knew how to spot a chap's potential, and steer him back to sanity.

To The Ends Of The Earth: The Mystery Of The Missing U-Boat (C4) furthered the Boys' Own theme of the evening, with a search for U869, one of six Nazi subs sunk off the East Coast of the US in 1943. American men with beards and bright white T-shirts stood on deck discussing oxygen pressure and "rewriting the pages of history" before diving to find a cutlery knife.

So Woody Allen was right when he claimed to his classmates that he'd seen a Nazi sub off Coney Island. German commanders said they'd used the bright lights of Manhattan to back-light the cargo ships. They were so close, they "could see the lights of cars through the periscope".

Breaking The Seal (BBC2) claimed there was an X-ray of Hitler's brain somewhere inside the Public Records Office, London. Same corridor as two signed confessions by Guy Fawkes, one before he was tortured. The other, shakier, afterwards.

Bettany Hughes drove across Britain in her Size-Matters Peugeot Convertible, dark historian's hair blowing in the wind like a Wella ad. Breaking The Seal was like one of those Let's Revise History school programmes from the 70s, the sort you'd watch on a summer afternoon with the curtains drawn in class.

"We'll be travelling all over the country, seeking out human history, written down as it happened", Bettany enthused, before pouncing into the Peugeot to show how racy and exciting history could be.

Male historians seemed to lose their mind in Bettany's presence. One explained the development of local government in Britain as a giant scheme to prevent the Danes from invading. Bettany seemed excited by this, and jumped back into the Peugeot: "I'm heading back to London, my head full of ideas."

The object of her investigations was The Domesday Book. Bettany approached the sacred text, held in a highly authentic-looking trunk, on foot - Peugeot parked mercifully out of shot for once. "It's like approaching the Holy Grail", she said. Except for one thing. It was The Domesday Book.

Aircraft Emergency (ITV) claimed "you'd have to fly every day for 8,200 years before you were involved in a serious air crash and even then, the chances are you'd survive."

Small comfort to the 8,200 wipe-outs that followed, every shaky camcorder crash ever recorded: planes exploding, helicopters colliding, air show fighters ploughing into crowds and killing just a few people (a miracle!).

Aircraft Emergency was a You've Been Framed of air disaster and beggared belief both in terms of the horror of the clips, and the audacity in showing them.

A hi-jacked plane came down in The Maldives and tourists rescued the passengers with pedalos. A drunken man held up a Fed-Ex plane with a spear-gun; the pilot flipped the plane to knock him unconscious. "I guess I just went crazy", he said.

This was mesmerising footage, snuff voyeurism on a new level for terrestrial TV, backed up with eerily downbeat testimony from the people who'd lived. As if speaking of the programme, one man "became aware of the irony of the situation. I'd survived the crash only to be freezing to death in a river with 10,000 people looking on from the bank".

In Colditz, a man who could catch fish would have been put with the man who thought you should jump off the roof, so they could build a gIider together. Unlike today's welfare system, the escape officers knew how to spot a chap's potential, and steer him back to sanity. To The Ends Of The Earth: The Mystery Of The Missing U-Boat (C4) furthered the Boys' Own theme of the evening, with a search for U869, one of six Nazi subs sunk off the East Coast of the US in 1943. American men with beards and bright white T-shirts stood on deck discussing oxygen pressure and "rewriting the pages of history" before diving to find a cutlery knife. So Woody Allen was right when he claimed to his classmates that he'd seen a Nazi sub off Coney Island. German commanders said they'd used the bright lights of Manhattan to back-light the cargo ships. They were so close, they "could see the lights of cars through the periscope". Breaking The Seal (BBC2) claimed there was an X-ray of Hitler's brain somewhere inside the Public Records Office, London. Same corridor as two signed confessions by Guy Fawkes, one before he was tortured. The other, shakier, afterwards. Bettany Hughes drove across Britain in her Size-Matters Peugeot Convertible, dark historian's hair blowing in the wind like a Wella ad. Breaking The Seal was like one of those Let's Revise History school programmes from the 70s, the sort you'd watch on a summer afternoon with the curtains drawn in class. "We'll be travelling all over the country, seeking out human history, written down as it happened", Bettany enthused, before pouncing into the Peugeot to show how racy and exciting history could be. Male historians seemed to lose their mind in Bettany's presence. One explained the development of local government in Britain as a giant scheme to prevent the Danes from invading. Bettany seemed excited by this, and jumped back into the Peugeot: "I'm heading back to London, my head full of ideas." The object of her investigations was The Domesday Book. Bettany approached the sacred text, held in a highly authentic-looking trunk, on foot - Peugeot parked mercifully out of shot for once. "It's like approaching the Holy Grail", she said. Except for one thing. It was The Domesday Book. Aircraft Emergency (ITV) claimed "you'd have to fly every day for 8,200 years before you were involved in a serious air crash and even then, the chances are you'd survive." Small comfort to the 8,200 wipe-outs that followed, every shaky camcorder crash ever recorded: planes exploding, helicopters colliding, air show fighters ploughing into crowds and killing just a few people (a miracle!). Aircraft Emergency was a You've Been Framed of air disaster and beggared belief both in terms of the horror of the clips, and the audacity in showing them. A hi-jacked plane came down in The Maldives and tourists rescued the passengers with pedalos. A drunken man held up a Fed-Ex plane with a spear-gun; the pilot flipped the plane to knock him unconscious. "I guess I just went crazy", he said. This was mesmerising footage, snuff voyeurism on a new level for terrestrial TV, backed up with eerily downbeat testimony from the people who'd lived. As if speaking of the programme, one man "became aware of the irony of the situation. I'd survived the crash only to be freezing to death in a river with 10,000 people looking on from the bank".

webTitle: Robot probe keeps Valentine date with asteroid Eros

fields.headline: Robot probe keeps Valentine date with asteroid Eros
fields.trailText: With near flawless precision, a spacecraft slipped into orbit around the asteroid Eros, becoming the first manmade satellite of an asteroid. The craft now starts a year-long close-up study of the potato-shaped space rock, hoping to determine its origins and help scientists mount a strategy to protect Earth from boulders from outer space.
fields.body:
With near flawless precision, a spacecraft slipped into orbit around the asteroid Eros, becoming the first manmade satellite of an asteroid. The craft now starts a year-long close-up study of the potato-shaped space rock, hoping to determine its origins and help scientists mount a strategy to protect Earth from boulders from outer space.

A short rocket firing on Monday changed the orbital path of the Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous (NEAR) spacecraft to allow it to settle into an orbit of Eros. The manoeuvre successfully completed a four-year odyssey that included a failed attempt to rendezvous with the rock last year.

"The NEAR spacecraft is in orbit around the asteroid Eros," mission director Robert Farquhar announced minutes after engineers received a signal that a rocket had fired with an error of less than 1 percent.

"We are very happy and very excited," said Farquhar.

Automatic instructions stored aboard the craft triggered the rocket firing at 10:33am (15:33 GMT) and engineers waited tensely in Mission Control for almost 20 minutes before success was confirmed. They broke into applause when it was clear that NEAR had reached its target.

Farquhar said the rocket firing aimed for an Eros orbit of about 200 miles by 299 miles (320 by 480 kilometers) and the craft hit that target within 30 to 40 miles (50 to 65 kilometres). This is considered excellent "shooting" for such a small object that is 160 million miles (260 million kilometres) away.

Eros is so far out that a radio signal takes 14.5 minutes to reach Earth. Project scientist Andrew Cheng said the success thrilled scientists eager to get an unprecedented close-up view of an asteroid and gather data with five different instruments.

"Today may be Valentine's Day for most people, but its Christmas Eve for me and all the presents are piled about, waiting to be opened," said Cheng.

NEAR will spend a year orbiting Eros, dropping in stages to lower orbits. It will gather basic research that one day may help humans defend the Earth against a "killer asteroid" like the one thought to have wiped out the dinosaurs 65 million years ago.

"Understanding the physical characteristics of asteroids will be very important if we are ever called on to deflect one coming at the Earth," said Nasa's Carl Pilcher.

Although Eros itself poses no threat to Earth, a dangerous asteroid could be discovered at any time, Cheng said.

"This is something humanity needs to be concerned about," said Cheng. "It has happened before on Earth." In 1989, an asteroid a quarter-mile wide missed the Earth by just 400,000 miles (640,000 kilometres). Astronomers said the space rock and Earth passed the same point in space just six hours apart.

Scientists also hope to learn more about the formation of planets, such as Earth, since Eros may be leftover material from the creation of the solar system.

Eros is 21 miles long and eight miles wide; by comparison, New York's Manhattan Island is about 13.5 miles long and 2.5 miles wide.

The $224 million NEAR mission was launched February 17, 1996. The craft was supposed to have gone into an orbit of Eros in January 1999, but it malfunctioned after a rocket firing - intended to aim the spacecraft at the asteroid - shut down automatically.

NEAR sped past Eros and then went into wild gyrations, cutting its contact with Earth. When engineers again captured the NEAR signal, they found the craft had burned about 20 percent of its fuel.

Engineers let NEAR circle the sun for a year, guiding it with fuel-saving small rocket firings toward a Valentine's Day rendezvous with Eros. This time the spacecraft performed without a problem.

"Another perfect day," Farquhar announced.

During its mission, as NEAR descends closer and closer to Eros, the craft late in the year may actually brush the asteroid's surface with a solar panel and photograph the mark it leaves.

NEAR was built under Nasa contract at John Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory. Scientists from Cornell University and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory also participated.

NEAR has five instruments, including a camera that will map and probe every surface inch of Eros. The instruments will measure density, chemical composition and magnetic fields. The camera will send photos in different spectra, in black and white and colour.

webTitle: Thruster problem could cut short Earth mapping mission

fields.headline: Thruster problem could cut short Earth mapping mission
fields.trailText: A problem with a thruster on space shuttle Endeavour's 197-foot (59-meter) radar antenna mast could force the astronauts to cut short their ultra-precise mapping of the Earth. Endeavour was on the third day of an 11-day mission to produce the most precise and accurate three-dimensional map of the Earth ever produced.
fields.body:
A problem with a thruster on space shuttle Endeavour's 197-foot (59-meter) radar antenna mast could force the astronauts to cut short their ultra-precise mapping of the Earth. Endeavour was on the third day of an 11-day mission to produce the most precise and accurate three-dimensional map of the Earth ever produced.

Scotland was one of the last countries mapped by the Space Shuttle Endeavour before it developed technical problems, it was revealed yesterday.

Officials at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (Nasa) said the shuttle had taken images of the Scottish Highlands just hours before encountering difficulties with a radar antenna mast.

Despite the flow of nitrogen gas, a small valve on the end of the mast jutting out of the shuttle cargo bay provided little if any thrust Sunday. Engineers suspected a leak somewhere in the gas line. To compensate, Endeavour's pilots had to fire the shuttle thrusters more than usual to keep the mast - the longest rigid structure ever flown in space - in the right position.

The thruster firings did not interfere with the crew's radar scanning of the Earth or the quality of data being collected, but the additional firings meant more fuel was being used than anticipated.

Flight director Leroy Cain said the mapping, scheduled to continue through next Sunday, might have to be halted as much as a day early.

"We are anywhere from nominal end of mission to slightly reduced, and I think at this point not more than a day based on what I have seen. I think there's a great potential that we'll make the end of mission based on our ability to find some efficiencies," Cain said Sunday night.

"But again, I would stress that we need to go and look hard... before we can really characterise it accurately."

By Sunday evening, more than 17 million square miles (43.5 million square kilometres) of terrain had been charted, roughly equivalent to an area five times larger than the Unites States. The astronauts are trying to produce the most precise and complete 3-D map of Earth.

Scientists have already lost a full day of mapping and are loath to lose even another hour.

Last month, Nasa surprised scientists by reducing the number of mapping days from 10 to nine. Shuttle managers wanted to leave enough time at the end of the mission for the astronauts to go out and crank in the mast if it jammed.

The decision resulted in a 10 percent loss of data. Nonetheless, scientists still expected to map more than 70 percent of the Earth's terrain, as far north as Hudson Bay and as far south as Cape Horn.

"Our intent is to map the entire Earth, and we always grudgingly give up any piece of real estate that we can't map because we know and we recognise that you don't get to do this very often," said Ed Caro, the project engineer.

Engineers installed the cold-gas valve on the end of the mast to help preserve shuttle fuel. Without any thruster firings, the shuttle and the mast constantly would try to roll right-side up in orbit, said Michael Kobrick, a scientist working at Mission Control.

The force that's supposed to be exerted by nitrogen flowing through the valve on the tip of the mast is just one-third of an ounce (10 grams).

"That's about the weight of a penny in the palm of your hand," Kobrick said. "It's hard to believe that that can make any difference, but I think Archimedes said, 'Give me a lever long enough and a place to stand, and I can move the world.' Well, given a long enough lever, like 200 feet (60 meters), a third of an ounce (10 grams) can move the orbiter around."

fields.headline: Feathering nests
fields.standfirst: Minister hands out cash to safeguard wildlife
fields.trailText: More than 3,000 English farmers are to be subsidised by the government to safeguard wild birds and flowers on their land, the countryside minister, Elliot Morley, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 3,000 English farmers are to be subsidised by the government to safeguard wild birds and flowers on their land, the countryside minister, Elliot Morley, announced yesterday.

It is part of a promised reform of EU agricultural policy which switches subsidies from intensive production to protecting the farmed environment and wildlife. An extra £16m has been allocated this year to help birds like the grey partridge, skylark, lapwing and tree sparrow, and mammals like hares and doormice which have suffered serious declines in numbers over the last 25 years.

The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds said: "This is the most important step this government has taken towards securing a viable future for farmland birds and other wildlife."

One rare bird Mr Morley hopes to save is the twite, which feeds its young entirely on seeds. The bird's English stronghold is the south Pennines where there are now only 225 pairs, according to a survey last summer.

webTitle: Two unions opt for rival mayor camps race

fields.headline: Two unions opt for rival mayor camps race
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Trade unions yesterday delivered two startlingly divergent results in Labour's London mayoral contest, with firefighters voting overwhelmingly to back Ken Livingstone, while a meeting of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical union last night opted for Frank Dobson.
fields.body:
Trade unions yesterday delivered two startlingly divergent results in Labour's London mayoral contest, with firefighters voting overwhelmingly to back Ken Livingstone, while a meeting of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical union last night opted for Frank Dobson.

The AEEU's decision - controversially taken by around 100 union delegates to local constituency Labour parties - will give the former health secretary just under 4% of Labour's mayoral electoral college.

The Fire Brigades Union vote, taken by more than 3,000, nets about 0.5% for the Brent East MP.

The FBU result, decided by a secret workplace ballot on a 60% turnout, has given Mr Livingstone his highest share of the vote, beating Mr Dobson by a margin of nearly 40 to one - pushing the Labour leadership's candidate into third place, as happened in last month's transport union poll.

Mr Livingstone secured 3,177 firefighters' votes, or 93.9% of the total. Former transport minister Glenda Jackson came second with 124 votes, or 3.7%, while Mr Dobson only attracted 81 votes, 2.4%.

The scale of Mr Livingstone's victory is likely to have been boosted by official FBU endorsement, but it also reflects a pattern of strong support among public service workers in London.

An indicative vote by members of the Rail Maritime and Transport union - excluded from the contest because of late payment of Labour affiliation fees - gave Mr Livingstone a similar level of backing, as did the Transport and General Workers' Union ballot.

Most unions voting in the affiliated third of the electoral college will announce their decisions at the end of this week, when the the result of the crucial individual members' section and the heavily pro-Dobson MPs' and MEPS' section will also be unveiled. Voting in the individual members' section closes at 5pm tomorrow.

Mr Dobson last night said that the firefighters' vote had been "no surprise" as his campaign had not "worked the membership at all".

He added that while he would have preferred unions to have balloted and cast their vote proportionally, he welcomed the AEEU's boost to his support.

Commenting on the AEEU's decision - described by some of Mr Dobson's supporters as the "Valentine's Day massacre" - Mr Livingstone said: "The Labour Party should not have allowed anybody to cast votes if they haven't consulted their membership in a ballot."

He added: "There should be no place for this kind of thing in 2000."

Although the AEEU backing for Mr Dobson had been long expected, its general secretary Sir Ken Jackson spoke against Mr Livingstone at last night's meeting in Central Hall, Westminster.

The union's decision not to ballot, while casting 50,000 votes, has been strongly criticised during Labour's mayoral campaign. Almost all other Labour-affiliated unions have balloted their London memberships.

fields.headline: Ji Pengfei
fields.standfirst: China's man in Hong Kong
fields.trailText: Chinese Red Army officers had to show great versatility after the revolution, turning their hands to any task demanded of them - from running whole industries to taking responsibility for national health or education. The career of Ji Pengfei, who has died aged 90, performed a similar great leap.
fields.body:
Chinese Red Army officers had to show great versatility after the revolution, turning their hands to any task demanded of them - from running whole industries to taking responsibility for national health or education. The career of Ji Pengfei, who has died aged 90, performed a similar great leap.

Born in the rural heartland of China, he spent the years of the second world war as a political commissar fighting the Japanese, and then the Chinese nationalists. Soon after liberation he left the country for the first time, to become the new China's ambassador to East Germany.

No one could have guessed then, at the height of the cold war, the circumstances in which Ji's name would become familiar to the outside world two decades later. He is enshrined in the 1972 Shanghai communiqué concluded by the US president Richard Nixon and the Chinese premier Zhou Enlai. Nixon and the premier, it says, held "earnest and frank discussions" on normalising US-China relations. In addition, US secretary of state William Rogers and Chinese foreign minister Ji "held talks in the same spirit."

Ji went on, as head of the Chinese Hong Kong and Macau office, to play a key role in the negotiations over the future of the British colony. He was a tough negotiator in 1983-84 as Mrs Thatcher reluctantly came to accept the inevitability of an eventual handover. He then oversaw the drafting of the Chinese basic law, which governs the one-country-two-systems relationship between Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland.

After the 1984 agreement, Ji intervened several times during the rocky transition process, visiting Hong Kong three times with varying degrees of cordiality. He made clear China's dislike of speedy political reform in the territory and put forward a doctrine of convergence, which proposed that political change under the British should not outstrip the post-1997 model set out in the basic law.

But Ji also insisted that Hong Kong's courts should have the "final right of adjudication" because the former colony's social and legal systems were different from the mainland. This is now in question after a court of final appeal decision last year was undermined when Beijing delivered a new "interpretation" of the relevant part of the basic law.

No one would ever have accused Ji of being either impulsive or particularly affable. Britain's then foreign secretary Geoffrey (now Lord) Howe, describing the critical events of 1984, recalled a stilted Peking duck banquet "with Ji Pengfei as our less than sparkling host." But he was sufficiently trusted to have been called back, at the age of 73, to join the negotiations.

Ji came from Linyi, Shanxi province, deep in northern China near a remote bend of the Yellow river. In 1926, at the age of 16, he went to school in an army college - like many young men in those warlord years - to study medicine. Following a revolt by his unit, he transferred his skills to the Red Army and joined the long march.

Pursuing politics in the beleaguered communist movement soon left no time for medicine. Ji spent the war as a political commissar in the 3rd field army, led by Marshall Chen Yi. After liberation Chen also shifted to the diplomatic track, becoming China's foreign minister in 1958 and a prime target of the red guards in the cultural revolution 10 years later. Ji, by then a deputy foreign minister, managed to keep his head down.

He finally retired in the 1990s, joining a group known as the "new eight elders" - to distinguish themselves from the really old veterans headed by the late Mr Deng. He adopted their characteristic lifestyle, however, and he and his entourage were well provided for in housing and transport. He was apparently still consulted on Hong Kong issues, but kept out of the public eye.

His son, General Ji Shengde, has been more conspicuous. As head of China's military intelligence, he is alleged to have secretly channelled funds from Beijing to the shadowy Democratic fundraiser Johnny Chung before President Clinton's last election.

John Gittings

Ji Pengfei, politician, born 1910; died February 10 2000

In 1926, at the age of 16, he went to school in an army college - like many young men in those warlord years - to study medicine. Following a revolt by his unit, he transferred his skills to the Red Army and joined the long march. Pursuing politics in the beleaguered communist movement soon left no time for medicine. Ji spent the war as a political commissar in the 3rd field army, led by Marshall Chen Yi. After liberation Chen also shifted to the diplomatic track, becoming China's foreign minister in 1958 and a prime target of the red guards in the cultural revolution 10 years later. Ji, by then a deputy foreign minister, managed to keep his head down. He finally retired in the 1990s, joining a group known as the "new eight elders" - to distinguish themselves from the really old veterans headed by the late Mr Deng. He adopted their characteristic lifestyle, however, and he and his entourage were well provided for in housing and transport. He was apparently still consulted on Hong Kong issues, but kept out of the public eye. His son, General Ji Shengde, has been more conspicuous. As head of China's military intelligence, he is alleged to have secretly channelled funds from Beijing to the shadowy Democratic fundraiser Johnny Chung before President Clinton's last election. fields.headline: Ernest Walter
fields.standfirst: Cameraman who captured images of war
fields.trailText: Ernest "Ernie" Walter, who has died aged 80, was a cameramen in the army film and photo unit which recorded the passage of allied frontline troops during the second world war as they advanced across Europe - from the Normandy beaches to the liberation of the concentration camps - and later in the far east. After the war, he became a Hollywood film editor.
fields.body:
Ernest "Ernie" Walter, who has died aged 80, was a cameramen in the army film and photo unit which recorded the passage of allied frontline troops during the second world war as they advanced across Europe - from the Normandy beaches to the liberation of the concentration camps - and later in the far east. After the war, he became a Hollywood film editor.

Born in Cardiff and educated locally, he was training to be an accountant when he enlisted in the Welch Regiment. From there, his interest in photography led to his joining the training school of the army film and photo unit (AFPU) set up by the war office to recruit and prepare cameramen for action. Ernie was chosen to be one of the camera sergeants with No 5 AFPU, which went to Normandy. As head of the unit, I was struck by his calm, organised manner, his decisiveness, initiative and sense of humour.

A special kind of determined courage is needed for war photography. The infantryman has his gun pointing at the enemy whom he can see, whereas the cameraman has to put his camera within his line of vision - with no possibility of seeing what is going on outside that line. Ernie was a prime example of a cameraman with guts.

On D-Day in 1944, landing with the Canadian commandos at 8am, he provided a vivid record of the action. The fighting which followed the landings was fierce and bloody. The work of the unit gave the newsreels and newspapers evidence of the fighting and the role of the allied troops. Ernie's companion was the stills photographer Bert Hardy, who later became internationally known through his work on Picture Post. The two became great friends, and Ernie gave a moving and affectionate tribute to Bert at his memorial service.

When Ernie was accused of setting up a famous shot of an old woman dressed in black, holding a shopping bag and walking down a shattered street in Caen, with a "convenient blitzed tank as a prop", he pointed out - with admirable self-control - that the tank was his pro tective cover, and that, given a battle was raging, to have "arranged" the entrance of the old lady would have been ludicrously dangerous. We took the view that whatever temptations there might be to stage action, nothing compared with the real thing.

When the war in Europe ended, Ernie, unusually, gained a commission and was posted to south-east Asia, where he was responsible for all cine and stills coverage. It was a successful transition based on mutual respect for his dedication and technical expertise.

After the war, Ernie became an editor for MGM, and subsequently, as a freelance, worked for such directors as Mark Robson, Billy Wilder, Blake Edwards and Robert Wise. Sadly, a stroke ended his film career, but he wrote a definitive editing manual, and taught at the National Film School. He married Brenda Gibson in 1942, and she survives him with their daughter and son.

Hugh Stewart

Ernest Henry Walter, cameraman and film editor, born November 29 1919; died December 14 1999

fields.headline: Ann Browne
fields.trailText: In 1977, Ann Browne, who has died of cancer aged 50, paid her first visit to Latin America. Then working as co-ordinator with the Joint Working Group for Refugees from Latin America (JWGRLA), she accompanied a delegation from the National Union of Mineworkers on a semi-clandestine visit to Bolivia and Chile, both then dictatorships.
fields.body:
In 1977, Ann Browne, who has died of cancer aged 50, paid her first visit to Latin America. Then working as co-ordinator with the Joint Working Group for Refugees from Latin America (JWGRLA), she accompanied a delegation from the National Union of Mineworkers on a semi-clandestine visit to Bolivia and Chile, both then dictatorships.

It took all Ann's diplomacy and determination to get the group through the visit unscathed. But it also awoke her interest in the mineworkers and their unions, and particularly in Latin American working conditions. The contact led eventually to her move, in 1981, to the Mine- workers International Federation (MIF), based first in London and, from 1985, in Brussels. As education and organisation projects secretary at MIF, later the International Federation of Chemical, Energy, Mine and General Workers Union (ICEM), she helped develop a long-term education policy for trade unionists and miners' wives, and encouraged their organisations.

For the MIF's global health and safety campaign, Ann wrote its slogan, "the stronger the union, the safer the mine". In 1995, the campaign led to the approval of a tough convention by the International Labour Organisation on mining industry health and safety. Ann also worked on links between Latin American, United States and European unions. This strategy paid off, particularly in Colombia, where, with Ann's help, US unionists at Exxon mines helped their Colombian counterparts negotiate with the US corporation.

Ann was born in Strabane, Northern Ireland, the third of five daughters and two sons. Her father worked in a local bakery. She attended Mount Carmel grammar school in Strabane, and read Spanish at Queen's University, Belfast. There she came in contact with two radicalising influences in her life, Latin American literature and the Northern Ireland civil rights movement. She took an MA at London's Institute of Latin American Studies, and in 1974 went to work at the newly-formed JWGRLA.

Patient and even tempered, she welcomed and resettled anxious, traumatised - and often quarrelsome - Chilean refugee families, fought and cajoled immigration officials, lobbied MPs, trade unions and local councils, and helped formulate long-term policy as part of a working group on legal procedures for asylum seekers. Then came that first trip to Latin America.

Latterly, Ann's energies were also directed to her personal battle with bone cancer, which was diagnosed in 1991. She intially drew on rationality, rage and sheer willpower, but later explored techniques which would let her manage the experiences of illness and death, finding particular help in the methods of the American oncologist Dr Carl Simonton.

She received a stream of friends from all over the world, and, until the very last, followed the progress of the Northern Ireland peace process, planned future holidays, and sent Christmas cards. After her death, messages came from Peruvian mining villages, former Chilean, Uruguayan and Argentinian political refugees, and trade unions in Finland, Japan, Brazil, Germany, and South Africa. They remembered her commitment and political skills, her capacity for hard, constant work, and the trust she inspired; but they also recalled her humour, charm, kindness, her joy in life - and her unforgettable laugh.

Imogen Mark

Ann Browne, trade unionist, born October 18 1949; died January 29 2000

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Wahid gets rid of rival Wiranto
The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, yesterday cemented his grip on power by suspending his rival, General Wiranto, from the post of senior security minister while retaining the support of the armed forces leadership.
fields.body:
Wahid gets rid of rival Wiranto
The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, yesterday cemented his grip on power by suspending his rival, General Wiranto, from the post of senior security minister while retaining the support of the armed forces leadership.

Mr Wahid, who changed his mind twice before suspending Gen Wiranto, said the move was necessary because of the public outcry over Gen Wiranto's alleged role in crimes against humanity in East Timor last year, when he was Indonesia's armed forces commander.
John Aglionby, Jakarta

Ships collide off Italy, killing 12
Twelve Spanish sailors are feared dead after a Portuguese-registered cargo ship collided with a larger Italian vessel seven miles off Punta Stila on the toe of Italy yesterday.

Rescuers found three bodies. They are not expecting to find the other nine missing crewmen from the 4,313-tonne Zafir, which split and sank within minutes of colliding with the 14,398-tonne Espresso Catania.
Rory Carroll, Rome

Dubcek death not foul play
Slovak investigators have ruled out the possibility that Alexander Dubcek, the leader of the 1968 Prague Spring liberalisation period, was assassinated, the Slovak news agency TASR reported yesterday.

A BMW carrying Dubcek and his driver, Jan Reznik, crashed on a wet road in 1992 and Dubcek later died in hospital. The Slovak Social Democratic party sued an unknown perpetrator after a book alleged that the crash was caused deliberately. However, the investigators found that Reznik was driving up to 55mph faster than the 50mph speed limit.
AP, Bratislava

Exhibition shut to save fish
An art display with 10 goldfish swimming in blenders has caused outrage among animal rights activists and a high turnout for a small museum in Denmark.

Visitors flocked to see the display, which opened on Friday at the Trapholt Art Museum in Kolding, 125 miles north of Copenhagen, and lets visitors decide whether to turn on any of the 10 blenders filled with water and a live goldfish. Police ordered the plugs pulled after two fish were blended at the weekend
AP, Copenhagen

Doomed plane failed checks
The Alaska Airlines plane that crashed on January 31 had been considered in 1997 for replacement of a key tail part, but the plan was dropped after further tests, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.

It said records showed workers had considered replacing the gimbal nut, which controls the horizontal stabiliser, but then changed their minds. The pilots complained of difficulties controlling the horizontal stabiliser before Flight 261 plunged into the Pacific Ocean near Los Angeles,killing all 88 people on board.
AP, Washington

Nuclear reactor malfunctions
A nuclear reactor at Ukraine's Zaporizhia power plant malfunctioned yesterday and was shut for repairs. No radiation leaks were reported and causes of the incident are being investigated.

A regulation system of a turbine malfunctioned and forced operators to stop the reactor, the state nuclear Energoatom company said. Zaporizhia is one of Europe's largest power plants and has four of its six nuclear reactors in operation.
Reuters, Kiev
