webTitle: Iran to lead new era of secular reform

fields.headline: Iran to lead new era of secular reform
fields.standfirst:
David Hirst argues that appearances can be deceptive in the Muslim world - fundamentalism is waning

More about Iran
fields.trailText: Analysis: David Hirst argues that appearances can be deceptive in the Muslim world - fundamentalism is waning.
fields.body:
The Iranian general election on Friday will be crucial - not just for the Islamic republic, but for Islamism everywhere. Islamic fundamentalism was initially perceived by the west as a global threat comparable to that other great messianic ideology of the 20th century, communism, and Ayatollah Khomeini's revolution gave the threat an immense boost.

The election will decide whether, in its main stronghold, Islamism is capable of the reform needed for its survival. Even if the outcome of the elections is not decisive, the polls will have highlighted the contradiction that besets Islamism everywhere, between the "sacred", reflecting God's sovereignty over people's affairs; and the "popular", the people's sovereignty.

In Iran's power struggle, President Mohammed Khatami and his reformist camp believe that the popular has precedence over the sacred. The arch-conservatives, headed by the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, insist on the reverse.

The conservatives will lose this struggle: either peaceably and constitutionally, for in any fair election, the reformists will take control of parliament; or violently, for if they falsify the results the people will eventually turn to insurrection.

The conservatives' defeat will reverberate through fundamentalism everywhere. Just as, at its birth, the republic dramatically strengthened a movement then in general ascent, so, now, the republic will accelerate its decline.

Hardline excesses

There is much to suggest that Islamism is on the increase. Islam has undergone a revival almost everywhere. And the notion that religion should dominate public life has put down deep roots; most governments have responded to this sentiment with pious gestures, from the prohibition on bank interest imposed by the new military rulers of Pakistan to the Egyptian parliament's retreat from new legislation on women's rights. Bigotry and extremism are rampant still.

On the 11th anniversary of the fatwa against Salman Rushdie yesterday, the hardline Islamist Khordad foundation increased its bounty for any Muslim who executes the British author.

In Indonesia, once a bastion of inter-communal tolerance, 100,000 demonstrators riot in Jakarta. Addressing them, Amien Rais, the speaker of the people's consultative assembly, says "tolerance is absurd", giving the green light for Christians to be massacred by Muslims.

Moderate Islamists are the most powerful opposition force in most Muslim countries. From Malaysia, where in recent elections they greatly increased their parliamentary representation, to Nigeria, where one federal state has adopted the sharia , or "holy law", they continue to make gains.

In Chechnya, that most bloody front line of the "clash of civilisations", a small band of Islamists, infused with extraordinary valour, are keeping the might of Orthodox Russia at bay.

More spectacular Islamist triumphs may lie ahead. The "Talibanisation" of Pakistan now looks a possibility.

Failure of Islamist rule

Yet the evidence points to the fact that Islamism is in decline.

At first, Islamism thrived ideologically on the failure of secular-modernist credos which Muslim societies borrowed from the west.

Its natural constituency was the middle and lower classes, which should have benefited most from the secular-modernist order, but actually suffered most. Its rank and file in the vast new urban slums from Jakarta to Cairo sought social justice and political representation, but using religious, not discredited leftwing, means to achieve them. Its activists were often former communists.

While bent on "renewal", these early Islamists looked for it in asala - back-to-roots cultural authenticity - and found it in the 7th century Koran. The literal interpretation of the holy book reduced human freedom to a minimum.

Islamists had two alternative routes to political power. The revolutionaries sought to "re-Islamicise" society from the top. An elitist vanguard undertook this task, finding sanction in all that is most intolerant in Koranic revelations.

The other route was that of gradual change. The gradualists sought the long-term re-education of society, purifying individual minds of secular deviation. Through good works, they sought to undermine the state's political legitimacy. Most claimed to believe in democracy.

Islamism was supra-national, promoting the unity of the "Islamic nation". There was no directing bureau. But an Islamist seizure of power in one country would inevitably have an exemplary effect on Islamists striving for it elsewhere.

But Islamism has failed to supplant nationalism, improve the conditions of its natural constituency, or gratify the quest for authenticity. And in the places where it set up Islamic states it has failed to be a model to others.

It might be expected that the Islamist revolution would have begun in the Arab heartlands of the orthodox Sunni faith - especially Egypt, the movement's fountainhead. That it happened in Shi'ite Iran made it, like the Russian revolution, a kind of aberration.

From the outset, Khomeini was bent on "exporting" his revolution. An opportunity soon came. When Saddam Hussein went to war against him, he resolved to turn Iraq into the world's second Islamic republic. Yet he failed to subvert even his vulnerable next-door neighbour.

What failed at home could never have been a model abroad. The revolution had come about in a genuine, nationwide insurrection. But its most bigoted component, the traditionalist mullahs, constructed an apparatus of repression which far outdid the Shah's manmade one in brutality, torture and mass executions.

Betrayal of supporters

The revolution also betrayed its original leftwing bent. It began with a disposition in favour of the "oppressed". But the conditions of ordinary people grew immeasurably worse. Islamism in power proved incapable of applying an "Islamic economy" rooted in "Islamic justice". The mullahs were no better at curing characteristic third world socio-economic ills than the secular regimes they despise.

Few things are genuinely Islamic about a system that sought to Islamicise everything from labour laws to school curricula. There is the stress on ostentatious, state-sponsored religious ritual and symbols; the retrogressive interpretation of penal and personal status laws; and the imposition of outward observances, such as the chador (a loose-fitting, head-to-toe robe worn by women). There is also the carefully vetted religious background of those who run its institutions. These factors have turned people not just against the mullahs, but against Islam itself.

The world's only two other examples of Islamism in power were largely the outcome of special circumstances. Hassan Turabi claimed that Islam subsumes democracy, but he presides over an oppressive regime in Sudan. And in Afghanistan the Taliban is a pariah excoriated even by Iranian clerics who once occupied the frontiers of extremism.

Revolution and reform

Elsewhere, Islamism remains an opposition force only, and, though still potent, is losing ground. An obvious exception is Chechnya. It is the latest magnet for those "permanent revolutionaries" who, as itinerant jihadists, move from battlefield to battlefield in defence of the faith.

Islamists are most formidable when allied to a local patriotism. In Palestine, Hamas still commands a much greater popular appeal than it would in a society without an external foe.

However, only in peripheral regions of the "Islamic nation" is Islamism still a rising force, largely because it is relatively new there. In the Caucasus and central Asia its opportunity came only with communism's collapse - more than a decade later than in the Middle East.

But the permanent revolutionaries of Islam are quixotic, isolated, confined largely to remote and mountainous terrain - indicating that there is no such thing as the pan-Islamic solidarity Islamists clamour for. And sharing their flaws, they are unlikely to be any more successful than their brethren in the heartlands, who failed to remove the existing order.

Recent Islamist challenges have come from the mainstream Muslim Brothers in Egypt and the FIS in Algeria. They also came from the militants: al-Gama'a al-Islamiya and Jihad in Egypt and the GIA in Algeria. Less despotic than in Iraq or Syria, the governments nonetheless fought back, suppressing democratic rights and waging military campaigns as vicious as the "terror" they combated.

But there is more to the decline than state oppression alone. Even in reasonably fair elections, Islamic opposition groups have never won anything like an outright majority. Even in Algeria in 1992, the FIS only won 3.25m votes in an electorate of 13m. Turkey, Kuwait, Yemen and Pakistan have seen the same pattern of strong initial gains followed by a steady decline in subsequent consultations.

The loss of popularity grows partly out of the way Islamic opposition groups have conducted their struggle. The revolutionaries discredited the movement as a whole with such atrocities as the massacre of tourists in Luxor.

The re-introduction of the sharia is a rallying cry of Islamic opposition groups everywhere. But they have almost invariably confined themselves to pressing for those mechanically applicable, yet ethically empty forms and observances: on alcohol, dress, the status of women.

A global movement which came to reform others now needs its own reforms. Many Islamists now acknowledge the importance of what Islamism began by rejecting utterly: democracy.

Could Iran's elections usher in the most far-reaching transformation of the system since the revolution? A victory, both ideological and institutional, of popular sovereignty over God's could be so far-reaching that the world's first Islamic state would eventually become its first post-Islamic state, secular in all but name. In dissolving itself, the theocracy Khomeini founded would become a pan-Islamic model of a kind he never imagined.

And in the places where it set up Islamic states it has failed to be a model to others. It might be expected that the Islamist revolution would have begun in the Arab heartlands of the orthodox Sunni faith - especially Egypt, the movement's fountainhead. That it happened in Shi'ite Iran made it, like the Russian revolution, a kind of aberration. From the outset, Khomeini was bent on "exporting" his revolution. An opportunity soon came. When Saddam Hussein went to war against him, he resolved to turn Iraq into the world's second Islamic republic. Yet he failed to subvert even his vulnerable next-door neighbour. What failed at home could never have been a model abroad. The revolution had come about in a genuine, nationwide insurrection. But its most bigoted component, the traditionalist mullahs, constructed an apparatus of repression which far outdid the Shah's manmade one in brutality, torture and mass executions. Betrayal of supporters The revolution also betrayed its original leftwing bent. It began with a disposition in favour of the "oppressed". But the conditions of ordinary people grew immeasurably worse. Islamism in power proved incapable of applying an "Islamic economy" rooted in "Islamic justice". The mullahs were no better at curing characteristic third world socio-economic ills than the secular regimes they despise. Few things are genuinely Islamic about a system that sought to Islamicise everything from labour laws to school curricula. There is the stress on ostentatious, state-sponsored religious ritual and symbols; the retrogressive interpretation of penal and personal status laws; and the imposition of outward observances, such as the chador (a loose-fitting, head-to-toe robe worn by women). There is also the carefully vetted religious background of those who run its institutions. These factors have turned people not just against the mullahs, but against Islam itself. The world's only two other examples of Islamism in power were largely the outcome of special circumstances. Hassan Turabi claimed that Islam subsumes democracy, but he presides over an oppressive regime in Sudan. And in Afghanistan the Taliban is a pariah excoriated even by Iranian clerics who once occupied the frontiers of extremism. Revolution and reform Elsewhere, Islamism remains an opposition force only, and, though still potent, is losing ground. An obvious exception is Chechnya. It is the latest magnet for those "permanent revolutionaries" who, as itinerant jihadists, move from battlefield to battlefield in defence of the faith. Islamists are most formidable when allied to a local patriotism. In Palestine, Hamas still commands a much greater popular appeal than it would in a society without an external foe. However, only in peripheral regions of the "Islamic nation" is Islamism still a rising force, largely because it is relatively new there. In the Caucasus and central Asia its opportunity came only with communism's collapse - more than a decade later than in the Middle East. But the permanent revolutionaries of Islam are quixotic, isolated, confined largely to remote and mountainous terrain - indicating that there is no such thing as the pan-Islamic solidarity Islamists clamour for. And sharing their flaws, they are unlikely to be any more successful than their brethren in the heartlands, who failed to remove the existing order. Recent Islamist challenges have come from the mainstream Muslim Brothers in Egypt and the FIS in Algeria. They also came from the militants: al-Gama'a al-Islamiya and Jihad in Egypt and the GIA in Algeria. Less despotic than in Iraq or Syria, the governments nonetheless fought back, suppressing democratic rights and waging military campaigns as vicious as the "terror" they combated. But there is more to the decline than state oppression alone. Even in reasonably fair elections, Islamic opposition groups have never won anything like an outright majority. Even in Algeria in 1992, the FIS only won 3.25m votes in an electorate of 13m. Turkey, Kuwait, Yemen and Pakistan have seen the same pattern of strong initial gains followed by a steady decline in subsequent consultations. The loss of popularity grows partly out of the way Islamic opposition groups have conducted their struggle. The revolutionaries discredited the movement as a whole with such atrocities as the massacre of tourists in Luxor. The re-introduction of the sharia is a rallying cry of Islamic opposition groups everywhere. But they have almost invariably confined themselves to pressing for those mechanically applicable, yet ethically empty forms and observances: on alcohol, dress, the status of women. A global movement which came to reform others now needs its own reforms. Many Islamists now acknowledge the importance of what Islamism began by rejecting utterly: democracy. Could Iran's elections usher in the most far-reaching transformation of the system since the revolution? A victory, both ideological and institutional, of popular sovereignty over God's could be so far-reaching that the world's first Islamic state would eventually become its first post-Islamic state, secular in all but name. In dissolving itself, the theocracy Khomeini founded would become a pan-Islamic model of a kind he never imagined.

webTitle: Anger grows as US jails its two millionth inmate

fields.headline: Anger grows as US jails its two millionth inmate
fields.standfirst: The land of the free is now home to 25% of the world's prison population
fields.trailText: Vigils are being mounted today in more than 30 major cities in the United States to draw attention to the arrival of the two millionth inmate in American jails. The US comprises 5% of the global population yet it is responsible for 25% of the world's prisoners. It has a higher proportion of its citizens in jail than any other country in history, according to the November Coalition, an alliance of civil rights campaigners, justice policy workers and drug law reformers.
fields.body:
Vigils are being mounted today in more than 30 major cities in the United States to draw attention to the arrival of the two millionth inmate in American jails. The US comprises 5% of the global population yet it is responsible for 25% of the world's prisoners. It has a higher proportion of its citizens in jail than any other country in history, according to the November Coalition, an alliance of civil rights campaigners, justice policy workers and drug law reformers.

The coalition is co-ordinating protests across the US to draw attention to what they feel is a trend for locking up ever more offenders, most of them non-violent.

"Incarceration should be the last resort of a civilised society, not the first," said Michael Gelacak, a former vice-chairman of the US sentencing commission. "We have it backwards and it's time we realised that."

"Two million is too many," said Nora Callahan of the coalition, which is calling for alternatives to prison for the country's 500,000 non-violent drug offenders.

"We are calling on state and federal governments to stop breaking up families and destroying our communities. Prison is not the solution to every social problem," she said.

In New York city, the Prison Moratorium Project will focus on the fact that one in three black youths is either in custody or on parole. Kevin Pranis, of the project, said: "New York state is diverting millions of dollars from colleges and universities to pay for prisons we can't afford."

Criminal justice is already a campaign issue in the presidential race. The Republican frontrunner George W Bush, governor of Texas, is a staunch supporter of both the death penalty and stiffer sentencing for drug offences.

Since he took over in Texas, the prison population there is up from 41,000 to 150,000, much of this as a result of locking up people for drug possession. This is one of the reasons that commentators have pressed Bush to be more open about his own alleged drug use in the past.

Second biggest employer

Of those held in federal rather than state prisons, 60% are drug offenders with no history of violence. Aminah Muhammad, who is organising the Los Angeles vigil, said: "My husband is doing 23 years for just being present in a house where drugs were found, so my 10-year-old son doesn't have his father."

The vigil also coincides with the publication of Lockdown America, a report by Christian Parenti analysing the US criminal justice system. He notes the expansion of the private prison sector - dubbed by one investment firm the "theme stock for the nineties" - which now runs more than 100 facilities in 27 states, holding more than 100,000 inmates.

A total of 18 private firms are involved in the running of local jails, private prisons and immigration detention centres. It is estimated that firms such as Goldman Sachs and Merrill Lynch write between $2-3bn in prison constructions bonds every year.

This has led some commentators to suggest that the United States is effectively creating a prison-industrial complex in much the same way as the military-industrial complex operates.

Critics of the system suggest that so much money is invested in incarceration that politicians would find it difficult to reverse the trends against the wishes of their financial backers and lobbyists.

In his study Christian Parenti suggests: "In many ways the incarceration binge is simply the policy byproduct of rightwing electoral rhetoric."

With the economic restructuring of America, politicians found it necessary to address domestic anxieties, Parenti suggests and this "required scapegoats, a role usually filled by new immigrants, the poor and people of colour".

The cost of building jails has averaged $7bn per year for the last decade and the annual bill for incarcerating prisoners is up to $35bn annually. The prison industry employs more than 523,000 people, making it the country's biggest employer after General Motors. Some 5% of the population growth in rural areas between 1980 and 1990 was as a result of prisoners being moved into new rural jails.

The national convention of the American Bar Association, held in Dallas, Texas last weekend, was told there was growing momentum for a moratorium on the death penalty. This follows the recent announcement by the Illinois governor, George Ryan, that the state will suspend executions pending an investigation into the number of death row inmates who turn out to have been wrongly convicted. There are 3,600 people awaiting execution in the US - 463 of them in Texas alone.

Today's vigils are being held near jails, courthouses and prisons and span the US from Spokane in Washington state to Gainesville in Florida, from Austin in Texas to Newhaven in Connecticut.

In 1985, the then Chief Justice Warren Burger said: "What business enterprise could conceivably succeed with the rate of recall of its products that we see in the 'products' of our prisons?"

The demonstrators today are hoping to make the same point count, if not with the politicians, then at least with the voters who will be called in to endorse such penal policies in the coming months.

fields.headline: Columbine grieves again
fields.standfirst: Gun violence in America: special report
fields.trailText: Two teenagers who attended Columbine high school - the scene of the biggest classroom massacre in American history - were found shot dead yesterday in a sandwich shop.
fields.body:
Two teenagers who attended Columbine high school - the scene of the biggest classroom massacre in American history - were found shot dead yesterday in a sandwich shop.

The bodies of a boy of 15 and a 16-year-old girl were discovered less than a mile from the school in a suburb of Denver where two teenagers, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, shot dead 12 pupils and a teacher before turning the guns on themselves last April.

At least one of yesterday's victims worked at the shop. "As far as a motive, I think it will be a while before we can establish that," said Steve Davis, a police spokesman.

The new killings coincided with the disclosure that Harris and Klebold were much more heavily armed than was previously realised.

The pair were equipped with 95 explosive devices, enough to destroy the buildings and kill hundreds of pupils.

fields.headline: 22 killed as tornados hit Georgia
fields.trailText: Tornados slashed through south-west Georgia early yesterday, tearing apart mobile homes, uprooting power lines and killing at least 22 people.
fields.body:
Tornados slashed through south-west Georgia early yesterday, tearing apart mobile homes, uprooting power lines and killing at least 22 people.

More than 100 people were injured by the twisters which touched down just after midnight. Camilla, 200 miles south of Atlanta, was hardest hit when the tornado cut a five-mile path through a housing development south of the town.

Georgia's governor, Roy Barnes, declared a state of emergency in the four most severely affected counties. Hospital officials said staff were initially overwhelmed by the large influx of patients but worked throughout the night treating lacerations, setting fractures and trying to stabilise the most critical cases.

"We've treated between 80 and 100 patients and they're still coming in with daybreak," Ron Gilliard, a spokesman for Mitchell County hospital, told the television news station CNN. The search and rescue teams are beginning to find additional patients."

Many of the injured were transported to a hospital across the state line in Tallahassee, Florida, because of power cuts across Georgia.

Liz McQueen, a Red Cross representative working at a temporary morgue in Camilla, said 14 people died in the town and its surrounding area, Mitchell County.

The county is a rural area with about 20,000 residents, many of whom work in chicken processing plants, textile factories and at Autry state prison, which is five miles south of Camilla.

Seven people were also confirmed dead in neighbouring Grady County and one in Colquitt County.

Mikie Newsome, a volunteer firefighter, estimated that between 50 and 60 homes were demolished in the worst hit area, south of Camilla. Some 90% of them were mobile homes.

"It's like somebody took a bulldozer and levelled it," he said. He and his father had watched a large dark funnel cloud dip down about three miles from their house near Camilla.

"All you heard was a roar, woo-woo-woo," said Johnny Jones, whose mobile home south of Camilla was lifted up and thrown on its side. He freed his 14-year-old son, who was pinned under a washing machine, and they crawled out of a window.

Aerial photos of Camilla showed that the entire neighbourhood had been flattened by the storm.

High wind and hail also caused scattered damage in much of Alabama, including widespread damage in the city of Cullman, and knocked out power to an estimated 22,000 customers.

Strong wind and thunderstorms also destroyed at least six houses in Arkansas and injured two people. Trees and power lines also were down in parts of Mississippi and Tennessee, where one woman was injured by wind-blown debris.

One or more tornados destroyed at least four houses in the Florida Panhandle community of Sand Hills and damaged more than 40 others, officials said. No injuries were reported.

The stormy weather was part of a line of thunderstorms and heavy snow pushing across the eastern third of the US. By yesterday morning, rain stretched from Florida to New England. Six inches of snow fell in Maine, closing scores of schools, and there were forecasts that up to 18 inches of snow could fall by late last night.

webTitle: Car maker sues over tilt claims

fields.headline: Car maker sues over tilt claims
fields.trailText: A libel action which pits one of the world's most successful car makers against consumer groups opened this week, promising to have major ramifications on the motor industry and environmentalists.
fields.body:
A libel action which pits one of the world's most successful car makers against consumer groups opened this week, promising to have major ramifications on the motor industry and environmentalists.

At the heart of the dispute is a 1996 report by the magazine, Consumer Reports - the American equivalent of Which? magazine - in which the testers claimed that the Isuzu Trooper sports utility vehicle (SUV) had a tendency to roll over while taking very sharp turns.

"If you already own one, drive it only when necessary and use extreme caution," the report said of the Trooper.

Isuzu Motors says that the bad publicity led to a 50% drop in sales at a cost of $500m and it is claiming that the report was dishonest and malicious because the magazine was motivated by disdain for the SUV.

The SUV is one of the most popular vehicles for young, affluent Americans, but it has drawn criticism from environmentalists for its bulk, fuel consumption and the damage it can do when driven off-road.

Isuzu is believed to be seeking $50m in damages. This would have a crippling effect on the magazine and its parent company, the Consumers' Union, which is the equivalent of Britain's Consumers' Association.

Free speech campaigners claim that a victory for the manufacturer would have an inhibiting effect on other media which sought to criticise the safety of such vehicles.

"The Consumers' Union created a headline-grabbing media event that served to advance its political agenda," Andrew White, lawyer for the motor company, told the jury in the Orange County courthouse in Santa Ana yesterday.

He suggested that a corporate decision to malign the Trooper had been made because subscriptions to the magazine were slipping (from 5.3m in 1992 to 4.3m in 1996) and because the union was failing in its attempts to lobby against the SUV. The company also claims that the magazine deliberately failed to inform readers that statistics showed that there had been no fatalities from Trooper rollovers.

But Joseph Cotchett, the lawyer for the Consumers' Union, replied: "We're not out to trash anybody." He suggested that Isuzu had been losing sales to competitors and "they had to blame somebody". The magazine, Cotchett said, had a "duty and obligation" to report its findings. It is also claimed that documents show that the motor company saw the action as a useful "PR tool".

At the centre of the case, which has already produced crippling legal expenses for both sides, is a video tape of the Trooper undergoing the test at the union's test track in Connecticut. It is seen to tilt up and, the Isuzu lawyers claim, cheers from the spectators can be heard, indicating that the magazine wanted the Trooper to fail.

The magazine has claimed that the Trooper was tested 192 times and tipped on 75 occasions. Its supporters claim that it has the freedom to criticise because a motor corporation is essentially a public figure and US libel laws give freedom to make honest criticisms - even if inaccurate - against public figures. In this way, the libel laws are much less strict than in Britain.

The magazine also argues that it has tested 80 SUVs and only two, the Trooper and the Suzuki Samurai have failed to pass the test. Suzuki has filed a separate suit against the magazine which has still to be heard.

Isuzu's argument that the report was motivated by malice means that the magazine has no protection under the first amendment which guarantees free speech. In its 63 years of existence, the Consumers' Union has been sued in 12 separate actions but has lost none of them.

Underpinning the case is the public attitude towards the SUV. Sales of the vehicle have rocketed from 7.1m in 1992 to 14m in the last annual figures. Although some SUVs return only 10 miles to the gallon and insurance premiums are 30% higher than for an ordinary car, they have continued to thrive.

But SUVs have been criticised as anti-social by some who complain that they cannot see past them on freeways. They are perceived by others as the epitome of the yuppie lifestyle with an aggressively macho image.

An SUV was torched in San Francisco during anti-gentrification demonstrations last year and there are even websites dedicated to attacking the "sports futility vehicle".

fields.headline: 'Don't leave me here to die'
fields.standfirst:
Four hours from the summit of Everest, Cathy
O'Dowdcame across a stricken climber. She
faced a brutal choice: to risk her own life in a
doomed rescue - or to push on to the top. Here
she explains why she left the barely breathing
body
fields.trailText:
Four hours from the summit of Everest, Cathy
O'Dowdcame across a stricken climber. She
faced a brutal choice: to risk her own life in a
doomed rescue - or to push on to the top. Here
she explains why she left the barely breathing
body
fields.body:
I stared at the body, blinking in disbelief. We were in the shadow of the First Step, so the light was dull. The body lay about 10 metres from where I stood and was angled away from me. It jerked - a horrible movement, like a puppet being pulled savagely by its strings.

We had been on a well-organised and, so far, successful trail towards the summit of Everest, worrying only about ourselves. Now a stranger lay across our path, moaning. Lhakpa shouted down at me and waved me to move on, to follow him up onto the Step. I looked back at the raggedly jerking figure.

Each team or solo climber did, or should, arrive at the mountain self-sufficient. Anyone who turned up assuming they could borrow food, clothing or tentage would receive short shrift. Similarly, you could not climb yourself to a standstill then expect other teams to risk their lives to save you.

Saving someone was not straightforward. There was no emergency number to call, no mountain rescue to whom the problem could be handed over. We would not be able to walk away, feeling we had done our civic duty and that "the experts" were now in charge. Anyone who becomes immobile on a mountain as large and remote as Everest is probably going to die. On this side of the mountain, we would have to get the victim all the way back to base camp before we could contemplate trying to find a helicopter. If they had to be carried, that would require a number of teams, dozens of people, and at least three days climbing.

Whoever it was on the rocks in front of me was so badly incapacitated that they had spent the night out on the mountain rather than crawl down. Life lay in keeping moving, as that generated body heat and, with every metre of descent, moved you into thicker air. I suspected we had virtually no chance of saving this climber.

We stood to throw away an entire expedition: the money, the time, the thousands of vertical feet of physical and mental effort. We had sponsors who expected us to go for the summit. We had personal ambitions that pointed in the same direction. We were only 240 vertical metres from the top, only four or five hours in climbing time. We were so close to fulfilling everything we had set out to do.

Should we throw it all away for some rescue attempt that was doomed? The body was lying in a ghastly inverted V. It looked as if the climber's spine might be broken. If they couldn't walk they were probably condemned. Why waste time, stand around getting cold and demoralised, when the attempt was futile? Why not just turn away and climb on? This all ran through my head in the space of a few seconds. But all the debates, the issues, the logical analysis were useless. I simply could not do it. I could not put the summit of a mountain ahead of a human life. I would not want to live with myself if I could. However hopeless this person's situation might be, I had to try. I walked back to Ian, who was standing with Jangbu, watching Lhakpa climbing the First Step.

"That body's alive. I'm going to have a look." It took him a moment to understand what I was talking about. "We can't just leave," I insisted.

He nodded and I stepped down from the trail and walked across the loose shale towards the body. I thought it might be one of the Russian team. The person was lying with their harness clipped to a line of fixed rope, stomach uppermost, head and legs dangling down on either side. I knelt down cautiously next to the body and saw it was a woman.

"Don't leave me," she said. Her skin was milky white, and totally smooth. It was a sign of severe frostbite and it made her look like a porcelain doll. Her eyes stared up at me, unfocusing, pupils huge dark voids. "Don't leave me," she murmured again.

I felt sick. With her long, dark hair, she looked like me. For a shocked second, I felt as if I was glimpsing a possible future for myself. The fact that she was conscious both encouraged and appalled me. It might be possible to save her - or we might yet have to leave her.

"I need to fetch the rest of my team," I said to her. "We have several people here. We will try and help you. I will come back, I promise."

"Why are you doing this to me?" she asked.

Ian and Jangbu came back with me. Lhakpa, Pemba and Ci Luo, seeing the turn events had taken, began to descend towards us. The woman had no visible trauma injuries and her bizarre position turned out to be the result of complete muscular limpness. She was as helpless as a rag doll. It looked as if someone had clipped her harness to the end of a fixed rope, presumably so she would not slip down the slope, and had then left her to go for help. Next to her was an orange bottle of oxygen, of Russian make, and a mask. The bottle was empty.

While Ian and Jangbu pulled her straight, I collected her down gloves, which had been thrown to one side. Her jacket was over her shoulders but her arms were not in the sleeves. Our bodies can react bizarrely to trauma. A fairly common occurrence with severe hypothermia is a sensation of extreme warmth. The victim may start tearing off clothing; it looked as if she had done this.

The men tried to replace her clothing. Her hands were swollen masses, her arms limp. She had no motor control. As Ian tried to get her arms into her sleeves, she gave no resistance and no assistance. Jangbu was trying to give her hot juice from his thermos. Then they each grabbed her under one arm and tried to pull her into a sitting position against a boulder. She was a dead weight. The two strong men took several heaves to get her sitting, and then both doubled over, gasping for breath. It showed us what it would take to try to actually carry her anywhere, let alone carry her or drag her for days down the mountain.

We had no capacity for giving her oxygen. Her mask would not fit our bottles. We carried spare bottles but no spare masks. For the oxygen to have any effect, she would have to be put on high flow, and stay on for hours. A few whiffs would have no effect. One of us would have to go off oxygen permanently to give her a mask, which would exhaust our spare supplies very quickly. Until we established that we had a real chance of saving her, the risk was too great.

We had no means of communication with the outside world. Pemba tried calling base camp, but their set was not switched on.

"I am an American. I am an American," the climber suddenly said.

American? But the American team was below us, a full day behind. My mind wandered back to what I had seen the day before: two tiny figures at the foot of the First Step, one still, one moving around.

Could she be Fran, the bubbly American woman who had sat in our ABC kitchen tent one night, passing the hours while she waited for her husband, the Russian climber, Serguei? That might make sense. She and Serguei were climbing as a twosome. They had no Sherpas, no oxygen. They would not be in radio contact with others on the mountain. But that did not explain how she came to have an oxygen bottle lying next to her. Nor did it explain where he had gone. Three Uzbek climbers were approaching.

"Will you help us?" I asked. "This woman is dying. We might be able to carry her down. Would you help?"

The leader of the three looked down at me reluctantly. "We tried to help yesterday. We left her with oxygen. She is too far gone to help."

He spoke into his radio, presumably talking to his base camp. However, they did stay, watching Ian and Jangbu to see what decision they took. Ian had the climber by both shoulders and was speaking directly at her, his face only inches from hers. "You have to help us. If you can help us, we can try and move you down the mountain. If you don't you are going to die." He was staring into her face, looking for some reaction. There was nothing. She knew we were there, but she was not mentally coherent. It was difficult to know what was left in her head.

I noticed her other crampon a few feet below us and took a tentative step down the slope to retrieve it, but immediately thought better of it. The slope was covered in loose rock shards, like a million smashed dinner plates. They were slipping away under my feet, rolling down the slope towards the Rongbuk glacier 4,300 metres below us. It was like trying to move across ball-bearings. I could see how a climber, having lost their balance, would not be able to stop the downward momentum. Had that happened to Serguei?

Ian and Jangbu had been trying to pull the woman into an upright position. Ian thought that if she could take some of her weight on her feet, even if she could not actually walk, it might be possible to move her down the mountain with a climber at each shoulder. However, her legs simply crumpled under her weight, as useless as strands of spaghetti.

We had been with Fran for nearly an hour, standing still in temperatures of around -30 C. Perched perilously on the steep, unstable slope, I could not even stamp my feet for warmth. I was beginning to feel profoundly cold. My fingers were almost totally numb. I had full-body shivers and my teeth were chattering behind my oxygen mask.

The decision to leave Fran came upon us without much discussion. The Uzbek climbers and Lhakpa had long been of that opinion. What hope I had faded in the face of her incoherence, her physical incapacity. Now Ian and Jangbu straightened up and turned away. She had stopped talking and seemed to have sunk into unconsciousness. The thought of going on was intolerable. I had lost the will to reach the summit. Besides the physical drain of the cold, I was emotionally shattered. I had never encountered anything like this. I had passed bodies, I had had friends not come back, but I had never watched anyone die. Nor had I had to decide to leave them.

It was harder for me because she was female. It is not that I thought women immune to the risk, but it was such a male-dominated environment. Everywhere you turned, everyone you talked to was male. I climb because I enjoy it. I climb for the pleasure of the activity, of the surroundings. There was no pleasure left. I wanted to be down, to be off the mountain, to have both feet on flat ground.

 After abandoning that attempt, O'Dowd went on, in 1999, to become the first woman to reach the summit from both south and north. Francys (Fran) Arsentiev died after O'Dowd's group left her. It later emerged that Fran had made it to the top, becoming the first American woman to do so without oxygen. Her husband Serguei also died on the mountain.

 This is an edited extract from Just for the Love of It, by Cathy O'Dowd, published by Free to Decide on March 2, £20.

fields.headline: The hole truth
fields.standfirst: Sexism and racism are fine. But God help golfers who cheat.  Jim White  reports on the scandal that has rocked St Andrews
fields.trailText: Sexism and racism are fine. But God help golfers who cheat.  Jim White  reports on the scandal that has rocked St Andrews
fields.body:
Yuille Bayley has just suffered the final indignity of the golfer. He has been asked to resign from the New Club in St Andrews for "bringing the club into disrepute". In the absence of epaulettes and a regimental sword, presumably the shame was communicated to Bayley by having the diamonds unpicked from his Pringle sweater and then being obliged to watch as his prized pitching wedge was broken over the knee of the club captain.

But his ignominious retreat from the grandest of golf clubs will have sent a frisson of fear through the rest of us who hack our way round courses in the pathetic pretence that we can play the game: Bayley was asked to go after accusations that he had cheated.

The 59-year-old, who plays off five (which in layman's terms means he's not bad), had been competing in the Eden Tournament, played on the links which lie alongside the famous St Andrews course. His opponent accused him of carrying replacement balls, which he would drop in strategically more opportune positions than those where his shot had actually landed. On one occasion, his rival was convinced he had watched Bayley's drive fly several kilometres off course, only to discover, on reaching the green, a ball comfortably close to the hole.

The accused strenuously denies the charge. But he felt, since the club committee took it seriously, he had no option but to tender his resignation. "It is the ultimate sensitive issue," a spokesman for the St Andrews club said of cheating. "It is golf's cardinal sin." As such it is regarded as more morally reprehensible among the swingers and hackers of the golf world than, for instance, the institutionalised prejudice against women and ethnic minorities that seeps through virtually every clubhouse in the country.

Bayley is not the first to fall foul of the foul shot. In 1994, such was the ill-feeling about accusations of cheating involving a golfball down the trouser leg during a match at the Sherwood Forest golf club that the protagonist launched a libel case in an attempt to restore his reputation, a case he promptly lost.

In 1988, a golfer called Sylvia Goff sued Shrewsbury golf club for £3000 worth of emotional distress after they ejected her for moving a ball. She admitted she had indeed lifted the object of her frustration from the greensward, but only to clear a leaf from its path. She too lost her case. And even professionals are not immune from the lynx-eyed gaze of the cheatspotter. In 1985, a Scottish pro called Dave Robertson was disqualified by the Royal & Ancient Club for playing a ball from the wrong place during qualification for the Open Championship. He was banned by the Professional Golfers' Association for 20 years and fined £20,000.

Golf is not renowned for the humour of its administrators. It is a game which takes itself seriously. Etiquette, rules and petty regulations are the order of play. In golf nobody objects if you are a swindler, an arsonist or a mass poisoner, just as long as you don't wheel your trolley across the green, always yield to faster players and never wear short socks with short trousers.

In every clubhouse there is a board full of rules and regulations banning this and precluding that. But this is nothing compared to the unwritten rules, the unchanging set of unspoken assumptions about behaviour you are expected to adopt by a process of osmosis the moment you step on to a course. And heaven forfend anyone who breaks them.

Nowhere was this clearer than during the last Ryder Cup, when the exuberant celebration of the US team on securing victory was described by the European team vice-captain, Sam Torrance, as the most disgusting thing he had seen in his life. Which suggests he has not been exposed to recent post-watershed offerings on Channel 4.

But cheating is the gravest of all golfing sins because it undermines the sport's essential self-policing nature. Out in the rough, the temptation to alter the lie or steal a yard or claim it has taken one shot less than it did to recover is overwhelming. Take it from me: I have been overwhelmed. And to be overwhelmed, according to aficionados, is to let down your opponent and yourself. Cheats at golf, they say, are cheats in life. Richard Nixon, after all, was a renowned golfing cheat. But, unlike poor Bayley, nobody ever accused the president to his face. Which is why golf is the ultimate metaphor for modern life: it is not the cheating that matters, it is whether you can get away with it that counts.

fields.headline: No: 1577 Angela Rippon
fields.body:
Age: 55

Occupation: The BBC's first female television newscaster and presenter of shows ranging from What's My Line? and Countdown to Watchdog Healthcheck and Start the Week.

Great legs, I seem to recall. You'll be referring, presumably, to the footwork skills Rippon acquired at ballet school, aged three to 17 - qualifications English National Ballet was keen to stress yesterday when announcing her appointment as its new chairman, replacing Pamela, Lady Harlech.

No, I meant... Or perhaps you were thinking of her long stint as presenter of Come Dancing, arguably another source of expertise for her new job?

No, I meant... Yes, yes, we know what you meant: her high-kicking, ratings-detonating, career-overshadowing performance in a split skirt on the 1976 Morecambe and Wise Christmas special. Next you'll be telling me that for males of a certain generation, that broadcast remains a cherished memory of sexual awakening in post-Sixties Britain.

But for British males of a certain generation, that broadcast remains... Yes, we know. Some would also say it marked the beginning of news and current affairs journalists' slide into celebrityhood - witness Martyn Lewis's coffee-table book about cats, Edward Stourton's forthcoming modelling deal with Calvin Klein underwear...

Is that true about Ed Stourton? What do you think?

Does Rippon mind this unremitting focus on her limbs? Not awfully, it seems. "Twenty-two years later and not a week goes by when somebody doesn't come up to me and say 'I remember you from Eric and Ernie'," she told an interviewer in 1998. "My legs are part of the public's image of me. They often say, 'Oi, Ange, let's look at your legs' - but they also remember me as a pretty good newsreader. If they had only remembered the legs, then that would be different."

Don't say: "Oi, Ange, let's look at your legs."

fields.headline: Trial and error
fields.standfirst: When the professor of journalism at Northwestern University in Chicago set his students the task of re-examining a string of capital convictions, he could not have imagined the effect. Now three men have been freed from death row, Illinois has suspended executions and the rest of the US may follow suit.  Julian Borger  reports
fields.trailText: When the professor of journalism at Northwestern University in Chicago set his students the task of re-examining a string of capital convictions, he could not have imagined the effect. Now three men have been freed from death row, Illinois has suspended executions and the rest of the US may follow suit.  Julian Borger  reports
fields.body:
In the ever-shifting landscape of US politics, there have been a few enduring shibboleths, none more so than the overwhelming public support for the death penalty. No serious candidate for national office even dares to raise it as an issue. That was the conventional wisdom until a few days ago, when something remarkable happened: America started to think again about execution.

On January 31, a moratorium was declared in Illinois by a Republican governor, George Ryan, who had formerly been an enthusiastic supporter of lethal injection as punishment for capital crimes. Last Friday, the attorney-general, Janet Reno, launched a justice department investigation into whether capital punishment is inflicted disproportionately on black people. On the same day, a bill designed to improve defendants' chances of proving their innocence was presented to the senate. This week, President Clinton is considering arguments for a federal moratorium and the presidential candidates, pro-death penalty all, are being persistently questioned about their stand.

This is an extraordinary turnaround for an issue which - as recently as last month - was considered politically dead. But even more extraordinary is that this accelerating chain of events was set in motion by an undergraduate journalism class in Chicago.

For their class projects, students at Northwestern university's Medill school of journalism re-examined a string of capital convictions built on minimal evidence and dubious confessions. Their work raised the spectre that convicts, usually black men, were being put to death for crimes they did not commit. No one was more surprised than the students themselves - who, like most people, had assumed that their fellow citizens would not be sentenced to death without cast-iron proof. His students devoted themselves full-time to the investigation, cancelling holidays and missing other classes as they pored over old transcripts and tapes of the trial, which had clearly been a travesty of justice. Porter was free two days later. Emerging into the Chicago winter light after 16 years on death row, he ran straight to Protess and lifted him off the ground. Then he did the same thing to Armbrust and the rest of the students who had gathered outside the jail. "I'm just overwhelmed," Porter said at the time. "I been down so long, I been trying to fight for my life for so long. And these people trying to kill me. Them crooked cops framed me. They didn't care nothing for the truth. It hurt me so much. My life is torn apart."

Porter has the right to sue for wrongful imprisonment, but despite the evidence of his innocence, the bureaucratic obstacles to redress are daunting. The only financial help he has received to help rebuild his life has been $5,000 (£3,000) - a down-payment from a film producer interested in the rights to his story. "Only in America would we depend on a Hollywood producer to give money as recompense for a man who had been falsely imprisoned," Protess points out.

Since the death penalty was reintroduced in Illinois in 1977, 13 inmates on death row have been proved innocent - more than have been executed. No prosecutor or policeman has been prosecuted for their role in twisting or fabricating evidence.

Ciolino, the ex-cop, explodes with amusement at the idea that his former colleagues might be held responsible. "Are you kidding me?" he bellows down the phone line. "Never, never, not once have they been held accountable. I saw this shit over and over again."

The Protess-Ciolino partnership is perfectly balanced. Protess supplies soft-spoken, painstaking, idealism. Ciolino provides the necessary clout and hard-bitten cynicism. Telephone callers to his private investigator agency hear a voice warn them repeatedly: "Remember if we're not working for you, you better hope we're not working for them."

"It's not that me and Protess are geniuses," Ciolino says in a heavy Chicago accent, which makes him sound as if he's constantly chewing. "We're hard working guys who take on the system. We beat them because we know how to use the media."

But for all the wrongful convictions the team has helped reverse, Ciolino is doubtful that the current rethink will lead to imminent repeal. He argues: "All we've done is slow down the process a little. I don't see none of the guys on death row jumping up and down."

Taking a coffee break from his crusade at his offices on the shores of Lake Michigan, Protess is more sanguine. "One of the wonderful things is the way the capital punishment debate has been framed out of this," he says. "It is not about the morality of the death penalty. It has become an issue of whether innocent people should be on death row."

Protess's current class is working on two cases of Illinois death row inmates he believes are innocent, and next year Protess wants to look at cases elsewhere in the country.

The campaign launched in Protess's classroom shows signs of spreading, as other journalism and law schools have followed Northwestern university's lead, but he has a warning for them about the toll death row cases take on young students. "I have real concerns about the pressure on this year's students to save someone from death row. It's become not just a matter of taking a course. It's about saving lives, and the university is using it as a recruiting device."

Protess recently received a note from one outgoing student complaining: "I dream about death all the time." The toll is worst when class efforts fail to prevent an execution. In May 1995, he and his students believed they had enough evidence to cast doubt on the conviction of Girvies Davis. Once again, there was no written evidence and Davis, a black man, had been convicted by an all-white jury on the basis of a confession. But Davis had been illiterate and could not have written the confession. Protess's class also found that he'd signed confessions to virtually every major unsolved crime in the area, including three murders the authorities later accepted he could not have committed.

But despite entreaties by Protess - and even a jury member who swore he would not have agreed to convict Davis if he had known he was illiterate - the Illinois governor at the time, Jim Edgar, upheld the conviction. Davis was executed by lethal injection.

The students who gathered at their teacher's house that night will never forget it. One of them, Lara Flint, now studying law in Washington, recalls: "Girvies called at about 9 o'clock and talked to David and was really nice and said he was grateful for the work we had done. It was pretty emotional and pretty difficult, knowing that the state was going to kill someone, just like that."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: An article on our Law pages, pages 10 and 11, G2, yesterday, about the sentencing of battered women who kill their abusers, concluded, "There is a simple answer. Abolish the automatic death penalty for murder, leaving it to the judge to sentence... according to all the circumstances." There is, of course, no death penalty at all. The writer meant to call for the abolition of the automatic life sentence for murder.
fields.body:
An article on our Law pages, pages 10 and 11, G2, yesterday, about the sentencing of battered women who kill their abusers, concluded, "There is a simple answer. Abolish the automatic death penalty for murder, leaving it to the judge to sentence... according to all the circumstances." There is, of course, no death penalty at all. The writer meant to call for the abolition of the automatic life sentence for murder.

In "A (very) occasional series in praise of the sub-editors' craft", page 7, Media, yesterday, we repeated a seven-line section practically word for word. We did not notice but you did.

In an article on page 58, Media, yesterday, we referred to Guardian Media Group, owners of the Guardian. The owner of the Guardian is, in fact, The Scott Trust.

The Kampuchean airlines aircraft on standby at Brize Norton, front page, February 12, was a Tristar, not a Trident (which is a missile).

John Lennon, contrary to what we suggested in the Tapehead column of the Guide, page 52, February 12, did not shoot himself. He was murdered in December 1980, two days after his last solo album Double Fantasy (not Woman) had entered the charts.

Peter Tatchell, Profile, page 6, Saturday Review, February 12, worked at Myers (not Meyers), the largest department store in Melbourne.

Department of instant contradiction, page 3, February 12, in our story about Manchester United and Vodafone, we said, "By pointing the miniaturised camera [in your mobile phone] to your open mouth you may be able to give enough data for the doctor to qualm you fears about that mouth ulcer." More optimistically, he might calm them.

The Fiat Multipla, road tested on page 9, G2, yesterday, does not have a middle seat in the font, but it does have one in the front.

webTitle: Beauty and beast of the new Japan

fields.headline: Beauty and beast of the new Japan
fields.standfirst: Two industrial cities have taken oppposite routes to reform - one western, the other traditional
fields.trailText: As the debate rages on in Japan about how to reform the country's outdated management model, all eyes are on the two cities which have come to represent the beauty and the beast of the alternatives.
fields.body:
As the debate rages on in Japan about how to reform the country's outdated management model, all eyes are on the two cities which have come to represent the beauty and the beast of the alternatives.

Toyota City, the headquarters of Japan's biggest carmaker, and Musashi Murayama, the site of a huge Nissan plant west of Tokyo, were once mentioned in the same breath as the shining lights of the Japanese economic miracle.

Foreign businessmen would flock there to learn about lifetime employment, seniority-based promotion and other pillars of an economic system that was the envy of the world.

But that system, which worked so well to achieve success and expansion, has proved ill equipped to cope with the failure and contraction of the past 10 years, now known in Japan as the "lost decade".

The decline is symbolised by the plight of the town of Musashi Murayama, threatening to wreck the lives of its 60,000 citizens. Nissan once employed 6,000 people here and contributed 60% of the municipal budget. But the shabby city hall is evidence of the fact that the company, which has posted losses for the last five years, has not paid full taxes for some time.

The town is bracing itself for the closure of the plant, which is part of the most brutal restructuring program ever undertaken by a Japanese manufacturer. The Nissan revival plan, announced in October, axes five plants, 21,000 jobs and links with more than half Nissan's suppliers.

Local people blame the decline on the arrogance of Nissan's former executives, who believed cross-shareholdings and close ties with bankers and politicians would protect them from a crisis they refused to acknowledge until it was too late.

But there is also anger with the man behind the revival plan, Carlos Ghosn, who became chief operating officer of Nissan after France's Renault took a life-saving 37% stake in the ailing company last year.

In the Japanese press, Ghosn is known as "le cost cutter", and there are constant references to ruthless "western" methods. It is not quite true: the job cuts will be made through natural attrition and workers at Musashi Murayama have been offered alternative employment hundreds of miles away with incentives of up to 3m yen, or £16,800, to relocate.

But his methods have stunned employees who took out home loans from Nissan on the understanding that they were had a job for life. A third have still not decided whether to move.

"In the Japanese way of thinking, Ghosn's plan is unforgivable," said Shigeki Sakai of the all-Japan metal and information machinery workers' union, which joined a recent protest of 8,000 workers against the closure. "There has never been anything like this before. Companies have gone bankrupt rather than do this."

Another fierce critic is Hiroshi Okuda, chairman of Toyota and head of the Japanese employers' federation, who champions a "third way" between Japan's traditional corporate culture and no holds barred global capitalism.

This has made Toyota City a beacon of hope for those - probably the majority in Japan - who balk at western management techniques.

Filled with gleaming buildings of marble and glass, the company's home town could hardly offer more of a contrast with Musashi Murayama. A fifth of its 350,000 population is directly employed at more than a dozen local Toyota factories, where the average annual wage for union workers is 6m yen. With the company and its affiliates providing everything from sports facilities to marriage counselling and funeral services, it is more like a socialist utopia than the hub of one of capitalism's biggest empires.

But change is on the way - not least because the company listed last year on the London and New York stock exchanges, where investors will be looking for higher profit margins than Toyota offers now.

Last year the company avoided full-time job losses despite a 25% cut in domestic production to 3.1m units. Executives admit, however, that if production falls below 3m, the pressure to trim the workforce will be hard to resist. The uncertainty of the times is illustrated by the fact that the company now talks of "long-term employment", rather than the "lifelong employment" of the past.

It is also gradually shifting from a seniority to a merit-based pay system. This is vital, as the company has five middle managers for every two at General Motors, which means big salary costs and slow decision-making.

"There is a big movement to reform traditional Japanese business practices but not necessarily towards western-style capitalism," said Mitsuo Kinoshita, director of human resources at Toyota.

"The Japanese system has its strong points. As long as we make improvement on a daily basis, we don't need major surgery." Whether to adopt domestic remedies or western-style amputation remains the subject of fierce debate.

The public would undoubtedly prefer Toyota's "new Japanese way", but few companies are strong enough to take such a long term view.

At the same time there is a reluctance to follow Ghosn, whose ability to save Nissan is still far from certain - last week its credit rating was cut to junk status. But in private many executives admit the foreign executive has broken taboos and created a new model for managing failure.

"Basically, Ghosn is doing what has to be done at Nissan," acknowledged the head of one conglomerate. "Managers at other Japanese companies would probably like to do a similar thing, but for the moment it is still difficult."

With the company and its affiliates providing everything from sports facilities to marriage counselling and funeral services, it is more like a socialist utopia than the hub of one of capitalism's biggest empires. But change is on the way - not least because the company listed last year on the London and New York stock exchanges, where investors will be looking for higher profit margins than Toyota offers now. Last year the company avoided full-time job losses despite a 25% cut in domestic production to 3.1m units. Executives admit, however, that if production falls below 3m, the pressure to trim the workforce will be hard to resist. The uncertainty of the times is illustrated by the fact that the company now talks of "long-term employment", rather than the "lifelong employment" of the past. It is also gradually shifting from a seniority to a merit-based pay system. This is vital, as the company has five middle managers for every two at General Motors, which means big salary costs and slow decision-making. "There is a big movement to reform traditional Japanese business practices but not necessarily towards western-style capitalism," said Mitsuo Kinoshita, director of human resources at Toyota. "The Japanese system has its strong points. As long as we make improvement on a daily basis, we don't need major surgery." Whether to adopt domestic remedies or western-style amputation remains the subject of fierce debate. The public would undoubtedly prefer Toyota's "new Japanese way", but few companies are strong enough to take such a long term view. At the same time there is a reluctance to follow Ghosn, whose ability to save Nissan is still far from certain - last week its credit rating was cut to junk status. But in private many executives admit the foreign executive has broken taboos and created a new model for managing failure. "Basically, Ghosn is doing what has to be done at Nissan," acknowledged the head of one conglomerate. "Managers at other Japanese companies would probably like to do a similar thing, but for the moment it is still difficult."

webTitle: Ford to step into Daewoo bidding

fields.headline: Ford to step into Daewoo bidding
fields.trailText: Ford, one of the world's largest carmakers, is to bid for Daewoo, and Germany's DaimlerChrysler is also reportedly "seriously considering" a bid for the Korean group.
fields.body:
Ford, one of the world's largest carmakers, is to bid for Daewoo, and Germany's DaimlerChrysler is also reportedly "seriously considering" a bid for the Korean group.

Ford vice chairman W Wayne Booker said: "We expect to submit a bid. Our intentions are serious and we want to maintain Daewoo Motor as a separate company."

General Motors, the world's biggest motor manufacturer, is also bidding but both Ford and General Motors' main obstacles to a deal revolve around how Daewoo's debt will be handled.

The Wall Street Journal claimed that DaimlerChrysler was still considering whether to join the bidding, but a spokesman declined to comment. The auction of Daewoo is being conducted by a panel overseeing the restructuring of Daewoo Group's major affiliates.

In a separate development, Ford appeared to have abandoned plans to build a compact minivan as it battles to stop its European market share from shrinking.

Ford said that it saw no point in moving ahead with the car, which had been in the works for several years and was close to its launch, now that rival GM produces the Zafira. That minivan has seven seats, whereas Ford's vehicle is planned as a five-seater.

webTitle: BASF defends switching drugs board to London

fields.headline: BASF defends switching drugs board to London
fields.trailText: BASF yesterday defended its decision to switch the board of its restructured drugs business to London after disquiet in Germany that the company is preparing a sell-off.
fields.body:
BASF yesterday defended its decision to switch the board of its restructured drugs business to London after disquiet in Germany that the company is preparing a sell-off.

Top executives argued that the internationalisation of the drugs business meant it needed the bridge between Europe and the United States; London provided access to the talent which was essential for a pharmaceuticals business.

"The battle for talent, that is the battle for the future," according to Dr Thorlef Spickschen, the chairman of the BASF Pharma board. "London, New Jersey and Basle are where the most successful chemical companies are located. London is a wonderful bridge between Europe and America."

BASF, which is one of the world's leading chemicals companies, is restructuring its drugs business to give it more flexibility and a greater international focus as it responds to the mergers and alliances which have transformed the pharmaceuticals industry. Only 10% of BASF's sales are now in Germany, 40% are in the US.

The move has caused disquiet in Germany, with unions concerned that it may run contrary to site agreements. BASF executives sought to provide reassurance, saying that the new London team would only be 20-25 strong and that the holding company which will control the businesses was most likely to be based in Germany, especially if recent proposals to relax tax laws are approved.

There has been widespread speculation that BASF will sell its Pharma business, which has less than 1% of the world market and is ranked number 22 in the world by sales.

But Eggert Voscherau, a member of the board of the parent company, said: "Selling BASF Pharma is not our only option. We have a full range of options at our disposal... acquisition, joint venture, spin-off and divestment."

Mr Voscherau said later that BASF has discussed the strategic options with an "inner circle" of investment banks. He admitted that the business was under pressure from the main BASF board to improve its return on sales but he said that no specific time frame had been laid down.

"There is no implicit threat that if Pharma does not achieve the target it will be sold," said Mr Voscherau. "That is not the case."

Though the BASF Pharma business is relatively small - analysts reckon it is worth between 12bn and 20bn marks (£3.7bn-£6.3bn) - Mr Voscherau argues that size is not essential. Though the rising costs of research and development and pressure on healthcare spending were forcing the pace of change, "massive research budgets and large marketing and sales teams are not necessarily a 100% guarantee of profitability and innovation," he said.

As his colleague Mr Spickschen put it: "Dinosaurs do not lay the most promising eggs."

webTitle: Stagecoach loses chief executive and US chairman

fields.headline: Stagecoach loses chief executive and US chairman
fields.trailText: Stagecoach last night denied that its high profile chief executive, Mike Kinski, had quit his job over a row with chairman, Brian Souter, caused by the latter's support for section 28, the law which prohibits the promotion of homosexuality in schools.
fields.body:
Stagecoach last night denied that its high profile chief executive, Mike Kinski, had quit his job over a row with chairman, Brian Souter, caused by the latter's support for section 28, the law which prohibits the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

Stagecoach said that Mr Kinski has left the company amicably and that section 28 was not the reason for his departure. It said that Mr Souter had employed an outside company to promote his campaign in Scotland, where Stagecoach is based, and had not allowed the campaign to interfere with the firm's day-to-day business.

Industry sources yesterday said that Mr Kinski had become increasingly concerned with the effect this could have on Stagecoach. A spokesman for Mr Kinski denied, however, that there was any difference of opinion.

Others took a more pragmatic approach. The view among some analysts was that Mr Kinski had left the company because of growing concern about the bus and coach operator's dash for expansion in the American market.

Mr Kinski has spent the past two years developing the organisation and integration plans for Coach USA, bought last June for $1.24bn (£750m), giving Stagecoach access to the $40bn market.

Mr Souter said that Mr Kinski would remain as a consultant for six months, but his departure as chief executive was immediate. His place has been taken by Keith Cochrane, finance director.

The company's shares fell 5p to 110p. They have more than halved in value since last September. Mr Kinski, who was paid £777,000 in the year to April 1999, could be in line for a payout of £1m to £2m.

The boss of Coach USA, Larry King, is also leaving. He chaired the company after the takeover last year and joined the main board of Stagecoach. Mr Kinski has been closely involved in the integration of Coach USA and the group's strategy in the US.

Only a fortnight ago, Mr Kinski and Mr King hosted a trip to Houston to see Coach USA's operations, but there was speculation yesterday that the US operations may be in trouble.

Wyn Ellis, leading transport analyst at Commerzbank, said: "Inevitably people will put two and two together and assume that the resignations are connected, which would lead people to think that all is not well with Coach USA."

Stagecoach said: "This is not a financial statement. It is a management statement. There is no black hole in any Stagecoach company."

Another analyst said: "It looks like Souter is drawing the reins in towards himself. It's great from the point of view that Souter is the major architect of the group and has created a tremendous amount of value, but it's rather a strange way of going about it."

Mr Kinski was poached from Scottish Power in 1998. His name has been linked with several leading companies.

He owned 24,160 shares in Stagecoach at the time of the last annual report. His options over a further 1.3m shares can be exercised when the share price is above 200p.

webTitle: Ashanti sacks chief and summons investors

fields.headline: Ashanti sacks chief and summons investors
fields.trailText: Hard-pressed Ashanti Goldfields fired its finance director, Mark Keatley, yesterday and confirmed that the chairman, Ghanaian finance minister Richard Kwame Peprah, had resigned.
fields.body:
Hard-pressed Ashanti Goldfields fired its finance director, Mark Keatley, yesterday and confirmed that the chairman, Ghanaian finance minister Richard Kwame Peprah, had resigned.

Africa's third-largest gold producer had been under pressure to dismiss Mr Keatley following massive losses on its gold hedging book which brought the Accra-based group to the brink of default.

Ashanti last week was ordered to hold an extraordinary general meeting on March 3 to consider demands for board changes from disgruntled investors led by Swiss-based Adryx Mining and Metals.

Ashanti has proposed that Mr Keatley steps down formally after completing the final accounts for 1999, although it wants him to stay on until a successor is found.

Mr Kwame Peprah has left with effect from last week to concentrate on his governmental role. Phillip Tarsh, the company's most senior non-executive director, has become acting chairman until a new figurehead is appointed.

The Ghanaian government, which holds a 20% stake and a golden share in Ashanti, has called for a meeting with shareholders this week to discuss ways forward for the problem-stricken group.

The courts have ruled that Ashanti cannot enter into new financial transactions until after the meeting.

But the company had been due to sign a $100m loan agreement last Thursday, and needs cash quickly to pay for work on the attractive Geita gold project in Tanzania. It aims to sell a 50% stake there to raise money in the future.

Ashanti has blamed its financial difficulties on a sudden rise in the gold price following the announcement in September that 15 central banks had decided to limit sales of gold into the market.

The gold price rose $86 in the next 11 days while Ashanti's hedge book was geared to prices continuing a steady decline. Other gold producers have seen their stocks hit by the price spike but Ashanti's margin-free limits were lower than its peers in north America because of its Ghanaian base.

Ashanti's woes also hit Lonmin, Britain's fourth biggest mining company and Africa's third biggest platinum producer, which owns 32% of Ashanti. It announced in December that it was weighing up the sale of majority stakes in its two coal units, Duiker Mining and Tweefontein United Collieries, after analysts discounted the Ashanti holding as next to worthless.

"The sale of Lonmin's coal operations will form the next stage of our strategy to refocus our activities into a precious metals group and to provide shareholders with the benefit of the higher market rating given to that sector," said chairman John Craven.
