fields.headline: BAE fury over Airbus job
fields.standfirst: European consortium overrides UK objections
fields.trailText: The future of Airbus, the European aircraft-maker, came under a renewed cloud yesterday when BAE Systems threatened to veto a top-level executive appointment.
fields.body:
The future of Airbus, the European aircraft-maker, came under a renewed cloud yesterday when BAE Systems threatened to veto a top-level executive appointment.

The European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company (Eads), being formed from the merger of France's Aerospatiale Matra, Germany's Dasa and Spain's Casa, overrode BAE's objections and named Noel Forgeard as head of its Airbus operations.

Mr Forgeard is already chief executive of the four-nation consortium running Airbus, and BAE made plain that his proposed dual role created an immediate conflict of interest.

BAE, which has a 20% stake in the consortium compared with the 80% holding controlled by Eads, is determined to resist Franco-German efforts to push it into accepting a new corporate structure for Airbus.

The row is the latest in a series of tensions between BAE and its European partners since the British group walked out of a proposed marriage with Dasa in December 1998 and took as its merger partner the Marconi defence business of the then GEC.

That prompted Manfred Bischoff, the Dasa chief executive now set to become co-chairman of Eads, to refuse point-blank to talk with John Weston, BAE chief executive, for several months. Relations, though now formally cordial, have scarcely improved since.

Mr Forgeard's nomination as chief executive of Eads' Airbus division came as Dr Bischoff and Jean-Luc Lagardère, his co-chairman, named 52 top managers to run the company - if and when its formation is approved by regulators.

Eads will have two chief executives, Philippe Camus, Aerospatiale Matra's current chief, and Rainer Hertrich, now in charge at Dasa. They will be based in Paris and Munich respectively.

The management structure - 25 French, 23 German and four Spanish executives but, officially without any national quota - was greeted by British industry sources as "a complete dog's breakfast" that Anglo-Saxon shareholders would throw out and "a typical Franco-German political fudge".

There was ridicule that Eads, in its official communiqué posted in Amsterdam where it is to be incorporated, said: "Eads will have an integrated central organisation with functions in Amsterdam, Madrid, Munich and Paris."

But it was Mr Forgeard's dual role that prompted quiet rage, even though BAE sources went out of their way to stress that discussions continued with a view to finding a solution.

"This is not a closed subject. Eads is not yet a formed company and this issue will not die until it is.

"People need to understand that there's a dialogue and we have a voice which is to be heard," senior BAE officials said.

The original idea was to turn Airbus into a fully fledged plc, but Eads now wants it to become Airbus Integrated Company - effectively an unlisted subsidiary of the Franco-German-Spanish combine.

Mr Camus reiterated plans to float off 34.5% of Eads, raising Euro4bn-Euro5bn (£2.5bn-£3bn) in June, but the Airbus structure will have to be finalised by then or the float cannot go ahead.

BAE, which makes the wings for the Airbus fleet, is seeking a bigger stake in the eventual company because it contributes up to 30% of profits.

The row also casts a new shadow over the planned A3XX superjumbo, a project costing $11bn (£7bn) and prompting BAE to ask for record government loans of up to £500m.

fields.headline: Trading names
fields.standfirst: EU and South Africa's war of words
fields.trailText: A "trivial" complaint over whether the terms ouzo and grappa can be used outside Greece and Italy is threatening the European union's reputation as a trading partner, South Africa's trade minister, Alec Erwin, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
A "trivial" complaint over whether the terms ouzo and grappa can be used outside Greece and Italy is threatening the European union's reputation as a trading partner, South Africa's trade minister, Alec Erwin, warned yesterday.

Efforts by the two countries to protect their domestic producers from competition from South Africa have derailed an $18bn (£11.3bn) annual trade pact with South Africa, even though it produces no ouzo at all and only negligible quantities of grappa.

Speaking at the United Nations conference on trade and development in Bangkok, where security has been tightened because of protester action, Mr Erwin said the EU was gaining a reputation as an "unreliable" partner in trade talks and unable to raise itself above trivia.

Mr Erwin warned that the bad blood over the trade pact would give other countries a poor impression of the EU's position on trade liberalisation. "It is often not wise to tweak a tiger by the tail," he said, referring to the Cairns group of farming exporting countries which have being putting pressure on the EU to free its heavily protected agricultural sector.

The South African-EU trade pact, which would liberalise 90% of trade between the two regions, has been under negotiation for four years and was supposed to come into force on January 1.

However, at the last minute, Italy and Greece refused to ratify the agreement because it did not explicitly protect the terms ouzo and grappa.

"It is impossible to negotiate when you never know when it is stopping," Mr Erwin said. "On some very silly issues we feel the European union is incapable of raising itself above peripheral concerns."

webTitle: Lloyd's sports group serves an ace with Disney deal

fields.headline: Lloyd's sports group serves an ace with Disney deal
fields.trailText: MV Sports Group, chaired by Britain's Davis Cup captain David Lloyd, has won a potential £10m licensing deal with Walt Disney to supply Winnie the Pooh and Mickey Mouse characters in Europe.
fields.body:
MV Sports Group, chaired by Britain's Davis Cup captain David Lloyd, has won a potential £10m licensing deal with Walt Disney to supply Winnie the Pooh and Mickey Mouse characters in Europe.

The loss-making toy licensee, which supplies its products mainly to catalogue firms such as Argos and Index, said the agreement coincided with the Easter release of The Tigger movie, Disney's feature-length film based on Winnie the Pooh.

Negotiations to land the licence to make spin-off games and cards from the Japanese craze Pokemon, have proved more difficult and are still progressing, the company said.

MV, which reported a £526,000 loss in the half to June last year, is expected to see the Walt Disney agreement boost turnover by £10m over the next two years.

The company is also considering changing its financial year end from December to June, to account for the Christmas period's dominance of more than 50% of sales.

Mr Lloyd said yesterday he expected MV, which also holds the European licence for Barbie-related products, would return to profit in 2001.

The group's difficulty has been blamed on delays in integrating its acquisition of Chelful, which repositioned the company as a toy and leisure supplier. The decline in the skateboard market and the poor sales of Star Wars products were also contributors.

"This is marvellous news for the company," Mr Lloyd said. "Winnie the Pooh is the most consistently performing global children's licence. The Easter cinema release of the Tigger movie and subsequent video release is the perfect icing on the cake."

The company also gains the licence for selling products of the movie Toy Story 2, which is Disney's highest-ever grossing film.

MV has also struck a deal with football club Manchester United for the licence to manufacture and distribute its bikes, scooters and related products in Britain and internationally.

"We will be looking at anything in the toy business that will add shareholder value," Mr Lloyd said. "We are about building up a very strong brand of licences and we are still looking for opportunities."

The loss-making toy licensee, which supplies its products mainly to catalogue firms such as Argos and Index, said the agreement coincided with the Easter release of The Tigger movie, Disney's feature-length film based on Winnie the Pooh. Negotiations to land the licence to make spin-off games and cards from the Japanese craze Pokemon, have proved more difficult and are still progressing, the company said. MV, which reported a £526,000 loss in the half to June last year, is expected to see the Walt Disney agreement boost turnover by £10m over the next two years. The company is also considering changing its financial year end from December to June, to account for the Christmas period's dominance of more than 50% of sales. Mr Lloyd said yesterday he expected MV, which also holds the European licence for Barbie-related products, would return to profit in 2001. The group's difficulty has been blamed on delays in integrating its acquisition of Chelful, which repositioned the company as a toy and leisure supplier. The decline in the skateboard market and the poor sales of Star Wars products were also contributors. "This is marvellous news for the company," Mr Lloyd said. "Winnie the Pooh is the most consistently performing global children's licence. The Easter cinema release of the Tigger movie and subsequent video release is the perfect icing on the cake." The company also gains the licence for selling products of the movie Toy Story 2, which is Disney's highest-ever grossing film. MV has also struck a deal with football club Manchester United for the licence to manufacture and distribute its bikes, scooters and related products in Britain and internationally. "We are about building up a very strong brand of licences and we are still looking for opportunities."

fields.headline: Pringle to cut 140 in shake-up
fields.trailText: Knitwear company Pringle said yesterday that it would cut up to 140 jobs in a shake-up that also heralded the arrival of a former Marks & Spencer marketing executive as the company's boss.
fields.body:
Knitwear company Pringle said yesterday that it would cut up to 140 jobs in a shake-up that also heralded the arrival of a former Marks & Spencer marketing executive as the company's boss.

The redundancies were announced by Pringle's parent company, Dawson International, which said it was restructuring its manufacturing operations at its factories in the Scottish Borders, and were the result of Pringle's expected sale to Hong Kong firm Fang Brothers Knitting.

Dawson International said the deal would safeguard the future of more than half of Pringle's 400 employees at its factory in Hawick.

M&S said that marketing executive and divisional director Kim Winser was leaving the group at the end of the month to become Pringle's chief executive.

"She was offered an excellent opportunity at Pringle and we are looking for a replacement," M&S said.

Pringle's relatively weak performance has been blamed by many retail analysts on the "Alan Partridge factor".

The spoof character, played by comedian Steve Coogan in the cult BBC television comedy Knowing Me, Knowing You, favoured the company's "sports casual" look in a vain attempt to follow fashion trends.

Richard Perks, of Retail Intelligence, said: "I don't think Pringle has really tried to reinvent itself. The brands that are doing well at the moment tend to be rather more fashionable."

Mr Munn said the cuts came after a review of manufacturing capacity across its factories.

webTitle: Sara Lee bid fails to suit Courtaulds

fields.headline: Sara Lee bid fails to suit Courtaulds
fields.trailText: Courtaulds Textiles was last night fighting for its independence after a hostile $166m (£104m) bid from American food and consumer products group, Sara Lee.
fields.body:
Courtaulds Textiles was last night fighting for its independence after a hostile $166m (£104m) bid from American food and consumer products group, Sara Lee.

Shares in the London-based firm surged 82% and closed up 52 at 115p. However, the US move was rejected by Courtaulds management as "opportunistic" amid expectations of a higher offer.

Courtaulds - a designer and manufacturer of branded and own-label clothing and textile products - is a leading supplier to high-street retailer Marks & Spencer which accounts for 40% of Courtaulds turnover. The texile group employs 20,000 in 17 countries around the world and has recently boosted its sales to M&S whilst other British suppliers have missed out.

Sara Lee chief executive John H Bryan said the 100p per share offer would provide shareholders with "a full cash exit for their existing holdings and remove any risk and uncertainty ... in connection with the challenges facing Courtaulds".

He said the offer represented a 60% premium on Friday's closing price.

The British firm's chief executive, Colin Dyer, said talks between the two sides had revealed that Sara Lee was prepared to make a higher offer. "There is no way this current bid reflects the value of the company. They are trying to steal it."

Courtaulds's value was "very significantly in excess of 100p" according to Dyer, whose view was backed up by analysts, one of whom recently put a price of 138p per share on it.

Sara Lee insisted Courtaulds would gain substantially from the financial strength of the US group which has its headquarters in Chicago, employs 138,000 and has operations in 40 countries.

"The combination of Sara Lee and Courtaulds has strong commercial logic and will bring benefits for retail trade customers and consumers which could not be achieved by Courtaulds alone, a spokesman said."

The Courtaulds name - which dates back to 1891 - and its operations in 17 countries would all remain as independent units while leading brands such as Gossard, Berlei and Aristoc would be developed faster, he added.

Courtaulds, like other textile suppliers, has been hard hit by price deflation but Mr Dyer claimed he was "transforming the business" by switching manufacturing to lower cost centres in Asia. Ten years ago Courtaulds employed 18,000 staff in Britain but this number is now closer to 11,000.

webTitle: OFT flattens the beer even more

fields.headline: OFT flattens the beer even more
fields.trailText: There is not much fizz left in the share price of British brewers but the regulators managed to flatten the beer even more yesterday with details of the office of fair trading review.
fields.body:
There is not much fizz left in the share price of British brewers but the regulators managed to flatten the beer even more yesterday with details of the office of fair trading review.

It is often said that when bureaucrats meddle in business they usually end up with the opposite result to the one they expected. It would be ironic if further depressing the stock price of companies such as Whitbread, down 12p at 445p, ended in a foreign takeover bid. It is no secret that this company was already cheap and vulnerable, but that also goes for the other big brewers.

After some early falls Bass ended up a marginal 3p at 612p, and Scottish and Newcastle up 2p at 352p. They took heart from the only thing new in the OFT statement: the swift timescale of the review.

John Bridgeman promised to complete by August. Six months of uncertainty was well received, considering the original "beer orders" published a decade ago after a review that took three years.

But its not just British competition regulators who are on the prowl. Investigators from Brussels burst into the offices of Groupe Danone, brewer of Kronenbourg, two weeks ago trying to find evidence of a French beer cartel.

New European Union rules that take effect in June will limit the power of the continent's largest brewers to lock retailers and distributors into restrictive supply deals.

The OFT says it will consider whether the beer orders should be "removed, relaxed, tightened or stay the same" and concentrate on issues of price and choice. Whitbread yesterday welcomed the investigation believing it will clear the brewers of being part of "rip-off Britain".

Few commentators expect anything truly negative to be unearthed but neither do they expect brewers to be let off. Critics such as the Campaign for Real Ale want loan ties to be barred and no firm to control more than 2,000 pubs.

Whitbread, which also controls Marriott Hotels and David Lloyd Leisure, is already close to throwing in the brewing towel. It has made clear its brewing arm would be sold off for the right price.

Prospects for a major upturn in beer sales are limited with the market flat while there is also an oversupply of pubs. It is small wonder many conclude the only reason to buy this sector is in hope of bids.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The banking sector suffered a Monday morning hangover after the bidding binge of recent weeks. Lloyds TSB , down 23p to 601p, the so-called "star" of the sector, watched as its shares fell even further after Friday's profit figures and ill-received internet plans.
fields.body:
The banking sector suffered a Monday morning hangover after the bidding binge of recent weeks. Lloyds TSB , down 23p to 601p, the so-called "star" of the sector, watched as its shares fell even further after Friday's profit figures and ill-received internet plans.

The bank's shares are now at the level they last visited at the height of the LTCM hedge fund crisis in October 1998. Barclays , whose chief executive Matt Barrett meets the City for the first time this morning at its 1999 results, also fell, ending at £14.33, down 38p. NatWest fell 43p to £11.33, while victorious bidder Royal Bank of Scot land slipped 64p to 807p as investors reminded themselves that integration will take a lot of work.

Disappointment also hit the Britain's merging media giants. They encountered a bit of static on the stock market yesterday, following a declaration that the competition commission is to examine their proposed tie-up.

Carlton Communications tumbled 62p to 686p, while United News & Media - the owner of Express Newspapers - slumped 61p to 733p.

Although the regulatory investigation was generally expected, the decision by trade secretary Stephen Byers reminded investors that it could be many months before the deal is completed. Fellow ITV franchisee Granada , which has indicated that it may try a hostile approach to break up the deal, fell 20p to 634p as the likelihood of any immediate action receded.

Media group Reuters lost ground in sympathy, losing 30p to £13.88, contributing to a general sell-off in blue-chip shares - the FTSE 100 index lost 124.7 points, closing at 6,068.6.

The biggest component of the fall was newly enlarged Vodafone AirTouch , which slipped 16p to 329p. Vodafone has become such a large slice of the FTSE 100 that its modest decline cost the index 51 points. There was talk that realism was beginning to set tle in, after the euphoria surrounding the mobile phone company's takeover of German rival Mannesmann. However, analysts believe Vodafone shares are likely to remain volatile while fund managers adjust their portfolios to take account of its size.

Marks & Spencer recovered from a nine-year low, climbing 5p to 237p amid further whispers of bid interest, while MEPC climbed 15p to 338p amid weekend reports that the property sector looks cheap.

Among the smaller stocks, hi-tech stockbroking specialist Durlacher jumped 360p to £37.00, amid talk that it could join the FTSE 100.

webTitle: EU to back German as new head of IMF

fields.headline: EU to back German as new head of IMF
fields.trailText: The European union is almost certain to back former World Bank executive Caio Koch-Weser as its candidate to be the next head of the International Monetary Fund, ending months of wrangling.
fields.body:
The European union is almost certain to back former World Bank executive Caio Koch-Weser as its candidate to be the next head of the International Monetary Fund, ending months of wrangling.

Foreign ministers meeting in Brussels are understood to have reached a consensus that will allow the 55-year-old German to be officially proposed at a meeting on February 28.

Both France and Britain had expressed concern over Mr Koch-Weser's credentials for the key post of IMF managing director to replace Frenchman Michel Camdessus.

German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer said, however, there had been no objections at the Brussels meeting to the name of Mr Koch-Weser, a deputy finance minister, going into the IMF hat.

"Nobody expressed any opposition, not even Hubert Vedrine [the French foreign minister]," Mr Fischer told reporters.

France's earlier cool reaction to Mr Koch-Weser's bid had hampered Germany's efforts to boost its international profile and claim a job which has traditionally been held by a European.

Mr Vedrine made clear that Paris had softened its line: "If there is a consensus over an EU candidate, France will not stand in the way," he said.

The German finance ministry, confirming expectations that Mr Koch-Weser would be officially nominated by EU finance ministers later this month, stopped short of describing Mr Vedrine's comments as a breakthrough.

"We regard this as another positive signal for our candidate," a spokeswoman told the news agency Reuters yesterday.

French officials said in Paris that in the end, the importance of certain misgivings about Mr Koch-Weser were outweighed by the need to nurture France's traditional strong relations with Berlin in European matters.

The United States and some emerging countries have also been cool to Mr Koch-Weser's bid to head the global lender, but Germany hopes resistance will crumble once he finally gains EU support.

US treasury secretary Lawrence Summers, in a clear jibe at Mr Koch-Weser's lack of experience in national government, has called for a strong leader to replace Mr Camdessus, whose 13 years at the helm of the IMF officially ended on Monday.

Critics of Mr Koch-Weser, a 25-year World Bank veteran who specialised in development issues before moving last year to take charge of international affairs at the German finance ministry, say that he is lacking in real authority on monetary issues. But Mr Koch-Weser remains the front runner, challenged only by former Japanese finance ministry official Eisuke Sakakibara.

 The economies of Britain and the United States are running close to full capacity, with consumer demand at "near unsustainable" levels, Bank of England governor Eddie George said last night.

fields.headline: Buried treasure
fields.standfirst: Chris Smith says we can now rummage through the Tate's private vaults. So why don't the gallery staff see it that way?  Jonathan Jones reports
fields.trailText: Chris Smith says we can now rummage through the Tate's private vaults. So why don't the gallery staff see it that way? Jonathan Jones reports
fields.body:
It could be a Sherlock Holmes story - The Mystery of the Phantom Stores. Last week culture secretary Chris Smith proudly told the Guardian that museums are opening their jealously guarded storerooms to the public, with the Tate Gallery leading the way.

"Under our access schemes, anyone can go down to the Tate's warehouse and rummage around," said the minister.Yet call the Tate demanding to exercise your right of access and you'll be told that, while the Tate does indeed have a "fantastic new storage space" in south London, which curators "hope in due course people will be able to visit", this is not possible at the moment.

The department of culture, media and sport had "absolutely no idea" of the confusion's source. Instead they offered other examples of good practice: the Museum of London is sending objects in boxes to school programmes; various community groups are being encouraged to delve into the stores of Newcastle's Laing Art Gallery.

The opening of museum stores is one of a raft of proposals to improve access in a policy paper issued by the DCMS last year. Museums for the Many says that museums directly funded by the department must set targets for access in their new three-year funding agreements.

There's nothing new here. If you want to see backstage at the Science Museum, you can book a visit to its stores at Wroughton, an airfield on the outskirts of Swindon, where hangars hold a treasure trove of engineering history. The site dates back to the 70s. When the Tate stores were at Millbank they could be visited on request - so it's ironic that the Tate is currently alone among major London museums in not rushing to open its stores to the public.

The V&A has its own plans to open public-access stores at Wroughton, and guarantees anyone can see any objects in its collection on request. National museums are gradually moving their collections out of shared storage at Blythe House to more public facilities. In 2003 the British Museum is to open a new study centre in a former Bloomsbury post office to make its vast collection of artefacts more accessible.

The real mystery is not why the Tate has not opened its stores, but why the others have. Museums have a double function: they are centres of display and places of conservation. Do the roles really need to be integrated? Opening the storeroom sounds democratic: rather than deferentially peering at objects in glass cases while the real fun is had by experts behind the scenes, we will all be able to unwrap a mummy, handle a piece of 18th-century porcelain or rifle through a box of Roman coins.

Handling an object is not in itself enlightening, however. Museums do good by setting artefacts in context: using the relics of ancient civilisations to reconstruct what those civilisations were like, displaying art in a way that makes sense. Without that orderly display, you might as well rummage through your attic.

The solution to the mystery is, unsurprisingly, a murky bit of political evasion. When you examine Museums for the Many, it becomes all too clear that the push to open stores is blurring the issue of free entry. There is no mention in this document of Smith's original ambition that there should be universal free access to museums: that is no longer a New Labour promise or even aspiration. Instead this document says that "access involves more than just tackling the issue of charging". It talks about the cultural and social factors that might stop people going to museums and the "sensory barriers" that museums put between artefacts and the public. One way to widen the appeal of museums, suggests the document, is by "providing appropriate means of access to reserve collections and stored items for the general public as well as scholars".

There is one exemplary case of a museum opening its entire collection to the public in a way that complements and enriches its displays. The National Gallery has all its collection, except paintings that are being conserved or are on loan, permanently on display. The paintings that don't pass muster jumble into the Lower Galleries, where you can look at bizarre, forgotten, sometimes bad paintings to your heart's content. You can sample the National Gallery's entire collection, whenever you want, as often as you like. That's because the museum has the only kind of access programme that counts - it's free.

webTitle: Reach for the stars - on a bicycle

fields.headline: Reach for the stars - on a bicycle
fields.standfirst: Can a lawnmower engine take us into space? Does balsa wood make a good rocket? Belgian artist Panamarenko thinks so. By  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Can a lawnmower engine take us into space? Does balsa wood make a good rocket? Belgian artist Panamarenko thinks so. By Adrian Searle
fields.body:
The flying saucer lies on the gallery floor like a gigantic infant's discarded toy. Next to it is a huge zeppelin, a bloated, patched and discoloured envelope of air, wedged between floor and ceiling, taking up almost an entire room in the Hayward Gallery. It appears to have been uncomfortably inserted into the space like a vast, nightmarish suppository. An air-pump keeps the thing inflated, but it isn't going anywhere. Nor is the spaceship, nor any of the other flying machines, hovercrafts, back-pack levitation devices and solar-powered prehistoric birds, in this first British survey of the work of Panamarenko, one of Belgium's leading artists.

One might, uncharitably, think of Panamarenko as an entertainer, a sort of continental Heath-Robinson, but that would be a mistake. This singular artist, whose work is influenced by the poetics of the great avant-gardist Marcel Broodthaers and the idealistic notions of Joseph Beuys, has, since the 60s, been preoccupied by ideas of escape. In a way, he is a real-life equivalent of Russian artist Ilya Kabakov's fictional character, who dreamt of escaping the confines of his wretched Moscow flat, constructing a craft from the things he had about him. Panamarenko also recalls those Colditz prisoners who hoped to escape in a glider built from paper, cocoa tins and stolen scraps.

A self-styled "artist/technologist" who long ago abandoned his original name, Panamarenko lives and works in Antwerp. His pseudonym conflates Pan American Airlines with a Russian-sounding suffix, as though to weld together east and west. The word Panama also reminds us of the canal that links the Pacific to the Atlantic. But Panamarenko's aspirations go beyond the global: he envisions outer space as his next frontier. His flying saucer, however, is made of fibre-glass, and runs on compressed air. Nasa does not call him for advice.

Surrounded by his experimental machines and a flock of parrots, Panamarenko dreams of flight but rarely travels outside the city of his birth. It's a Belgian thing, according to Jon Thompson, curator of the Hayward's show. Another of Belgium's foremost (and equally reclusive) artists, Thierry de Cordier, appears to want to bury himself in the dark, damp earth.

Out on one of the top-floor sculpture courts, a submarine squats in the sunshine, the London Eye slowly turning behind it. What is the submarine doing up here? Maybe Panamarenko has anticipated a greater rise in the sea level than global warming suggests. Like all his machines, the submarine looks as if it ought to work and is clearly the product of thousands of hours of labour. The stubby body, though, appears too small for the conning tower. "It has to have a conning tower that size," its inventor has said, "so that no one who saw it coming would think that it was only as big as a kitchen."

Panamarenko is one of art's - and nature's - originals. His fantasies of gravity-defying, pedal-powered flight, of electromagnetic levitation, of lawnmower-engine powered jet propulsion, have driven most of his working life. He's been trying to get off the ground since the mid-60s. His failure is, at least in part, intended and ironical. His is a tragicomic aspiration. His earliest machine was bicycle-powered. Beckett's Molloy travelled by bike (though he wasn't really going anywhere), and Godot, who never arrives, was named after a Tour de France cyclist. There's a thesis in there somewhere.

Panamarenko sometimes dresses in an ill-fitting military garb. His hat is on display at the Hayward: a Soviet-looking kepi with a badge bearing the artist's name. He's painted the top of the cap in gold, and on it rest two little plastic trout. "With a hat like this you could enter the best hotel and they would immediately give you the best suite," Panamarenko once said. "I know because I have tried it."

Panamarenko seems so laden with eccentricities, and his work so wayward, that one is more than merely amused. There is something awesome about him. He has his own theories of physics - mish-mashes of Newton, Einstein, quantum mechanics, ironical wit and gobbledygook. But before you dismiss him as a dotty "character" or a mad professor, remember that Newton never lost his interest in alchemy, and suffered a monumental crack-up; that Einstein cultivated a somewhat eccentric persona; and that some of the terms of quantum physics come from James Joyce's Finnegans Wake.

Call his machines what you will - sculptures, utopian models, proposals, follies - they reflect a will to succeed. Yet their failure is certain. Take his balsa-wood, one-man V1 rocket, of which he says "This is the fastest way to get to New York_ you would have to wear goggles, otherwise your eyes would be gouged out by the force of the speed". Or the Flymo-engine powered back-packs, which would almost certainly burn the wearer to death, or propel him forcefully into the ground. The Aeromodeller, that vast zeppelin-shaped balloon, with its wickerwork basket and asbestos suits, was originally designed as an airborne house that would impress Brigitte Bardot when it landed on her front lawn and whisked her away from the paparazzi.

Panamarenko admits that the earliest work in the exhibition, Das Flugzeug, which he made just after he left art school in 1967, isn't successful. A racing bike's pedals, handlebars and seat are positioned in the middle of long steel tubes, held together with gaffer tape. The pedals power two sets of propellers, held in place by a filigree of wires. The handlebars are set low to prevent the rider being decapitated. Das Flugzeug takes up an entire gallery. It is delicate, beautiful and utterly impractical. "I discovered all that stuff about art being an unconscious thing," said Panamarenko. "You thought that something was great but you didn't know why. I think this aeroplane is great but I don't know why."

I think it's great too, and I don't know why either. It's useless. It'll never get off the ground by pedal-power alone. Only a supreme act of mental will could get it airborne. This is the point, I think.

The exhibition is exhilarating, alarming and frustrating. Exhilarating because Panamarenko's inventions are so charming, so clunky, so very nearly plausible. Alarming because of both the effort that has gone into their construction, and their inherent mechanical dangers. Frustrating, because nothing works, nothing moves. None of the devices are set in motion. No records of his attempts at flight, no test-bed films of his machines actually working, however disastrously, are in the show. We can watch a couple of videos of Panamarenko lecturing before a blackboard, in Flemish, but these excerpts unhinge his claims to science, as he grapples, incoherently and unpersuasively, with his very personal take on the laws of physics.

A few years ago I saw Panamarenko's solar-powered Archaeopterix perched on a tree trunk in the Middelheim sculpture park on the outskirts of Antwerp. As I approached the trunk, something seemed to be scrabbling and jumping about on it. It was a mechanical prehistoric chicken, programmed to leap into life when anyone approached, activated by a sensor buried in the trunk. Every time the weather turned nasty, one of the park staff had to run out of their shed to rescue the poor creature from the rain.

This encounter with Panamarenko's imagination was wonderful, and a little scary. Some of these solar-powered creatures are in the Hayward, but they're lifeless, static, pinned down by little vices and clamps.

In his illuminating essay in the exhibition catalogue, Jon Thompson invokes Pieter Bruegel the Elder's Icarus, distantly crashing into the sea, unnoticed by the ploughman on the cliff-top. We look on from a slightly elevated position, as though we ourselves were levitating, seeing everything. As though, in fact, the entire world were within our compass. It is a haunting, dream-like painting, in which we are given a kind of omnipotence. Everyone dreams of flying. We've all had nightmares of falling. Most of us wake up.

 Panamarenko is at the Hayward Gallery, London SE1 (0171-960 4242), till April 2.

fields.headline: Lightning conductor
fields.standfirst: Can Gerard Schwarz save the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic? The orchestra's new music director talks to  Stephen Moss
fields.trailText: Can Gerard Schwarz save the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic? The orchestra's new music director talks to Stephen Moss
fields.body:
It is close to midnight and Gerard Schwarz has had a tough week. But you would never know it. Immaculately dressed and sipping a brandy, he rattles off the reasons he has taken on Liverpool's ailing orchestra. He was originally a trumpet player from New York - and you can't get much lippier than that.

Like almost every British regional orchestra, the Royal Liverpool Phil harmonic has had a sticky few years. Its deficit stands at £2.5m and, according to spokesman Ed Jones, "had it not been for an understanding bank manager, we might easily have gone under". Audiences average 75-80% but are in gentle decline, and attracting younger concertgoers is proving tricky.

The outgoing music director, Petr Altrichter, can't be blamed for the deficit - its origins lie further back than his arrival in 1996. But he has not proved popular and - an odd complaint, perhaps - has been deemed too preoccupied with the music. Liverpool is seeking a conductor who offers vision as well as sound.

Enter Schwarz, who was last week named as the RLPO's new music director and hence chief conductor. Does he mind the management presenting him as a sort of corporate executive? "Orchestras hire a music director for their ability to conduct," he says. "But a music director has a lot of other responsibilities: dealing with the personnel, dealing with guest conductors and guest soloists, building a season, dealing with the orchestra's position in its community. If you're not willing to take them on, you shouldn't take the job."

Schwarz, 52, was first trumpet with the New York Philharmonic under Bernstein and Boulez, but left in the 70s to concentrate on conducting. "I loved playing and I was pretty good," he says, "but it wasn't what I ultimately wanted to do with my life."

He has transformed the Seattle Symphony Orchestra, where he has been music director for the past 15 years. "When I went to Seattle, there was a lot of work to do," says Schwarz. "The city was not particularly affluent or cultured. The Seattle Symphony was a decent orchestra, but it didn't have a very strong staff or a strong board. But it had the makings of a first-class orchestra. Now Seattle is the richest city in the country and the orchestra is phenomenal. We have a great hall, and a recital hall, and do 150 concerts a year. Ticket sales are 92% of capacity and next year our ticket income will be $9m. What's happened is a miracle."

How does Liverpool compare? "It's a little better placed than Seattle was 15 years ago," says Schwarz. "Everyone in Liverpool is on the same path and they are open to almost anything."

Even sackings? "I don't do that," he insists. "In all my time in Seattle I've fired two people. I've moved a few people around and encouraged a lot of retirements, but I'm not a firer. You work with the people you have."

Schwarz has run the summer Mozart festival at New York's Lincoln Center for the past 20 years and, more recently, spent time in Japan with the Tokyo Philharmonic. His stint with Tokyo has now ended and next year he relinquishes the Mozart festival, leaving him commuting between Seattle and Liverpool, where he will spend 14 weeks a year.

Is that enough to make a difference? "It's a lot of presence," he says. "If you're there too much, it would drive everybody crazy. Conductors need to get out of town - Karajan said that. But I will be involved the whole time and I'll shape the programme. If you don't like the programme, blame me; if you don't like the soloists or the guest conductor, it's my fault, even if I'm not there."

So what are the priorities? "Financial stabilisation is crucial. We have to raise our earned income and make sure the community sees us as an important part of civic life. I want to make it possible to do concerts at different times, on weekday afternoons say, to attract people who can't get to evening concerts."

There will also be occasional pay-what-you-can concerts for those unable to afford the £10-£15 ticket prices. "Every once in a while you have to give back to your community," he says. "You have to say, 'We love you and we want you to know that we are not an elite organisation.' "

webTitle: 'I didn't want to write an opera. I wanted to burn opera houses'

fields.headline: 'I didn't want to write an opera. I wanted to burn opera houses'
fields.standfirst: As Mark-Anthony Turnage's latest opera premieres,  Andrew Clements asks why he changed his mind
fields.trailText: As Mark-Anthony Turnage's latest opera premieres, Andrew Clements asks why he changed his mind
fields.body:
Was music a major part of your life when you were a child? Yes, it was an obsession. My mother played the piano and my father was a tenor; my mother also played the cornet in father's band. I had piano lessons from the age of six, which I didn't like to start with. But gradually I became obsessed: my parents were very religious and the piano became an inner world I could escape into. I hadn't thought about composing then; I was fascinated by the sounds but I didn't know how to put them together, and certainly never knew how to write them down.

From the age of nine I was writing pieces, and improvising before that. I used to pretend to my parents that I was playing the pieces that were set, but really I was improvising and distorting them. That's how I discovered composition, by distorting other people's music out of boredom.

None of my early pieces (they were very ambitious - symphonies and concertos) made sense. I remember they had lots of notes - nothing's changed in that way! I had a list of the works I wanted to write in the future - I was obsessed with the idea of being a composer. You can imagine that coming from a fairly working-class background, the idea of being a composer was very strange - certainly to my school friends. Not to my parents, they were very supportive. But I had a lot of resistance from school; I had a music teacher who was very dismissive, but I was determined.

What did you hear at home?
My mother listened to Beethoven, the symphonies and concertos. That's what I grew up with, as well as Haydn and Mozart. I bought records when I was quite young, before I started composing, and I became fascinated by the lives of the composers. I had my Top Ten - my school-friends thought I was very eccentric - I remember Nielsen was number one at one stage; later it was Shostakovich. I was about 11 then. I didn't know anything about pop music; obviously there were The Beatles but my parents considered them... evil is too strong a word, but their music was thought to be corrupting, and so I never listened to it.

I listened to Radio 3 continually. There was loads of contemporary music broadcast then. I was resistant to it at first, but it's how I got to know about composers like Stockhausen. My musical education at school was so poor I thought I could learn much more by listening to the radio.

At the age of 14 you were accepted by the junior department of the Royal College of Music. When did you begin to study with Oliver Knussen?
After I had been there about a year my composition teacher left, and I received a card that just said, "You're studying with Oliver Knussen." I thought this was fantastic - he was a composer I'd actually heard of. He was astonished because I had recognised him and that immediately started our friendship. Olly had to do a lot to instil confidence in me.

Without Olly's brilliant teaching, I would never have written Night Dances. People ask me how I was able to write such an assured orchestral piece when I was 20; well, that's because of Olly. Even now, I take new pieces to him and he knows instinctively what works in my music.

By the time you wrote Night Dances you were studying full-time at the RCM, weren't you?
Yes. During that time too I was discovering another type of music, which actually was pretty much peculiar to Essex, where there was an incredible following for fusion. It's very much black American fusion - Herbie Hancock, Freddie Hubbard, Donald Byrd. At the other extreme, there was soul as well - Funkadelic, George Clinton. It was a really rich time, but I think if I'd been living in Somerset, for instance, it would never have happened.

When did you discover Miles Davis?
That was later. I found out about Miles Davis through Herbie Hancock; I'd probably heard a few things by Miles, and so I went back to Kind of Blue. I didn't actually know about Bitch's Brew, although the things I was listening to were more close to Bitch's Brew. I was listening to all this but of course my music sounded nothing like it, though jazz obviously did find its way in, because the second movement of Night Dances is a tribute to Davis.

I then became obsessed with this music. Those influences are still there in my music because it was a key time in my development.

You composed your opera Greek between 1986 and 1988. How long had you wanted to write an opera?
I didn't want to write an opera at all. I agreed with Pierre Boulez about burning down opera houses. I had a real antipathy to it from my background. I'd seen some opera - I think I saw La Bohème on a school trip - I just found it irritating. I needed to be persuaded by composer Hans Werner Henze to write Greek.

It's always so hard to find subject matter for an opera, really almost impossible. Henze's first suggestion was that I look at Edward Bond's The Pope's Wedding. I was a bit nervous and so it took me quite a while to write to such a famous writer. He didn't reply immediately, so I gave up and approached Steven Berkoff. Berkoff did reply, saying that he thought Greek was the most operatic of his works. I wasn't convinced at first but the more I got submerged in the project the more convinced I became.

How did you set about adapting the text of Greek?
I just got stuck into cutting Berkoff's play and setting the lines almost as soon as I'd cut them. It was a strange way of working. Greek is a very wordy play, and the language is unbelievable - the opera libretto's tame by comparison. I had to match that language, that extraordinary combination of Shakespeare, colloquial English and cockney, and the sort of seaside humour that suddenly becomes incredibly lyrical. But I was so terrified of writing an opera; the very word scared me and almost made me freeze up. So I tried to fool myself - I remember thinking, well, I'll just begin it; I'll mess around, I'll do the pub scene at the beginning, and this won't be in the final version. The football rhythm at the beginning - it's not from BBC Grandstand as a lot of people think, incidentally, it's actually from ITV's World of Sport from years ago - I thought was just too ridiculous and that I couldn't possibly use it in the opera, but I just put it in because I was having fun. Basically I tried to relax. And of course the rhythm did end up in the final version.

I wanted the score to be direct and I felt too that all the bad language couldn't be set to music. I think it's ridiculous when you hear it set elaborately by certain composers. You have to figure out another way of dealing with it. So there is a lot of speech in Greek, which I wouldn't do now.

You received the commission for The Silver Tassie from English National Opera in 1989, so when did you find the subject you wanted? Had you already fixed on that Sean O'Casey play before you began working with librettist Amanda Holden?

I thought The Silver Tassie was remarkable, especially the second act, which is set in the trenches of the first world war. But I sat on the idea for a year before I met Amanda Holden. She gave me the confidence to think that this project could work.

Presumably you realised at an early stage that The Silver Tassie would have to be a very different kind of opera from Greek - much bigger in scale?
Yes. If I'm really honest, I was disappointed when I first got the commission for Greek that I was only allowed an ensemble of 18 players. But for The Silver Tassie I felt that it would be great to write something that made a big noise on stage - hence I was attracted to using a male chorus in the second act. I love Benjamin Britten's opera Peter Grimes, especially the section when the villagers are shouting out his name, and I had seen all those big shows at ENO like Britten's Grimes, Billy Budd and Shostakovich's Lady Macbeth, which were very impressive, so I thought, yes, if I'm going to do another opera it's going to be big.

 The Silver Tassie opens at the London Coliseum tomorrow. Box office: 0171-632 8300. This is an edited extract from Andrew Clements's book Mark-Anthony Turnage, published by Faber & Faber. My mother played the piano and my father was a tenor; my mother also played the cornet in father's band. I had piano lessons from the age of six, which I didn't like to start with. But gradually I became obsessed: my parents were very religious and the piano became an inner world I could escape into. I hadn't thought about composing then; I was fascinated by the sounds but I didn't know how to put them together, and certainly never knew how to write them down. From the age of nine I was writing pieces, and improvising before that. I used to pretend to my parents that I was playing the pieces that were set, but really I was improvising and distorting them. That's how I discovered composition, by distorting other people's music out of boredom. None of my early pieces (they were very ambitious - symphonies and concertos) made sense. I remember they had lots of notes - nothing's changed in that way! I had a list of the works I wanted to write in the future - I was obsessed with the idea of being a composer. You can imagine that coming from a fairly working-class background, the idea of being a composer was very strange - certainly to my school friends. Not to my parents, they were very supportive. But I had a lot of resistance from school; I had a music teacher who was very dismissive, but I was determined. What did you hear at home? My mother listened to Beethoven, the symphonies and concertos. That's what I grew up with, as well as Haydn and Mozart. I bought records when I was quite young, before I started composing, and I became fascinated by the lives of the composers. I had my Top Ten - my school-friends thought I was very eccentric - I remember Nielsen was number one at one stage; later it was Shostakovich. I was about 11 then. I didn't know anything about pop music; obviously there were The Beatles but my parents considered them... evil is too strong a word, but their music was thought to be corrupting, and so I never listened to it. I listened to Radio 3 continually. There was loads of contemporary music broadcast then. I was resistant to it at first, but it's how I got to know about composers like Stockhausen. My musical education at school was so poor I thought I could learn much more by listening to the radio. At the age of 14 you were accepted by the junior department of the Royal College of Music. When did you begin to study with Oliver Knussen? After I had been there about a year my composition teacher left, and I received a card that just said, "You're studying with Oliver Knussen." I thought this was fantastic - he was a composer I'd actually heard of. He was astonished because I had recognised him and that immediately started our friendship. Olly had to do a lot to instil confidence in me. Without Olly's brilliant teaching, I would never have written Night Dances. People ask me how I was able to write such an assured orchestral piece when I was 20; well, that's because of Olly. Even now, I take new pieces to him and he knows instinctively what works in my music. By the time you wrote Night Dances you were studying full-time at the RCM, weren't you? Yes. During that time too I was discovering another type of music, which actually was pretty much peculiar to Essex, where there was an incredible following for fusion. It's very much black American fusion - Herbie Hancock, Freddie Hubbard, Donald Byrd. At the other extreme, there was soul as well - Funkadelic, George Clinton. It was a really rich time, but I think if I'd been living in Somerset, for instance, it would never have happened. When did you discover Miles Davis? That was later. I found out about Miles Davis through Herbie Hancock; I'd probably heard a few things by Miles, and so I went back to Kind of Blue. I didn't actually know about Bitch's Brew, although the things I was listening to were more close to Bitch's Brew. I was listening to all this but of course my music sounded nothing like it, though jazz obviously did find its way in, because the second movement of Night Dances is a tribute to Davis. I then became obsessed with this music. Those influences are still there in my music because it was a key time in my development. You composed your opera Greek between 1986 and 1988. How long had you wanted to write an opera? I didn't want to write an opera at all. I agreed with Pierre Boulez about burning down opera houses. I had a real antipathy to it from my background. I'd seen some opera - I think I saw La Bohème on a school trip - I just found it irritating. I needed to be persuaded by composer Hans Werner Henze to write Greek. It's always so hard to find subject matter for an opera, really almost impossible. Henze's first suggestion was that I look at Edward Bond's The Pope's Wedding. I was a bit nervous and so it took me quite a while to write to such a famous writer. He didn't reply immediately, so I gave up and approached Steven Berkoff. Berkoff did reply, saying that he thought Greek was the most operatic of his works. I wasn't convinced at first but the more I got submerged in the project the more convinced I became. How did you set about adapting the text of Greek? I just got stuck into cutting Berkoff's play and setting the lines almost as soon as I'd cut them. It was a strange way of working. Greek is a very wordy play, and the language is unbelievable - the opera libretto's tame by comparison. I had to match that language, that extraordinary combination of Shakespeare, colloquial English and cockney, and the sort of seaside humour that suddenly becomes incredibly lyrical. But I was so terrified of writing an opera; the very word scared me and almost made me freeze up. So I tried to fool myself - I remember thinking, well, I'll just begin it; I'll mess around, I'll do the pub scene at the beginning, and this won't be in the final version. The football rhythm at the beginning - it's not from BBC Grandstand as a lot of people think, incidentally, it's actually from ITV's World of Sport from years ago - I thought was just too ridiculous and that I couldn't possibly use it in the opera, but I just put it in because I was having fun. Basically I tried to relax. And of course the rhythm did end up in the final version. I wanted the score to be direct and I felt too that all the bad language couldn't be set to music. I think it's ridiculous when you hear it set elaborately by certain composers. You have to figure out another way of dealing with it. So there is a lot of speech in Greek, which I wouldn't do now. You received the commission for The Silver Tassie from English National Opera in 1989, so when did you find the subject you wanted? Had you already fixed on that Sean O'Casey play before you began working with librettist Amanda Holden? I thought The Silver Tassie was remarkable, especially the second act, which is set in the trenches of the first world war. But I sat on the idea for a year before I met Amanda Holden. She gave me the confidence to think that this project could work. Presumably you realised at an early stage that The Silver Tassie would have to be a very different kind of opera from Greek - much bigger in scale? Yes. If I'm really honest, I was disappointed when I first got the commission for Greek that I was only allowed an ensemble of 18 players. But for The Silver Tassie I felt that it would be great to write something that made a big noise on stage - hence I was attracted to using a male chorus in the second act. I love Benjamin Britten's opera Peter Grimes, especially the section when the villagers are shouting out his name, and I had seen all those big shows at ENO like Britten's Grimes, Billy Budd and Shostakovich's Lady Macbeth, which were very impressive, so I thought, yes, if I'm going to do another opera it's going to be big.  The Silver Tassie opens at the London Coliseum tomorrow. fields.headline: Sweet and sour
fields.standfirst: Philip Ridley's Vinegar Street is a poetic fantasy which should be cherished, says Philip Pullman
fields.trailText: Philip Ridley's Vinegar Street is a poetic fantasy which should be cherished, says Philip Pullman
fields.body:
Vinegar Street
By Philip Ridley
Published by Puffin
Price £3.99
Age 10+

For Poppy Picklesticks, Vinegar Street is a realm of delight, where the moonlight glimmers on the green slime in the canal and beetles scurry over broken glass. The other inhabitants are eccentric: Auntie Bruiser with her motorbike, Uncle Larry with his cocktail habit... but one day a new tenant arrives: the stunning, sexy Mandy Nylon. And everything starts to go wrong.

How it all comes right again forms the story. This is a genuine poetic fantasy of a kind that doesn't come along very often, and ought to be cherished when it does.

webTitle: Toy Story 2 leads record cinema weekend

fields.headline: Toy Story 2 leads record cinema weekend
fields.standfirst: Computer-generated characters beach DiCaprio, defeat the Phantom Menace and take £7.75m in three days
fields.trailText: It has no sex, no stars and it was made without even using a camera. Toy Story 2, the computer-animated film that broke all the Hollywood rules, topped the charts yesterday after the biggest weekend in British box office history.
fields.body:
It has no sex, no stars and it was made without even using a camera. Toy Story 2, the computer-animated film that broke all the Hollywood rules, topped the charts yesterday after the biggest weekend in British box office history.

The adventures of Woody, Buzz Lightyear and the dumb dinosaur Rex surpassed Star Wars: The Phantom Menace - the most hyped film of all time - and put the biggest human star on the planet in the shade, too.

Leonardo DiCaprio may have brought hundreds of screaming fans out on to the streets of London last week for the premiere of The Beach, but it made less than one-third of the £7.75m that Toy Story 2 took in its first three days. Toy Story 2's performance was all the more astonishing because most of those who went to see it were children, paying only half price.

The Beach's strong showing, based on the twin appeal of the "dream team" of DiCaprio and Trainspotting director Danny Boyle, plus a bevy of new "British" films led by American Beauty and The End of the Affair, helped to push the total weekend take to a record-breaking £14.2m. That is more than £1m up on the previous high, when cinemagoers queued to see the no-budget horror film The Blair Witch Project at Halloween.

It has been a terrific week for British films, with no fewer than six movies in the top 10 either shot here or made by homegrown film-makers - The Beach, American Beauty, The End of the Affair, Angela's Ashes, Sleepy Hollow and East is East.

Mary Scott, of Screen International, who compiles the figures, said that even allowing for the period covering half-term in many schools, the statistics were staggering.

"It's just amazing how Toy Story 2 has crossed over," she said. "To get such figures it can't just be children - adults must be going as well.

"It's a unique film in many ways, not least in being a sequel that is even better than the original."

Toy Story was the first computer-animated feature film, and Toy Story 2 is another technological first, with digital projecters being used to show it.

Already they are plans for a second sequel which will pick up from where Buzz Lightyear, the superhero with a 40-watt intellect, rescues his cowpoke buddy Woody from the clutches of an evil toy collector.

"It's a landmark in many ways," said Ms Scott. "It's just a good film. People really like it. On any other week, The Beach would have topped the charts on what it did this weekend."

While Toy Story 2 has just sneaked into the American all-time 20 top-grossing films, it still has a long way to go to match the success of Stars Wars and Titanic.

But it has one big advantage on them, said Scott: "It's far shorter, so cinemas can squeeze in seven or eight showings a day while they could only get in maybe five of Titanic."

Best performances

1 Toy Story 2 £7.75m

2 The Beach £2.41m

3 American Beauty £1.65m

4 The End of the Affair £754,419

5 House on Haunted Hill £547,879

6 Double Jeopardy £414,946

7 Angela's Ashes £229,347

8 Sleepy Hollow £132,703

9 The Sixth Sense £128,028

10 East is East £111,337

(Source: Screen International)

webTitle: Four clubs charged in one day

fields.headline: Four clubs charged in one day
fields.standfirst:
Coach of Wimbledon and three players face the music as FA clamps down
Call to deduct points from clubs
Comment
fields.trailText: In a sweeping attempt to stop the ugly indiscipline which is blighting the Premiership the Football Association yesterday charged four clubs, three players and a coach with misconduct.
fields.body:
In a sweeping attempt to stop the ugly indiscipline which is blighting the Premiership the Football Association yesterday charged four clubs, three players and a coach with misconduct.

Leeds and Tottenham have been brought to book as punishment for a scuffle at Elland Road on Saturday which involved the majority of players from both sides.

Chelsea and Wimbledon have been charged in connection with the post-match violence which erupted in the tunnel at Stamford Bridge on Saturday after Chelsea's Dennis Wise reportedly squirted Lucozade at the Wimbledon defender Kenny Cunningham.

Wise and Cunningham, together with the Wimbledon coach Mick Harford, face separate misconduct charges relating to that scrap. The Leeds left-back Ian Harte has been charged for an alleged stamp on Tottenham's Chris Perry.

The FA also emphasised its determination to stamp out the confrontational attitude to officials shown in particular by Manchester United in the past fortnight. It has written to clubs warning them they will be held responsible if their players show collective dissent.

"Intimidation of match officials is unacceptable," said the FA's chief executive Adam Crozier. "Clubs must take responsibility. Although referees are currently empowered to deal with individual cases of dissent, the FA will take action where a number of individuals are seen to become involved."

The FA's unprecedented action signals its fear that football is reaching meltdown and could have serious repercussions on the championship race and the battle for Champions League places.

The worry for Leeds and Chelsea is that there is a precedent for deducting points where clubs have failed to con trol their players. Arsenal lost two points and United one after a mass brawl in October 1990.

Leeds' chairman Peter Ridsdale said last night: "We will duly consider the Football Association's announcement and give a considered response within the time frame which has been handed to us." All those charged have 14 days to respond.

Leeds are three points behind United going into Sunday's game between the teams at Elland Road. They need only talk to Middlesbrough to know how damaging the docking of points can be. Boro were relegated from the Premiership by two points in 1997 after losing three for failing to fulfil a fixture against Blackburn.

Fines and suspensions are the alternative. What is clear is that the FA will not allow the "unedifying sights" to continue.

It was no surprise to hear the Chelsea coach Ray Wilkins say: "We don't want to see points lost, we want to see the best team win."

It was no surprise either that he insisted responsibility for the spiral towards anarchy rests with the players.

"I think it's something the players rather than the clubs have to sort out," he said. "I think we've seen over the last couple of months that it's the players and not the clubs that are bringing this into football.

"I think sooner or later we have to get our footballers into line; they have to take responsibility. I want the PFA to come out and attempt to stop what's going on."

Crozier did not disguise his anger that the increase in violence and dissent has coincided with a directive ordering referees to be more lenient because of fears there were too many cards being dished out.

"What is particularly disappointing is that at a time when referees are adopting a more relaxed approach, many of the players are clearly not," he said.

"I have spoken to the Premier League, the Professional Footballers' Association and the League Managers' Association about the action we are taking and they are all fully supportive.

"We made it clear two weeks ago that the game as a whole must improve its conduct and image and recognise the need to accept our position as role models." The days of FA inaction seem to be gone

webTitle: England fly on in false sense of progress

fields.headline: England fly on in false sense of progress
fields.standfirst: Hussain should forget building and start winning
fields.trailText: England will have to play tough in Zimbabwe to change the perception that one-day cricket does not really matter. As Paul Weaver reports, talk of building for the future is too often a poor excuse for a shoddy present.
fields.body:
When England arrived here yesterday, amid talk of instability and an uncertain future, it was not immediately clear whether the topic of conversation was Robert Mugabe's shaky administration or the current state of the England cricket team.

After losing Sunday's one-final final - having bowled South Africa out for 149 after having them 21 for five at one stage - most players, particularly those who have been out here for almost four months, would have preferred yesterday's flight to have touched down at Heathrow.

Their performance was a keen disappointment, even though the pitch was a shocker. Those who argue that there is something impressive about the coach Duncan Fletcher's thoughtful, meticulous style, and who identify in Nasser Hussain perhaps England's best captain since Mike Brearley, would have welcomed something tangible to come from a tour that has produced a number of positives.

England's playing record in South Africa was not good. They lost the Test series 2-1 and in the triangular one-day series lost three out of four matches against South Africa while drawing 1-1 with Zimbabwe. If they fail to win the latest four-match one-day series against Zimbabwe, which starts here tomorrow, no-one will be surprised.

It can only be hoped that both Fletcher and Hussain are given enough time to pull things round. But it is not too early to identify some flawed thinking in their one-day strategy.

First, England should almost always bat first if they win the toss. Their batting is rarely strong enough to achieve even modest targets under pressure, and there is always more pressure batting second.

Second, a tail of Darren Gough, Andrew Caddick and Alan Mullally is not plausible in one-day terms, however good bowlers they are. Only two, preferably one, should play.

Third, any side that bats Mark Alleyne at No5 in an important one-day international cannot escape the accusation that it still does not take this form of cricket seriously. Where is Alec Stewart?

As for the talk of building for the 2003 World Cup, this is clearly nonsense. It is akin to saying that only Ashes series will be taken seriously and that all other Tests should be used for experimentation. Again, the message is that one-day cricket does not really matter. It does.

Besides, talk of building for the future is too often a poor excuse for a shoddy present. And it suggests, somehow, that the present does not matter, that the here and now will be magically removed from the records, that there will be no Wisden almanac in 2001.

Certainly, Fletcher and Hussain should have half an eye on 2003. But the best way to prepare for that is to pick the best players now, develop a winning habit and gradually introduce new cricketers into a successful environment.

The fashionable excuse is that England players do not play enough one-day internationals. But it is no good playing more if all you are doing is practising defeat. New players will seldom thrive in an unsuccessful dressing room. There are also too many bits and pieces cricketers. Such players rarely pull a side through in a crisis.

There is not much wrong with England's batting that a vintage innings or two from their most commanding one-day player, Graeme Hick, would not put right.

Harare-born Hick, 33, is looking forward to playing international cricket in his native country for the first time after a disappointing triangular tournament that saw him score just 62 runs in six innings. If anyone can bring the best out of Hick, it is surely fellow Zimbabwean Fletcher.

"I watched England play 'South Africa in the Test series on TV and could already sense a different atmosphere," Hick said. "The fielding has improved dramatically... Everything feels more relaxed. Off the field, the guys have enjoyed their time off a little more. Practice is shorter, sharper and more purposeful. We're not just practising for the sake of it.

"Duncan and I went to the same school in Harare, Prince Edward, and just the other day we were having a few laughs about it. It's really up to me now, not Duncan. I've been disappointed with my scores here because I've been hitting the ball really well in the nets."

fields.headline: Izzet opts for Turkey
fields.standfirst: Leicester midfielder shuns England
fields.trailText: Turkey, after two previous attempts, finally got their man yesterday when Leicester's Muzzy Izzet agreed to play for the land of his father.
fields.body:
Turkey, after two previous attempts, finally got their man yesterday when Leicester's Muzzy Izzet agreed to play for the land of his father.

The midfielder, who has been given assurances he will not have to do national service, formally applied for Turkish citizenship at the weekend. He is likely to make his debut against the Czech Republic in early April and will almost certainly be included in the squad for Euro 2000.

"It is a fantastic opportunity," he said. "My Leicester team-mate Neil Lennon tells me they are an excellent side after playing them in the Euro qualifiers."

Mozart's troubling comedy of manners is an exacting test for the most experienced of operatic hands. For someone tackling only his second opera it is a real ordeal by fire, and one that has badly burnt the Catalan director Calixto Bieito at Welsh National Opera. His production of Calderon's Life is a Dream, at the Edinburgh Festival two summers ago, suggested that Bieito's eye for theatrical imagery and sense of dramatic pacing might be powerfully transferred to the operatic stage. However, this Cosi Fan Tutte turns out to be a horrible disappointment, a disaster partially redeemed by the dependable conducting of Robert Spano and promising performances from some of the principals. Bieito has new shows (Don Giovanni and A Masked Ball) scheduled at English National Opera in coming seasons; they will need to be far, far better.

Bieito's inadequate response to the almost insoluble dramatic problems of Cosi - the debatably effective disguises; the emotional switchback that the two pairs of lovers experience; the ambiguous conclusion - is to turn everything into a brittle, hyperactive romp. He dodges the challenge of the ending by playing the final ensemble in front of the curtain, with no one relating to anyone else, or giving a hint of how these strange events might have changed their relationships.

Alfons Flores's handsome set places the action in a present-day Italian bar, with mirrored back wall and lots of chrome chairs and tables; these, and the unremarkably contemporary costumes (by Mercé Paloma), provide plenty of opportunity for distracting business. When extras aren't re-arranging furniture, the protagonists are rearranging each other's clothes: some of Mozart's most beguiling numbers are sung against a counterpoint of fumbling hands and awkward unbuttonings.

Bieito renders everyone pretty repellent. Ferrando and Guglielmo (Gregory Turay and Neal Davies) are simply macho and loutish young men; Dorabella and Fiordiligi (Imelda Drumm and Cara O'Sullivan) seem to be girls who want nothing out of life apart from a good time. Alfonso's misogyny is so caricatured in Donald Maxwell's ranting performance that you half expect him to turn into a serial killer. No character is well defined or, with the possible perverse exception of Despina (a typically accomplished portrayal from Linda Kitchen), appears to learn anything from the experiment they, willingly or not, undergo. If the events of Cosi Fan Tutte are turned into nothing more than an opportunity for a bit of extra-mural groping and none of the characters seems even momentarily sympathetic, the opera is hardly worth staging at all.

 Further performances: tomorrow, February 19 and March 2 - box office, 01222 878889 - then touring

fields.headline: Should I keep quiet?
fields.standfirst: What to do when you think you are being paid too much
fields.trailText: What to do when you think you are being paid too much
fields.body:
The problem

Two months ago I started a new job as personnel manager for a small company. Job contracts are renewed yearly and I was recently asked by the MD to print out the job contracts for all staff. I noticed that the salary stated on my contract was £750 more than I had agreed to.

I handed them all to the payroll clerk, she noticed the 'mistake' and made a note to pay me the back pay from the last two months. Initially I was pretty happy about this but am now getting paranoid that the MD will think that as the contracts were stored on my PC I have amended the contract myself. Should I keep quiet?

The solution

Dear Personnel Manager

The safest course of action would be to come clean. Of course, you have done nothing wrong, but you are being overpaid in terms of what was verbally agreed. If you were paid £750 less, I'm sure you would be quick to point this out to the MD!

The fact that you may need or feel you deserve this extra cash is not the point - you agreed to a particular salary and, due to some confusion, have been paid more. If you point out the mistake to the MD, you may risk losing the extra cash (although, really, as the contract is signed, sealed and dusted, you should be legally entitled to keep it) but will gain far more in terms of reputation, trustworthiness and honesty - all of which may be worth far more that the £750 in time.

Arrange to meet with your boss and tell him/her that when you gave the contracts to the payroll clerk, s/he noticed a discrepancy between your original pay and that in the contract (no need to mention that you noticed this before the clerk!) and has now brought your salary in line with the contract. Explain that, whilst you are delighted with the increase, you are worried that anyone should think anything underhand was going on. And, leave it at that. Don't apologise nor offer profuse reassurances that you did not tamper with the contract yourself - the MD can easily check if this is suspected.

Chances are, your boss will either leave your unexpected bonus, or perhaps try and negotiate it as being in lieu of a forthcoming rise (in which case you will have to decide whether or not to accept that). But, at least you will be able to stop worrying and enjoy your work with a clear conscience.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: A&L plans shares buy-back
fields.trailText: Alliance & Leicester sparked life into its sickly shares yesterday as it left the door open to mergers and laid out plans for a new internet bank.
fields.body:
Alliance & Leicester sparked life into its sickly shares yesterday as it left the door open to mergers and laid out plans for a new internet bank.

The former building society also said it would buy back £300m worth of its shares after reporting 1999 pre-tax profits of £500m, up from £455m in 1998.

Its shares, as with those of rival banks, have plunged in recent months. They have fallen from over 900p three months ago and while they rose 17p to 519p yesterday, they stayed stubbornly below the 533p price set on flotation in 1997.

Ever since A&L's failure to merge with Bank of Ireland last year, and the acrimonious departure of chief executive Peter White, the City has raised doubts about A&L's continued independence. As a former building society, it is protected from a hostile takeover until next year.

John Windeler, the chairman and acting chief executive, insisted that the bank had an independent future, although the bank would consider a deal "that would enhance shareholder value".

He pointed to a deal similar to the ill-fated one with Bank of Ireland which would allow the bank to cut costs and enhance the returns to shareholders - but refused to disclose any potential partners or indicate whether any talks had taken place.

Since the departure of Mr White, who is taking the bank to an employment tribunal over the way he was dismissed, A&L has repeatedly been linked with Woolwich. The bank is not yet able to name a new chief executive but said it was ready to fight Mr White's claims all the way to a tribunal.

A&L felt the pain of competition in the mortgage market where, despite record levels of business, its share of net lending fell to 3% from 4.6%. Its share of savings products also suffered but the more profitable credit card and personal loan business grew.

While the bank has been criticised for being slow to develop on the net, it claimed its existing service offered more features than its rivals. The site is receiving 70,000 visits a month but the bank refused to reveal how many customers had signed up for its internet current account, set up only two weeks ago.

A&L will now spend another £15m this year in setting up a "stand-alone" internet bank, being developed by a separate management team.

The bank moved to allay fears that A&L, which owns Girobank, the former post office money transmission system, would lose out from government plans to automate social security payments by saying it was positioning itself to provide cash to other financial institutions.

Girobank handled £55.2bn in cash last year, a rise of 2% and a 28% market share.

Its shares bucked the general trend for its rivals, whose stock continued to languish yesterday as the annual reporting season got under way.

In particular, Lloyds TSB, which reported its results last week, saw its shares fall yet further.

Its total dividend will be 29.3p, up 20%.
