webTitle: One in five office workers bewildered by use of jargon

fields.headline: One in five office workers bewildered by use of jargon
fields.standfirst: Talking shop: send us your jargon
fields.trailText: One in five office workers no longer understands what his or her colleagues are talking about, according to a survey released yesterday.
fields.body:
One in five office workers no longer understands what his or her colleagues are talking about, according to a survey released yesterday.

At meetings they are left floundering by management jargon and specialised electronic babble - by phrases like "low-hanging fruit", "blue-sky ideas", "win-win situations" and "gap analysis".

If they dare to ask, they discover that "getting into bed with" now means "to be more familiar with someone on a strictly professional level".

But most do not dare to ask and are discouraged from doing so. For the survey indicates that more than a third of speakers use these buzzword phrases "deliberately, to show they are in control and therefore more credible".

The study, by the secretarial recruitment firm Office Angels, covered 1,000 office staff. It found that these staff had to attend an average of one meeting a day. Some 65% had to cope with jargon derived from corporate gurus, American slang and the internet.

The report said: "One in five employees felt obliged to use 'in' phrases to keep pace with their colleagues, even though they admitted they didn't actually know what many of the phrases meant."

Forty per cent found the phrases irritating and distracting at meetings, while 10% dismissed speakers who used them most often as "pretentious and therefore untrustworthy".

Babblespeak is reportedly most common in creative sectors such as advertising but has infiltrated financial institutions. The survey found that it was particularly common in the south-east, where 40% of staff used it compared with 25% in the north; and 30% said they used it to liven up meetings.

Paul Jacobs, a director of Office Angels, said the survey showed that "corporate buzzwords are rife in the workplace. It can help to bring people and teams together in an almost tribal way as companies and sectors develop their own jargon. Or it can be used to exclude and confuse others as well as mask inexperience and lack of expertise."

Buzzwords and babble

Helicopter view Summary

Talk offline Discuss it after the meeting

Heavy site Website claiming to get many hits

Drool-proof Technical advice catering for idiots, as in the official manual that suggests "do not expose your Apple laserwriter to open fire or flame"

Blue-sky ideas Wild or ambitious proposals

Get into bed with Be more familiar on a professional level

Face time Non-electronic discussion

Capture Gather more information

Orderly roll-out Unbearably slow phasing-in of a technological process

Strategic fit A perfect match, or hand-in-glove with

Who owns this? Which sucker is going to do the work?

Low-hanging fruit Easy targets

Sources: Office Angels survey and other monitors

fields.headline: Insecurity 'fuels job bullying epidemic'
fields.standfirst: Survey shows Britain has worst workplace record in Europe
fields.trailText: Long hours and growing job insecurity have helped fuel an epidemic of workplace bullying, with one in four employees saying they have been bullied in the past five years, according to the first comprehensive survey of the problem, published yesterday.
fields.body:
Long hours and growing job insecurity have helped fuel an epidemic of workplace bullying, with one in four employees saying they have been bullied in the past five years, according to the first comprehensive survey of the problem, published yesterday.

Almost half of employees have experienced or seen bullying and one in 10 say they have been bullied in the past six months, the study by Manchester university's institute of science and technology found - response rates significantly higher than elsewhere in Europe.

The survey of 5,300 workers, the largest of its kind ever carried out, and supported by both the TUC and CBI, defined bullying as long-term and persistent negative behaviour, ranging from abuse, humiliation and ridicule to the imposition of unmanageable workloads, unreasonable deadlines and continual fault-finding.

The authors, Cary Cooper and Helge Hoel, found that victims were spread across all levels from senior managers to shopfloor workers, but that 75% of bullies were managers.

Bullying was reported to be most rife in teaching, the prison service, post and telecommunications and the performing arts, and worse in the public than private sector.

The TUC general secretary, John Monks, called for "zero tolerance". John Cridland, human resources director of the CBI, described the extent of workplace bullying as morally unacceptable and bad for business because of its effect on morale, absenteeism, staff turnover and productivity.

The Umist survey, funded by the British Occupational Health Research Foundation, estimated that victims took an extra seven days off a year compared with other workers.

It also uncovered higher levels of physical and mental ill health among victims and even among those who had only witnessed bullying.

One victim yesterday described how incessant bullying by a manager drove her out of her job in a software firm and landed her in hospital for three weeks with acute stress.

"The atmosphere at work was terrible," she said. "She would yell and scream at us and undermine everything we did. We weren't able to take responsibility for our own work and we were never given any training. After two years of almost constant bullying, I just felt I couldn't take any more."

Prof Cooper linked the higher incidence compared with other European countries to the growth of long hours, job insecurity and the effects of "downsizing" on workloads.

"Bullying then becomes a management style in the face of unmanageable workloads," he said, adding that overworked and overstressed managers were now replacing psychopathic bosses as the most common workplace bully.

Typical bullying managers were identified as autocratic and divisive with a tendency to punish on an arbitrary basis.

The authors recommended mechanisms for victims to report bullying without fear of retribution, effective procedures for dealing with complaints, training of managers, and stress audits to avoid work environments which contributed to bullying.

webTitle: Online betting aims to tap new markets

fields.headline: Online betting aims to tap new markets
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Ladbrokes, the gaming arm of Hilton group, yesterday unveiled a multimedia strategy that it believes can transform betting into a mass market pursuit and double turnover within two years.
fields.body:
Ladbrokes, the gaming arm of Hilton group, yesterday unveiled a multimedia strategy that it believes can transform betting into a mass market pursuit and double turnover within two years.

Britain's biggest bookmaker is launching two online betting sites and has struck deals with BSkyB, Telewest and Cable & Wireless that will enable digital satellite and cable television subscribers to place bets from their living rooms. It is also working with Ericsson on a service to allow betting through wireless application protocol (Wap) mobile phones.

Ladbroke's John O'Reilly said that further technology is being developed to enable interactive real-time betting on major sports events. "Customers will soon be able to bet on whether Alan Shearer will score or miss from the penalty spot or whether Tiger Woods' next tee shot will land on the green or on the fairway," he said. Hilton shares, which have almost halved since last May, closed up 14.75p or 9% at 175p on the news.

The initiatives are part of a £100m investment programme aimed at broadening the appeal of betting and making it a more entertaining and interactive pastime, Mr O'Reilly said.

"It has been difficult to encourage younger, more affluent consumers to cross the threshold of the betting shop but these moves will enable us to reach a far wider and more affluent audience. At the moment around 70% of adults play the national lottery regularly compared to 6% of the population who use betting shops.

"We need to close that gap and should be able to get that figure to 12% in 18 months to two years."

As an introductory offer, Ladbrokes is to make bets on its new football-led bet.co.uk website tax-free as an incentive to new customers. Ladbrokes.com, a multilingual, multi-currency betting platform that will go live next week will be permanently tax-free and maintained from Gibraltar.

Traditional bookmakers are struggling to cope with the threats and opportunities posed by the internet and also the growth of off-shore tax free betting. Research firm Datamonitor predicts that revenues from internet gaming in western Europe will more than double to $5.5bn (£3.5bn) over four years.

fields.headline: Taken for a fast ride
fields.standfirst:
The Animalhouse
Zodiac, Oxford
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText: The Animalhouse are the new band of former Ride frontman Mark Gardener, which naturally dictates that the first thing you look for at one of their gigs is a gently swaying object which bridges the gap between an upside-down floor mop and a pretty boy, old-school indie-rocker. Gardener, despite being turned into a somnambulist icon by a series of mocking Mary Whitehouse Experience sketches, was always the "talented" songwriter in Ride (the "other" one being Andy Bell, who has since formed the dreary Hurricane No 1 and joined Oasis), and you can't help feeling a certain disappointment to see that he's abandoned his mother-of-all-fringes in favour of an extremist grade-one cut.

Gardener, despite being turned into a somnambulist icon by a series of mocking Mary Whitehouse Experience sketches, was always the "talented" songwriter in Ride (the "other" one being Andy Bell, who has since formed the dreary Hurricane No 1 and joined Oasis), and you can't help feeling a certain disappointment to see that he's abandoned his mother-of-all-fringes in favour of an extremist grade-one cut.

Gardener's new hair suggests something dynamic, and The Animalhouse, live, are a bit like a grown-up Ride on speed. The leviathan waves of fuzz and bubblegum feedback are still there, but pepped up with a (surely previously untested) juxtaposition of Eagles harmonies and clangy Big Black guitar bits (courtesy of Gardener's co-songwriter Sam Williams, formerly of The Mystics). The resulting melodies could have come from a Sonic Youth who've abandoned Charles Manson and John Cage for sunshine and the Archies.

That said, The Animalhouse have yet to learn to engage with a crowd, and find themselves stuck somewhere in the no man's land between sulky shoe gazers and unashamed rockers. Their only interaction with the crowd is the standard indie "cheers", and Williams's obvious crotch-rock ambitions remain only half-fulfilled, despite a Herculean finale of Animal (like Sonic Youth's Teenage Riot, but, y'know, for kids).

If this criticism seems harsh for a band who haven't yet gigged into double figures or put out their first single (the excellent, imminent Animal EP), it's because the throbbing sense of anticipation in The Zodiac is so great. It feels like 1991 again: Radiohead and Supergrass have yet to be invented, Oxford is shoegazing central, every chic indie kid is out on the town, and the majority of students get their kicks from guitar, not dance, music. For the moment, The Animalhouse are getting by on atmosphere and nostalgia alone, cautiously feeding off a compassionate word-of-mouth crowd. We won't really see if their sunny promise is fulfilled until they venture beyond the forgiving cushion of their home city.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Labour to raise minimum wage
fields.standfirst: The minimum wage explained
fields.trailText: The government will this week unveil a surprise 10 pence an hour increase in the minimum wage for Britain's two million lowest paid workers as part of the move to regain ground among its traditional supporters, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
The government will this week unveil a surprise 10 pence an hour increase in the minimum wage for Britain's two million lowest paid workers as part of the move to regain ground among its traditional supporters, the Guardian has learned.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, and Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, agreed to the first increase in the basic adult hourly rate, from £3.60 to £3.70, which will come into effect later this year, after treasury experts concluded that it would have no adverse effects on inflation or employment.

Amid signs that the government is having trouble combatting apathy and disillusion in its heartlands, this week's decision is designed to lift Labour spirits and put the Conservatives on the spot over their new-found support for the minimum wage.

Mr Byers had previously signalled, in one of the government's flagship policies, that there would be no increase, but has now backed a rise both in the adult rate, and in the lower, hourly rate paid to workers aged 21 and under, which will increase 20 pence to £3.20.

Government sources said that they had been looking at the economic implications of an increase in the minimum wage, and there had been no question of the goverment bowing to outside pressure.

However, there has been strong lobbying for change from union leaders - including John Monks, general secretary of the TUC - and from a growing number of backbench MPs.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, endorsed the increase. A formal announcement by Mr Byers, scheduled for Friday, will pave the way for the new £3.70 figure to be implemented possibly in October or November. The increase for young workers will come into effect in June.

Ministers also plan this autumn to recall the low pay commission - the independent body made up of industrialists, trade unionists and academics - to recommend another hourly rate rise for October 2001.

Sources said the commission was unlikely to report until after the summer of 2001 and the next election, but stressed that the government wanted to force the Conservatives into stating whether they would back any further increases.

The commission last year proposed a 10p increase from this April but the government is determined to avoid a commitment to annual increases.

The government has also rejected a call by the commission to pay the adult rate for all workers aged 21 and over, with the treasury preferring to wait for further research by the commission on the impact on youth unemployment. Although only 8% of UK workers are covered by the minimum wage, it has an impact on about 30% of young workers.

A treasury source said last night: "The government is committed to a national minimum wage as a cornerstone of our policies, along with the working families' tax credit, to end poverty pay and make work pay."

However, the timing of the move is designed to steady nerves following the govenment's difficult start to the year.

Ministers risked a defeat tomorrow at the weekly meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party after six members tabled a motion demanding the first PLP vote since May 1997. The motion proposed by the left-winger Gordon Prentice stated: "This PLP believes the national minimum wage should be up-rated in April."

Although the planned increase will not be in pay packets until at least six months after the anniversary of the introduction of the minimum wage, the move should defuse backbench unrest, reflected in the 93 signatories to an early-day motion in December calling for a rise for the low-paid. Mr Monks won loud applause last Wednesday at a meeting of 50 Labour MPs when he declared any increase would enjoy widespread support.

Many unions back a minimum £5 an hour and will be disappointed the rise will not be in April, 12 months after the legal pay floor was introduced.

But one union leader said: "The minimum wage is Labour's flagship reform and sent out the message to traditional supporters that the government really does believe in social justice. A 10p increase would stop it being seen as a one-off measure and is a manifesto commitment honoured in spirit as well as law."

Others will also be unhappy the adult rate will not kick in at 21 or under. The GMB general union's John Edmonds has led a campaign to reduce and ultimately abolish a lower level for younger employees.

fields.headline: Women at war
fields.standfirst:
The Waiting Room
Tron Theatre, Glasgow
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText: Virginia Woolf, musing on militarism and fascism, famously said that as a woman she had "no country". No nation to defend, no country to die for.
fields.body:
Virginia Woolf, musing on militarism and fascism, famously said that as a woman she had "no country". No nation to defend, no country to die for.

Isabel Wright's short, sharp shock of a play, The Waiting Room, extends this feminist perspective into the present day to look at the lives of two women caught in a modern military conflict. The location is unspecified (though atrocities in Kosovo are referred to in the programme notes), the external conflict serving only as an intense backdrop to their internal drama. This is the psychological torment of war as seen from the private, cramped space the women share. The atmosphere in their safe house is cell-like, with just a bed and a window; the relationship between the two women, Naomi (Anita Vettesse) and Marah (Vivienne de Caris) - a young woman and her dead lover's mother - is like that of prisoners forced together.

They clash and spar, their differences magnified by their predicament. This is convincing writing, showing both women as unlikeably self-obsessed and equally deluded in their contrasting ways of coping. The younger woman dreams her lover is the best of men and still alive; she gets by through fantasising about "men, food and the amazing bath I'll have". Marah, with a weary realism about the evil that men do, is shut down, broken by it all, intolerant of hope.

The drama is the fight between them, the furious, mad, suspicious way they behave with one another, and the gradual realisation that all they have is each other. At little over an hour, it is an uphill struggle to get that sense of locked-in, pent-up resentment but also absolute reliance running between them; it's also hard on a set that might be cramped and basic but, all in new wood, looks like a minimalist Ikea interior. There is also too much walking in circles in an I'm-on-the-verge-look-I'm-pulling-at-my-hair way.

But by the end, this physical and mental torture feels real enough, as Marah reveals the secrets she knows. These are tragic and cruel but, cathartically, free the women from the tyranny of the past and present and maybe release them from the waiting room. A promising offering from this young playwright.

 At the Paisley Arts Centre - box office, 0141-887 1010 - tonight.
